With Sall, owns tony Prestonwood Country Club and local private school Cary Academy.
title: CEO

name: Billionaires
bio: Heads conglomerate New World Development, with interests in property, infrastructure, transport, retail, hotel, casino, brokerage, and telecom across China and Hong Kong. Wealth has rebounded along with property markets. Cheng is non-executive chairman of Lifestyle International Holdings, a department story operator partly owned by another billionaire, Joseph Lau.  Also a director of billionaire Stanley Ho's Shun Tak Holdings and SJM Holdings.  Sons Henry and Peter, along with grandson Adrian, sit on New World's board.  Born poor in Shunde in 1925, father was a silk store worker. At 15, Cheng left Shunde to Macau during Sino-Japanese war to earn a living in gold shop Chow Tai Fook as trainee. In 1943, Cheng married to Chow Chui Ying, daughter of Chow Tai Fook's founder, as arranged by the two fathers who were former colleagues in the silk store, before the young couple was born. Cheng inherited the gold trading and jewelry business of Chow Tai Fook in 1956. Also became involved in property development in Hong Kong. He amassed vast tracts of land in the late 1960s amid HK's property downturn, laying the foundation for New World Development, which he started in 1970.

name: Billionaires
bio: His retail empire Arcadia managed another year of flat sales, but British retail sector has gained significantly in value. Made headlines when he agreed to create a global entertainment company with ex-American Idol judge Simon Cowell, to be financed and established by the end of March. The duo's first big project will be an American version of Brit reality talent show X-Factor, to debut on Fox TV in autumn 2011. High school drop-out got his first break apprenticing with a London show importer. Bought his first store at 27 and climbed up the retail ladder. Bought then-struggling Arcadia Group in 2002 for $1.2 billion. Group sales now total $3.1 billion. New flagship outlet for teen mecca Topshop will launch this Easter with London property leased from Abu Dhabi royal family, opposite posh retailer Harrods. Less posh department store chain British Home Stores was integrated into his main retail business, Arcadia Group, in July 2009. Has two children with wife, Christina. Knighted in 2006 for his services to the retail industry.

name: Billionaires
bio: Has run transport and logistics group, Kuhne & Nagel, for four decades. Holds 56% stake in the public company; grandfather August Kuhne was group's founder. Lives in Switzerland but still has ties to his birthplace, Hamburg. In 2008, in an effort to keep the company anchored in Germany, Kuhne and a group of investors that included the city of Hamburg formed the Albert Ballin KG consortium to bid for 160-year old Hapag Lloyd, one of the world's leading container ship operators.  After a long bidding battle, the consortium obtained 57% of the company last year. Although he lives in landlocked Switzerland, has built an extravagant house said to look like the main command deck of an ocean liner.

name: Billionaires
bio: Longtime chairman and large stakeholder of $33 billion (assets) Al Rajhi Bank. With 3 brothers, Saleh, Abdullah and Mohammed, built small money-changing business in Saudi Arabia's Najd desert into the world's largest Islamic bank, the $22 billion (assets) Al Rajhi Bank. Shariah-compliant finance proved as vulnerable to the downturn as its secular counterpart, but shares are on the rebound: up 80% since last March's lows. Has variety of business interests outside banking including cement manufacturing, real estate, agriculture, warehousing and a shrimp farm.

name: Billionaires
bio: German immigrant studied at Columbia U.; started with television stations. Amassed fortune buying and selling broadcast, cellular properties. Sold out to WorldCom for $1.3 billion. Became richest man in America 1989, lost title to Bill Gates 3 years later. Investments derailed in 2008: private equity firm Atalaya Capital Management bought his Steak & Ale and Bennigan's brands for a mere $13 million in cash and assumed debt after chains filed for bankruptcy. His Ponderosa and Bonanza steak house chains also filed for Chapter 11. Pledged $400 million to alma mater Columbia University in 2007.

name: Billionaires
bio: His Alfa Group, which he shares with fellow billionaires German Khan and Mikhail Fridman, buoyed by rising oil prices; stake in TNK-BP up twofold over the past year. Interest in Alfa Bank also up; the bank recovered most of its money from borrowers like fellow billionaire, Oleg Deripaska. Kuzmichev met his future partners in college. In 1991 they started Alfa Bank, which is now the biggest private bank by capital in Russia. Bought Tyumen Oil from the state in the late 1990s and merged it with BP's Russian assets into TNK-BP. The group has stakes in two Russian cellular companies and owns the biggest retailer, X5. Kuzmichev heads the company called A1, which manages the assets Alfa Bank got from its debtors.

name: Billionaires
bio: Press-shy Israeli and his family own a vast global shipping empire, plus interests in banking and real estate. Announced formal retirement last September and returned to Israel, becoming permanent resident. Two sons active in dad's vast empire: Son Eyal, who runs real estate business and is a director of cruise line Royal Caribbean, splits his time between Monaco, New York and London; son Idan, based in Israel, is chairman of Israel Corp., which holds strategic stakes in chemicals, energy, technology and shipping (through Zim Shipping). Owns extensive collection of impressionist, post-impressionist and modern paintings. Awarded an honorary knighthood by Queen Elizabeth for his services to U.K. maritime heritage.

name: Billionaires
bio: Metals, mining magnate, is facing flak over his business practices. The Church of England recently sold its holding in his London-listed Vedanta Resources on grounds that it wasn't satisfied by company's level of respect for human rights, specifically, its treatment of tribal people in Eastern India who would be displaced by a proposed mining project. Agarwal denied the allegation and recently raised $883 million through a convertible bond issue. Is reportedly planning to enter India's ports sector and also list aluminium arm. Group's India-listed Sterlite Industries lost race against Grupo Mexico to get control of bankrupt American copper miner Asarco. The land acquisition for his new Vedanta University to which he's pledged $1 billion is still to be completed.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of hedge fund juggernaut SAC Capital remedying his returns: firm's main fund up 28.4% last year after falling 18.5% in 2008. Returns even higher before steep fees: 3% of assets, 35% of profits on most funds. Son of a dress manufacturer grew up in Great Neck, N.Y., attended Wharton. Became options trader at Gruntal & Co.; first day on the job reaped $8,000 profit. Founded SAC in 1992 with $25 million. Firm now manages $12 billion. Cools trading floor to 70 degrees to perk up employees.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Ukraine-born oil and aluminum baron fined $38 million last year by Swiss authorities investigating his 2006 share purchase in electronics maker Oerlikon; he is charged with concealing information about the deal but is appealing. Owns a stake in TNK-BP, Russia's second biggest private oil company; stock up twofold over past year. Also overseeing turnaround at aluminum giant, UC Rusal, which he formed with fellow billionaire, Oleg Deripaska; the company, raised $2.2 billion in an initial public offering in Hong Kong. Made his first million selling scrap copper from worn out cables. In the 1990s together with fellow billionaire Leonard Blavatnik bought aluminum smelters, united them in SUAL which later become a part of UC Rusal. Consummate dealmaker also has interests in chemicals, utilities and telecoms. Owns collection of Faberge eggs.

name: Billionaires
bio: Coal king last year bought US coal miner, Bluestone Coal, for $425 million plus shares. A nice recovery for his mining group Mechel, which lost 90% of its value during the financial crisis; however, 20% of Zyuzin's stake still held as collateral. In 1995 with partner Vladimir Iorikh formed Uglemetkooperatsiya, a coal-trading company which was among the first to buy up shares in coal mines and coal pits in the Kuzbass region. In 2001 Iorikh and Zyuzin bought a controlling stake in Chelyabinsk Metals Factory, which formed the basis of the Mechel group, now consisting of more than 20 plants and coals mines around the world. Since 2004 has traded in New York.

name: Billionaires
bio: Great-grandson of Friedrich Engelhorn, founder of German chemical company BASF.  Studied chemical engineering in Texas after World War II. For 36 years headed pharmaceutical companies Boehringer Manheim and DePuy. In May 1997 engineered their sale to Roche for $11 billion. Made $4.4 billion on the deal. Engelhorn, whose mother was American, sponsors the Heidelberg Center for American Studies at the University of Heidelberg, funding it with a yearly donation of more than $500,000.  Also supports the Reiss-Engelhorn Museum in Mannheim.  Retired to Switzerland with fourth wife, Heidemarie .

name: Billionaires
bio: He and brother Minoru, also a billionaire, inherited initial fortune from father but went their separate ways unable to agree on a business strategy. With his part has continued to build his Mori Trust, owner of office buildings, apartment blocks and hotels in high-rent districts of Tokyo. Recent projects include two office buildings outside Tokyo Station and northern Japan's tallest building, a tower in Sendai due to open 2010. Akira's hobbies: golf, Japanese chess and reading. Fortune up in part because of new shareholder information.

name: Billionaires
bio: The man who owns the news desperate to find ways to offset losses caused by declining ad market. Bought the Dow Jones news empire for $5.6 billion cash in 2007; sold 90% stake in the 113- year-old Dow Jones Industrial Average to CME Group for $675 million in February. Recently suggested he will soon charge for content on all his Web sites; considering Microsoft partnership that would pull content from Google. News Corp. rebounded in revenue and income in second quarter of fiscal 2010; quarterly revenue up 10% to $8.7 billion, profits $254 million. Australia-born tabloid titan inherited one newspaper at age 23. Oxford grad built media empire with Australian and U.S. papers, Fox film studio, conservative-leaning cable channel Fox News.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'News Corp', 'uri': 'companies/news-corp', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Google chief's fortune up $1.9 billion in past year; shares of search giant up 70%. Unveiled smartphone Nexus One in January; operates with Android software. Announced upgraded version of Chrome browser in March; gaining market share since November 2008. Sales for 2009: $23.7 billion. Stepped down from Apple board in August because of potential conflicts of interest. Technology advisor to President Obama began software career at Bell Labs, Xerox PARC. Took gig at Sun Microsystems in 1983; led development of Java technology. Recruited to Google chief executive post in 2001 by founders Larry Page and Sergey Brin. Signed ad agreement with Yahoo summer 2008; withdrew from agreement months later.
title: Executive Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Elected chairman of steel giant Evraz in December 2008 replacing fellow billionaire Alexander Frolov with whom he cofounded the group. Struggled with $10 billion debt burden: consolidated factories in the Urals and Siberia and refinanced Evraz's debts with state-owned banks. Evraz stock price up nearly threefold. Got start as head of a research lab before Soviet Union collapsed. In 1992 established a precursor to Evraz Holding; made a fortune exporting metals and coal from the Urals and Siberia. After 1998 Russian financial crisis, bought up hobbled steel companies and coal mines on the cheap. In 2006, partnered with fellow billionaire Roman Abramovich in Evraz. In 2007, made a number of acquisitions, including U.S. firms Claymont Steel Holdings of Delaware and Oregon Steel Mills.

name: Billionaires
bio: Harvard M.B.A. ran medical device maker Synthes for 30 years; stepped down as chief exec in 2007. Last year established bio-engineering institute at Harvard after announcing $125 million donation--largest individual gift in school's history. Now heads Wyss Foundation, which gives scholarships to students getting master's degrees in conservation. Owns a 900-acre ranch and vineyard in California.

name: Billionaires
bio: Reclusive mogul saw his big bet on Michael Jackson's comeback lurch into a drug-induced coma after the pop star's untimely death last June. His concert promoter, AEG, lost millions of dollars from ticket refunds, rehearsal costs; recouped some losses selling merchandise, rehearsal footage. Oil driller's son bought out father, struck energy riches in Utah, Wyoming. Parlayed proceeds into diversified telecom, sports, real estate, media, movies, wind empire. Has netted billions of dollars selling shares of Qwest Communications in past years. L.A. Live real estate development transforming 4-million-square-foot block of downtown Los Angeles into entertainment hub anchored by Staples Center, home to his L.A. Lakers (basketball) and L.A. Kings (hockey). JW Marriott hotel at L.A. Live opened in February; Ritz Carlton hotel expected to open in March.

name: Billionaires
bio: One of Sweden's richest women.  In 1982 succeeded her father as head of the Axel Johnson Group, a diversified trading company founded by her great-grandfather in 1873. The privately held $6.8 billion (sales) group has interests in everything from energy to telecom to real estate. Axfood AB, in which it holds a 45% share, is one of the largest food operations in Scandinavia. Attended Radcliffe College in Cambridge, Mass., as an exchange student in the early 1960s. Avid horsewoman and member of numerous Swedish charities, including the World Childhood Foundation, which was founded by the Swedish queen.

name: Billionaires
bio: In 2005 jet-setting beer magnate swapped control of his Bavaria brewery for 15% of SABMiller, now worth $5.6 billion. Other holdings include stakes in Colombia's biggest TV broadcaster Caracol, packaging maker Biofilm and forestry outfit Refocosta. Born into a rich family with interests in breweries, took over management of its holdings in 1972 after his father retired. No longer involved in daily operations. Has homes in New York City, Paris. Also owns a private island, Baru,  off the Caribbean coast of Colombia. Close friend of Colombian author and Nobel laureate Gabriel Garcia Marquez. Son, Andres, appears in U.S. gossip columns with socialite wife, Vogue magazine editor Lauren Davis. His oldest son, Julio Mario, died last March in New York, apparently of cancer.

name: Billionaires
bio: Rental-car titan's fortune has slid $3.5 billion in a year as the auto industry continues to struggle. Enterprise Rent-A-Car surviving by dealing with insurance claims instead of focusing operations at troublesome airports; demand for temporary rentals remains steady so long as people's cars break down. Left Washington University to join Navy; served as a fighter pilot on U.S.S. Enterprise during WWII. Became sales manager for St. Louis Cadillac distributor. Took 50% pay cut to start company that provided replacement cars. Business took off 1970s when insurance companies were ordered by courts to pay for replacement rentals. Added Vanguard Automotive (National, Alamo) in 2007. Son Andrew is chief executive, daughter Jo Ann Taylor Kindle runs Enterprise Foundation.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Youngest son of Orascom conglomerate founder and fellow billionaire, Onsi Sawiris. Took over leadership of empire's flagship construction and fertilizer division in 1998. Shares in Orascom Construction Industries have doubled over the past year as projects have picked up. In January announced joint venture with investment bank, Morgan Stanley, to invest in infrastructure assets in the Middle East and Africa. Spun off group's cement division 3 years ago to French giant LaFarge, landing Nassef a seat on the board and a 13% stake. Joined his 15% interest in Texas Industries with the late Roy Disney's Shamrock holding in voting for slate of new directors at the company last fall.

name: Billionaires
bio: Controls Internet and telecom firm SoftBank. Its mobile-phone unit, which sells popular iPhones in Japan, outpacing rivals for new subscribers. Sold $2 billion worth of bonds to pay off some of its $21 billion in debt. Firm owns half of Yahoo Japan and one-third of Chinese e-commerce site Alibaba.com. Partnering with Chinese broadcaster, Shanghai Media Group, to develop digital content. Moved to U.S. at age 16 and returned to Japan after earning economics degree from the University of California, Berkeley. Owns Japanese baseball team Fukuoka Hawks.
title: CEO

name: Billionaires
bio: Eldest of the 3 brothers behind $33 billion (assets) Al Rajhi Bank. With billionaire siblings, Sulaiman, Abdullah and Mohammed, built small money-changing business in Saudi Arabia's Najd desert into world's largest Islamic bank, the $33 billion (assets) Al Rajhi Bank. Shariah-compliant finance proved as vulnerable to the downturn as its secular counterpart but shares are on the rebound: up 80% since last March's lows. Nonagenarian also invested in Kingdom's expanding agriculture sector: owns 11% stake in one of country's biggest wheat producers and in July sold poultry business Hail Agricultural Development to Gulf's dairy giant Almarai for $253 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: One of Hong Kong's biggest landlords kept occupancy rates above 90% at his Chinese Estates despite downturn; doing even better amid property rebound. Launched first development in Chengdu. Owns stakes in other companies including retailer Lifestyle International, which his brother Thomas runs. Art collector paid $39 million for Paul Gauguin's Te Poipoi a while back. Owns several jets.  Spent $9.5 million for a 7.03-carat blue diamond, which he renamed Star of Josephine after youngest daughter.  Said to be one of largest collectors of red wine, with at least 10,000 bottles.

name: Billionaires
bio: Reclusive construction tycoon, he chairs the 141-year old Shapoorji Pallonji group which his sons Shapoor and Cyrus run. The biggest piece of his largely private fortune is his 18.4% stake in Tata Sons, holding company of the $71 billion (revenues) Tata Group which owns Corus Steel in the U.K. and marquee brands such as Jaguar, Land Rover and Tetley tea. Has another personal link to Tata: his daughter is married to Noel, group boss Ratan Tata's younger step-brother. His listed entity Forbes & Company whose subsidiary sells the Eureka Forbes brand of water purifiers was taken to court by Unilever for allegedly making misleading claims in an advertising campaign. His construction firm has recently put in a bid to build an iron ore terminal at a port on India's west coast, estimated to cost $1.5 billion.  He and his family are Irish citizens though businesses are located in India.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fortune up $500 million in last year on investment and art gains. AIG stock was decimated by collapse of insurance giant in 2008. Sold off much of his stake in AIG; claims to have stemmed further losses by shorting the S&P 500 late in 2008. Son of Lithuanian immigrants; born in the Bronx, raised in Detroit. Bought first patch of land at age 20. Cofounded Kaufman & Broad with $25,000 borrowed from in-laws; became one of nation's biggest home builders supplying parents of baby boomers with affordable housing. Bought Sun Life Insurance (later renamed SunAmerica) in 1971; sold to AIG 1998 for $18 billion in cash and stock. Contemporary art collector created the Broad Art Foundation 1984; lending library makes his collection available to institutions around the world. Expanded plans to build museum for Broad Art Foundation; Southern California cities competing for the collection.

name: Billionaires
bio: Owns 17.4% stake in auto maker BMW, which his late father, Herbert Quandt, rescued from bankruptcy over five decades ago.  Sits on supervisory board of the car maker along with sister Susanne Klatten. Owns and manages Delton AG, a $3.4 billion (sales) holding company whose subsidiaries include a maker of homeopathic drugs and producer of household goods. Also holds stakes in  a logistics company and in Data Card Corp, a smart card maker. Trained engineer.

name: Billionaires
bio: Took over tiny screw business from his father at age 19. Turned it into $10.7 billion (sales) Wurth Group; company also has interests in a bank and solar energy firm.   Sales dropped 15% lin 2009 as a result of the world recession.  Daughter Bettina heads the supervisory board; son-in-law Markus runs group's specialty building products division. Now retired, Wurth rides a Harley-Davidson and has a  professional pilot's license.  Vast art collection includes works by Emil Nolde, Ernst, Leger, Alfred Hrdilicka, Edvard Munch and Pablo Picasso. Holds honorary doctorate in art history and museography from the University of Palermo. Owns a  280 foot long yacht,  Vibrant Curiosity..

name: Billionaires
bio: Once Colombia's top builder, Sarmiento parlayed his construction fortune into a financial services empire, Grupo Aval Acciones y Valores.  Over the years bought up stakes in four Colombian banks, a leasing company and a pension fund.  Sarmiento has canceled plans to bid for a new Colombian television network license with Venezuelan billionaire Gustavo Cisneros.  In association with the Grameen Bank,  will begin extending credit to micro-entrepreneurs.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former military man turned financial whiz. While teaching in the Siberian city of Kogalym in the late 1980s, met Vagit Alekperov, who was head of the local oil and gas company. In 1990s helped privatize Lukoil, which was formed out of the best Russian oil properties; now is Lukoil head Alekperov's right-hand man with a 9.3% stake in the company. Also oversees the investing activities of IFD Capital. Owns famous Moscow soccer club Spartak. Every summer hosts horse races at the Moscow Hippodrome.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Hon Hai Precision Industry, one of the world's largest contract electronics manufacturers. Started company with $7,500 in 1974. Today, better known by its trade name, Foxconn Group, which churns out products for Apple, Nintendo and Nokia, among others. A Taiwan tech industry icon, Gou has enjoyed a huge rebound in his wealth in the past year as Hon Hai's shares doubled on hopes that global economy has bottomed out. Remarried in 2008 after first wife passed away.

name: Billionaires
bio: Petroleum magnate's fortune up $2 billion in 12 months; shares of his Continental Resources up 72%. Youngest of 13 children grew up in one-bedroom Oklahoma house; parents were sharecroppers. First job: pumping gas. Bought truck in 1965; founded Harold Hamm Tank Truck Service the next year. Became one of top Oklahoman oilfield fluid transporters. Founded Continental Resources, oil and gas exploration, production company, in 1967; public 2007. Took gas processing firms Hiland Partners and Hiland Holdings private in 2009. Committed to curing diabetes through Harold Hamm Oklahoma Diabetes Center.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Continental Resources', 'uri': 'companies/continental-resources', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Following months of rumor and speculation, cultish king of the iGeeks presented the highly anticipated iPad in January; ten-inch, multi-touch computer intended to fill gap between smartphone and laptop. Delighted: nerds everywhere. Scared to death: newspaper and magazine publishers. Also unveiled new iBookstore and iBooks application in direct challenge to Amazon's Kindle; several book publishers have committed to content agreements. Apple shares up 100% in past 12 months. Reed College dropout founded Apple in 1976. Revolutionized music industry with iTunes, iPod. Best investment: bought Pixar from George Lucas in 1986 for $10 million. Created string of hits (Finding Nemo, Toy Story); sold to Disney in 2006 for $7.4 billion in stock. Today is Disney's largest shareholder; stake worth $4.2 billion. Reportedly cooperating on a biography with author Walter Isaacson.

name: Billionaires
bio: Investor in distressed companies, sold nearly all his Russian assets, including shares in Gazprom, government-owned Sberbank and a massive housing development in suburban Moscow prior to Russia's 2008 financial meltdown. The money allowed him to settle his debts and also to purchase stakes in a few European banks including Royal Bank of Scotland and Fortis as well as Russia's largest gold mining outfit, Polyus Gold. Has also invested in real estate company PIK and Moscow department store, Voyentorg. In autumn 2006 was seriously injured in car accident after losing control of a Ferrari Enzo on the Promenade des Anglais in Nice. Recovery was prolonged and painful.

name: Billionaires
bio: Hardware mogul's fortune spared from demolition despite tough economic times as legions of cash-strapped suburbanites shunned pricey contractors and took to do-it-yourself home renovation. U. of Wisconsin-Eau Claire grad earned handyman credentials constructing post-frame buildings to finance education. Began selling tools from a single store in 1970s; Menard's is now nation's third-largest home improvement (by sales) brand behind Home Depot, Lowe's. Revenues in 2009: nearly $8 billion.
title: president and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Menard, Inc.', 'title': 'president and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Widow and her children control one of Brazil's largest steelmakers, Companhia Siderurgica Nacional (CSN). The Steinbruch and Rabinovitch families, through their Vicunha Textile, paid a reported $800 million in 1993 for control of CSN, a formerly state-owned steel company. In 2005 Steinbruch bought out the Rabinovitch stake for a reported $590 million. Her brother-in-law, Eliezer Steinbruch, who shared control of CSN, died in mid-2008. She is not involved in running the business; son Benjamin serves as chairman and chief executive of CSN, whose shares have appreciated over the past year.   Company made an unsuccessful bid for Cimpor, Portugal's largest cement manufacturer, earlier this year. Family also owns Banco Fibra;  son Ricardo is chairman of the board.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of Sankyo, the pachinko gambling-machine maker, now run by his son Hideyuki. Newest units feature comic book characters and pop diva Kumi Koda. Expects big gain in net income for fiscal year, reversing the one-third drop in previous 12 months. Known to nongamblers as sponsor of the Sankyo Ladies Open golf tournament.

name: Billionaires
bio: Apparel maker is designer to the stars. Also makes perfume, baby clothes, home decor and 5-figure watches. Last year opened 43,000-square-foot megastore on Manhattan's Fifth Avenue. Has licensed his name for a string of hotels; first Armani Hotel scheduled to open in Dubai in the Burj Khalifa in March 2010. Spent 2 years in medical school at the University of Piacenza before dropping out in 1957 to take a job as a department store buyer. Presented with award by France's Legion of Honor in summer 2008.

name: Billionaires
bio: Master of the leveraged buyout once drove a tow truck. Now the richest person in Australia and New Zealand. In recent years turned his Rank Group into packaging powerhouse, buying up Australasian forest products group Carter Holt Harvey, Swiss packager SIG, Alcoa's former packaging unit and a North Carolina paper mill. Though Hart was not doing much dealmaking in the last 12 months, he did restructure some of his holdings. In October his SIG agreed to pay $3 billion for his Reynolds Consumer Products and Closure Systems International (both previously part of Alcoa's packaging unit). Up for sale:  Rank's 29 dairy farms. Drew up idea for Rank as an M.B.A. student at University of Otago. Boating enthusiast owns 190-foot yacht Ulysses.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fortune of Greece's richest man recovered 40% as financial services, oil refining, real estate, shipping, and travel companies rebounded from recession lows. Controls large stakes in EFG International, EFG Eurobank, Lamda Development, and Hellenic Petroleum. Latsis, who has a Ph.D. from the London School of Economics, elected to the board of Institute of Advanced Studies in Princeton.

name: Billionaires
bio: Investor made fortune through junk bonds secured by metals companies he acquired. Bought contractor AM General in 1992 for $133 million; maker of military Humvees, luxury SUV Hummers. Sold majority stake to Ronald Perelman for $930 million in 2004. Studied political science at Brooklyn College; earned M.B.A. from NYU. New York City native believed to have lost $100 million in Madoff Ponzi scheme. Now facing unrest over his Renco Group's Peruvian smelter; low metals prices have forced it to sit idle and put an emissions cleanup on hold. Third suspension announced in February.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of a coal miner, built his business in the mid-1990s by forging ties with then prime minister Viktor Yanukovych. With Yanukovych winning back the prime minister post in February, Akhmetov poised to benefit. Already fortune has rebounded in past year thanks to improved outlook for his metals group, Metinvest. Invested $1 billion in U.S. coal miner, United Coal. His energy company, DTEK, rumored to be considering public offering. Christened his $400 million soccer stadium last August; it will host 2012 Euro Cup. Won retraction from French daily newspaper Le Figaro for calling him "a scandalous Ukrainian oligarch." Spent more than $30 million on personal charities over past two years.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sold TV satellites from truck with wife in 1980s; built EchoStar Communications into satellite mammoth. Dish Network boasts 14.1 million subscribers today, adding 249,000 net subscribers in last quarter and outpacing rival DirecTV, after several quarters of successive losses in subscriber base. Spun off cable box manufacturer EchoStar in 2008; shares down 43% since. EchoStar plans to invest $112 million over 10 years in Mexican satellite-TV venture called Dish Mexico. Stepped down as chief executive of EchoStar in November, remains chairman. Still heads Dish Network. Ordered to pay $103 million in June to TiVo for video-recorder patent infringement; plans to appeal. Net worth up $1.3 billion in a year as Dish stock surges 35%. Former pro poker player lost out on bid to John Malone's Liberty Media for control of Sirius Satellite radio last year.
title: Founder and Chairman
employment: {'name': 'DISH Network', 'uri': 'companies/dish-network', 'title': 'Founder and Chairman', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Third generation to chair consumer products conglomerate Godrej Group whose 3,500-acre campus, with school and hospital, in suburban Mumbai is family's most valuable asset. Group's property arm, where son Pirojsha is a director, went public in December, raising $100 million and listing at a 9% premium. Is aiming to buy out Sara Lee's 51% stake in their joint venture, which makes household care products, including insecticides. Daughter Tanya, who oversees branding and marketing, talked about as front runner to succeed him. Younger daughter Nisa given charge of overseeing  personnel. Godrej was one of 40 chief executives to model in a charity fashion show in Mumbai.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fortune up $1.6 billion on surging Ebay stock price; shares up 115% in past year. French-born computer programmer launched online auction outfit Ebay 1995. Remained chairman after Meg Whitman became chief in 1998. Users: 84 million. 2009 Sales: $8.7 billion. Has pledged more than $900 million to nonprofit causes and for-profit investments, supports issues ranging from microfinance to his home state of Hawaii. Completed 70% sale of Skype in November, valuing computer video conference outlet at $2.75 billion.
title: Founder and Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Scion of family of Iraqi Jews who made early fortune in Shanghai more than a century ago and later settled in Hong Kong. Chairs power supplier CLP Holdings, the largest provider of electricity in Hong Kong in which family is big shareholder. CLP is still core of Kadoorie's wealth but Hongkong & Shanghai Hotels, which he also heads, generated some of his best returns last year. Opened the Peninsula in Shanghai, the city where family got its start before leaving in wake of Communist revolution. Took control of the Peninsula in Chicago. Board member of billionaire Li Ka-shing's Hutchison Whampoa.

name: Billionaires
bio: One of the trio of Brazilians who share control of Anheuser-Busch Inbev, the world's largest beer company. With his former investment banking partners and fellow billionaires Jorge Paulo Lemann and Carlos Alberto Sicupira, turned around Ambev, a Brazilian beermaker, and merged it with Interbrew of Belgium in 2004 to form Inbev. In November 2008 Inbev acquired Anheuser-Busch for $52 billion. The trio also control Brazilian retailer Lojas Americanas. Sits on newly formed international committee at Itau Unibanco, Brazil's largest private bank. Reportedly enjoys spearfishing and spending time in Monaco.

name: Billionaires
bio: Hollywood's richest man claims to have moved most of his fortune out of the markets in 2007 before economy cratered. "There were billionaires who could not qualify for The Forbes 400. That was one of many warning signs for me to get out." Today owns gobs of bonds, hundreds of millions of dollars' worth of art and real estate. Dropped out of U. of Texas; sorted mail at William Morris talent agency. Founded Asylum Records 1970, then Geffen Records. Launched careers of the Eagles, Aerosmith, Guns N' Roses; MCA acquired firm in 1990 for $550 million in stock. With partners Jeffrey Katzenberg and Steven Spielberg launched DreamWorks movie studio 5 years later.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandson of Cox Enterprises founder James M. Cox (d. 1957), who finished high school at 17 and worked as a schoolteacher and newspaper reporter before shelling out $26,000 for the Dayton Evening News in 1898. James Sr. later moved into politics. Today Cox Enterprises includes Cox Communications cable company, 17 daily newspapers, 15 TV stations, 86 radio stations, Manheim auctions (cars), AutoTrader.com. Revenues of $15 billion; ad sales at media operations dwindling. Inherited 25% stake in business after mother, Barbara Cox Anthony, passed away in 2007; now serves as Cox chairman. Fortune up $500 million in past year.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: One of Germany's post war retail pioneers. Began career in 1948 selling clothes.  Opened first Massa Department store in 1965. Sold chain in 1986 but smartly held on to the underlying real estate, which he now rents to retailer Metro. Kipp also owns real estate in the U.S., notably several high-end properties in Manhattan including 950 Third Avenue. Also has four Swiss luxury hotels and resorts including the Hotel Eden Roc in Ascona, the 105-room Carlton Hotel in St. Moritz and the Tschuggen Grand Hotel, where he lives with wife of some 60 years, Hannelore

name: Billionaires
bio: With $120 in savings, he and 3 brothers got start raising quail, chickens in 1982. Their Hope Group became one of China's largest makers of animal feed. Siblings split in 1995; Yongxing moved to Shanghai. His privately held East Hope Group is still one of China's biggest feed producers, making 100 types; core feed business has done well amid rising demand for meat in China as household incomes rise. Company is looking to expand in southern Vietnam. Also owns aluminum smelters and is investing in the plastics industry in China. Only son Shawn, a graduate of the University of Southern California, is heir apparent; his wife is from Texas.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, Hendrik, immigrated from the Netherlands 1900s; became barber. Opened North Side Grocery 1934 with 14-year-old son Frederik. Duo launched Meijer Thrifty Acres in 1962; pioneered 'superstore' one-stop shopping. Frederik took over after father's death 1964. Today there are more than 180 Meijer stores in 5 states. Estimated sales: $15 billion. Recently revamping stores. Fred Meijer: Stories of His Life published last year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Diamonds in the rough: sales of De Beers, the world's largest diamond producer, which he runs, dropped 44% to $3.8 billion; group posted a net loss of $220 million. Cutting costs allowed it to remain cash positive. Along with De Beers' other two investors, he and his family who own 40% of the group were asked to invest another $1 billion to help the company recapitalize and keep the ownership structure in tact.  His family's portion: $400 million. Consumer demand starting to recover, led by China and India. Still owns a stake in mining giant Anglo American, founded in 1917 by grandfather Ernest.  Passionate conservationist, owns Tswalu Kalahari Reserve, largest private game reserve in South Africa.

name: Billionaires
bio: Granddaughter of Cox Enterprises founder James M. Cox (d. 1957), who finished high school at 17 and worked as a schoolteacher and newspaper reporter before shelling out $26,000 for the Dayton Evening News in 1898. James Sr. later moved into politics. Today Cox Enterprises includes Cox Communications cable company, 17 daily newspapers, 15 TV stations, 86 radio stations, Manheim auctions (cars), AutoTrader.com. Revenues of $15 billion; ad sales at media operations dwindling. Inherited 25% stake in business after mother, Barbara Cox Anthony, passed away in 2007; not active in family business. Fortune up $500 million in past year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Immigrated from Germany to Chile as a teenager after WW II.  Decades later still holds dual citizenship. Began with a handful of supermarkets; opened first Jumbo hypermarket in 1976, now has 42.  In 1978 established $11 billion (sales) Cencosud,  one of Chile and Latin America's largest retailer conglomerates, owner of malls, supermarkets, department stores and home centers, an insurance  brokerage, family entertainment centers and a travel agency; took it public in 2001.  Paulmann and his family own 63.65% of the group.  Located in  Chile, Argentina, Brazil, Peru and Colombia; company planning on building the region's tallest building in Santiago. His three children all sit on firm's board of directors.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cofounded German software firm SAP with four former IBM colleagues in 1972. Retired in May 2003 after 30 years as Its chief executive; now head of supervisory board. With 2009 sales down 8% to $15.3 billion and software profits down 28% to $3.7 billion, company is restructuring to regain it's market lead; in February replaced CEO with two co-chief executives.   Sports enthusiast, sails his Morning Glory yacht competitively; skis, snowboards, plays golf and tennis. Owns luxury golf course and hotel, Fancourt Estate, in South Africa's Western Cape province. His Hasso Plattner Ventures based in Potsdam incubates promising IT technology companies.  One of Germany's largest philanthropists.  In 1998 donated 2.1 mil SAP shares then worth $1.5 billion to establish the Hasso Plattner Foerderstiftung which supports the sciences, historical preservation and projects in South Africa focusing on underprivileged children and teenagers.

name: Billionaires
bio: Merged his MDM Bank with Siberian Ursa Bank in 2008; retains controlling stake. After sale of jointly-owned pipe producer TMK in fall of 2006, began divvying up assets with partner, billionaire Andrey Melnichenko. Assets remaining in joint ownership: coal miner SUEK which they plan to take public. Left university to sell pipes and copper cable in 1990s; Melnichenko was his banker. Pair began to buy assets, creating TMK, Russia's largest pipe exporter; Eurochem, the country's largest mineral-fertilizer producer; and SUEK, Russia's largest independent coal producer.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former secretary and third wife of the late Herbert Quandt, German executive who rescued auto maker BMW from bankruptcy.  Retired from BMW's supervisory board in 1997; still owns 17% of the $74 billion (sales) auto maker.  Her children, Susanne Klatten and  Stefan Quandt, have large stakes as well and are also billionaires.  Lives quietly in spa town of Bad Homburg near Frankfurt. Last September was recognized by the German government for her cultural and social endeavors in support of journalism and learning.

name: Billionaires
bio: Recently named Lonnie O. Moulder to run his Abraxis BioScience; Soon-Shoing running Abraxis Health, specializing in disease biomarkers. Sold APP Pharmaceuticals to German dialysis clinic operator Fresenius for $5.6 billion 2008; believed to have personally netted $3 billion just before market crash. Shares of Abraxis BioScience down 50% since last February. Father was village doctor in China; family immigrated to South Africa during WWII. Finished high school at 16; doctor by 23. Took American Pharmaceutical Partners public 2001. Launched cancer treatment Abraxane 2005; drug more potent, with fewer side effects than treatments then available. Split company in 2007: APP Pharmaceutical creates hospital products, Abraxis BioScience develops drugs.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder and retired chairman of Fubon Group. U.S. educated sons Daniel and Richard are chairman and vice chairman, respectively, of Fubon Financial. Have successfully steered the financial services firm into telecom, through an investment in Taiwan Cellular. Fubon has been aggressive in seeking out growth in China; bought 19.9% stake in the Xiamen City Commercial Bank. Uncle of three billionaire brothers on list, Tsai Hong-tu, T.Y. Tsai and Cheng-da Tsai, who run Cathay Financial.

name: Billionaires
bio: Trader-turned-industrialist chairs Adani Group, which he founded in 1988 as commodities trading outfit. Expanded into energy, infrastructure. His Mundra Port on India's west coast is country's biggest in private sector. Raised $650 million in August by taking 70%-owned Adani Power public. He's planning to raise $325 million more through a rights issue of listed Adani Enterprises to invest in coal mining. Also plans to convert Mundra into a subsidiary of Adani Enterprises. Is reportedly on good terms with Narendra Modi, powerful chief minister of Gujarat state where Adani's businesses are located. Younger brother Rajesh, who works with him, was recently arrested and released on bail over charge of allegedly evading customs duty on an import consignment.

name: Billionaires
bio: Opened first apparel store in Barcelona 1984. Today the Mango group, known for producing reasonably priced trendy women's apparel, has more than 1200 stores in 92 countries and $2 billion in sales.  Opening new stores in Dutch Antilles, Belarus, Guatemala, Iraq and Iran. Now also makes Mango He, menswear line. Has shares in Banco Sabadell, one of Spain's largest banking groups; sits on its board.  Media-shy entrepreneur's family came to Spain from Turkey in 1960s; apparently an enthusiastic sailor.

name: Billionaires
bio: Began building his empire in 1990 when, with partner Vitaly Malkin, he set up Rossiysky Kredit Bank. Over the years, had sold other businesses he accumulated during country's privatization era including ore mining and metals interests; invested proceeds in Russian stock market. Buoyed by rising markets: Russia's MICEX index is up nearly 100% over the past year. Also has interests in hotels and a Russian chain of drugstores called Doctor Stoletov. Was the subject of some interest in the art world following his reported auction purchases, for far above their estimated prices, of works by Picasso and the contemporary artist Peter Doig. Now lives in the Georgian village of Chorvila, where he was born.

name: Billionaires
bio: Runs Rakuten, country's most popular online mall with 30,000 vendors selling 40,000 products. Hoping to repeat his success overseas; opened online store in Taiwan in 2008, plans one in Thailand this year. Hiring 100 foreign graduates in 2010 to help expand into as many as 30 nations in four years. Company also owns baseball team Rakuten Eagles. Bid to expand into broadcasting in Japan thwarted by reluctance of Tokyo Broadcasting System to agree to partnership despite fact that Rakuten is its largest shareholder, with 20% stake.

name: Billionaires
bio: Discount brokerage pioneer founded eponymous firm in 2-room office 1971. Deregulation of brokerage commissions, birth of online investing propelled company to enormity. Client assets: $1.4 trillion. Market malaise taking its toll: top-line fell 19% in 2009 as market valuations dropped and declining investment yields undercut interest revenue. Schwab shares up 45% in past 12 months. Left chief exec post in 2008, still chairman.
title: Chairman and Founder
employment: {'name': 'Charles Schwab', 'uri': 'companies/charles-schwab', 'title': 'Chairman and Founder', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Blackstone tycoon made back some of his billions amid market rally. Shares of the investment firm have surged 120% in 2009; still off 60% since public offering 2007. Yale grad found mentor in Peter Peterson at Lehman Brothers; duo left to create private equity outfit Blackstone 1985. Total assets then: $400,000. Added real estate, hedge fund, financial advisory divisions. Peterson left after Blackstone went public 2 years ago. Firm now manages $98.2 billion. Fellow Blackstone billionaire Hamilton ("Tony") James is Schwarzman's heir apparent.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Blackstone Group', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded JCDecaux outdoor advertising company. Started out putting ads on "street furniture" such as public toilets and bus shelters. Now places advertising in airports, malls, subways and billboards in almost 50 countries.  Number one outdoor advertising company in Europe and Asia-Pacific and number two worldwide  is feeling the pinch of the recession:  revenues dropped 11.5% in 2009 to  $2.7 billion. According to Decaux, it was the company's most difficult year since its founding in 1964. Leading provider of eco-friendly transportation in big cities, including bicycles for hire. Places recycling bins for batteries, glass or other waste near its street furniture. Decaux is chairman of the company; sons Jean-Francois and Jean-Charles are co-chief executives.

name: Billionaires
bio: Tailored tastemaker defying retail chill; shares of Polo Ralph Lauren have doubled during past year. Opened stores in China as US, European sales slowed. Wide-ranging product mix--affordable (Chaps), collegiate (Rugby), high-end (Collections), nonclothing (paint, bedding, lights)--all contributing to resilience. Sales exceed $5 billion. Bronx native worked first job at Brooks Brothers, left business school to design ties for Beau Brummel 1967. Launched Polo later that year with $50,000. Sold 28% of company to Goldman Sachs in 1994 for $138 million; took public 3 years later. Car collector partial to European makes: Bugatti, Bentley, Alfa Romeo, Ferrari, Porsche.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Ralph Lauren', 'uri': 'companies/ralph-lauren', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Runs Sun Pharma, India's most valuable drugmaker, which he founded 27 years ago. Got traction through 14 acquisitions. Company's 3-year-old bid to acquire Israel's Taro Pharma, a generic drugs maker, for $454 million is still mired in court battles after Taro backed out of the deal in 2008. The Israeli Supreme Court recently blocked Sun from converting warrants into shares, pending the ruling. Templeton Asset Management, which has shares in Taro and was earlier against Sun taking it over, is now backing the Indian firm. Last June inspectors from the U.S. Food & Drug Administration seized drugs from Sun's U.S. subsidiary, alleging deviation from manufacturing practices. In October it settled a patent battle against Forest Laboratories to make the generic version of an Alzheimer's drug.

name: Billionaires
bio: With brothers, controls one of country's largest private oil outfits. Father, Perry, inherited family fortune created by oil baron uncle Sid Richardson 1959. Passed on to eldest son, Sid, 1968. Bass Enterprises Production planning deepwater exploration off Nova Scotia. Sold one division to Southern Union for $1.6 billion 2005. Robert runs Oak Hill Capital management.

name: Billionaires
bio: Shrewd banker started hoarding cash 2004 as consumers and companies bathed themselves in debt; waited until economy began to crumble 2007. Set about snapping up loans jettisoned by struggling banks, desperate investors. Bottom-feeding a boon: combined net income at his 2 banks surged 95% to $547 million in 2009. Son of a mechanical engineer scraped together early kitty fixing used televisions; sold to low-income families. Bought Lansing, Mich. rental home at age 19. Opened first branch of Beal Bank in Texas 1988. Added Nevada bank years later. Buys loans on the secondary market instead of originating them. Gifted poker player took on renowned card sharks Doyle Brunson and Phil Ivey at the Bellagio in Las Vegas in some of the highest-stakes games ever played.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded Cook Group from Bloomington apartment in 1963; now the world's largest privately held medical device manufacturer. Products include stents, needles, antibiotic-impregnated catheters and vena cava filters. Wants doctors to have more input into medical device development; believes American health care depends on nationwide network of low-cost clinics and better access to primary care. Invested $500 million to restore Indiana's French Lick Resort Casino and West Baden Springs Hotel into destination golf resort; hotel revenues on upswing as Midwest travelers stay close to home. Donated $15 million to Indiana U's new basketball facility.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fortune rising despite sluggish American consumer spending; Alticor sales increased 15% to $8.2 billion in 2008 on growth in China, Russia, India. Cofounded Amway in 1959 with high school chum and fellow WWII vet Jay Van Andel (d. 2004), reorganized as Alticor in 2000. Used direct-selling to turn all-purpose-cleaner company into a consumer products empire. Retired 1993; youngest son, Doug, lords over a sales staff of 3 million in 80 countries. Revived Amway brand name and marketing campaign in May. Planning to form joint venture with nutritional products maker Metagenetics. Owns pro basketball's Orlando Magic.

name: Billionaires
bio: Owns the Tengelmann Group, one of Germany's largest food retailers; also 40% of U.S. grocery chain A&P. The 151-year-old A&P  continues to focus its operations on eight states in the Northeast, after having pulled out of New Orleans and the Midwest in late 2007.   Haub retired in 2000 and turned over reins to sons Karl-Erivan, Georg and Christian. Big fan of the U.S., owns extensive land in Washington State,  a buffalo ranch in Wyoming and a ski resort in the Cascades called Sun Mountain Lodge. Small town celebrity in Tacoma, Wash., thanks to his contribution to the town's revitalization.

name: Billionaires
bio: Contraction in world economy spoiling food family's fortune. Fiscal 2009 earnings down 15% to $3.3 billion despite revenues remaining steady at $117 billion. William Cargill, son of Scottish sea captain, founded Iowa grain storage business after Civil War. Will's son-in-law John MacMillan took control 1909. Low-profile family owns 88% of Cargill; hasn't run company since Whitney stepped down as chief executive 1995. Firm controls food from stable to table: animal feed, meat, crops. Also runs large commodity trading and risk management operations. Family owns majority of fertilizer maker Mosaic; shares up 30% since February 2009.

name: Billionaires
bio: Contraction in world economy spoiling food family's fortune. Fiscal 2009 earnings down 15% to $3.3 billion despite revenues remaining steady at $117 billion. William Cargill, son of Scottish sea captain, founded Iowa grain storage business after Civil War. Will's son-in-law John MacMillan took control 1909. Low-profile family owns 88% of Cargill; hasn't run company since Whitney stepped down as chief executive 1995. Firm controls food from stable to table: animal feed, meat, crops. Also runs large commodity trading and risk management operations. Family owns majority of fertilizer maker Mosaic; shares up 30% since February 2009.

name: Billionaires
bio: Contraction in world economy spoiling food family's fortune. Fiscal 2009 earnings down 15% to $3.3 billion despite revenues remaining steady at $117 billion. William Cargill, son of Scottish sea captain, founded Iowa grain storage business after Civil War. Will's son-in-law John MacMillan took control 1909. Low-profile family owns 88% of Cargill; hasn't run company since Whitney stepped down as chief executive 1995. Firm controls food from stable to table: animal feed, meat, crops. Also runs large commodity trading and risk management operations. Family owns majority of fertilizer maker Mosaic; shares up 30% since February 2009.

name: Billionaires
bio: Newspaper and magazine meltdown has slashed $3.5 billion from fortune since 2008. Suffering the most: glossy magazine giant Conde Nast. Folded Gourmet, Domino, Portfolio in 2009. McKinsey consultants advised magazines on cost-cutting. Father, Sam Newhouse (d. 1979), started with one newspaper, Bayonne Times; built Advance Publications, nation's largest privately owned newspaper chain. Last March announced unpaid furloughs for most newspaper employees and freeze on pension plans. Bright spot: owns stake in publicly traded Discovery Communications; holdings include Discovery Channel and Animal Planet, shares up 106% in year. Bright House Cable also holding value. Owns a dizzying art collection that includes works by Rubens, Johannes Lingelbach.

name: Billionaires
bio: Contraction in world economy spoiling food family's fortune. Fiscal 2009 earnings down 15% to $3.3 billion despite revenues remaining steady at $117 billion. William Cargill, son of Scottish sea captain, founded Iowa grain storage business after Civil War. Will's son-in-law John MacMillan took control 1909. Low-profile family owns 88% of Cargill; hasn't run company since Whitney stepped down as chief executive 1995. Firm controls food from stable to table: animal feed, meat, crops. Also runs large commodity trading and risk management operations. Family owns majority of fertilizer maker Mosaic; shares up 30% since February 2009.

name: Billionaires
bio: One of the trio of Brazilians who share control of Anheuser-Busch Inbev, the world's largest beer company. With his former investment banking partners and fellow billionaires Jorge Paulo Lemann and Marcel Telles, turned around Ambev, a Brazilian beermaker, and merged it with Interbrew of Belgium in 2004 to form Inbev. In November 2008 Inbev acquired Anheuser-Busch for $52 billion. The trio also control Brazilian retailer Lojas Americanas. Sicupira earlier worked as an investment banker in Brazil.

name: Billionaires
bio: Bank examiner got taste for takeovers after buying Dallas drugstore in 1961 for $5,000 cash plus $95,000 loan; sold chain to Eckerd Corp. for $50 million 12 years later. Built publicly traded holding company Valhi through hostile buyouts. Stock up more than 50% in that time. Stake in Titanium Metals up more than 175% in the same period. in July Dallas County jury found his holding companies guilty of conspiring to lower the value of portfolio company NL Environmental Management Services when minority shareholders wanted to cash out; verdict upheld in November. Award was reduced to $101 million following post-trial motions. NL Environmental has appealed.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Chinese-literature major worked as a manager in a state-owned company before striking out on his own in air-conditioning wholesale market in his native Nanjing 1990. Soon shifted to retail. Opened first store with $12,000 of savings and 200 square meters of floor space. Now China's second largest electronics retailer is benefiting from double-digit growth in nation's retail spending; shares up by half in past year. Member of Forbes Asia's 2009 "Fab 50" list of Asia's best large businesses, Suning bought Hong Kong appliance retailer Citicall Retail Management in February. His elder brother, property developer Zhang Guiping, is also a billionaire.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cruise captain's fortune up $1.5 billion as Carnival stock surges 59% in past year. Sailing against stiff currents as cash-strapped consumers, global pandemics eat away at Carnival's profits. Cheap prices forced 2009 revenues down more than 9% to $13.2 billion; swine flu scare forced 27 ships to reroute away from Mexican ports last spring. Plans to expand European business in 2010 in face of weaker North American demand. Took over boat business from father Ted, named president 1979; chairman and chief executive 1990. Today operates 95 ships under 11 brands, including Cunard, Princess, Holland America. Company claims 225,000 people are sailing on its flagship fleet at any given time; donated $5 million towards relief efforts in Haiti. Also owns pro basketball's Miami Heat.
title: Chairman and CEO

name: Billionaires
bio: Former plantation field supervisor sold ice cream on a bicycle as a kid to help support his family. Now heads IOI Group, one of world's leading operators of palm oil plantations, refineries. His plants produce specialty oils, metallic stearates, fats used in soaps, detergents, cosmetics, food additives. Making inroads into Indonesian palm oil estates. The group is also one of the biggest property developers in Malaysia.

name: Billionaires
bio: Started out with chain of currency-exchange booths; founded MDM Bank in 1993. Met fellow billionaire Sergey Popov and pair began to buy assets, creating TMK, Russia's largest pipe exporter; Eurochem, the country's largest mineral-fertilizer producer; and SUEK, Russia's largest independent coal producer. In 2006 the pair started splitting their business empire, Melnichenko kept Eurochem and a stake in SUEK. In 2009 increased his share in German fertilizer company K+S to 15%. Owns a $350-million megayacht, which resembles a submarine and which he named "A" after his wife Alexandra Kokotovic, a Serbian model.

name: Billionaires
bio: Oil trader Gennady Timchenko aiming to increase stake in Mikhelson's Novatek, the largest independent gas producer in the country; the deal gives Timchenko the largest stake in the company, 23%. In 1987, Mikhelson inherited management of expansive Soviet enterprise that built pipelines, roads and industrial facilities. Four years later reorganized the company and began gathering up oil and gas production licenses, even accepting them as payment for construction work in order to build Novatek. In 2006 Gazprom bought nearly 20% of Novatek from Mikhelson and his partners, a deal widely seen as a way for the firm to ensure its survival. At that time, Mikhelson got $1 billion for part of his stake and was able to remain chairman. Prolific art collector.

name: Billionaires
bio: Second wife and now widow of Reinhard Mohn who died last October at 88. She and her family inherited a fortune based on a 23% share of  $22.5 bil  (sales)  Bertelsmann AG, one of the world's leading media conglomerates.  Assets include the RTL Group, the No. 1 European broadcaster; Random House, world's largest book-publishing group; and Gruner + Jahr, Europe's biggest magazine publisher of such titles as The Financial Times Deutschland and Der Stern.  Bertelsmann has been  cutting jobs, dropping non-profitable segments and restructuring to deal with the global economic crisis and the drop in advertising revenues. Liz, as she is known, has been actively involved in the company for years; as a member of the supervisory board represented her husband after he retired; also vice CEO of the Bertelsmann Foundation which owns 77% of the company.   President of a foundation that seeks to prevent strokes, which she founded in 1992.  In 2003 she and her husband were awarded the Teddy-Kollek prize given out by the Jerusalem Foundation for person or persons who have actively promoted German-Jewish understanding.

name: Billionaires
bio: Invested $600 million with Carl Icahn in struggling Guaranty Financial Group in 2008; company filed for bankruptcy later that year. Father founded Tana Oil & Gas 1980. Robert practiced tax law for one year; jumped over to father's firm. Duo merged Tana's production properties with Texaco (now Chevron) 1989; received $480 million in cash and stock. Bought Omni Hotels for $500 million in 1996; hotel investments now make up majority of fortune. Three years later sold rest of Tana to Unocal. Traded in half of his Chevron shares for cash and oil and gas fields 2007. Other investments: Gold's Gym, Mexican retailer Waldo's.

name: Billionaires
bio: His BYD Co. is now one of China's top automakers; began selling electric cars in December 2008, just a few months after Warren Buffett's MidAmerican Energy bought a 10% stake in firm, a move that helped push up stock six-fold in 10 months. Hopes to start selling models in U.S. in 2010. Also makes batteries and battery chargers; its stock tumbled this fall after its 65%-owned subsidiary BYD Electronics recalled the battery chargers it supplied to Nokia due to potential electric shock. Left his post at a government-affiliated research institute in Beijing in 1995 to co-found BYD Co. with Lu Xiangyang, now also a billionaire. Initially was a rechargeable battery manufacturer. In 2003 BYD acquired a state-owned, midsize automaker in Xian.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of Austrian retail chain Billa, sold out to German REWE group in 1996. Invested proceeds in Austrian real estate and is now one of the country's largest, possibly largest, private real estate owners. Assets include 5-star Hotel Radisson in Salzburg, the historic building that houses the Vienna Stock Exchange, and 4 palaces in Vienna. Former jazz pianist whose stage name was Charlie Walker has an authorized biography: Karl Wlaschek: A Success Story.

name: Billionaires
bio: Gave up his orthopedic practice in 1956 to take over family's shoe business. Turned it into Europe's largest shoe retailer Deichmann-Schuhe GmbH, a household name throughout Europe. Also owns U.S. retail chains, Rack Room Shoes and Off Broadway. Son Heinrich runs daily operations. Committed philanthropist, regularly donates large sums to missionary and humanitarian organizations, including a program to help leprosy victims in India, which he visits annually.  Holds the Martin-Luther Foundation's "Luther Rose" award for his social and charitable work.

name: Billionaires
bio: Great-grandfather owned a brick factory, grandfather worked in cement. Father Max carved up his estate 1984: brother Stephen, also a billionaire, got construction company Eternit, Thomas got Holcim, the world's second-largest supplier of cement and concrete. Ran it for 2 decades; stepped down as chairman in 2003; still holds 20% stake. Shares up 120% in past 12 months as credit markets percolate, construction slow-down begins to subside. Wine aficionado owns vineyards in Argentina, Australia, California. Also owns Swiss vineyard in his native town of Balgach. Honorary Consul-General of the Republic of Cyprus in Switzerland.

name: Billionaires
bio: Convinced a skeptical Japanese executive three times his age to partner with him in Taiwan's rice cracker industry three decades ago. Now, Want Want Holdings, which he heads, is one of China's most popular food brands.  Currently trying to build on brand success by expanding in the beverage industry. Also moving into hotels and insurance. Tsai keeps busy with other investments: acquired Taiwan's China Times Group in 2008, also took a stake in broadcaster ATV in Hong Kong. Son and a nephew are members of Want Want's board of directors.

name: Billionaires
bio: Inherited real estate and shipping outfit Wheelock & Co. from father-in-law Sir Y.K. Pao; chairs company. Its main subsidiary, the Wharf, which includes  Hong Kong's Times Square, Harbour City rebounded along with real estate sector. Group is close to finishing one of Shanghai's tallest structures in prestigious Jing'an district. Its I-Cable subsidiary  is bidding for free-to-air broadcast license, city's third. Daughter Jennifer Woo runs family's Lane Crawford retail chain.

name: Billionaires
bio: One of South America's most prominent businessmen oversees a diversified empire with interests in Venezuelan television stations, telecom outfits, a regional brewery and a baseball team.  Sold U.S. Spanish-language TV network Univision to a private equity consortium led by U.S. billionaire Haim Saban for $700 million in 2007.  After locking horns with president Hugo Chavez, Venevision, his Venezuela TV company, is avoiding politics these days, preferring to  concentrate on entertainment content, including hugely popular Latin American soap operas. Cisneros and his wife are familiar figures in high society, hobnobbing with former presidents, designers and fellow billionaires; George H.W. Bush is his fishing buddy. Boasts an extensive collection of Latin American art: one favorite is an Amazonian landscape by German artist Frank W. Post. His foundation promotes education and protection of indigenous people in the Amazon basin.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sold most of his Banco Real to Dutch bank ABN Amro in 1998 for $2.1 billion. With remaining assets built Banco Alfa, now Brazil's 16th-largest bank. Also owns Agropalma, Latin America's biggest palm oil producer (now moving into biodiesel), and C&C, a chain of home improvement stores. Today is mostly retired, reportedly owns 150 purebred horses. Trained as a doctor and practiced medicine for 2 years. When his father died suddenly, Faria took his place running Banco Real.

name: Billionaires
bio: Leveraged buyout pioneer's firm finally went public. After a series of postponements, KKR merged with Amsterdam-listed affiliate in October. Estimated value of combined company: $6.7 billion. Firm manages $55 billion across buyout, credit funds. With fellow Bear Stearns colleagues George Roberts and Jerome Kohlberg, formed leveraged buyout firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts 1976. Used junk bonds to buy underperforming companies; refined operations, flipped for profit. Kohlberg left 1987. Remaining duo immortalized 3 years later in bestselling book Barbarians at the Gate after $25 billion RJR Nabisco buyout. Extended streak of megadeals with TXU buyout 2007: partnered with David Bonderman and James Coulter's TPG and Goldman Sachs to acquire power giant for $45 billion in cash and assumed debt. KKR-owned discount retailer Dollar General went public in November.
title: Co-Chair and Co-CEO
employment: {'name': 'KKR and Co', 'title': 'Co-Chair and Co-CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: His $5 billion (revenues) HCL Group, among the top-tier of Indian technology giants, was cofounded by him in 1976. Despite a tough environment overall for tech companies, sales of flagship HCL Technologies got boosted by large orders from key customers like Xerox and Rupert Murdoch's News Corp. But bottom line got hit due to foreign currency hedging losses. He's grooming his daughter Roshni as successor; last April he appointed her as chief executive of HCL Corp., the holding company that has stakes in his two listed flagships. The heiress is overseeing the Shiv Nadar Foundation and the rollout of a chain of schools in Northern India aimed at rural children. Wife Kiran, an avid art collector, recently opened an art museum in Delhi.

name: Billionaires
bio: The Philippines richest man came from China as a child to work in father's convenience store. Saved to start a small shoe store in Manila, which he built into one of the country's largest retail groups. SM Prime, the Philippines largest shopping mall developer, which he controls and is run by son Hans, has 36 malls in the country; continues China expansion. Banco de Oro Unibank, run by daughter Teresita Sy-Coson, recently merged with GE Capital's banking arm in the Philippines. SM Investment, family's listed holding company, expanding into gaming with new Las Vegas style casino complex in Manila Bay, scheduled to open this year. Shares fortune with wife and children.

name: Billionaires
bio: Majority of wealth held in Montana Rail Link railroad, Montana Resources copper and molybdenum mine--and cash. Also owns largest tug and barge fleet in British Columbia, environmental remediation, construction equipment and aviation companies. Built reputation on rehabilitation of Butte copper mine (which he purchased in 1986) and turnaround of bankrupt Morrison Knudsen in 1996. Public company Washington Group International declared bankruptcy in 2001 after tangle with Raytheon. Founded Dennis & Phyllis Washington Foundation 1998; so far has donated or committed $70 million to charities. Passion for yachts: refurbishing 333-foot Attessa IV.

name: Billionaires
bio: Largest individual shareholder of Nintendo, video game console manufacturer he created from playing cardmaker run by his grandfather. Ran the company for 55 years before retiring in 2005. Nintendo's net income halved in first half of business year, in part because of dearth of new game titles and slowing sales of Wii, which was forced to cut prices amid tough competition. (It lost top spot in U.S. to Sony's Playstation 3.) Bought baseball team Seattle Mariners in 1992, later transferred ownership to Nintendo's U.S. unit.

name: Billionaires
bio: Family fortune up $1 billion in 12 months as markets rebound; shares of General Dynamics up 19% in 12 months. Son of financier Henry Crown, who founded sand, stone and gravel company Material Service with 2 brothers 1919. Grew firm into world's largest building materials distributor, merged with General Dynamics 1959. Lester inherited fortune after father's death 1980. Diversified into hotels, sports, technology. Owns stakes in Chicago Bulls, New York Yankees, Aspen/Snowmass ski resorts.

name: Billionaires
bio: Reclaims title as Australia's wealthiest person. Founded Fortescue Metals; despite gifting part of his stake, still owns 31% of Australia's third-biggest iron ore exporter. Value of those shares rose steadily through 2009, thanks to increased Chinese demand. The onetime stockbroker and keen amateur boxer started his first mining company Anaconda Nickel (now called Minara) in 1994. Then hitched his fortune to an iron ore mine in the rugged Pilbara region of Australia's northwest. Founded Fortescue Metals in 2003. His net worth peaked at $12.7 billion in June 2008 when the mining stock hit its all-time high. Known by his schoolboy nickname "Twiggy," Forrest is a descendant of the first premier of the state of West Australia, Lord Forrest of Bunbury. Cleared in legal action Australia's corporate regulator took against him for allegedly misleading shareholders. Donated millions to combat poverty and alcoholism among Aborigines.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former marketing executive created Red Bull energy drink with Thai business partner Chaleo Yoovidhya. Marketed it to young people using cheeky advertising and extreme-sports sponsorships. A Taurus (the zodiac sign of the bull), Mateschitz owns 49% of the $4.7 billion (sales) company, which is expanding into India, Africa, Russia and Japan. Now also sells in France, Denmark and Norway where it had been banned because of its contents; still banned in Iceland and Uruguay. New product:  Energy Shots, a concentrated, non carbonated mini version of original Red Bull. Company has stakes in 2 soccer teams: Red Bull Salzburg and New York Red Bulls; also a Formula I team, Red Red Bull Racing.  Mateschitz's other interests include Seitenblicke magazine; Servus TV;   luxury resort on Fiji island of Laucala; and Hangar-7, the event center on the grounds of Salzburg airport that houses his historical aircraft collection called the Flying Bulls.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of Thai energy drink producer T.C. Pharmaceuticals. Teamed up with Austrian Dietrich Mateschitz two decades ago to create energy drink Red Bull. Chaleo provided beverage formula and his partner contributed the marketing flair. Today Red Bull, which has $4.7 billion (sales), is expanding into India, Russia, Africa and Japan. Now selling Energy shots, a concentrated, non carbonated mini version of original Red bull . Each partner owns 49% of the company. Chaleo's son, Chalerm, who owns one of Asia's leading wine producers, Siam Winery, holds remaining 2% stake in Red Bull.

name: Billionaires
bio: Turned small cork factory started by his grandfather in 1870 into world's largest producer of cork, $650 million (sales) Corticeira Amorim; group now also has real estate and tourism interests. No longer involved in daily operations, but owns 50% of the group. Most of his fortune now comes from his extensive investments in equities, particularly in finance and energy industries; holdings include 7% stake in Banco Popular; 28% in investment company Finpro; 25% in bank BIC Angola; 18% in Galp, Portugal's former state energy company; and 25% of Tom Ford, a luxury fashion designer.   Also has land in northern Brazil that he hopes to develop into a tourist spot. With his two brothers, has established a separate private equity fund to take advantage of financial crisis and acquire failing companies. Last June was awarded an honorary doctor of commercial science from St. John's University  in New York.

name: Billionaires
bio: With brothers Manuel and Placido, founded Bodega Aurrera discount supermarket chain 1958. Through Grupo Cifra, expanded into Vips and El Porton restaurants and Suburbia clothing stores. Cifra teamed up with Walmart in the early 1990s and was later bought out by the American retailer; stores renamed Walmart de Mexico (better known as Walmex). Deal netted Arangos more than $2 billion. Brothers also own real estate in Mexico City, Baja and Acapulco, where Jeronimo reportedly has a cliffside mansion called Marbrisa (which means "Sea Breeze"). Placido reportedly has extensive art collection, including pieces by El Greco, Henry Moore and Goya; has donated some artwork to the Prado Museum in Spain, where he is president of the board of trustees. Manuel founded the Mexican Center for Philanthropy and was co-producer of Academy Award-winning Sentinels of Silence (1971), an Orson Welles-narrated documentary about Aztec and Mayan ruins.

name: Billionaires
bio: Energy wunderkind grew up in Dallas. Father was a lawyer, mother an accountant. Finished Vanderbilt U. in 3 years. Hired by Enron 1995; said to have generated $750 million in trading profits 2000. Founded hedge fund Centaurus Energy 2002 after Enron collapsed. Returns stellar ever since: believed to be up 85% in 2008 and 26% last year through September (net of fees). Assets: $5.5 billion.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Omnipresent entrepreneur launching businesses on land, space and sea. This winter his Virgin Money expanded UK banking operation with purchase of Church House Trust. Private space agency Virgin Galactic getting closer to commercial space flights; this December unveiled VSS Enterprise spacecraft, due to launch in 2011. In July Abu Dhabi's Aabar Investments bought $280 million piece of Galactic. Implied company value: $900 million. In February introduced high-tech "aero-submarine" available for rent for $25,000 a week. Son of a barrister and flight attendant got his start with a mail-order record business almost 40 years ago, then turned it into retail chain Virgin Records; now empire spans air travel, rail, health care, finance, telecommunications and entertainment.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandmother founded H.E. Butt Grocery in 1905 from a small house in Kerrville, Tex. after husband fell ill with tuberculosis. Former bag boy expanded HEB operation; today firm owns 343 stores throughout Texas, Mexico. Sales: $15 billion. Caters to the wine-and-cheese set via Central Market; organic foods, in-store cafes. Waging fierce battle with Wal-Mart for Texas market share; irked when superstore giant ran ad claiming Wal-Mart could save shoppers $700 a year. Company donates 5% of pretax profits to charity.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of Bridgewater, world's largest hedge fund. Dives into myriad markets: currencies, stocks, bonds, interest rates. Son of a jazz musician bought first stock at age 12. Harvard M.B.A. 1973. Became futures trader at brokerage CBWL-Hayden Stone. Left to found Bridgewater Associates at age 25. Today firm manages $73 billion. Contrarian culture: employees encouraged to find fault with superiors' opinions. Enjoys bow-hunting; meditates 5 times a week.
title: Founder & Co-Chief Investment Officer
employment: {'name': 'Bridgewater Associates', 'title': 'Founder & Co-Chief Investment Officer', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Recession not killing Navy vet's buzz; sales of his Patron tequila up nearly 10% so far this year. Made first fortune from shampoo. Cofounded hair-care outfit John Paul Mitchell Systems with Paul Mitchell in 1980 with $700; lived in car, hawked products door-to-door in Los Angeles. Annual sales now approach $900 million, sells only to professional salons. Created tequila distiller Patron Spirits with Martin Crowley (d. 2003) in 1989. Friends Clint Eastwood and Wolfgang Puck helped make $50 bottles of tequila a staple at high-end restaurants, nightclubs. Today company sells more than 2 million cases a year. Bacardi bought minority stake in Patron for undisclosed sum last year. Giving more to charity as others decrease gifts; supports Food4Africa, Mineseekers, Blazer House.

name: Billionaires
bio: Turned Formula One racing into one of the world's most popular sports, with contests held in cities from Monte Carlo to Malaysia. Cashed in on F1 by selling his remaining stake in 2005 to private equity firm CVC Capital Partners, then turned around and reinvested with CVC in a new joint company called Alpha Prema. The new corporation now controls 100% of Formula One Group, and Bernie, who keeps 5% stake in F1, still gets to run the empire. Took an uncharacteristic stab at buying unprofitable carmaker Saab in January, losing out to a Dutch suitor. Got divorced in March 2009 from Slavica Ecclestone, former model and his wife of 24 years. With nearly all of Ecclestone's fortune tied up in the offshore Bambino trust for his two daughters, split likely will not result in huge payout for Slavica. With fellow billionaire Lakshmi Mittal and pal Flavio Briatore, owns the second-tier British soccer club Queens Park Rangers.
