name: Billionaires
bio: Property developer took his Evergrande Real Estate public in Hong Kong in November, raising $730 million; for brief time, was China's richest person. Shares have since fallen from their peak. Early investors in the offering included Hong Kong billionaire Joseph Lau's Chinese Estates Holding, Hong Kong billionaire Cheng Yu-tung's Chow Tai Fook and Singapore's Temasek Holdings. Company raised another $750 million in January, selling five-year debt at a 13% interest rate. Earned bachelor's degree in metallurgy in 1982 form Wuhan University of Science and Technology; has served as adjunct professor there since 2003. Shares wealth with wife.

name: Billionaires
bio: The brothers' secretive, privately held, diversified empire extends from oil refineries and gas stations to sawmills and forests; also has publishing interests and potato farms. Irving empire founded in 1881 by grandfather J.D. Irving now dominates the economy of New Brunswick and neighboring provinces. Teaming with Repsol YPF to construct a liquefied natural gas terminal; global economic conditions have made them cancel the planned construction of a $7 billion refinery in St. John with BP Plc.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, Rupert Sr., founded early mutual fund shop Franklin Distributors 1947. Charles became chief exec in 1957, half-brother Rupert Jr. joined 8 years later. Duo expanded into Franklin Resources 1969; added Templeton Funds 1992, Fiduciary Trust 2001. Company managed $523 billion at end of fiscal year 2009. Collective fortune up $3.3 billion in a year. Charles is chairman, Rupert Jr. vice chairman.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of Estee Lauder (d. 2004) slowly ceding control of mother's eponymous cosmetics empire to third generation. Son William named executive chairman last year. Niece Jane elected to board last July to fill seat left empty after brother Ronald retired. Other niece Aerin is Senior Vice President. Leonard's "Lipstick Indicator Theory" holds that people buy more inexpensive luxuries, like lipstick, during times of economic strife. Investors are convinced: company's shares up 40% since recession began in December 2007. Owns $800 million art collection including Cubist pieces.
title: Chairman Emeritus
employment: {'name': 'Estée Lauder Cos', 'uri': 'companies/estee-lauder-cos', 'title': 'Chairman Emeritus', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandfather Harry began developing real estate 1901. Father, Sam, expanded in New York City and New Jersey; built LeFrak City in Queens 1959. Richard joined family business 1970s, became chairman after dad died 2003. Today portfolio includes 5,000 apartments in LeFrak City and a $3 billion investment in 16-million-square-foot commercial, residential, retail complex in Newport, N.J. "Mini-city" with Westin hotel, 10 residential towers for 30,000 residents, marina. Invested in oil and gas wells. Expressed interest in bidding for Stuyvesant Towns. Bought interest in BankUnited and Blackstones Mineral Company in 2009.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of Marcel Merieux, a former laboratory aide of Louis Pasteur. Founded BioMerieux in 1974, which had roots in his father's first laboratory, Institut Merieux. Now chairman of the $1.5 billion (sales) company whose  biotech outfit specializes in in-vitro diagnostics; helps diagnose such as HIV and tuberculosis. Eldest son Rodolphe was killed in 1996 at age 27 when TWA flight 800 crashed over Long Island. Second son, Christophe, who was expected to take over from his father, died of cardiac failure in July 2006 at age 39. Third son Alexandre, 32, is a member of the board. Family supports the Merieux Foundation, which helps developing countries combat infectious diseases

name: Billionaires
bio: Newspaper and magazine meltdown has slashed $4 billion from fortune since 2008. Suffering the most: glossy magazine giant Conde Nast, folded Gourmet, Domino, Portfolio in 2009. McKinsey consultants advised magazines on cost-cutting. Father, Sam Newhouse (d. 1979), started with one newspaper, Bayonne Times; built Advance Publications, nation's largest privately owned newspaper chain. Last March announced unpaid furloughs for most newspaper employees and freeze on pension plans. Bright spot: owns stake in publicly traded Discovery Communications; holdings include Discovery Channel and Animal Planet, shares up 106% in year. Bright House Cable also holding value.

name: Billionaires
bio: Vancouver magnate's private conglomerate reaped benefit of strong market and high loonie. After finishing university, Pattison parlayed car dealerships into media, advertising, fishing and supermarket empire. During acquisition spree in 2008 added Guinness World Records to portfolio. Also owns stake, sits on board of Canadian telecom company, BCE Inc. Runs eclectic tourist attractions including Ripley's Believe It or Not and owns massive Palm Springs lair that once belonged to Frank Sinatra.

name: Billionaires
bio: One of three sons of publishing magnate William Ziff Jr. (d. 2006), who left career in academia to take over Ziff-Davis publishing company from father 1953. Built niche media empire (PC Magazine, Car & Driver, Boating). Sold 95% of business to Forstmann Little for $1.4 billion in 1994, retired to Florida. With two brothers founded Ziff Family Investments; today money scattered across hedge funds, real estate, debt, equities, commodities. Seeded hedge fund manager Daniel Och in exchange for 10% stake 1994; Och-Ziff public 2007.

name: Billionaires
bio: One of three sons of publishing magnate William Ziff Jr. (d. 2006), who left career in academia to take over Ziff-Davis publishing company from father 1953. Built niche media empire (PC Magazine, Car & Driver, Boating). Sold 95% of business to Forstmann Little for $1.4 billion in 1994, retired to Florida. With two brothers founded Ziff Family Investments; today money scattered across hedge funds, real estate, debt, equities, commodities. Seeded hedge fund manager Daniel Och in exchange for 10% stake 1994; Och-Ziff public 2007.

name: Billionaires
bio: One of three sons of publishing magnate William Ziff Jr. (d. 2006), who left career in academia to take over Ziff-Davis publishing company from father 1953. Built niche media empire (PC Magazine, Car & Driver, Boating). Sold 95% of business to Forstmann Little for $1.4 billion in 1994, retired to Florida. With two brothers founded Ziff Family Investments; today money scattered across hedge funds, real estate, debt, equities, commodities. Seeded hedge fund manager Daniel Och in exchange for 10% stake 1994; Och-Ziff public 2007.

name: Billionaires
bio: World's youngest billionaire leading his addictive social networking site Facebook to an inevitable public pay-day. Firm became "cash-flow positive" last year, instituted dual-class voting structure akin to what Google put into place before it held its 2004 offering. Fresh-faced entrepreneur launched Facebook from Harvard dorm room in 2004. Left school for Silicon Valley later that year; bagged initial $500,000 investment from PayPal cofounder Peter Thiel. Last May Russian investment firm Digital Sky agreed to buy stock from Facebook employees; deal priced company at $10 billion. Shares continue to change hands on private equity exchange SecondMarket; recent transactions put the value at upwards of $15 billion. Growing rapidly: in past 12 months user base has surged 130% to 400 million.
title: Cofounder, Chairman and CEO

name: Billionaires
bio: Bought his father's one-route Ontario bus company for a dollar in 1951; eventually built it into Power Corp., a $32 billion (sales) financial services and communications giant; stock regained 25% of its value over the past year. Company owns Montreal daily, La Presse, as well as 6 other newspapers in Quebec and Ontario. It also controls Power Financial, which includes life insurer Great-West Lifeco and Investors Group, the largest mutual fund company in Canada. Desmarais' sons, Paul Junior, and Andre, share the chairmanship of Power Corp. Desmarais Sr. collects Canadian art and hunts birds at his private estate in Quebec. Family is friends with French President Nicolas Sarkozy.

name: Billionaires
bio: Orchestrated merger of troubled Swiss watchmakers SSIH (Omega, Tissot) and ASUAG 1983; introduced popular low-cost "Second Watch." Company renamed The Swatch Group 1998. Acquired luxury time-piece brand Breguet a year later. Struck licensing deal with Tiffany 2007. Swatch Group's sales in 2009: $5 billion, down 6.3% (holding exchange rates constant). Shares up 160% in 12 months. Son Nick Jr. serves as chief executive; Hayek still advises on major decisions.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of apartment managers ran Wyoming Hotel and gas station. Expanded business to Utah, Arizona; bought Sinclair Oil 1976. Energy empire now includes 3 refineries, 1,000 miles of pipelines, 2,600 gas stations. Also owns swanky ski resorts in Snowbasin, Utah and Sun Valley, Idaho. Sold Barnett Shale natural gas acreage to Chesapeake Energy for $300 million 2006; still drilling in North Dakota's Bakken Shale.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former real estate executive started first self-storage facility 1972; today Public Storage has more than 2,100 facilities in U.S., Europe with 135 million rentable square feet. Also owns 20 million square feet of commercial, industrial property. Retired as chief executive 2002; remains chairman. Son and daughter serve on board. Owns Thoroughbred horses.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chief executive of real estate developer Longfor Properties, which she co-founded with husband Cai Kui, who shares fortune. Company went public on Hong Kong stock exchange in November 2009; cornerstone investors included Ping An Insurance, Temasek Holdings and Singapore's government. Has a degree in navigation engineering. Worked at Qianwei Meter Factory from 1984 to 1988; spent the next five years working as a journalist and editor at the China Shirong News Agency. Shortly after that, she began developing real estate in her hometown of Chongqing. Now her firm has property in Beijing and other large cities.

name: Billionaires
bio: With mother Ingeburg, his four siblings Daniela, Gunter, Joachim and Wolfgang, inherited a fortune from his late father, coffee baron Max Herz. Helped push out brother Gunter and sister Daniela in 2003 in a drawn-out family feud. Now holds 35% stake in $4.4 billion (sales)  Maxingvest AG, formerly called Tchibo, makers of Germany's best-known coffee brand, Tchibo. Group also has 50% stake in Beiersdorf AG, which makes Nivea skin care products.  Michael and Wolfgang are on the holding's board of management. Brother Joachim died in  May 2008 after being  hit by a boat while swimming in a Georgia lake. Left his share of the family fortune to a charitable foundation.

name: Billionaires
bio: With mother Ingeburg, his four siblings Daniela, Gunter, Joachim and Michael (all billionaires), inherited fortune from his late father, coffee baron Max Herz.  Holds 35% stake in $4.4 billion (sales) Tchibo Holding, now Maxingvest AG, makers of Tchibo, a well-known German coffee brand. Group also has 50% stake in Beiersdorf AG, makers of Nivea skin care products. Wolfgang and Michael are on the holding's board of management.  Brother Joachim died in May 2008 after being hit by a boat while swimming in a Georgia lake and left his share of the fortune to a charitable foundation.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, Rupert Sr., founded early mutual fund shop Franklin Distributors 1947. Half-brother Charles became chief exec in 1957, Rupert Jr. joined 8 years later. Duo expanded into Franklin Resources 1969; added Templeton Funds 1992, Fiduciary Trust 2001. Company managed $523 billion at end of fiscal year 2009. Collective fortune up $3.3 billion in a year. Charles is chairman, Rupert Jr. vice chairman.
title: Vice Chairman and Director
employment: {'name': 'Franklin Resources', 'uri': 'companies/franklin-resources', 'title': 'Vice Chairman and Director', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: New York City magnate reeling as the 2 pillars of his fortune--property and banking--falter; lost $700 million in 12 months as real estate market crumbled, bank valuations fell. Father, Morris, founded Circle Co. 1919; laid hardwood floors and carpeting for Madison Square Garden, Rockefeller Center. Paul took over Circle; brother Seymour (d. 2001) ran a tile manufacturer. Sold Circle 1968, built New York real estate empire. Succession issues threatened to split business; two sides agreed to settlement 2003. Today Milstein Properties owns apartment towers and offices throughout Manhattan. Acquired New York City's oldest savings bank, Emigrant, for $90 million 1986; today assets exceed $14 billion. Son Howard oversees operation.

name: Billionaires
bio: Studied chemistry at UC, Berkeley, earned Ph.D. from Caltech. Cofounded Intel 1968; ignited PC revolution. Chief exec until 1987. Created Moore's Law: computing power will double every 18 months (later updated to 2 years). Intel expects trend to continue throughout decade. Execs have seen "significant interest" in low-powered Atom processor designed for popular netbooks. Current fiscal plan: focus on India for sales growth. Acquired software firm Wind River Systems in June for $884 million; will assist expansion into handheld and GPS markets. Moore no longer involved in company's management. Gordon & Betty Moore Foundation doles out $183 million annually to support environmental conservation and fundamental science, plus science museums, nursing care, and land conservation in the San Francisco Bay Area.
title: Cofounder and Chairman Emeritus
employment: {'name': 'Intel', 'uri': 'companies/intel', 'title': 'Cofounder and Chairman Emeritus', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Leveraged buyout pioneer's firm finally went public. After a series of postponements, KKR merged with Amsterdam-listed affiliate in November. Estimated value of combined company: $6.7 billion. Firm manages $55 billion across buyout, credit funds. With fellow Bear Stearns colleagues Henry Kravis and Jerome Kohlberg, formed leveraged buyout firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts 1976. Used junk bonds to buy underperforming companies; refined operations, flipped for profit. Kohlberg left 1987. Remaining duo immortalized 3 years later in bestselling book Barbarians at the Gate after $25 billion RJR Nabisco buyout. Extended streak of megadeals with TXU buyout 2007: partnered with David Bonderman and James Coulter's TPG and Goldman Sachs to acquire power giant for $45 billion in cash and assumed debt. KKR-owned discount retailer Dollar General went public in November.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded generic drug maker Apotex in 1974; today sales exceed $1 billion. Company sent seven million pills to treat AIDS patients in Rwanda in 2009. Locked in court fight with relatives who allege they are owed a piece of the fortune; Sherman filed countersuit, rebutting their claims. Son Jonathan Sherman is new owner of Ontario's bankrupt Steelback Brewery.

name: Billionaires
bio: Left his medical practice in South Africa to join identical twin brother, Thomas, in founding generic drug maker Hexal AG in 1986. Brothers eventually built Germany's second-largest generic drug maker. In February 2005 sold business as well as their 68% stake of U.S. Eon Labs to Novartis for $7.5 billion. Now brothers run their Santo Holding investment arm, which invests in the German biotech sector, in particular companies involved in cancer research.  Brothers have established a neuroscience research center in Frankfurt named after their father, Ernst Strungmann. Said to love sailing, golf and skiing.

name: Billionaires
bio: With identical twin brother, Andreas, founded generic drug maker Hexal AG in 1986., eventually building it into  Germany's second-largest generic drug maker. In 2005 sold business and their 68% of U.S. Eon Labs to Novartis for $7.5 billion.  Brothers now manage their Santo Holding investment arm which invests in the German biotech sector, in particular companies involved in cancer research.  Brothers have established a neuroscience research center in Frankfurt named after their father, Ernst Strungmann. Is said to be the more extroverted of the brothers. Reportedly collects modern art and Swiss watches.

name: Billionaires
bio: Property baron in bankruptcy bind. Took control of Tribune Co. 2007 in $8.2 billion deal done with newspaper giant's employees. Colossal debt, declines in ad revenue forced firm into bankruptcy;  working out reorganization plan, ceded chief exec. title to top deputy, Zell remains chairman. Bondholders claim property maven is responsible, demanding investigation. Made first fortune buying and selling real estate from distressed owners with partner Robert Lurie (d. 1990). Sold Equity Office Properties to Blackstone for $39 billion cash 2007. Still owns stakes in Equity Residential and Equity Lifestyle REITs. Other investments: affordable housing in Egypt, shopping malls in Brazil, homes and warehouses in China. Raised $625 million fund in August; capital to be used to buy real estate, corporate debt.

name: Billionaires
bio: Heads copper producer Kazakhmys, which has rebounded from last year's market collapse; the stock is up fivefold in the past year returning Kim to billionaire ranks. Company recently secured $2.7 billion loan from the China Development Bank and Kazakh state welfare fund Samruk-Kazyna to boost copper production. A descendent of Koreans forced by Stalin to move to Kazakhstan, Kim joined Kazakhmys during Khazakstan's early 1990s privatization.

name: Billionaires
bio: Owns 60% of $12.7  billion (sales) Helm AG, one of the world's leading independent chemicals marketing enterprises with  interests in trading, chemicals and pharmaceuticals.  Founded company after World War II; ran it until 1984 when he handed chairman title over to son Dieter, also a billionaire. Dieter still in charge. Herman's Else Schnabel foundation, named after his wife, promotes German-Czech Relations. Has an art collection with paintings by Van Gogh, Monet, Renoir, Rembrandt and Degas. Supports Hamburg Opera. Apparently dislikes wristwatches, collects stamps.

name: Billionaires
bio: Heads Russia's largest private bank, Alfa Bank, a business within the Alfa Group conglomerate controlled by fellow billionaires Mikhail Fridman, German Khan and Alexei Kuzmichev. Grew up in Moscow, attended a well-regarded high school for the city's elite and prestigious Moscow State University. Later worked at the Institute for Systems Studies at the Soviet Academy of Sciences. In 1989 went to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs; tapped to be minister of foreign economic relations two years later. In 1994 met Alfa Group's Mikhail Fridman and soon became a shareholder of Alfa-Bank. Owns the largest private collection of Russian art in Russia.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded retailer Metro AG in 1964.  Metro now has $95 billion in sales. Beisheim still owns some 13% of the publicly traded company.  Also manages Beisheim Holding Schweiz AG, which invests in internet and technology companies. In Berlin, owns Beisheim Center, a high-end complex with apartments, office buildings, two five star hotels, shops and cafes. Widower with no children, he has homes in Switzerland, Paris and Germany's Rottach-Eggern. Sports fan supports several foundations that mainly fund athletic programs.

name: Billionaires
bio: Good year for Hyundai Motor chairman and his company. Hyundai Motor became the world's fourth-largest automaker moving past Ford in the first half of 2009. Faring well in U.S.; Genesis model won North American Car of the Year award in 2009. Program to let people who lost jobs return newly purchased cars got favorable reviews. Should benefit from Toyota's massive recalls earlier this year; offered $1,000 incentive to anyone trading in their Toyota for a Hyundai. Avid sports fan began supporting Korea Archery Association after a Korean woman won a gold medal in 1984; paid for various high-tech training devices.

name: Billionaires
bio: Quit job as Enron president 1996; uneasy with "asset light" approach. Formed pipeline firm Kinder Morgan with college buddy William Morgan. Purchased Enron pipeline business; added more tubes from ExxonMobil and Shell, terminals from ConocoPhillips. Today controls 37,000 miles of pipe, 165 terminals. Took private in 2007 for $22 billion with investor Fayez Sarofim, Goldman Sachs. Owns 31%. Salary: $1 a year. Forgoes bonuses and restricted stock grants; like investors, makes money from large MLP payouts.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Kinder Morgan', 'uri': 'companies/kinder-morgan', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Former manager at a state arms plant has built China's largest private-sector construction equipment manufacturer, Sany Heavy. Sales in China were up 19% to $870 million in first half of year despite tough competition from rival China Zoomlion. Overseas sales dropped by half to $103 million. Added to his wealth with successful public offering of Sany's coal-equipment manufacturing arm Sany Heavy Equipment in Hong Kong in November.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder and executive chairman of one of world's biggest shopping mall chains, Westfield. Owns 119 malls in Australia, New Zealand, the U.S. and Britain. Hit by economic downturn; in January 2009 Westfield announced dividend cut and $3 billion writedown of assets, sending stock tumbling. Stock hit $6.30 low in March 2009 before beginning slow recovery; up more than 70% since then. In October 2009 opened a $2.4 billion mall in central London. Czech-born Lowy moved to Hungary, then Palestine, arrived in Sydney in 1952 and opened a delicatessen. His 3 sons, David, Peter and Steven, work in the business. Named in a U.S. Senate investigation into tax havens like Liechtenstein; denied he or his family had ever hid money in offshore banks. President of Football Federation Australia, sold his stake in Sydney FC team in 2008 to avoid conflict of interest and is now leading Australia's bid to host 2018 World Cup.

name: Billionaires
bio: One of China's richest Internet entrepreneur cofounded Tencent in 1999 with fellow billionaire Zhang Zhirong. Its powerful "QQ" brand has attracted almost 500 million regular users that have made it China's most popular provider of online chat services, also a leader in online games. Its chairman and chief executive, Ma led research and development of Internet paging system development at China Motion Telecom Development, a supplier of telecommunications services and products in China, before starting Tencent. Member of a city congress in Shenzhen, where Tencent is headquartered. Holds B.A. in computer field.

name: Billionaires
bio: Business student and professional soccer player successfully transformed family's bankrupt fertilizer company into a $125 million business with interests in agriculture, aerospace, animal health products, plastic, fiber optics and pharmaceuticals. Later produced such classic movies as Pretty Woman, Fight Club and Mr. and Mrs. Smith. Recently produced Marley & Me with Jennifer Aniston; Bride Wars with Kate Hudson and box office success Alvin & The Chipmunks. This summer plans to release Knight and Day with Tom Cruise and Cameron Diaz; Marmaduke with Owen Wilson. Started security company last year to protect friends from terrorists. Close friend of Shimon Peres has vowed to help bring about peace in Middle East. Has extensive art collection.

name: Billionaires
bio: Joined father's Hartz Mountain Pet Products at the age of 21; sold company for $350 million in 2000 to private equity firm J.W. Childs. Plowed proceeds into burgeoning real estate empire: today owns 38 million square feet of commercial, residential, retail property in New Jersey and New York. In July started construction on Edison Towne Square, 98-acre mixed-use redevelopment of the former New Jersey Ford plant; project slated to include retail, restaurants, a hotel, entertainment venues, office space. On the prowl for cheap real estate. Son Emanuel oversees family's real estate empire, including hip Manhattan hotels Soho Grand and Tribeca Grand. Gave $30 million to alma mater NYU 1988; business school now bears his name.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Hartz Mountain Industries, Inc.', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: President of Mashreq, leading United Arab Emirates commercial bank founded by father, Abdullah, in 1967. Stock down over 60% in past year as bank buffeted by rocky Gulf economy and soured loans. Third-quarter net profit nearly halved due in part to bank's $400 million exposure to massive defaults by 2 prominent Saudi family businesses. Now suing one of the families, the Algosaibis, in a New York court in hopes of recovering some of the losses (the Algosaibis have countersued). Other family investments include bottled water, cement, real estate and one of the country's largest grain processors.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sound sultan worked on audio and instrumentation projects at Ampex in high school; played integral role in developing first videotape recording system. Earned physics Ph.D. at Cambridge 1961. Founded Dolby Laboratories in London 4 years later; made fortune with audio-processing systems that eliminate background noise, audiotape hiss. Relocated to San Francisco, took public 2005. Shares have doubled in past year; strong licensing fees from partnerships with Microsoft (Windows 7), Toshiba (HDTVs ) aiding recovery. Owns at least 50 patents.
title: Founder and director emeritus
employment: {'name': 'Dolby Laboratories', 'uri': 'companies/dolby-laboratories', 'title': 'Founder and director emeritus', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: With brother Victor, runs Li & Fung, outsourcing firm that supplies fashions, furnishings and toys to retailers. Recently signed an agreement to act as buying agent for Walmart; also supplies to Target. Last year picked up Liz Clairborne's sourcing operations in Asia, became exclusive sourcing agent for Talbots; bought children's apparel maker Wear Me, footwear supplier Shubiz. William was named to Singapore Airlines board in January. Brothers own stakes in newly public luxury menswear retailer Trinity. Grandfather Fung Pakliu started the company a century ago with partner Li To-ming; duo sold porcelain, antiques. Father Fung Hon-chu ran it while brothers studied business in U.S.; they returned to take helm 1970s. William is managing director; Victor, a U.S. citizen, is chairman.

name: Billionaires
bio: With his father, opened Rimi discount supermarket in the late 1970s, later partnering with Swedish retailer ICA Group and supermarket giant Royal Ahold. In 2004 Hagen exercised an option to sell his remaining 20% stake in the venture, forcing Ahold to pony up $1 billion. Bought into department store chain Steen & Strom, then took the whole thing private in late 2007. Chairman of consumer goods company Orkla, which has experienced tepid recovery from downturn. Also invests in real estate and local companies through his Canica group.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father started privately held kretekmaker Djarum in 1950s. With brother Budi, turned it into one of the largest in Indonesia. He owns 49% of the company while Budi, also a billionaire, owns 51%. Djarum was bestselling clove cigarette brand in the U.S. before FDA banned the product in 2009. Hasn't had big impact on sales or fortune given that bulk comes from massive Indonesian market. Besides, most of brothers' wealth now comes from their controlling stake in Bank Central Asia, Indonesia's largest private bank. Together they also own Grand Indonesia, a luxury shopping mall, office building and hotel complex in the center of Jakarta.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father started privately held kretekmaker Djarum in 1950s. With brother Michael, turned it into one of the largest in Indonesia. He owns 51% of the company while Michael, also a billionaire, owns 49%. Djarum was bestselling clove cigarette brand in the U.S. before FDA banned on clove cigarettes in 2009. Hasn't had big impact on sales or fortune given massive Indonesian market. Besides, most of brothers' wealth now comes from their controlling stake in Bank Central Asia, Indonesia's largest private bank. Together they also own Grand Indonesia, a luxury shopping mall, office building and hotel complex in the center of Jakarta.

name: Billionaires
bio: Abandoned Harvard Ph.D. in economics to drive New York City taxi. Started trading soybeans; turned $3,000 he borrowed on his credit card into $45,000. Went to work for Michael Marcus at Commodities Corp. Founded hedge fund Caxton Associates 1983; his Caxton Global fund returned 6.15% net of fees last year, 13% in 2008. Assets: $8 billion. Music aficionado used to study harpsichord at Juilliard; donated collection of 140 scores and sketches by Bach, Beethoven and Brahms for school's benefit.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandson of the founder of Danish toymaker Lego. Ran company for 25 years before stepping down in 2004 after several years of losses; remains its sole owner and vice chairman of the board. Despite downturn, world's sixth-largest toymaker by sales ($1.8 billion), has been profitable since 2006, thanks to restructuring and sale of assets such as its four Legoland amusement parks. Initiated the Next Generation Foundation, focused on children's development.

name: Billionaires
bio: Makes big comeback thanks to jump in stock price of palm oil giant Wilmar, which he runs. Also due to shareholder restructuring that revealed his stake to be 12%, more than previously estimated. Started out as a flour trader working for his uncle, Malaysian billionaire Robert Kuok. Struck out on his own, eventually partnering with Martua Sitorus to buy a small palm oil plantation in Sumatra in 1991 that later became publicly traded palm oil company Wilmar International. Merged Wilmar with the senior Kuok's plantation and agribusiness group in June 2007, turning Wilmar into one of the world's largest palm oil producers. Mulling sugar business in Indonesia.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chinese Internet entrepreneur returns to the billionaire ranks and is now nearly twice as rich as he was in 2008 when he last made the cut. Heads China's online search leader, Baidu, which posted 48% rise in fourth quarter profit. Stock up 281% in the past 12 months, thanks to the strong results but also more recently due to its ongoing rivalry with Google. Baidu shares, and his fortune, jumped a third after Google said in January it might pull out of China. Before cofounding Baidu in 2000, Li worked as a staff engineer in Silicon Valley for Infoseek, a pioneer in the Internet search engine industry. Li sits on board of New York-listed New Oriental Education & Technology, which provides educational services in China. Wealth estimate includes shares held by wife, Melissa Ma.

name: Billionaires
bio: Head of Empresas Polar, one of Venezuela's largest private companies. Produces Polar beer and staples like  flour and condiments, tuna fish and wine. Grandson of company founder. Despite leftist president Hugo Chavez's public threats to nationalize Polar if it was caught hoarding food (Polar said it has no role in the country's food shortages),  company remains private.  Family runs one of Venezuela's largest charities

name: Billionaires
bio: Helped then husband Amancio Ortega make dressing gowns and lingerie in their home. It became one of world's most successful apparel manufacturers, Inditex, which also owns Zara retail stores. Couple divorced years ago, but Mera still holds 7% stake in now $14.5 billion (sales) business. At time of Inditex's public offering also got $600 million in cash, which she's invested in a Spanish film production outfit, a marine fish farming group, a company that looks for cancer treatments in compounds found in the sea, a hotel chain, and a maker of a fingerprinting identification system for newborns. Has received various awards for her contributions to Spanish society via her Paideia Foundation, which helps people with physical and mental disabilities.
title: Investor, Philanthropist

name: Billionaires
bio: Cell phone tycoon operates in dozens of Caribbean islands, Honduras, Haiti, Fiji, Tonga and Papua New Guinea, braving coups, riots and threats of nationalization. Endears his firm to masses by cutting prices, donating to local causes. Recently deployed mobile cell towers to restore cell service in earthquake-torn Haiti. Digicel Group planning to buy majority stake in Digicel Pacific this year. Companies boast a combined 10.75 million subscribers. O'Brien's other holdings: radio stations, online recruiting sites in China, Portuguese resort. Son of a human rights activist created nonprofit Front Line to fly activists out of harm's way.

name: Billionaires
bio: Global recession was especially harsh to media heir and onetime richest Australian. Son of legendary media tycoon Kerry Packer inherited $5 billion empire after dad's death in 2005. Last year it was worth half that, as market carnage spared no part of his empire. Quick to put personal stamp on business, had spun off media assets and bet on gaming business Crown, which started trading in December 2007. Recent biography criticized his expansion into Vegas casino industry. But Packer's situation has started to turn around, along with his wealth. Crown shares are up 13% in past year; Consolidated Media Holdings up more than 40%. In the last 12 months sold off stakes in 2 public companies, a luxury yacht and property, but still holds private stakes in a women's retailer, cosmetics company and ski field. Other good news: Packer and his model wife, Erica, welcomed their first child, daughter Indigo, in July 2008 and a second, son Jackson Lloyd, in February.

name: Billionaires
bio: Secretive brothers own almost 16% of retailer Metro. Also own Travel Charm, a chain of 12 luxury hotels and spas in Germany, Austria and Italy. Together fund the Mercator Foundation, which helps immigrant children in Germany improve their language and professional skills through  extracurricular study programs.

name: Billionaires
bio: Intrepid investor's fortune has swelled 190% in the past year on timely financial investments. Example: in early 2009 his Appaloosa hedge fund bought large chunk of Bank of America for $3 per share; these days BofA trades for more than $16.50 a share. Born in Pittsburgh, attended Carnegie Mellon business school. Headed junk bond desk at Goldman Sachs; left after being passed over for partner. Founded Appaloosa Management 1993. Firm has racked up 30% annual returns net of fees; main fund returned 132% last year after falling 26% in 2008. Other years with triple-digit gains: 1996 and 2003. Manages $12.5 billion in assets.
title: President and Founder
employment: {'name': 'Appaloosa Management', 'title': 'President and Founder', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of United Overseas Bank, the largest in Singapore, was educated in mainland China. Son Wee Ee Chong is now chief executive after Wee stepped down in 2007 after 33 years at helm; his father founded the bank in 1935. Family also owns large land bank in Singapore. Avid tennis player.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of carbide industrial cutting tool manufacturer, Iscar, sold out near top of market in 2006 to Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway, which paid $4 billion for an 80% stake; retains remaining stake with son Eitan as president. Through his four industrial parks Wertheimer seeds high-tech Israeli startups including Blades Technology, a maker of jet-engine blades. After fleeing Nazi Germany, the high school dropout joined the Palmach, the elite strike force of the Haganah, the pre-state defense organization. Former Israeli parliament member supports joint Israeli-Palestinian businesses. Investing $20 million to create first joint Jewish-Arab industrial park in Nazareth.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded windmill manufacturer Enercon in 1984; reportedly built its first wind turbine in his backyard. Trained engineer probably got his inspiration close to home; grew up in windy North Germany. In 1992 Enercon began producing non-polluting windmills without gears or hydraulics. The company is now world's fourth-largest windmill producer with a 10% market share and $4 billion in sales. It has 14,500 wind turbines in 30 countries. Enercon now expanding into water: investing in hydroelectric power plants and seawater desalination projects.

name: Billionaires
bio: Israel's richest woman inherited 2 of the country's largest companies: $75 billion (assets) Bank Hapoalim and infrastructure behemoth Housing & Construction. Stake in late father's cruise operator Carnival recovering from last year's steep drop in value. Launched Miya, a $100 million venture dedicated to reducing leaks in underground water pipes. Eccentric heiress published book outlining philosophy of connecting business with spirituality. Created controversy in Israel for speaking of "visions" and premonitions of global crisis and Hurricane Katrina.
title: Investor, Philanthropist

name: Billionaires
bio: Brothers control 19% of Bouygues Group, diversified industrial conglomerate founded by their father in 1952. Martin is chairman and chief executive; Olivier is deputy chief executive. $14.5 billion  (sales) company has interests in telecom, media, construction. Well-known projects have included the Hassan II mosque in Casablanca, Morocco; University of Riyadh in Saudi Arabia; English Channel Tunnel; the Kwun Tong viaduct in Hong Kong; motorways in Hungary and  Sydney  CityRail airport link. Martin, who celebrated 20 years as head of Bouygues last September,  is a close confident of French President Nicolas Sarkozy and godfather of the president's son.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded his first hospital in 1984. Named it Asklepios after Greek God of medicine. Now owns 111 hospitals with $3.3 billion in sales in 2009; employs 36,000 worldwide. While 96 are in Germany, also has hospitals in Portugal, Greece, Russia, Romania; has six in California in the U.S operated by Pacific Health Corp. Also has joint venture with Tongji University in China. Practiced as an accountant and lawyer before founding the hospital chain; has degree from Insead at Fontainbleau, France, and an MBA from Harvard University. Owns the Kempinski Hotel Falkenstein in Koenigstein, a five star luxury spa and hotel in the Taunus mountains near Frankfurt, Germany.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fujian native is founder of New Huadu group and also an active investor. Made bulk of his fortune through Hong Kong-listed Zijin Mining, one of China's biggest nonstate mining companies, with a focus on gold and base metals. New Huadu is also a major shareholder in a publicly traded retail chain. Turned day-to-day management over to former head of Shanda Interactive Tang Jun in 2008. Has since reduced his holding in Zijin, and bought stake in Tsingtao Brewery. Also invested $25 million in four IT companies in January.

name: Billionaires
bio: Blogging shareholder-activist who forced resignation of Japan Airlines president 4 years ago. Began buying into troubled carrier again last year after cutting his holding in favor of stake in broadcaster TV Tokyo. Not a good move as JAL filed for bankruptcy in January. Onetime lawmaker derives bulk of fortune from golf courses. Collector of expensive wines also an avid sailor; Itoyama claims to have circumnavigated the world three times in his 150-foot yacht. Maintains a trophy wall of snapshots on his Web site of him with kings, presidents and other global figures.

name: Billionaires
bio: Head of conglomerate Hong Leong Group Malaysia gets biggest part of fortune from stake in its investment holding company, Guoco Group. Has other interests in financial services, property development and hotels across Southeast Asia. Hong Leong Bank's offer to takeover Malaysian bank EON Capital, partially owned by billionaire Tiong Hiew King, rejected by board in February.  Upped shares in Hong Kong's third largest bank, Bank of East Asia through Hong Kong listed Guoco Group late last year.  Shares control of massive Hong Leong Group with Singaporean cousin, Kwek Leng Beng, and Kwek's family. Inherited fortune from his father, one of 3 brothers who started a small banking group in the 1920s.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former tax lawyer founded real estate developer Related Cos. 1972. Initially focused on building, financing low-income housing; branched into riskier luxury buildings in New York City. Net worth down $1.6 billion in past year as real estate market crumbles; still opened $500 million shopping center in the Bronx last summer. Opened offices in Shanghai and Abu Dhabi; planning to "reinvent" firm with developments in China, Middle East. Raised $1.1 billion with partners to acquire national commercial bank through SJB Bank. Completed $1 billion purchase of pro football's Miami Dolphins in last year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Statistician met at partner James Goodnight at North Carolina State. Cofounded SAS Institute 1976. Despite downturn, world's largest private software company saw record $2.31 billion revenues in 2009, up 2.2% from 2008 as clients relied on its business intelligence software to spot risks and profitable customers. Chief executive Goodnight kept his promise of no layoffs in 2009; company says it reinvested 23% of 2009 revenue in research and development. Cary-based firm known for worker-friendly policies; wellness programs, two on-site child care centers and free snacks. With Goodnight, owns tony Prestonwood Country Club and local private school Cary Academy.
title: Co-Founder, Executive Vice President
employment: {'name': 'SAS Institute', 'title': 'Co-Founder, Executive Vice President', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Former bank clerk; founded Public Bank in his mid-30s from profits made in a real estate deal. The bank is among the top three largest banking groups in Malaysia in terms of market value; employs 16,000 people. Has operations in China including Hong Kong, Cambodia, Vietnam, Laos and Sri Lanka. Cambodian Public Bank Plc claims to be the largest commercial bank in the country for its lending business. Teh underwent a minor surgery in 2009 and is back at work.

name: Billionaires
bio: Yang's wealth is up to $3.4 billion from $2.3 billion in the past year but still well below her 2007 net worth of $16.2 billion when she was China's richest person. Her fortune is tied up in her holding in Guangdong developer Country Garden, run by her father Yeung Kwok Keung, who transferred the shares to her before the firm's 2007 public offering. Ohio State grad is now apparently responsible for supervising the company's procurement and resource strategies. The company continued to expand its investments outside of Guangdong in January through a winning bid for a land plot in the central Chinese city of Wuhan.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partners and longtime friends Alexander Machkevich and Alijan Ibragimov (both billionaires) built a metals and mining empire in Kazakhstan. Stock of its London-listed Eurasian Natural Resources Corp. up 200% over the past year. Company is using cash pile for acquisitions in Africa: in September purchased Central African Mining & Exploration Co. (Camec) for nearly a billion, also reportedly in discussions to purchase assets of International Mining Corp., which is owned separately by the trio. Chodiev visited Mauritania in June to check out potential metals and mining projects. Uzbekistan native lived in Japan before teaming up with his pals in Kazakhstan.

name: Billionaires
bio: With brother William, runs Li & Fung, outsourcing firm that supplies fashions, furnishings and toys to retailers. Recently signed an agreement to act as buying agent for Walmart; also supplies to Target. Last year picked up Liz Clairborne's sourcing operations in Asia, became exclusive sourcing agent for Talbots; bought children's apparel maker Wear Me, footwear supplier Shubiz. William was named to Singapore Airlines board in January. Brothers own stakes in newly public luxury menswear retailer Trinity. Grandfather Fung Pakliu started the company a century ago with partner Li To-ming; duo sold porcelain, antiques. Father Fung Hon-chu ran it while brothers studied business in U.S.; they returned to take helm 1970s. William is managing director; Victor, a U.S. citizen, is chairman. Possible successor: Victor's son Spencer, an executive director.

name: Billionaires
bio: Largest individual shareholder of IT software maker CA (formerly Computer Associates). Sold data processing firm to University Computing 1968; that company bought by Computer Associates 1987. Today holds 24% stake in CA. Also owns Automobil-und Motoren AG (AMAG), Switzerland's main importer of Volkswagen, Seat, Skoda and Audi. His Moyglare Stud Farm in Ireland boasts 100 horses with names like Simple Exchange and Media Puzzle.

name: Billionaires
bio: Stepped down as chairman of Midea Group, one of China's biggest appliance makers last August, but remains largest shareholder. Company owns one-fourth of Wuxi Little Swan, known for its washing machines. Company is one of China's top advertisers. Bid to list Midea Group logistics company, Annto, on China's new small-enterprise board of the Shenzhen Stock Exchange last year turned down by regulators; speculation that it relied too much on its parent company for business.

name: Billionaires
bio: Seasoned developer has thrived in China's latest property market boom. Operating profit at his Shimao Property Holdings increased 36% in first half of 2009. Hot seller: units of Shanghai Riviera Garden's newest tower near city's Lujiazui financial district. Has been buying up land in hometown province of Fujian, where prices are rising on hopes for better relations with nearby Taiwan. Hui is active in business groups, serving as vice chairman of the China National Federation of Industry and Commerce, vice president of China Overseas Chinese Entrepreneurs Association, chairman of Shanghai Overseas Chinese Chamber of Commerce, and vice chairman of China Housing Industry Association. He is an honorary professor at Tong Ji University in Shanghai and also vice chairman of the Beijing University of Chemical Technology. Son Jason is heir apparent.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partners and longtime friends Alexander Machkevich and Patokh Chodiev (both billionaires) built a metals and mining empire in Kazakhstan; stock of its London-listed Eurasian Natural Resources Corp. up 200% over the past year. Company using cash pile for acquisitions in Africa: in September purchased Central African Mining & Exploration Co. (Camec) for nearly a billion, also reportedly  in discussions to purchase assets of International Mining Corp., which is owned separately by the trio. Native of Kyrgyzstan moved to Kazakhstan when the group decided to pursue business interests there. Devout Muslim has 6 sons.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partners and longtime friends Patokh Chodiev and Alijan Ibragimov (both billionaires) built a metals and mining empire in Kazakhstan; stock of its London-listed Eurasian Natural Resources Corp. is up 200% over the past year. Company using cash pile for acquisitions in Africa: in September purchased Central African Mining & Exploration Co. (Camec) for nearly a billion, also reportedly in discussions to purchase assets of International Mining Corp., which is owned separately by the trio. Machkevich is also promoting development of banking assets. Native of Kyrgyzstan studied literature; later moved to Moscow to start a trading business with Chodiev and Ibragimov. Early on obtained Israeli citizenship and has been very active in Jewish causes. Arts patron spent $20 million at a Damien Hirst auction at Sotheby's.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of hedge fund outfit Och-Ziff rebounded briskly; main fund up 23% last year after falling 16% in 2008. Wharton grad joined now famous investors Thomas Steyer, Richard Perry and Edward Lampert at Goldman Sachs in risk arbitrage department 1982. Founded Och-Ziff with $100 million in seed money from Ziff brothers 12 years later. Took firm public 2007; shares down 50% since. Assets under management: $24 billion. Vice chairman of Robin Hood Foundation.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Och-Ziff Capital Management Group', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Sold data processing firm Perot Systems to Dell last November for $3.9 billion. With billionaire son, legendary Texas magnate has lost a combined $1.3 billion in past 12 months. Last April debt woes reportedly forced family's real estate firm, Hillwood, to cede stake in high-profile Dallas development to German investment partners. Cotton broker's son served in Navy, salesman for IBM before founding Electronic Data Systems 1962. Sold to General Motors for $2.5 billion 22 years later. Used proceeds to fund two failed presidential bids; Perot Systems.

name: Billionaires
bio: Made first fortune with popular kids TV show Mighty Morphin Power Rangers. Sold majority stake in German broadcaster ProSiebenSat.1 to KKR and Permira for $4 billion in 2007. Later that year bought A. Jerrold Perenchio's Spanish-language outlet Univision for $13.7 billion with partners. Network settled long-running dispute with Televisa over program license agreements last year; six months later a judge ruled in favor of Univision's exclusive rights to broadcast wildly popular Spanish-language soap operas in the U.S. Network received exclusive Spanish-language television rights from FIFA to broadcast World Cup soccer in US and Puerto Rico in 2010 and 2014. With partners reportedly selling controlling stake in Israeli telecom company Bezeq to Israeli businessman Shaul Elovitch. Paid $250 million in back taxes and penalties after his former lawyer allegedly placed $1.5 billion of his funds in an illegal tax shelter. Senate report deemed Saban a victim, lawyer pled guilty in December 2009. Saban now suing him for $36 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Inveterate deal-maker dialing up pressure on bookseller Barnes & Noble. Sent letter to company's top execs in late January seeking 37% stake, condemning board's adoption of anti-takeover measures that bar him from upping his ownership. Company's response: "acceding to your request would not be in the best interests of all Barnes & Noble's shareholders." Grocer's son joined union local as box boy at age 13. Formed investment firm Yucaipa 1986. Made fortune buying and selling supermarket chains Fred Meyer, Jurgensen's, Ralphs. Hired Bill Clinton as advisor 2001; Clinton left a couple years ago to stump for wife, Hillary.
title: Founder
employment: {'name': 'The Yucaipa Companies, LLC', 'title': 'Founder', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Low-key Chen moved to Hong Kong from China in 1949 after the end of the civil war on the mainland. He set up cotton-yard maker Nan Fung Mill in 1954, marking his rise as a major yarn supplier in the British colony for decades. Reached a major turning point in 1976, making his first overseas investments in the U.S., Singapore and Malaysia.  Nan Fung is now a property developer, with interests also in shipping. Partnering with HSBC to invest in property in China; the 2 recently formed venture with U.K's Tesco to invest in malls. Chen owns minority stake in Sino Land. His foundation provides philanthropic support in the fields of medicine, education and welfare, as well as for the promotion of Buddhism.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded temporary employment agency Randstad Holding in 1960. Took company public in 1990. Randstad merged with Dutch group Vedior in 2008 to form world's second-largest temp agency with combined revenues of more than $24 billion. Although retired, Goldschmeding remains vice chairman of the supervisory board and still owns 44%. Enjoys sailing.

name: Billionaires
bio: Memphis native studied economics at U. of Virginia. Made first fortune trading cotton on Wall Street. Launched Tudor Investment Corp.1980. Anticipated 1987 market crash, returned 125% net of fees that year. His BVI Global fund lost 4% in 2008, up 16.5% last year. Assets under management: $10 billion. Hunts, fishes on estate in Zimbabwe. Founder of New York's poverty-fighting Robin Hood Foundation.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Inherited chunk of Walmart stock after father James (Bud) Walton died 1995. Shares up 7% in last 12 months. Married to E. Stanley Kroenke, owner of pro basketball's Denver Nuggets, hockey's Colorado Avalanche, plus stakes in football's St. Louis Rams and English soccer titan Arsenal.

name: Billionaires
bio: Took his aluminum products maker, China Zhongwang, public on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange in May in one of last year's biggest IPOs. The company has faced accounting controversy since, at one point asking Ernst & Young to clarify statements in its prospectus about reported customer orders. Business continues: in early February the company said it would acquire western Chinese aluminum alloy maker Qinghai Guoxin Aluminum for $175 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Small-town jute trader, he founded and chairs GMR Group, infrastructure player headquartered in Bangalore. His GMR Infrastructure built a new airport at Hyderabad and has constructed a new terminal in Delhi, due to open in July, ahead of the Commonwealth Games to be held in October. Canceled a $500 million placement in July following a tepid response from investors. Its profits fell 85% in latest quarter. A new GMR-built terminal at Istanbul's Sabiha Gokcen International airport was opened by Turkey's prime minister last October. Also owns 50% of InterGen, a Dutch utility from which it bought Island Power, a private power producer in Singapore. Is looking to raise money for power generation arm GMR Energy.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former butcher's apprentice owns and runs $10.3 billion (sales) Anton Schlecker drugstore chain; group's 14,000 locations account for 70% of Germany's drugstores. Has 3,000 stores in Austria, Holland, Denmark, Spain, France, Italy, Portugal and Eastern Europe. Faced with increased competition at home, company has started its own drug mail order and wholesale businesses.  Wife Christa and children Lars and Meike help run the business. Soccer fan. Enjoys sport cars, apparently owns a Ferrari, Aston Martin, Porsche and Jaguar

name: Billionaires
bio: Brothers made a killing selling their 34% stake in generics maker Ranbaxy Laboratories to Japan's Daiichi Sankyo for $2 billion in 2008. Older brother Malvinder continued as chairman and chief executive for several months but stepped down last May, ending family's 48-year reign at company founded by their grandfather. Cash-rich brothers are expanding their interests in health care and financial services. Their hospital chain Fortis Healthcare, looked after by Shivinder, struck deal to buy 10 hospitals for $196 million from beleaguered pharma tycoon Habil Khorakiwala. Financial arm Religare Enterprises recently struck deal to acquire private equity fund Northgate Capital in California for an estimated $200 million. Brothers are scouting for a new partner in health insurance after proposed joint venture with Swiss Re fell through

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairs financial services firm, Ursalib. Former air force lieutenant colonel and a veteran of the Afghan war; met Leonid Fedun, also a former military officer, who was a privatization consultant for Lukoil. After setting up Nikoil (later renamed Uralsib) in partnership with other top Lukoil managers such as Vagit Alekperov, Tsvetkov helped them gain a controlling stake in the oil company; for his services was rewarded with a sizable Lukoil stake. Still sits on the oil firm's board but has since sold most of the stake; retains less than 1%. Owns legendary Lomonosov Porcelain, to which he returned its original name, Imperial Porcelain Manufacture. Passionate about Eastern philosophy and yoga.

name: Billionaires
bio: Beekeeper's son now one of Asia's biggest philanthropists and most innovative investors. Made first fortune when he and brother Christopher, also a billionaire, invested proceeds from selling parents' retailing business in Hong Kong real estate. Together founded investment firm Sovereign Global, focusing on transitioning economies in Russia, Latin America, Asia and eastern Europe. Brothers amicably parted ways in 2006. Richard founded Orient Global in Singapore, continuing his focus on value investments in emerging markets with emphasis on social returns. In 2009 started buying up shares of Russian bank Sberbank; now holds 4.8%. Also invests in India where he owns 9.5% of Axis Bank. Recently set up $100 million fund aimed at improving education in the developing world, beginning with India. Lent artist mother a reported $4 million to open Manhattan gallery for her paintings.

name: Billionaires
bio: Apparently met Helmut Horten, founder of eponymous German department store chain, in a hotel bar in 1959 when she was 19. Despite 30-year age difference, they wed 7 years later. He died in 1987 and left her an estimated $1 billion fortune. Austria's merry widow now divides her time between a penthouse in Vienna, a residence in Tessin, Switzerland, and a home in Lyford Cay in the Bahamas. Owns one of world's largest yachts, the 315-foot Carinthia VII. Rumored to have sold a 35.5 carat diamond, once part of the crown of Bavaria, for $24 million at Christie's auction in December 2008. Said to enjoy hunting and collecting art.

name: Billionaires
bio: Casino titan betting all of his chips on $8.5 billion City Center gambling paradise, which opened in December. Most expensive privately funded project in U.S. history lords over Sin City with 3 hotels, casino. Yet-to-be finished: residential tower, another hotel. MGM stock has tripled in past year as default fears have eased. Eighth-grade dropout trained fighter pilots during WWII. Flew surplus Air Force planes across Atlantic after war before building charter flights company Trans International Airlines; sold for $104 million profit 1966. Went Hollywood: bought, sold MGM movie studio 3 times between 1986 and 1996. Bought Steve Wynn's Mirage Resorts for $6.4 billion 2000, then Mandalay Bay Resorts for $7.9 billion 4 years later.

name: Billionaires
bio: Vice chairman of BYD, cofounded auto and battery maker with his cousin Wang Chuanfu, also a billionaire. Worked as a banker for 14 years prior to that and now runs his own investment company, Guangzhou Rongjie Investment, as well.

name: Billionaires
bio: Construction worker's son worked at first U.S. computer magazine, Computers & Automation, while studying at MIT. Founded International Data Group 1964; began publishing Computerworld 3 years later. Company now runs more than 300 magazines, 750 trade shows, 450 Web sites. Media brands available in 90 countries. Sales in 2008: $3.2 billion. Company's venture capital firm IDGVC manages $2.6 billion in China. Funds brain research through MIT's McGovern Institute.
title: Founder and Chairman
employment: {'name': 'International Data Group', 'title': 'Founder and Chairman', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Made headlines in the art world this year: announced $100,000 prize for artists under age 35 to be awarded every two years and was appointed to the board of Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles. Sixth year hobnobbing at Davos. Despite glitzy lifestyle, his pipemaker Interpipe is struggling. Fitch downgraded the company's debt to restricted default over concerns of meeting its $900 million of total debt, nearly half secured by company assets and future sales. Sold his Ukrsotsbank in 2008 at top of the market to Italy's UniCredit Group for $2.2 billion. Reportedly paid Britain's former prime minister Tony Blair to give a speech in Ukraine, which was seen as encouraging Blair, who is up for European Union president, to support Ukraine's ascension into the EU. Son-in-law of ex-president Leonid Kuchma used his Ph.D. in pipe design to found Interpipe in 1990.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founding patriarch of Egypt's most famous business dynasty; remains chairman. Shares in primary holding, Orascom Construction Industries, have doubled over the past year as projects have picked up. In January announced joint venture with investment bank, Morgan Stanley, to invest in infrastructure assets in the Middle East and Africa. His 3 sons run construction, telecommunications and tourism divisions. Studied agriculture in college after lawyer father urged him to pursue farming. Found it boring, instead opened a small contracting firm in Upper Egypt. Construction baron forced to rebuild empire after it was nationalized in 1960s.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of Keyence, leading supplier of sensors and measuring instruments to small-factory owners, midsize companies looking to automate production. Outsources production to avoid cost of investing in manufacturing plant. Bought stake in software maker JustSystems last year. Headquarters in an ultramodern high-rise in Osaka, western Japan, featuring displays of dinosaur fossils (supposedly to convey tacit message to employees to keep aiming high or become a fossil). Takizaki attracts engineers with above-average pay but bans personal items such as photographs from employees' work spaces.

name: Billionaires
bio: Made his fortune selling fashion to the Chinese masses. His trendy retailer, Metersbonwe, targets the 18-to-25-year-old set, hires pop stars as spokespeople and launches 3,000 designs in a year. Opened first store in 1995; now has nearly 3,000 stores. Launched second store brand, Me & City, in 2008 to appeal to older crowd; now approaching 100 outlets. Former tailor sold first handmade pieces. Set up his own textile factory at age 17. Zhou and his daughter still own 90% of the company. In December, Metersbonwe set up an investment fund with Xian International Trust and China Bingqi Zhuangbei Group, a military-connected business. His Metersbonwe Costume Museum in 2005; contains more than 8,000 pieces from the Ming Dynasty up to 1930s Shanghai.

name: Billionaires
bio: Heir to engineering giant Bechtel Corp., firm that built the Hoover Dam, Chunnel. Sales in 2008: $31.4 billion. Riley, father Stephen each believed to own 20% of the company; Riley now runs the show. New projects include a solar thermal power plant in California, a 21-kilometer tunnel for London's new railway and a multibillion liquefied natural gas facility in Australia. Reportedly member of San Francisco's exclusive all-male Bohemian Club, whose fellows are thought to include every Republican President since Herbert Hoover.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Bechtel Corp.', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Heir to engineering giant Bechtel Corp., firm that built the Hoover Dam, Chunnel. Sales in 2008: $31.4 billion. Stephen became Bechtel president at age 35, chairman 13 years later. Believed to own 20% of the company. New projects include a solar thermal power plant in California, a 21-kilometer tunnel for London's new railway and a multibillion liquefied natural gas facility in Australia. Reportedly member of San Francisco's exclusive all-male Bohemian Club, whose fellows are thought to include every Republican President since Herbert Hoover.
title: Former Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Hailed as one of Brazil's greatest businessmen of the last decade for masterminding the marriage of giant retailer Pao de Acucar to Casas Bahia in December, resulting in the country's biggest private employer. Reportedly plans to take e-commerce and electronics subsidiaries public this year. In 1989 was kidnapped by Canadian terrorists who held him captive in underground cells for 7 days until the federal police set him free. At 73 remains a fitness fanatic, exercises several hours a day, has run multiple marathons.

name: Billionaires
bio: Revered voice among Brazilian business chairs family-owned conglomerate Grupo Votorantim, whose activities span steel, finance, farming, chemicals, cement and pulp and paper. Latter business went public last year after merging with Aracruz into a $3.2 billion (sales) company called Fibria. Cement business will likely surge as Brazil's infrastructure sector takes off in preparation for 2014 World Cup and 2016 Olympics. Antonio pens a weekly column for Sao Paulo newspaper Folha de Sao Paulo. Grupo Votorantim was founded in 1918 by Antonio's father, senator Jose Ermirio de Moraes. Group is divided among three siblings.

name: Billionaires
bio: One of the richest men in health care could be on the verge of taking hospital giant HCA public for the third time. Former Air Force flight surgeon founded Hospital Corp. of America with father and Jack Massey 1968; public offering the following year. Led management buyout 1989; took public again 3 years later. Took private again with Bain Capital, KKR and Merrill Lynch in 2006 in $33 billion leveraged buyout. Now analysts speculating that the nation's largest hospital operator will go public to take advantage of impending Obamacare.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of poor preacher worked at local 5-and-10 store in high school, opened first arts and crafts outfit Hobby Lobby with $600 loan 1970. Today sales of $2 billion. Company has no long-term debt. Keeps expenses low by shipping to stores in 36 states from one warehouse. Believes the way to good business is to follow biblical principles: "He is the only one who knows the future." Plays Christian music in stores. Has delivered over 440 million copies of the Gospel to children in 100 countries through Book of Hope ministry.
title: CEO

name: Billionaires
bio: Oldest son of slain Lebanese prime minister Rafiq Hariri runs his real estate and private banking business from Geneva. Sold stake he inherited in family construction empire, Saudi Oger, to younger brother and fellow billionaire Saad in January 2008. Derives the bulk of his fortune from investments.  Also real estate: his Horizon Development  focuses on commercial projects in Jordan and Lebanon; it is also a major shareholder in the Abdali Investment and Development Company, a 20-million-square-foot mixed-use revitalization project in downtown Amman. Dual citizen of Switzerland and Saudi Arabia.

name: Billionaires
bio: Youngest son of Texas wildcatter H.L. Hunt (d. 1974), who was said to be the inspiration for J.R. Ewing character on TV's Dallas. Family sold Hunt Petroleum to XTO for $4.4 billion in 2007; personal holdings not included. Sees future in natural gas: massive plant in Yemen almost complete, another planned in Peru. Cattle rancher's real estate holdings include Hyatt Hotels, commercial property around Dallas.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sunglasses maven hawked motorcycle grips from car trunk 1975. Moved to eyewear 1983; built brand enticing hotshot athletes to sport his trendy Oakley sunglasses. Took "The O" public 1995. Focused on cutting-edge optics technology; some Oakley glasses can withstand a shotgun blast. Sold company to Italian rival Luxottica for $2.1 billion in 2007. Today spends time focused on Red Digital HD camera company. Outfit the first to offer "affordable" high-definition digital cinema cameras to the masses; Red One camera sells for $17,500. Cameras used on movie sets by A-list directors, including Peter Jackson (Lord of the Rings), Steven Soderbergh (Ocean's Eleven).

name: Billionaires
bio: Polish immigrant married Johnson & Johnson heir John Seward Johnson 1971; inherited 36 million J&J shares when he died in 1983. Stock up 30% in the last 12 months; stake now worth $2.25 billion. Collects Renaissance, baroque art; raked in $33 million in December, selling Rembrandt piece to Steve Wynn. Dumping money into building Children's Bay Cay, a private island residential complex in the Bahamas.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, James, founded specialist firm that became Spear, Leeds & Kellogg. New Jersey native went to work at dad's firm early 1970s; turned outfit into dominant marketmaker. Spear Leeds was first specialist to control more than 10% of stocks trading on Big Board 1992. Engineered sale to Goldman Sachs for $6.5 billion 2000. Plowed proceeds into reinsurance outfit IAT. Firm owns large stakes in TRC (environmental engineering). Sold stake in consumer products-maker Chattem, famous for Selsun Blue shampoo and Gold Bond powder, to French drugmaker Sanofi-Aventis in December.

name: Billionaires
bio: One of 4 sons of Fred Koch, who invented method of refining  gasoline from heavy oil. Expanded oil industry in U.S.S.R. 1930s; returned home before WWII. Founded Koch Industries, passed to sons after death in 1967. With brother Frederick, sold stake to brothers Charles and David for $1.3 billion in 1983. Sued for more, case settled 2001. Created energy conglomerate Oxbow; produces calcined petroleum coke, coal, steel, natural gas. Sales: $4.5 billion. Art and wine enthusiast suing collectors and auction house for selling him counterfeit vino; paid $500,000 for 4 bottles alleged to have belonged to Thomas Jefferson. Sailor; won the America's Cup in 1992.

name: Billionaires
bio: Porcelain prince's fortune down $1 billion in 2 years. Grandfather started company 1873; now third generation is at the helm of faucet, cabinet, plumbing, toilet empire. Estimated sales: $5.5 billion. Real estate holdings include golf courses, spas, renowned Old Course Hotel at St. Andrews, Scotland. Breeds Morgan show horses.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Kohler Co.', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Onetime partner of Goldman Sachs, derives fortune from 48% stake in Kotak Mahindra Bank, which he started in 1985 as a small finance firm, with the backing of tractor tycoon Anand Mahindra who lent his name to firm. Bank has 17 million customers and is a leading player in wealth and asset management services. Also has a life insurance joint venture with Old Mutual. Family is biggest shareholder in Business Standard, a daily financial newspaper. He's set up the Kotak Education Foundation, family's private trust that focuses on educating poor children in and around Mumbai.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of ESL Investments flush from Sears rally, auto gains; shares of AutoZone, AutoNation up 45% and 15%, respectively, since beginning of 2008 while S&P 500 has fallen 25%. His largest investment--Sears Holdings--has surged 160% in past 12 months. Lawyer's son read corporate reports, financial textbooks in high school. Skull & Bones at Yale. Learned along side billionaire investor Daniel Och in risk arbitrage department at Goldman Sachs. Went solo 1988. Acquired Kmart in bankruptcy by buying its bonds. Merged with Sears, Roebuck; has served as chairman of combined company since 2005.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former lawyer borrowed $300 from wife to start real estate developer Lerner Enterprises in 1952. Made fortune building massive shopping malls in the suburbs of Washington, D.C.: Tysons Corner, Tysons II, Wheaton Plaza, Landover Mall, Dulles Town Center, White Flint. Today owns 20 million square feet of commercial, retail space and 7,000 apartments. Also owns stake in NYC's Chelsea Piers. Moved headquarters to a new 'green' building in Maryland last October. Owns pro baseball's Washington Nationals and small stake in regional broadcaster Mid-Atlantic Sports Network.

name: Billionaires
bio: Nicknamed The Boxer in part because his name recalls that of legendary heavyweight fighter Joe Louis but also because of dealmaking style.  Won battle to replace chairman at pub operator Mitchells & Butler, in which he has a 23% stake. Also the real estate developer behind Isleworth, the swank Orlando community that was the site of Tiger Wood's car accident last November. Lewis, who also owns a house in the community, is friends with Woods, with whom he is developing a Bahamas golf community called Albany. Has stakes in dozens of companies, through his Tavistock Group. Owns British soccer team Tottenham Hotspur (Spurs) Football Club. Art collection includes works by Francis Bacon and Lucian Freud. Born above a pub in London's East End, helped his family build a catering business. Sold it and became a currency trader. Some reports claim he made more on collapse of sterling on Black Wednesday in 1992 than George Soros. Still active trader.

name: Billionaires
bio: Darth Vader is now musical theater; Star Wars: In Concert touring America. Still a retail force; total merchandise receipts from franchise since 1977: $17.5 billion. Studied film at U. of Southern California. Founded Industrial Light & Magic in 1975 to create effects for original Star Wars film; now Hollywood's most bankable special effects shop. Executive produced fourth installment of the Indiana Jones franchise in 2008; despite tepid reviews, film grossed $782 million in worldwide box office.
title: Director/Producer

name: Billionaires
bio: Harvard business school graduate pursued banking career; founded Turkish bank Finansbank in 1987. Sold 46% of the entity to National Bank of Greece for $2.76 billion in 2006 and remaining 9% stake for $700 million in 2008. He later agreed to buy Banco Comercial Portugues SA's Turkish unit, in a return to the country's banking industry. Ozyegin will buy a 95 percent stake in Millennium Bank AS for $85 million, according to a recent regulatory filing. Retail businesses expanding with new Gap and Banana Republic franchises in Russia. His private Ozyegin University enrolled its first students fall 2008. Paid for four high risk schools to be strengthened and made earthquake-resistant.

name: Billionaires
bio: Lotti, as she is known to her friends, is second largest shareholder of trendy apparel retailer Hennes & Mauritz, founded by her father Erling Persson in 1947.   The biggest shareholder is brother Stefan who has run the company since 1982. Nephew Karl-Johan Persson became its chief executive last summer.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, Al, founded freight company with one truck 1935, grew rapidly through acquisitions, expanding into interstate shipping. Donald became president of Schneider National 1976, complemented father's eighth-grade education with Wharton M.B.A. Pioneered use of satellite tracking technology, transportation logistics. Today company's fleet is largest truckload carrier in North America. Continues to expand internationally: growth in China said to be helping offset freight shortcomings in U.S.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former economics student traded shrimp as a teenager, then switched to palm oil. Bought his first plantation in 1994. Later cofounded agribusiness Wilmar International with nephew of Malaysia's richest man, Robert Kuok. Merged Wilmar with the senior Kuok's plantation and agribusiness group in June 2007, turning Wilmar into one of the world's largest palm oil producers and largest cooking oil producers in Asia. Wilmar's chief operating officer, he still holds 10% of company shares. The stock has more than doubled in the past year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Film school reject's third movie, "Jaws," started unmatched string of blockbusters ("E.T.," "Jurassic Park") and dramas ("Schindler's List," "Saving Private Ryan"). Fourth installment of Indiana Jones franchise grossed $786 million worldwide; sas so confident that he didn't take his cut of the profits until the movie had made $400 million. In June his Dreamworks SKG stuck $1.5 billion agreement to start new film company with India's Reliance ADA Group; left Universal last February and signed distributing deal with Walt Disney Studios.
title: Director/Producer

name: Billionaires
bio: Uncle W.R. (Witt) founded Stephens Inc. 1933 with $15,000 in borrowed money. Father, Jackson (d. 2005), joined 1946; brothers paid $5.4 million for Arkansas-Oklahoma Gas 1954. Hefty gas dividends helped fuel financial empire. Jack became president 1957. Firm famously underwrote Walmart's public offering 1970. Warren became chief executive 1986; acquired 100% of Stephens Inc. in 2006. Enjoys golf, boasts 11 handicap.

name: Billionaires
bio: Born in China to Russian parents, drove taxis in Sydney before getting into construction in 1960s. Now focuses on building apartments in Sydney and Brisbane. During early 1990s global property boom curtailed expansion and suffered relatively minor damage during commercial property bust. His Meriton Apartments has no debt and has been buying up sites at bargain prices.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairs Dalian Wanda Group, one of Asia's largest property developers with more than seven million square meters of leased commercial real estate. Has 50 movie theaters; plans to open another 21 this year to become one of the largest in Asia with 700 screens. Also owns 8 five-star hotels. Active in politics as a deputy to the 17th Party Congress and a member of the National Committee of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference. He's also a vice chairman of the All-China Federation of Industry and Commerce.

name: Billionaires
bio: Powerful wife of Moscow Mayor Yuri Luzhkov started out as a factory worker, then entered the Moscow Institute of Management. Met Luzhkov in 1987 when they were both serving on the Mosgorispolcom, a Soviet-era municipal commission. In 1991 started plastic-products company Inteko, which produced furniture and crockery but has since expanded into construction and construction materials. Though Inteko had to freeze contruction on several expensive real-estate projects in Moscow as result of 2008 financial crisis; her newly formed company, Patriot, is focusing on affordable housing. Helped restore the gigantic monument, Worker and Collective Farmer, reinstalled in November 2009, at a cost of $100 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: The 8th Earl of Cadogan heads his family's 300-year-old real estate trust, which owns 90 acres in London's Chelsea. The posh neighborhood is home to luxury retailers like Jimmy Choo and Fendi as well as high-end restaurants; all hit by the recession. Meddlesome landlord not renewing lease of longtime tenant Oriel restaurant after his meal there proved sub-par and overpriced. Began his career at merchant banker Schroder Wagg. Took on the management of family's property portfolio in 1974.

name: Billionaires
bio: Opened a wholesale business that sold perfume and beauty supplies in 1994 in his southern hometown of Krasnodar. An admirer of Walmart, in 1998 established Magnit, a chain of grocery stores with the slogan "Always Low Prices." Took the company public in April 2006. Billion dollar expansion plans hampered by new Russian law that states retailers with a market share of 25% or greater are restricted from opening new stores in the same areas.
