Has said law is "a literal ban on the [retailing] business." As a child dreamed of becoming professional football player; in 2008 established the Krasnodar football team. Ferrari lover.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sentenced in February to 11 years and 8 months in jail and fined $300 million for embezzlement; Karamehmet, who is not in custody, has the right to appeal. Case is related to use of loans at Pamubank AS, a lender he owned until regulators seized it in 2002. Had to sell his second bank Yapi Kredi to Koc Group due to financial difficulties the next year. Fell out of billionaire ranks in 2003 but returned three years later, bolstered by interest in Turkcell, nation's largest mobile phone company of which he is chairman. Turkcell is only Turkish company to trade on the New York Stock Exchange. His holding group Cukorova also has interest in Genel Energy, which started exporting oil from northern Iraq in April 2009. Founded first trading firm at age 22.

name: Billionaires
bio: Made first fortune developing commercial and retail properties. Later sports: owns pro basketball's Denver Nuggets, hockey's Colorado Avalanche, plus stakes in football's St. Louis Rams, English soccer titan Arsenal; reportedly battling Russian oligarch Alisher Usmanov for control over the soccer club. Married to Ann Walton Kroenke, who inherited chunk of Walmart stock after father James (Bud) Walton died 1995.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder and Chairman of Quanta Computer, one of the world's largest manufacturers of notebook computer. Key customer: HP. Slipped to no. 2 in world in first quarter as Taiwan rival Compal surpassed Quanta in terms of shipments.  Working with MIT to come up with technology related to cloud computing.  Also active in art: a director of Cloud Gate Theatre Group and chairman of Quanta Culture & Education Foundation, which supports culture and arts.

name: Billionaires
bio: Television king of southern India where his Sun TV Network rules. He owns 77% of what is the country's biggest regional broadcaster with 20 television channels and 46 FM radio stations. Interests include Sun Direct, a direct to home television service, co-owned by Malaysian billionaire Ananda Krishnan's Astro Group, which has 4.5 million subscribers. His Sun Pictures, a film production outfit, is shooting a big-budget movie with a well-known cast, billed as India's most expensive movie-to-date. Is mulling expansion into aviation. His fortune on the rise after patch up with his powerful granduncle M.Karunanidhi, chief minister of the southern state of Tamil Nadu with whom his family had a bitter falling out. Following the rapprochement, his politician brother Dayanidhi, who was forced to resign as communications and IT minister, was reinstalled as minister for textiles after last May's federal elections.

name: Billionaires
bio: Stock in Russia's largest pipe maker up nearly threefold since lows last March, enabling the industrialist to justify the billions spent buying factories in the U.S. in 2008. Like many native sons of the Urals region, started out as a trader. Graduated from the Urals Polytechnic Institute with a concentration in metallurgy. Throughout the 1990s ran a variety of metals plants in the Urals. In 1998 ran the sales division of the Sinarsky Pipe Factory and soon became its main owner. Two years later Sinarsky became part of pipe conglomerate TMK, assembled by MDM Group founders Sergei Popov and Andrei Melnichenko. Pumpyansky became chief executive and acquired a 35% stake in the company, which controlled 3 major pipe plants and later acquired a fourth despite fierce competition from Mikhail Fridman's Alfa Group. In October 2006 bought out Melnichenko and Popov; listed TMK on the London Stock Exchange, raising $1 billion.

name: Billionaires
bio: Retailer's fortune up $600 million; Best Buy rebounded nearly 50% in last year. Sold electronics for father's company; opened car stereo shop 1966. Set up superstore model to lure customers, fatten margins; let customers touch, play with products. Renamed Best Buy 1983; took public 2 years later. Sales now top $45 billion. Appointed former sales clerk Brian Dunn chief executive in June.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of a Bangkok street vendor of fried mussel pancakes made his fortune selling inexpensive beer and whiskey. Took his Thai Bev, Thailand's largest brewer and distiller, public in Singapore in 2006 after mostly Buddhist protesters stopped the listing on Thailand's stock exchange. Recently rebranded popular, inexpensive Chang beer to attract broader customer base. His privately held TCC Land owns Bangkok's famous tech-mall Pantip Plaza, Hotel Plaza Athenee in Manhattan. Also owns other hotels in Asia, the U.S. and Australia, residential, commercial and retail buildings in Singapore and Thailand.

name: Billionaires
bio: U. of Santa Clara student began career selling residential property; later moved into commercial real estate. Today Sobrato Development owns and manages 7.7 million square feet of commercial office space, 7,600 residential units, 350 vacant acres in Silicon Valley. Largest clients: Yahoo, Nvidia. Has donated more than $300 million of office space in past 3 years, including $135 million building in San Jose to Silicon Valley Community Foundation.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Beanie Babies billionaire sold first line of stuffed animals 1986; Beanies collecting frenzy began in 1993. Popularity waned; Ty Inc. now focused on toys that allow for online interaction, including Ty Girlz and Beanie Babies 2.0. Real estate portfolio includes slew of high-end hotels and resorts. New York City Four Seasons Hotel home to the Ty Warner Penthouse Suite, the most expensive suite in the U.S.; currently renegotiating mortgage. Reopened the Coral Casino Beach & Cabana Club in Montecito, Calif. in 2008 after a 3-year, $65 million renovation. Announced $40 million renovation of Montecito Country Club to create Jack Nicklaus-designed golf course.

name: Billionaires
bio: His $2.5 billion (revenues) Essel group owns TV broadcaster Zee Entertainment, run by his eldest son, Punit. Has recently hived off its education business into a separate unit, Zee Learn. Other TV interests include Zee News and Veria, a wellness channel in the US. His Dish TV is the country's largest direct to home service with 6.5 million  subscribers. Group also owns stake in moneylosing Diligent Media, which publishes the Daily News & Analysis, rival to the market leader Times of India, owned by Indu Jain's, Bennett, Coleman & Co. Reportedly planning to build a Bollywood theme park in suburban Mumbai. Also owns a cricket league. Won industry award in November; reportedly said at ceremony that he would like to step down in 2 years to do socially meaningful things rather than make money.

name: Billionaires
bio: Press-shy money man issued rare press release in December announcing $705 million commitment to "medical research, education and the fight against poverty." Philanthropic sum includes $100 million for new neuroscience institute at NYU Langone Medical Center. Bowdoin U. grad ditched Ph.D. in economics, found work as oil analyst at Pittsburgh National Bank. Launched Duquesne Capital Management 1981 with $1 million. Hired by George Soros 7 years later. Duo said to have made $1 billion in single day "breaking" British pound 1992. Went solo 2000. Today Duquesne manages an estimated $10 billion.

name: Billionaires
bio:
Chief executive of Evraz Group; partner and fellow billionaire Alexander Abramov
is chairman. Struggled with $10 billion debt burden: consolidated factories in the Urals and Siberia and refinanced Evraz's debts with state-owned banks. Evraz stock price up nearly threefold. Also invests in Highlands Gold Mining, and Russia's electricity infrastructure. Got start working as research fellow at the I.V. Kurchatov Institute of Atomic Energy. Has a Ph.D. in physics and mathematics.

name: Billionaires
bio: Turned his father's dust removal business into thermal engineering firm GEA. Decade ago, sold his stake in GEA to MG Technologies for $1 billion in cash and 21% interest in combined group. Cashed out rest In March 2006 selling stake to various institutional investors for approximately $630 million.   Lives in  Switzerland his wife and six children. Enthusiastic sailor, has a yacht named Hetairos. Owner of a luxury resort, Fregate Island, in the Seychelles.

name: Billionaires
bio: College dropout drove a taxi in London before moving to Bahrain and taking over his deceased parents' baby products shop in 1973. Expanded single store into retail empire spanning 15 countries across Middle East and India. Beyond baby goods: $2.5 billion (sales) Landmark has since diversified into fashion, hospitality, shoes, furniture and electronics. Foothold in middle market helped group shelter itself against worst of retail downturn; sales up 20% despite slumping Gulf economy. Also owns stakes in Saks, Debenhams and U.K. restaurant chain Carluccio's. Donates to Indian poor through Chennai charity, Landmark International Foundation for Empowerment (Life).

name: Billionaires
bio: Matriarch chairs privately held media conglomerate Bennett, Coleman & Co. Its holdings include The Times of India, a daily newspaper and The Economic Times, a business daily; television channels Times Now, Zoom and ET Now; FM radio network Radio Mirchi and digital media unit Times Internet. Times Private Treaties, group's private equity arm, barters ad space for equity. Has recently partnered with Pakistan's Jang group for an Indo-Pak peace project that seeks to promote cultural ties between the two countries.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father Antonio founded tour outfit Globus in 1928 with a single boat that ferried tourists around Lake Lugano. Today Sergio controls family's tour and travel empire. Says he doesn't invest in equity markets; bulk of wealth tied up in low-risk bonds, minimizing damage wrought by global recession. Empire includes several charter airline businesses. Travels via helicopter, private jet, yacht ("Lady Marina"); owns $600,000 Mercedes Maybach.

name: Billionaires
bio: His family's firm got started in 1903 with asbestos reinforced cement; though the company Schmidheiny inherited, Eternit, got out of the asbestos business, consequences continuing  In December asbestos trial began in Turin, Italy involving allegations of negligence at four Italian asbestos-cement plants which prosecutors say caused deaths of around 2,000 workers and local residents. Schmidheiny denies the charges. Began running family business at age 29, installing filters in Eternit factories; training workers and moving company away from asbestos long before it was a banned substance. Eventually invested in forestry firm Gruponueva and other multinationals. In 2003 donated all of the shares of GrupoNueva, worth $1 billion, to his Viva Trust, whose profits are then used to promote causes like sustainability and education (his Avina Foundation has made $400 million in grants to date). Much of his personal wealth is now held in a diversified portfolio of stocks, bonds and private equity investments and is handled by professional managers. Art collector favors contemporary painters. Brother Thomas, also a billionaire, got cement firm Holcim, and bought out cement interests from Stephan in 1989.

name: Billionaires
bio: Studied at Chinese Culture University in Taiwan 1969, immigrated to U.S. 1971. Took over as manager of Thrifty Drug Store in Los Angeles; earned M.B.A. from Southeastern Louisiana 1973. Started Golden Eagle 1992; public on Hong Kong Stock Exchange 2006. Owns 70% of stock. Company owns, operates 16 stores.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, James (Bud) Walton, ran handful of small 5-and-10 stores in Arkansas and Missouri with brother Sam. Duo built first Walmart 1962. With sister Ann Walton Kroenke, inherited chunk of retailer's stock after Bud's death 1995. Shares worth nearly $2.5 billion today. Bought pro hockey's St. Louis Blues in 1999 with husband, Bill; sold 6 years later. Founded Cedar Lake Contemporary Ballet in New York 2003. Owns Providence Bank, commercial real estate, shopping centers.

name: Billionaires
bio: In late 1980s, acquired over 100-year-old  Knorr-Bremse AG and transformed it into world's leading manufacturer of braking systems for rail and commercial vehicles. Saw sales drop 18% in 2009 to $3.9 billion as a result of the global recession. Group is a big player in China where it has five joint ventures and its own production plant; last year won a $680 million contact to equip the Chinese CRH3 high-speed train with braking and door systems. Chairman of supervisory  board; said to  enjoy hiking, skiing and animal photography.  Has received various awards for his philanthropic contributions including his support of children cancer research and his aid to underdeveloped countries.

name: Billionaires
bio: With sister-in-law Wilma controls family fortune built by their late husbands, investors Preston (Bob) and Laurence Tisch. Duo started in 1946 with small New Jersey hotel. Acquired Loews Theatres 1959. Matrons' sons now run company. Today Loews Corp. holding corporation includes insurance (CNA), natural gas (Boardwalk Pipeline), offshore drilling (Diamond), hotels. Spun off cigarette maker Lorillard to Carolina Group in 2007.

name: Billionaires
bio: Left Budapest as a child, moved to New York. Entered aircraft business while still an undergraduate at UCLA; put together $1 million airplane deal for Air New Zealand senior year. With fellow Hungarians Louis and Leslie Gonda, used $150,000 savings and $1.7 million bank loan to start International Lease Finance Corp. Sold to AIG for $1.3 billion in stock in 1990; claims to have cashed out of AIG stock before stock plummeted. Retired as ILFC chairman and chief executive in February; certified jet-pilot starting a new aircraft leasing business. Gives to Smithsonian.
title: Director

name: Billionaires
bio: Started network that became Home Box Office; traded it to Time Inc. for small Long Island cable company in 1973. Today Cablevision reaches 4.7 million households. Spun off Madison Square Garden in a public offering February; new company includes Radio City Music Hall, pro basketball's New York Knicks and hockey's New York Rangers. MSG stock up 9% since.
title: Chairman and Founder
employment: {'name': 'Cablevision Systems Corp.', 'title': 'Chairman and Founder', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Built family's scrap-metal business into a media, utilities and oil empire, Compagnie Nationale a Portefeuille. Conglomerate sold its stake in media giant Bertelsmann in 2006. In July 2008, at age 82, he completed what some say is the greatest coup of his career by playing a key role in pushing through the stalled mega merger of CNP's subsidiary Suez with French utility Gaz de France. The new company, European energy giant $95 billion (sales) GDF Suez, is now one of the largest independent electricity suppliers in the world.

name: Billionaires
bio: Entrepreneur behind Dallah Albaraka, one of Saudi Arabia's largest diversified trading groups with 40 divisions spanning media, banking, tourism, real estate, agriculture and transportation. Got start negotiating lucrative contracting deals for the Saudi government before striking out on his own. Chairman of $1.2 billion (market cap) Al Baraka Bank looking to cement reputation as a pioneer of Islamic finance with impending public listing of new Islamic megabank Istikhlaf.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mother, Estee Lauder (d. 2004), sold skin cream concocted by chemist uncle. Emphasized personal customer attention, free gifts. Operation became cosmetics giant. Labels include Clinique, Aveda, Bobbi Brown, La Mer. Daughter Jane elected to board of Estee Lauder last July; other daughter Aerin is senior vice president. Like older brother, Leonard, owns vast art collection. Paid $135 million for 1907 Klimt portrait 2006, the largest sum ever spent on a single painting at the time.

name: Billionaires
bio: Left father's real estate firm 1979, started buying small manufacturing companies during junk bond frenzy 1980s. Result: Equity Group Holdings. Acquired crippled REIT, fused with other industrial companies to form Danaher; named after Montana stream where he once fished with billionaire brother. Took industrial pumpmaker Colfax public 2008.

name: Billionaires
bio: Left father's real estate firm 1979, started buying small manufacturing companies during junk bond frenzy 1980s. Result: Equity Group Holdings. Acquired crippled REIT, fused with other industrial companies to form Danaher; named after Montana stream where he once fished with billionaire brother. Took industrial pumpmaker Colfax public in 2008.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: At age 27, started ENKA with his brother-in-law Sadi Gulcelik who died in a car accident in 1980. (Gulcelik's wife and children still have share in ENKA.) It is now Turkey's largest construction company; also does business in Russia. Son Mehmet Sinan, also a billionaire, runs the company these days. Born in Macedonia.

name: Billionaires
bio: Polish-born developer fled Europe during World War II for then Palestine. Studied architecture, then went to Canada, where he got into real estate. Today his property business spans Canada, U.S., Europe and Israel. Octogenarian shows no signs of slowing down: Planning IPO for Azrieli Group this year, expecting to float about 25% of the Israeli company on the Tel-Aviv 25 large cap index. Plans to use some of the proceeds to purchase Migdal Insurance and Financial Holdings Ltd, the largest insurance company in Israel. Through his Azrieli Foundation supports architecture, education and the arts. Past president of Canadian Zionist Association, published book about contributions of Jewish and gentile Canadians to establishment of Israel. Loaned several pieces of extensive art collection to Tel Aviv Museum of Art.

name: Billionaires
bio: Worked at Drexel Burnham Lambert 1980s; formed Apollo 1990 after firm's collapse. Returns since: 26% annualized net of fees. Busy during the boom: invested $8.1 billion of equity in 10 buyouts valued at $67.4 billion between March 2006 and December 2008. Now coping with effects of downturn on portfolio companies like real estate brokerage Realogy, casino outfit Harrah's. Trying to take Apollo public. Assets under management last fall: $51.8 billion. Prodigious art collector owns works by old masters, impressionists; serves on board of Metropolitan Museum of Art.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former head of Seagram's empire inherited business from father, Sam (d. 1971), Russian immigrant who founded Distillers Corp. in Montreal in 1924; ran whiskey across U.S.-Canadian border during Prohibition. Edgar Sr. took U.S. side of business, brother Charles ran Canadian operation. Added premium brands (Absolut), juices (Tropicana), large stake in DuPont. Son Edgar Jr. went Hollywood in 1990s: sold off juice, nylons business to finance $5.7 billion purchase of MCA/Universal stake. Sold rest to Vivendi for $34 billion. Family fortune soon faltered; cut losses, sold out after losing billions. Edgar Sr. works on nonprofit activities, Jewish advocacy.

name: Billionaires
bio: Runs $3.2 billion (sales) Hubert Burda Media Holding, which publishes well-known German magazines such as Focus, Bunte and Freundin. Burda's early bet on internet is helping company compete in a difficult sector. Committed philanthropist: supports the Hermann-Lenz Prize for German literature;  established the Felix Burda Foundation, committed to reducing the the number of deaths from colon cancer in Germany; formed the Burda Academy of the Third Millennium, an inter-disciplinary forum for researchers and thinkers.  Holds the Leo Baeck Prize for his efforts to bring together Jewish and non-Jewish communities in Germany;  also the Federal Cross of Merit. Married to well-known German actress Maria Furtwangler.

name: Billionaires
bio: Formed private equity colossus Carlyle Group with Daniel D'Aniello, David Rubenstein 1987; early success putting ex-politicos to work buying defense-oriented businesses. Turned around operations, flipped for big profits. Vilified in Michael Moore's Fahrenheit 9/11 for investing Bin Laden family money. Rehabbing image ever since; severed ties with unsavory clients and political advisers years ago. Today outfit manages $88 billion across 65 separate funds.
title: Co-Chief Executive Officer and Co-founder
employment: {'name': 'Carlyle Group', 'title': 'Co-Chief Executive Officer and Co-founder', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Formed private equity colossus Carlyle Group with William Conway Jr., David Rubenstein 1987; early success putting ex-politicos to work buying defense-oriented businesses. Turned around operations, flipped for big profits. Vilified in Michael Moore's Fahrenheit 9/11 for investing Bin Laden family money. Rehabbing image ever since; severed ties with unsavory clients and political advisers years ago. Today outfit manages $88 billion across 65 separate funds.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded Gap in 1969 with late husband Donald, who died in September of cancer at age 81. Originally a San Francisco jeans and music store, Gap empire grew to more than 3,000 locations and expanded to include Banana Republic (1983), Gap Kids (1986) and Old Navy (1994). Shares up 120% in past year. Owns large contemporary art collection, featuring pieces by Andy Warhol, Chuck Close, Richard Serra and Alexander Calder. Loaned collection to San Francisco Museum of Modern Art in September after attempt to open museum in San Francisco's historic Presidio district was nixed following resident complaints. Handed control to 3 sons John, Robert, William 2004; John has minority stake in Oakland A's baseball team.
title: Cofounder

name: Billionaires
bio: Jewelry business insiders call British diamond merchant Graff the new Harry Winston. Specializing in the highest end of jewelry retailing, Graff has 31 stores worldwide. Clients include the Sultan and Queen of Brunei and Donald Trump. As demand for high-end diamonds revived this year, Graff's net worth climbed, based on his inventory stockpile of top quality diamonds. He scored a publicity coup in January when the Smithsonian unveiled a temporary exhibit of his 31-carat blue diamond, recently bought by Graff at auction in December 2008 for $24 million and renamed the Graff-Wittelsbach. The stone is in the same gallery as the renowned Hope Diamond. A self-made tycoon, Graff spent childhood in London's gritty East End, dropping out of school at age 14 to become a jeweler's apprentice. In 2008 Graff achieved full vertical integration when he bought a stake in publicly traded diamond miner Gem Diamonds. Other assets include jewelry company Graff Diamonds International, a polished diamond trading company in Antwerp, a real estate company in Luxembourg and a stake in a South African diamond wholesaler. Graff splits his time between homes in Gstaad, London, Cap Ferrat, New York City and his 150-foot Feadship yacht. Also owns a vineyard and winery in Stellenbosch, the Napa Valley of South Africa, and an extensive modern and contemporary art collection. On a personal note, Graff, 71, has acknowledged that he fathered a baby girl out of wedlock last year. He and French wife Anne-Marie have been married 47 years, and remain together.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of hotel legend Conrad Hilton started as an elevator operator before enlisting in army at age 17; stint as WWII Navy photographer. Struck out on his own after the war, declined job in father's company. Founded Carte Blance Credit Card, Air Finance Corporation and AFL's Chargers; helped negotiate merger with NFL to create Super Bowl. Returned to Hilton Hotels as president 1966; sold controlling interest in Chargers. Inherited $750,000 when dad died in 1979, purchased stock from father's estate. Reaped $800 million from sale of Hilton Hotels to Blackstone in 2007, $300 million from Harrah's sale to Apollo Management and TPG in 2008. Has committed 97% of his estate to Conrad N. Hilton Foundation, which he chairs. Enjoys flying, fishing.

name: Billionaires
bio: Accordion-playing fire-breather founded Cirque du Soleil in 1984 with a gang of street performing friends. Initially funded by the Canadian government, the Montreal-based circus, which has no animals, no speaking and no star performers, became a for-profit group in 1985. Bought out majority partner in 2000; today owns 95% of company. Hit jackpot when Steve Wynn brought Cirque to Las Vegas in 1991. Today group has six permanent shows in Sin City, including Beatles-themed "Love," which opened in June 2006; show replaced Siegfried & Roy at the Mirage. Up next: an Elvis-themed show in Vegas. In March opening "Banana Shpeel" in New York. In 2008 sold 20% of Cirque to two Dubai firms for $600 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cheese king weathering recession. Leprino Foods supplies cheese for budget-friendly fare like Dominos, Papa John's, Pizza Hut pizzas, Hot Pockets, string cheese. Father, Mike Sr., came to the U.S. in 1914, settled in Colorado. Whipped up homemade mozzarella and ricotta cheese for local customers in 1950s. Son Jim joined company at 18; turned modest family business into world's largest mozzarella producer. Today Leprino Foods operates 12 plants around U.S. and Europe. Sales: $2.6 billion. By-products whey protein, lactose, sweet whey powder used in infant formula, yogurt. Plans for plant in Colorado expected to boost dairy production, fuel local economy.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: With $120 in savings, he and 3 brothers got start raising quail, chickens in 1982. Their Hope Group became one of China's largest makers of animal feed. Siblings split in 1995. Now chairman of New Hope Group, with more than 380 subsidiaries and 60,000 employees. It is one of the largest suppliers of meat, eggs, dairy products in China. Has stakes in chemical maker Hebei Baoshuo and feed supplier Sichuan New Hope Agribusiness. Vice chairman of China Minsheng Banking, whose shares trade in Shanghai and Hong Kong. Wife Li Wei helps oversee property investments. Older brother Liu Yongxing runs East Hope Group and is also a billionaire.

name: Billionaires
bio: Made headlines in September when he paid $405 million for a 29% stake in Legend, the shareholder of struggling laptopmaker Lenovo. Owns big stake in Oceanwide Construction Group of Beijing, which he runs, but most of those shares are collateralized. Although low profile, Lu is an influential business leader, serving as vice chairman of the All-China Federation of Industry & Commerce. He is also a council member of Fudan University.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former Lebanese prime minister and current member of parliament founded telecom company Investcom with brother Taha at height of Lebanon's civil war in 1982. After public offerings in London and Dubai, sold company to South Africa's MTN Group for $5.5 billion in 2006; still MTN's second largest shareholder. Runs M1 Group, a holding company invested in real estate, Geneva airline Baboo and classy fashion line, Faconnable. Public service career launched in 1998 when Tripoli-born businessman was appointed to Lebanese cabinet as Minister of Public Works & Transport. Three-month stint as prime minister came in wake of Hariri assassination after predecessor Omar Karami quit in frustration. Philanthropist founded and think-tank Middle East Prospects Forum.

name: Billionaires
bio: Brother and business partner of onetime Lebanese prime minister and fellow billionaire Najib Mikati keeps low profile. Founded telecom company Investcom with brother at height of Lebanon's civil war in 1982. After public offerings in London and Dubai, sold company to South Africa's MTN Group for $5.5 billion in 2006; family remains MTN's second-largest shareholder. Co-founded M1 Group, a holding company run by his son Azmi; investments in real estate, Geneva airline Baboo and classy fashion line, Faconnable. M1 bought 14% stake in Audi Bank in January. Got start as cofounder of Abu Dhabi's Arabian Construction Company in late 1960s; 20 years later sold his stake and moved back to Lebanon.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded Future Electronics in 1968 and built it into the world's third-largest electronics distributor; products include semiconductors and electromechanical components. Rebounding from lagging electronic sales through most of 2009. Investing in Europe and Asia. Supports Alcor Life Extension Foundation, which promotes cryonics, the science of freezing bodies with the intent to restore life when technology becomes available.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fruit tycoon took his pineapples public again. Chairman of Dole Food raised $446 million from October public offering; using proceeds to pay down company's $1.9 billion debt load. Dyslexic high school dropout drafted into Army 1943, settled in Detroit after WWII. Made small profit flipping diner he bought with $1,800 loan. Took charge of struggling Dole, Hawaiian real estate company Castle & Cooke in 1985. Today Dole is world's largest producer of fruits and vegetables. Self-professed health nut's life-prolonging diet and exercise regimen: smoothies, no saturated fats and 50 push-ups a day.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sold off oil stocks ahead of the bursting of the energy bubble 2008. Now putting proceeds back to work by betting that growth in China and India will push oil prices once again. "Something's gotta give." Son of middle-class wholesaler studied at Stanford; brief stint at Goldman Sachs before leaving to run Bass family's $50 million portfolio 1970. Made hundreds of millions betting on energy; once claimed to be the largest individual shareholder of Chevron, ConocoPhillips. Part-owner of Pebble Beach golf course.

name: Billionaires
bio: Formed private equity colossus Carlyle Group with William Conway Jr., Daniel D'Aniello 1987; early success putting ex-politicos to work buying defense-oriented businesses. Turned around operations, flipped for big profits. Vilified in Michael Moore's Fahrenheit 9/11 for investing Bin Laden family money. Rehabbing image ever since; severed ties with unsavory clients and political advisers years ago. Today outfit manages $88 billion across 65 separate funds.
title: Co-Chief Executive Officer and Co-founder
employment: {'name': 'Carlyle Group', 'title': 'Co-Chief Executive Officer and Co-founder', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Eldest son of Orascom conglomerate founder and fellow billionaire Onsi Sawiris; now executive chairman of Orascom Telecom, one of largest mobile providers in Middle East, Africa and South Asia. His Weather Investments, which includes telecom companies Italy's Wind Telecomunicazioni and Greece's Wind Hellas, is saddled with debt from their leveraged buyouts four years ago. Consummate dealmaker reportedly looking to buy Serbian's Telekom Srbija.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of quantitative hedge fund D.E. Shaw earned Ph.D. in computer science at Stanford U. 1980; professor at Columbia until 1986. Launched hedge fund from office above communist book store 2 years later. Firm now manages $24 billion across hedge fund, private equity, insurance operations. Returned 21.5% last year net of fees; lost 9.7% in 2008. Midlife reinvention: turned over management to top execs 2001; spends his time solving scientific riddles. Recent project: supercomputer that Shaw designed allows scientists to run detailed simulations exploring the motions of proteins.
title: Founder
employment: {'name': 'D. E. Shaw & Co., L.P.', 'title': 'Founder', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Fifth wife and widow of Axel Springer, founder of $3.8 billion (sales) Axel Springer Verlag, one of Germany's leading publishing groups. Now owns more than 52% of company, which publishes more than 170 papers in 33 countries, including leading German conservative daily Die Welt and Germany's largest daily tabloid, Bild Zeitung. Axel Springer publishes foreign language editions of Forbes in Poland and Russia.  Active in various philanthropic organizations; has received numerous awards for her efforts to rebuild German-Jewish relations.  Also holder of the Federal Cross of Merit for her efforts to promote social,  cultural and scientific dialogue worldwide.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partner John Tu founded memory-chip operation Camintonn 1982, sold 4 years later for $6 million. Formed Kingston Technology; sold 80% to Softbank for $1.5 billion in 1996, immediately distributed  $100 million in employee bonuses. Bought back 3 years later for  $450 million. Today Kingston is nation's largest privately held computer memory outfit; products grace cell phones, digital cameras, MP3 players. Beating competitors on price by closely monitoring chip supply to avoid having excess inventory if chip prices fall. Another tactic: using less packaging. Both billionaires continue to work in cubicles at center of sales floor.
title: COO

name: Billionaires
bio: With partner David Sun founded memory-chip operation Camintonn 1982, sold 4 years later for $6 million. Formed Kingston Technology; sold 80% to Softbank for $1.5 billion in 1996, immediately distributed $100 million in employee bonuses. Bought back 3 years later for $450 million. Today Kingston is nation's largest privately held computer memory outfit; products grace cell phones, digital cameras, MP3 players. Counting on demand-hungry Asia to offset weakness elsewhere. Beating competitors on price by closely monitoring chip supply to avoid having excess inventory if chip prices fall. Another tactic: using less packaging. Both billionaires continue to work in cubicles at center of sales floor.
title: President

name: Billionaires
bio: Longtime head of Esprit steadily reduced his majority stake in Esprit in recent years, pocketing close to $2 billion along the way.  Still retains almost 9% stake in the company, which reported in 2009 its first drop in profits in a decade. Now a non executive director of Esprit, got his big break in 1971 when company's American founders hired him as their primary sourcing agent; eventually bought rights to the clothing brand in Europe and Asia. Married to former Taiwanese movie star Brigitte Lin. Said to be an amateur paleontologist and an enthusiastic golfer.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former trader of construction materials and construction subcontractor started his first real estate project, Sunshine Greenland, in Shanghai in 1996. Became Glorious Property Holdings, which went public in Hong Kong in October. Shares have lost one-fifth of their value since.  Glorious expaned mailand assets picking up property in eastern city of Tianjin in December. Also invests in shipbuilding. Lives in Hong Kong where Glorious is headquartered,    even though company's main operations are on the mainland.

name: Billionaires
bio: One of the largest individual investors in Saudi stock market. Holdings include stakes in food conglomerate Savola and commercial banking giant Banque Saudi Fransi. Recent victim of Saudi Capital Markets Authority's efforts to crack down on insider trading: fined $26,667 in June for profiting nearly $900,000 when he unloaded shares in hospitality concern Saudi Hotels Co., allegedly acting on a tip about an upcoming merger. Al Issa denied wrongdoing but paid the fine, telling the local press, "CMA decided the verdict, and I accepted. I rest the matter with God."

name: Billionaires
bio: Often called the Siberian hermit; rarely leaves remote town of Surgut. Avoids public attention and the trappings of wealth. A professional driller, he was appointed chief executive of Surgutneftegas at 33. In early 1990s privatized the company with his fellow managers. Company has accumulated $16 billion in cash.

name: Billionaires
bio: Record-label tycoon started out playing in a band at age 18 to support his mother and sister after his father's death. Moved to London in 1975 and founded Zomba Recordings, whose crown jewel is Jive Records. Ventured stateside in 1978, signing acts like Billy Ocean and the Cars, later Britney Spears, Backstreet Boys and 'N Sync. Sold Zomba Recordings to BMG for $2.7 billion in 2002. Now lives in the Cayman Islands, spending part of his time on charitable foundation, Elma Philanthropies, which works in nine African countries on children's education and health issues.

name: Billionaires
bio: Owner of pro basketball's Dallas Mavericks quickly extinguished rumors regarding his reported second attempt to expand into baseball; was said to have had interest in buying LA Dodgers after his failed Chicago Cubs bid in 2008. Investing in entrepreneurs to jump-start economy via the "Mark Cuban Stimulus Plan." Bought stake in Wickler; firm produces wireless patron-counting clickers, allowing bar owners to track customers' drinking habits. Launched audio and video portal Broadcast.com with college buddy Todd Wagner. Sold to Yahoo in 1999 for $5.7 billion in stock; a decade later the domain just redirects to Yahoo's home page. Invested in entertainment via HDNet, 2929 Entertainment, Lions Gate.
title: Owner

name: Billionaires
bio: Namesake of Campbell Soup founder lives quietly in South Dublin after cashing out of family business; sold off much of his 10.5% stake in Campbell Soup for $1.5 billion in mid 1990s. Renounced U.S. citizenship, moved to Ireland before the sale, presumably to avoid capital gains taxes. Said to frequent Bahamas with Finnish wife. Joined movement to legalize game ranching in Wyoming, fox hunting in Great Britain.

name: Billionaires
bio: In 1990s created Russia's largest coal-trading company, Rosuglesbyt. Later invested in cement, purchasing the Stern Cement plants and the cement business of fellow billionaire Elena Baturina's Inteko. Now his Eurocement Group, with 17 plants, is the country's largest producer. Recently bought out partner Georgy Kransyansky, to be the company's sole owner. In 2008, paid $1 billion for a 6% stake in Swiss cement maker Holcim, part of Swiss billionaire Thomas Schmidheiny's empire.

name: Billionaires
bio: Reclusive property developer. Owns 50% of two shopping centers: Chadstone, which opened a wing for luxury brands this year, and Northland. Also holds 17% of property trust that owns other half of both. Joined family retailer Sussan in 1950s and eventually ran it before selling out after buying Chadstone in 1983. This year bought into listed developer Charter Hall. Known for conservative approach and distrust of debt. Lives in what is believed to be Melbourne's priciest home.

name: Billionaires
bio: Tampa titan holds the majority of his fortune in an asset class that usually holds value in a recession: sports teams. Owns pro football's Tampa Bay Buccaneers, English soccer giant Manchester United. Man U won English Premier League in 2009, but massive debt load continues to rankle fans, hamper profitability despite rising revenues. Inherited watch-parts business from father at 15; expanded family empire into shopping malls, sports teams. Shopping: Today owns 6.7 million square feet of retail space. Glazer Children's Museum slated to open in Tampa later this year. Sons manage family assets.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman and chief executive of Fosun, which he cofounded in 1992 with fellow Fudan University grads. Now China's largest privately-owned conglomerate with interests in mining, retail, pharma and property. Has listed stakes in Fosun International in Hong Kong, Focus Media in the U.S. and Nanjing Steel United in China, among others. In January, brought on ex-U.S. treasury secretary John Snow had joined as an advisor to the board. In February announced strategic relationship with private equity firm The Carlyle Group; together they plan to set up a Chinese-currency investment fund. Media division licenses Forbes brand in China.

name: Billionaires
bio: Biggest shareholder in Renhe Commercial Holdings, which listed in Hong Kong in 2008 and runs shopping centers that occupy what were underground military shelters. Graduated from China's Heilongjiang University in 1986 with a degree in Chinese literature.  One of seven women who made their own fortunes in mainland China.

name: Billionaires
bio: Carpenter by trade, opened his own business in 1980 and developed it into one of Spain's leading property companies, Fadesa Inmobiliaria. Took company public in April 2004; sold his 55% stake to real estate group Martinsa for $3 billion in September 2006, just before collapse of Spanish real estate bubble. Holds 4% stake in Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria, one of Spain's largest banks. Collects art from Spanish province of Galicia; enjoys woodworking.

name: Billionaires
bio: Farmer's son started out with a small bicycle repair shop. Earned early fortune making auto parts for such carmakers as Ford and Toyota. Today his $4.2 billion (sales) Wanxiang Group holds stakes in listed autoparts firm Wanxiang Qianqiao; textile, dye firm Zhejiang Hangmin. Also has interests in agriculture, aquaculture, infrastructure. Injected family's property arm Shunfa Hengye into Shenzhen-listed Lan Bao Technology Information last year and renamed it Shunfa. Son Lu Weiding holds stakes in filmmaker Huayi Brothers and energy producer Amber Energy.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cable crusader swooped in with $530 million to save Sirius XM from bankruptcy last year; beat out rival media maven Charles Ergen's Dish Network. Cash injection gave Liberty Media 40% of satellite radio operator. Partner of TCI cable founder Bob Magness (d. 1996) sold nation's largest cable company in 1999 to AT&T for $54 billion. Today his Liberty Media owns stakes in cell phones (Sprint Nextel), Internet (Expedia), pro baseball's Atlanta Braves. Spun off DirecTV into separate entity in November. Moved to increase his stake in Live Nation Entertainment after merger of industry giants Live Nation and Ticketmaster received regulatory approval in January. Bid fizzled; Liberty got a small fraction of what it intended to buy. Move would have further aligned Malone with Live Nation chairman Barry Diller, whom he battled with two years ago over Diller's desire to break up his Web site conglomerate IAC/InterActiveCorp.

name: Billionaires
bio: Wine maker cut holes in shoe soles during hot walk in Nevada 1989. Developed membrane that let shoes breathe; blocked dirt and water. Idea turned down by Nike. Founded Geox 1995; took public 2004. Second largest casual shoe maker in world. Makes footwear for men, women, children; branched into golf spikes and clothing. Champions practical research and development, innovation, the importance of patents.

name: Billionaires
bio: Media maven rebounding from the brink; Viacom shares up 105%, CBS up 285% in past year. Nearly lost it all last fall when markets crashed; successfully restructured $1.46 billion of debt in May 2009, sold nearly $1 billion in Viacom and CBS shares in October 2009. Further reduced debt with sale of non-core theaters in U.S., South America and Russia. WWII vet earned law degree at Harvard, took over family's Northeast Theater Corp. Acquired controlling stake in Viacom 1987; spun off CBS 2006. Largest individual shareholder of Viacom (Paramount Pictures, MTV Networks) and CBS (CBS, CW, CBS Radio).
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Canada's cheese mogul enjoyed a spurt in profits after hefty acquisition spree. Saputo stock up by 40%. Born in Sicily, started Saputo in Montreal in 1954 with parents. Delivered mozzarella by bicycle in the early days. Snapped up U.S. and Canadian dairies in the 1980s as pizza's growing popularity boosted demand for his products. Still serves as chairman; son Lino Jr. is chief.

name: Billionaires
bio: Owns 40% of $12.7 billion (sales) Helm AG, one of the world's leading independent chemicals marketing enterprises with  interests in trading, chemicals and pharmaceuticals. Became chairman of executive board in 1984 when father, Hermann, the company's founder, retired. Dad still owns other 60%.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ebay's first president and full-time employee is no longer involved in the company; now focuses on inspiring social action by launching entrepreneurs through his Skoll Foundation and producing movies through Participant Media. Backed the Oscar-winning film, An Inconvenient Truth, the global-warming documentary that featured former Vice President Al Gore. On tap for 2009: The Soloist, starring Robert Downey Jr. and Jamie Foxx, and The Informant, with Matt Damon. Skoll pumped gas in Toronto before getting an M.B.A. from Stanford in 1995. Founded Skoll Global Threats Fund in 2009 to confront issues ranging from climate change to pandemics and nuclear proliferation.

name: Billionaires
bio: Medical device fortune slowly on the mend; Stryker Corp. stock up 20% in past 12 months. Shares lagging market recovery. Surgeon grandfather Homer Stryker (d. 1980) invented mobile hospital bed; founded medical supply Stryker Corp. 1941. Father, Lee, died in plane crash 1976; John Brown became chief executive. Public 1979. Today company produces hospital beds, joint replacements, medical software, surgical cameras. Sales: $6.7 billion. Ronda serves as vice chairman of Greenleaf Trust.

name: Billionaires
bio: The queen of television talk is expanding her empire. In 2008 partnered with Discovery Communications to create the Oprah Winfrey Network; launch date pushed back to later this year. Mississippi native moved to Chicago after news stints in Nashville, Baltimore. The Oprah Winfrey Show debuted nationally in 1986; today broadcasts to 145 countries. Show's lucrative syndication deal inked through 2011; she will retire the show after the deal expires. Launched Dr. Phil, Rachael Ray gabfests; Dr. Oz debuted new health show in September. Began communicating with fans via Twitter last April. Oprah's Angel Network has raised more than $70 million for international humanitarian causes.

name: Billionaires
bio: World's richest butcher prides himself on selling safe meat in a country where food safety scandals occur often. Yet even Zhu had a scare last April when small batch of meat sold by his China Yurun Food, one of China's largest pork processors, was found to be tainted. The problem, which turned out to be an isolated incident, was contained; stock is up 136% since. Also a major shareholder in Nanjing Central Emporium, a Shanghai-listed department store, and Yurun Dihua, a real estate company. Co-founded Nanjing Yurun Meat Product, a predecessor business to China Yurun, with wife Wu Xueqin in 1993.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Al Ghurair Group, one the UAE's oldest family empires. Group's diverse holdings include an iron-and-steel factory, packaging manufacturing, high-end shopping malls and Mashreq, bank helmed by nephew and fellow billionaire Abdul Aziz Al Ghurair. Recession's impact on credit-crunched Dubai hurting real estate values, bank stocks and consumer spending. Son Majed, head of family business and chairman of Dubai Shopping Malls Group estimated retail sales in family's tony malls plunged 30% in first half of 2009.

name: Billionaires
bio: With 3 brothers Saleh, Sulaiman and Mohammed, built small money-changing business in Saudi's Najd desert into world's largest Islamic bank, the $33 billion (assets) Al Rajhi Bank. Shariah-compliant finance proved vulnerable to last year's downturn but value of his 6% stake boosted by rebounding shares: up 80% since last March's lows. Bulk of fortune comes from stake in eponymous family bank, but also has holdings in various agriculture and manufacturing businesses, including 3 cement factories, a mineral-water bottler and a Syrian bank.

name: Billionaires
bio: Co-chief executive founder of BlackBerry maker Research In Motion with fellow billionaire Mike Lazaridis. In fierce battle for market share with BlackBerry nemesis, iPhone, and host of new rival smart phones. Along with Lazaridis and Chief Operating Officer Dennis Kavelman, was ordered to pay $62 million to settle backdating options case in 2009. Also forced to step down from RIM board of directors. Unpopular bid to buy Phoenix Coyotes was rejected by federal bankruptcy judge in October.

name: Billionaires
bio: Identical twins started together in the accounts department at General Electric, flipped houses and purchased first hotel in 1975. Today share empire spanning Ritz London, InterContinental Hotel Group, Telegraph Newspaper Group, and U.K.'s largest online retailer, Shop Direct Group. Live in  mansion on the isle of Breqhou; significant investments on neighboring Sark. In December 2008 elections, Sark voters rejected Barclay-backed candidates; billionaires fired nearly 100 employees in response, jobs have since been reinstated. Last winter bought 100 year-old Woolworth brand, whose stores shut down; relaunching as an online retailer.

name: Billionaires
bio: Timberland tycoon's father, Curly, owned a lumber mill. Archie took Sierra Pacific public 1969, private again 4 years later. Bought 522,000 acres of Santa Fe Southern Pacific Railroad timberland with a $460 million loan in 1988. Today firm owns nearly 2 million acres in prestigious California and Washington regions. Patiently waiting out recession; biological tree growth allows acreage to uniquely appreciate over time. Son Mark handles finances.

name: Billionaires
bio: With mother Ingeburg, three brothers, Joachim, Michael and Wolfgang, and sister Daniela, inherited a fortune from his father, coffee magnate Max Herz.  Headed the family Tchibo Holding, now called Maxingvest AG, for almost 35 years. A  nasty family feud led him and his sister Daniela to sell their combined 40% stake in the German consumer goods group to their mother and three brothers for an estimated $5 billion in August 2003. Now he and his sister own private equity firm Mayfair GmbH, through which they hold a 96% stake in German shipping company, Germanischer Lloyd.  Mayfair is reportedly backing Panel Board Holding, a Dutch company which makes building materials out of wheat straw waste.  Sold a stake in Puma  to Francois Pinault's PPR group for well over $1 billion in 2007.   Brother Joachim died in May 2008 after being hit by a boat while swimming in a Georgia lake.  Raises horses at his stud farm; races his yacht All Smoke.

name: Billionaires
bio: Stockbroker's son invested $4,000 in cable company with frat brother 1963. Continental Cablevision grew into largest privately held cable company in country; sold to US West for $11 billion 1996. Later bought company back, renamed MediaOne; sold to AT&T for $58 billion 3 years later. Invests via Pilot House Associates.
title: Chair

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Century Golden Resources Group, with business in real estate, hotels, and minerals. Owns stake in Bank of Beijing. One of the most generous individuals on mainland, according to a government-connected research body, his efforts have centered around Yunnan Province, in Western China where he develops property. Among the causes he supported there: relief for the elderly, education support and financial assistance to farmers. He also donates to educational causes in his home province of Fujian.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former Taiwan legislator who made fortune in real estate. Later founded the Liberty Times Group, a Taiwan newspaper that goes head-to-head with Hong Kong's Jimmy Lai-controlled Apple Daily for top spot in Taiwan market. Lin is also the majority investor in Union Bank of Taiwan. Three sons divide responsibility for the bank, the property business, and the newspaper. Started out selling rice and growing vegetables, began buying property in his 20s.  Policy advisor to two previous Taiwan presidents. Brother is fellow billionaire Lin Yu-lin.

name: Billionaires
bio: Forced out of McCain Foods' day-to-day operations in the 1990s after family feud; remains vice chairman with one-third stake in the company, which is the world's largest producer of frozen french fries. Took over meat processor Maple Leaf Foods, where son Michael is chief, in 1995. In February Maple Leaf announced a $25 million proposed settlement to a class action brought against the company after a strain of listeria causing 20 deaths was linked to its Toronto plant last summer. Wallace's son offered public apology. Donates to philanthropic causes like National Ballet School of Canada and National Gallery of Canada.

name: Billionaires
bio: Johannesburg mining magnate is South Africa's first black billionaire. Net worth up this year by $1 billion as a result of rising stock prices and South African Rand's strength against the dollar. Born in the sprawling black township of Soweto and then trained as a lawyer, became first black partner at Bowman Gilfillan law firm in Johannesburg, before starting a contracting business doing mine scut work. Bought low-producing gold mine shafts in 1994, turned them profitable using lean, mean management style. Since then built $1.3 billion (sales) mining conglomerate, African Rainbow Minerals (ARM), with interests in a wide swath of minerals: platinum, nickel, chrome, iron, manganese, coal and gold. Benefited from South Africa's Black Economic Empowerment (BEE) laws, which mandate that companies be at least 26% black-owned in order to get a government mining license. Also holds a 6.2% stake in Sanlam, a publicly traded financial services company outside Cape Town where he sits on the board. Invited to chair the board of Sanlam in December, but turned down the post.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Irish industrial conglomerate Quinn Group recovering from disastrous bet on Anglo Irish Bank. Bought financial contracts to quietly amass 25% stake in Anglo Irish. Credit crisis struck, Anglo was nationalized in January 2009. Quinn had borrowed from his flagship insurance business to fund purchases when shares were rising. Result: $1 billion writedown. Press-shy Quinn posted press release in October claiming "absolutely no impropriety" in contract purchases. Recently announced plans to take Quinn Group public "by the end of 2015." Other assets: radiator, plastic and glass factories, hotels, commercial real estate and a chain of pubs.
source: real estate, insurance, cement, glassmaking, hotel

name: Billionaires
bio: Taking over in April as interim chief executive of his family's publicly traded Swiss luxury group Richemont, which owns Cartier, Dunhill and other premium brands. Stock doubled in past year helped by Christmas sales that were ahead of expectations; also particularly bullish about continued growth in Asia-Pacific. His South African holding company, Remgro, bought out private South African investment outfit, VenFin, in which he also had a stake, in December.  Appointed to position of Chancellor of the University of Stellenbosch,  in South Africa's wine country where he has an office.  With family relatives, owns two of South Africa's best-known vineyards, Rupert & Rothschild and L'Ormarins; also owns one of the country's most exclusive golf clubs.

name: Billionaires
bio: Older of 2 living billionaire brothers descended from a Middle Eastern banking family. In 2006 Moise sold, to his brother Joseph, his holding in Banco Safra, now Brazil's 11th-largest bank, plus stakes in Safra-owned banks in New York, Luxembourg and other locations, for an undisclosed sum estimated at $2 billion. Joseph and Moise's deceased brother Edmond had a separate multibillion-dollar banking fortune, part of which he left to his wife Lily.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ohio State law school dropout started the Limited with $5,000 loan from aunt 1963; focused on women's sportswear. Took public 6 years later. Company now includes Victoria's Secret, La Senza, C.O. Bigelow, White Barn Candle brands. Fast-expanding Bath & Body Works division accounted for 40% of parent company's operating profit in 2009. Limited Brand stock up 131% in past 12 months. Sold 75% of Express brand to Golden State Capital for $600 million in 2007; company now focused on higher-margin lingerie, beauty product operations.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Limited Brands', 'uri': 'companies/limited-brands', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded YTL Corp, one of Malaysia's largest conglomerates, with interests in construction, utilities, hotels, property development and technology; shares up over 20% in the past year. All seven children work in the company; son Francis runs YTL's daily operations. Last year bought PowerSeraya, Singapore's second largest power generator from Temasek Holdings for $2.4 billion, which contributed to 12% growth in net profit. Through a real estate trust, controls major prime properties in Singapore, including Wisma Atria and Ngee Ann City. Plans to launch mobile WiMAX service with international partners such as Samsung, Cisco and GCT.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded Sodexo as catering and river cruise company in 1966 in a warehouse in Marseilles. Today the $12 billion (2009 sales) company supplies food to the U.S. Marine Corps; handles security for the Alaska natural gas pipeline; operates prisons; has majority stake in the Lido, the Parisian topless cabaret that features ice dancers and trapeze artists; 90% stake in Yachts de Paris, one of the best-known cruise companies operating on the Seine.  One of the leading food and facilities management services companies in India with its acquisition last year of  Radhakrishna Hospitality Services Group. Bellon stepped down as chief executive in 2005 but remains chairman. Penned autobiography, "I've Had a Great Time".

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, Heinz, amassed world-famous collection of works by Picasso. Nicolas grew up in France and Switzerland. First job: worked for Bass brothers' real estate investment group. Founded own firm in 1986. Shining deal: bought stake in Portugal's Media Capital for $9 million in 1992; took public 2006, sold shares to Prisa for $150 million. In July his Liberty International special-purpose acquisition company (SPAC) agreed to inject up to $800 million into debt-laden British insurance outfit Pearl Group. Other SPAC-driven investment dinged by downturn: shares in hedge fund GLG Partners have fallen 70% since company went public in 2007. Also owns Indian hotel chain, American vocational schools, Turkish wind-power licenses, Israeli real estate.

name: Billionaires
bio: Internet pioneer founded Netease in 1997 as a portal. Listed firm on New York Stock Exchange in 2000; briefly China's richest man. Later morphed into one of China's most successful online game developers. Its flagship game, Fantasy Westward Journey, is among nation's top 10 downloads. Partnered with U.S. game developer Blizzard Entertainment to distribute the World of Warcraft games on mainland China.

name: Billionaires
bio: U.K. citizen arrived in Hong Kong in the mid-1960s. Later founded Noble Group, commodities firm that supplies customers with coal, grain, oil, soybeans and more. Has run it from Hong Kong for more than two decades. Recently sold part of his stake to a Chinese-government-owned investment firm; still has 24%. Grew up in Brighton; quit school at 15. Worked in scrap business in U.S., Japan, Thailand, India. Later became regional director of commodities trader Phibro.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former dermatologist sold drug manufacturer Ivax to Teva Pharmaceuticals for $7.6 billion in 2005. Today owns more than $850 million in Teva stock; remainder of fortune held in bonds, cash, slew of medical startups. Took over Key Pharmaceuticals with partner Michael Jaharis 1972; created new delivery systems for old drugs. Sold to Schering-Plough in 1986; founded Ivax the following year to develop generic pharmaceuticals and veterinary products. Vice chair of Teva, trustee of the Scripps Research Institute. With wife, Patricia, gives away millions of dollars a year to the arts. The Patricia and Phillip Frost Art Museum celebrated first anniversary in December.

name: Billionaires
bio: Worked as a janitor and telemarketer to pay way through Michigan State. Learned distribution and sales business after cofounding lumber software company in his 20s. Learned buyout business with brother Alec. Started Platinum Equity out of house 1995; has made more than 100 acquisitions since. Operations specialist buys bad companies with good balance sheets; cuts costs, fixes sales force to increase revenue. Reacts fast to changing times. "You can't control the market. What you can control is your company." Closed $2.75 billion fund last September. Netted $500 million profit from sale of steel distributor PNA Group August 2008. Recently lost 3-year battle for auto parts maker Delphi. One of most active private equity firms in 2009; closed 10 deals.

name: Billionaires
bio: Quit Moscow for London a couple of years ago after trouble with the government. At end of 2006, was accused of violating terms of his oil license and failure to pay taxes. Gutseriev denied the charges; sold his oil firm, RussNeft, to billionaire Oleg Deripaska and left the country. Authorities have since lifted several charges and he is buying back RussNeft. Born in Kazakhstan, to which his Ingush family had been deported after World War II. Later became president of state oil company Slavneft. Was dismissed in 2002 before privatization, but was able to return to big oil. Over four year period, Swiss trader Glencore helped him buy a number of small Russian oil firms, which he united into RussNeft.

name: Billionaires
bio: With mother, Ingeburg, and four brothers, Gunter, Joachim, Michael and Wolfgang, inherited a fortune from her father, coffee magnate Max Herz. A nasty family feud led her and her older brother Gunter to sell their combined 40% stake in German consumer goods group Tchibo Holding, now called Maxingvest AG, to their mother and other three brothers for an estimated $5 billion in August 2003. She and her brother now own private equity firm Mayfair GmbH, through which they hold a 96% stake in German shipping company, Germanischer Lloyd. Mayfair is reportedly backing Panel Board Holding, a Dutch company which makes building materials out of wheat straw waste.  Sold a stake in Puma to Francois Pinault's PPR group for well more than $1 billion in 2007.  Brother Joachim died in May 2008 after being  hit by a boat while swimming in a Georgia lake.

name: Billionaires
bio: Real estate magnate founded Cyrela Brazil Realty in 1978; built it into largest developer of high-end residential buildings in Sao Paulo and Rio de Janeiro. Later expanded by inking development deals with partners in various regions of Brazil. Horn also owns slice of agricultural investor BrasilAgro. A low-profile man known for giving 20% of his earnings to charity reportedly told Brazilian press he plans to give away most of his fortune at his death. In 2008 told Wharton: "My history is to make money when there is a boom, not when there is a crisis."

name: Billionaires
bio: With older sister Esther, also a billionaire, inherited Fomento de  Construcciones y Contratas from late father. Their husbands ran the company from the early 1970s until 1989, when both marriages ended. The sisters took over and jointly ran the business until 1997 when Alicia sold her share to Esther for $800 million.  Over the years, has invested the proceeds into such companies as Acerinox, Iberdrola and Banco Sabadel;  also owns hotels in Spain, Italy and Portugal; real estate in the U.S., Hong Kong and China. Controls two hedge funds,  one in Spain and one in England, that manage over $500 million in funds. Through her charitable foundation, sends Spanish fellows to study child psychiatry in England and the U.S. at places like Columbia University's Medical Center. Last year was named an honorary member of the Spanish Society of Psychiatrists for her efforts in promoting the study and development of child and juvenile psychology. Has been linked romantically with the Duque de Huescar, heir to the Spanish aristocratic house of Alba.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded BlackBerry maker Research In Motion while student at University of Waterloo. Company's co-chief executive, along with fellow billionaire James Balsillie. In fierce battle for market share with BlackBerry nemesis, iPhone, and myriad of new rival smart phones. Along with Balsillie and Chief Operating Officer Dennis Kavelman, was ordered to pay $62 million to settle backdating options case in 2009. Founded Waterloo's Perimeter Institute for Theoretical Physics in 1999; has since donated $150 million to the quantum physics research institute. Chancellor of University of Waterloo.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandfather John T. Dorrance was a chemical engineer who discovered way to can condensed soup using half as much water, cutting costs by a third. Campbell Soup sales in fiscal year 2009: $7.6 billion. Stock up 8% in last year. Owns other familiar brands: Pace (salsa), V8 (vegetable juice), Pepperidge Farm (cookies, Goldfish), Swanson (broth). Owns horse breeder Iron Spring Farms in Pennsylvania.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of ABC Mart, discount shoe retailer, which is opening an average of 50 new stores a year. Moving abroad: has one store in Korea and another opened in Taiwan in October. At home expanding store size as recession hit and businesses vacate neighboring stores. Former amateur boxer stepped down as chairman in 2007 but still has large stake. In June he bought 23% of fashion retailer United Arrows.

name: Billionaires
bio: Gas godfather's horizontal drilling technique will provide the U.S over 100 years of cleaner energy, create tens-of thousands of jobs, and rejuvenate depressed U.S. regions. Spent 12 years developing method of harvesting hard-to-get gas out of shale formations; turning impoverished landowners into millionaires overnight as property over shale spikes in value. Son of Greek immigrants started Mitchell Energy & Development in 1946. Struck it rich in north Texas gas field. Sold out to Devon Energy for $3.5 billion in cash and stock 2001. Owns real estate: hotels in Galveston, Tex.; Bald Head Island, N.C. Gives big to alma mater Texas A&M; donated $35 million in 2006.

name: Billionaires
bio: South African-born member of legendary professional investing team at BT Funds Management in 1980s. Left to set up his own Platinum Asset Management, with backing from George Soros, in 1993. The now $16 billion (funds under management) Platinum manages long-short equity portfolios that tend to outperform bear markets. The group's flagship International Fund was up 18% in fiscal 2009, compared to 16% fall in MSCI World Index. He and his wife, Judith, opened an art gallery in Sydney to showcase Chinese contemporary art in August 2009.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sold off remaining 25% stake in oil company Rompetrol, to Kazakhstan's state-owned energy operator, KazMunaiGaz, which had purchased initial 75% stake in 2007. Onetime architect is now pursuing real estate, media and energy deals. Over past year won 2 licenses to explore for oil and metals in Black Sea; in January got patent for a method of mining and processing seabed sediment. Owns Adevarul Holding media trust, which publishes Forbes Romania under license from Forbes Media LLC. Patriuciu and several other former Rompetrol executives were involved in a scandal related to a promised investment to the Petromidia refinery.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chile's newly elected president. First time a conservative has been elected in Chile since 1958; won in a runoff. Credit card pioneer founded credit card Bancard. Later amassed 26% stake in Chile's national airline, LAN, worth a recent $1.5 billion. Has vowed to sell his stake by March 11, 2010, inauguration day.  Placed another  $400 million worth of investments in a blind trust. Also  has interests in one of the country's most popular football teams, music company Blanco y Negro and TV channel Chilevision.  Earned a doctorate in economics at Harvard before returning to Chile.

name: Billionaires
bio: Semiretired investment guru scored $27 million tax victory last fall after proving he spent more than half of 2000 outside New York City. North Carolina native took first job at Kidder, Peabody. Tapped to run firm's money management arm 1974. Founded Tiger Management 1980. Assets soared to $22 billion in 1998. Averaged 31.5% a year net of fees until tech bubble inflicted huge losses, prompted him to return money to investors. Large swath of his fortune invested with the "Tiger Cubs"--crop of highly successful hedge fund managers he mentored. Said to have returned 150% on his $200 million personal trading account in 2008. Owns vineyards, golf courses in New Zealand.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandson of visionary oil baron John D. Rockefeller now working to give away his fortune. Key beneficiaries: New York's Museum of Modern Art, Rockefeller University, Harvard, Americas Society, Council on Foreign Relations. Grandfather turned $4,000 in oil refining into Standard Oil, energy giant that fueled American industrial revolution. Company broken up in landmark antitrust case 1911. Father invested in real estate. Has collected modern and contemporary art for more than 70 years; parents helped establish MoMA. Insect enthusiast has one of largest beetle collections in world.

name: Billionaires
bio: Widow of Stefan Schorghuber who died unexpectedly in November 2008 at age 47.   The mother of three who worked for several years alongside her husband in the group's hotel, ski lift and golf segments, has taken her husband's place as head of the group's supervisory board. She oversees a fortune that includes breweries, real estate, construction and services.  Family is well-known in Munich for its support of modern art and its subsidized holidays for underprivileged children and their families.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fourth-generation banker continues as a nonexecutive director of his family's financial-services company, Schroders. Shares of Schroders up more than 60% since last February. Brother-in-law George Mallinckrodt is a longtime company director; nephew Philip Mallinckrodt promoted to board in December 2008. In spare time flies planes and breeds Middle White pigs at his estate in Islay, Scotland.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cochairs Natura Cosmeticos, a Brazilian version of Avon, which he founded in 1969. Its "consultants" sell Natura's cosmetics across Brazil and 7 other Latin American countries. With fellow billionaire and cochairman Guilherme Peirao Leal sold several millions of shares in secondary stock offering last July. Media-shy Seabra reported to live in London.

name: Billionaires
bio: Made $350 million selling stake in Bentoel to British American Tobacco last June. Sold interest in cell phone company, Excelcomindo Pratama, for more than $400 million in 2007. Biggest holding now is stake in cementmaker Semen Gresik. His Rajawali Group also has interests in hotels, mining, plantations. Group made a $20.5 million gift to Harvard in January to fund new Institute for Asia and a new Indonesia program.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former Minnesota state senator's first job: napkin stamper at Carlson Wedding Service. Bought majority interest from owner Bill Carlson 1975, founded Taylor Corp. These days sales eroding as consumers shift to electronic greetings. Invested in agribusiness on Iowa and Minnesota farmland; sells liquefied, pasteurized eggs to food companies and restaurants. Planning to earn millions more while finding a permanent solution to hearing loss. Recently invested in Envoy, a microdevice implanted deep within ear. Majority owner of pro basketball's Minnesota Timberwolves; looking to bring in experienced free agent to lead team's youth.

name: Billionaires
bio: Norwegian real estate magnate bought his first building in 1951 and opened his first restaurant in 1966. Now his Olav Thon Gruppen, the country's largest private real estate company by market cap, owns 420 properties in Norway and 25 abroad. The portfolio includes 61 shopping malls as well as office buildings, retail stores, hotels (7,000 rooms) and several Oslo restaurants and pubs. While retail portfolio has strengthened this past year, cash flow from hotels is weaker.

name: Billionaires
bio: First appeared in Forbes' ranks at age 8 but officially inherited fortune in June 2001 on his 18th birthday.  Went to high school in Rome; in June 2008 received an M.A. in economics and theology from the University of Edinburgh in Scotland. But hardly needs to earn his keep.  Assets include real estate, art and a tech company and  30,000 hectares of woodland in Germany, one of the largest forest holdings in Europe.  Despite local opposition  is apparently going ahead with plans to build   one of the world's largest solar farm in Bavaria, southern Germany, and sell electricity.  Lives in family castle,  Schloss Emmeram.  Eligible bachelor is also a race car driver; tours with a German auto-racing league.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mall magnate who introduced indoor snow skiing and big-box supermarkets to Dubai consumers presides over retail property empire stretching from Egypt to Iran. Assumed control of family's mall assets in 2000 after splitting from billionaire brother Abdulla. Dubai's reputation for glitz and consumerism wearing thin in postbubble climate but falling property values, retail occupancy rates not slowing group's expansion plans: in November announced plans to spend $4 billion to double retail presence in the Middle East. Operator of Carrefour brand hypermarkets in the region; recently opened Iran's first Western-style supermarket, under name Hyperstar, in Tehran.

name: Billionaires
bio: Together with siblings, Luciano, Giuliana and Gilberto, formed Benetton Group in 1965; now a $2.7 billion (sales) clothing company, which sells brands like United Colors of Benetton, Sisley. Stock down 35% since last year as retail sales suffer in the recession. Is also deputy chair of Edizione SRL, the family holding company that owns stakes in Atlantia, one of the world's largest toll-road companies, and Autogrill restaurants, which serve customers on highways and in airports around the world; stocks up 45% and 90% respectively since last February.

name: Billionaires
bio: Together with siblings Luciano, Giuliana and Carlo, formed Benetton Group in 1965. The $2.7 billion (sales) clothing company sells brands like United Colors of Benetton, Sisley; stock down 35% since last year as retail sales suffer in the recession. Chairs Edizione SRL, the family holding company that owns stakes in Atlantia, one of the world's largest toll-road companies, and Autogrill restaurants, which serve customers on highways and in airports around the world; stocks up 45% and 90% respectively since last February. Created La Ghirada, an indoor-outdoor sports complex for basketball, volleyball and rugby in Treviso, Italy. Makes investments via personal holding company Regia SRL.

name: Billionaires
bio: In 1965 formed Benetton Group with siblings: Luciano, Carlo and Gilberto. The $2.7 billion (sales) clothing company sells brands like United Colors of Benetton, Sisley; stock down 35% since last year as retail sales suffer in the recession. Edizione, the family holding company, owns stakes in Atlantia, one of the world's largest toll-road companies, and Autogrill restaurants, which serve customers on highways and in airports around the world; stocks up 45% and 90% respectively since last February. Giuliana originally knitted sweaters that brother Luciano would then peddle by bicycle; sold under a variety of labels before becoming United Colors of Benetton.

name: Billionaires
bio: Together with siblings Carlo, Giuliana and Gilberto, formed Benetton Group in 1965. After running it for 40 years, now chairman of the $2.9 billion (sales) clothing company, which sells brands like United Colors of Benetton, Sisley; stock down 35% since last year as retail sales suffer in the recession. The family also owns a large chunk of Atlantia, one of the world's largest toll-road companies, and Autogrill restaurants, which serve customers on highways and in airports around the world; stocks up 45% and 90% respectively since last February.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chief executive and chairman of Charoen Pokphand Group, one of world's largest agribusinesses and food producers with operations throughout Asia, including China, India and Indonesia; has new feed mill in Russia. Operates Thailand's over 5,300 7-Eleven stores. His father opened a small seed shop in Bangkok to import seeds from China to Thai farmers 8 decades ago. Dhanin, the youngest of four brothers, became general manager at age 25 and took over as chairman at age 50. He and his other 3 brothers each own 13% of group; Dhanin's net worth only reflects his shares plus his own holdings in China's agriculture, food, retailing and property development. Owns homes in Thailand, China and 1 in Houston in the U.S. Philanthropist restores Buddhist temples in Thailand, sponsors schools and orphanages.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairs Huabao International, which makes tobacco flavorings for China's top cigarette makers; also makes fragrances and food flavorings for use in detergents, beverages, dairy products and cosmetics. Founded the company a decade ago and took it public through a reverse takeover. Sold chunk of shares in 2008 and again in October 2009; still owns 51% of its shares. Holds several leadership positions in local industry groups.

name: Billionaires
bio: Commodities keeping Dangote afloat despite Nigeria's financial meltdown. Stocks of his sugar and flour companies are both up in the past year. Meanwhile, stake in Benue Cement has doubled, helped by demand from China. Dangote now expanding cement operations in Senegal and Zambia. Overcame negative reports about debts owned to banks and share price fixing allegations to become the newly installed President of the Nigerian Stock Exchange last August. Settled row with businessman Femi Otedola, who fell off the billionaires list this year. Dangote began career as trader; built his Dangote Group into conglomerate with interests in sugar, flour milling, salt processing, cement manufacturing, textiles, real estate, and oil and gas.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandson of steel tycoon John Hillman Jr., owner of Pittsburgh Coke & Chemical. Diversified family fortune via Hillman Co: real estate, venture capital, private equity. Early backer of venture capital monster Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, LBO titans Kohlberg Kravis Roberts; co-owner of downtown Pittsburgh's PPG Place. Philanthropist gives via various family foundations to U. of Pittsburgh, cancer research. Shuns publicity: "A whale is harpooned only when it spouts."

name: Billionaires
bio: Completed sale of pro football's Miami Dolphins to real estate tycoon Stephen Ross in February 2009. Price tag: $1.1 billion, 7 times what he paid for the team in 1994. Still owns 5% of the rebounding squad. Son of residential housing contractor bought garbage trucks; founded trash titan WMX 1968. Left 1984. Bought stake in small video-rental chain Blockbuster 3 years later; company sold to Viacom for $8.4 billion 1994. Now diversified: bonds, real estate, AutoNation, Republic Services, private jets, plush Gary Player-designed golf course.

name: Billionaires
