bio: Sudanese-born "Mo" founded Celtel, a mobile phone company that now serves 23 countries in Africa and the Middle East. Sold it in 2005 for $3.4 billion; pocketed $1.4 billion. The London resident now spends his time on philanthropy and investing in Africa. Created Mo Ibrahim Foundation to award monetary prize to former African heads of state who have shown exemplary leadership in such areas as promoting political freedom; panel of judges decided not to award prize in 2009.

name: Billionaires
bio: Recession isn't dirtying up Johnson family fortune as consumers continue to buy their household staples: Windex, Pledge, Ziploc. Son of Samuel Curtis Johnson (d. 2004), great-grandson of former salesman who started wax company 1886. Expanded to industrial cleaning, banking, camping supplies. Fisk heads S.C. Johnson. Going green despite manufacturing more than 100 chemical-heavy products; Racine factory powered by methane gas from nearby dump, wind turbine helps run Dutch plant.

name: Billionaires
bio: Recession isn't dirtying up Johnson family fortune as consumers continue to buy their household staples: Windex, Pledge, Ziploc. Widow of Samuel Curtis Johnson (d. 2004), great-grandson of former salesman who started wax company 1886. Expanded to industrial cleaning, banking, camping supplies.

name: Billionaires
bio: Recession isn't dirtying up Johnson family fortune as consumers continue to buy their household staples: Windex, Pledge, Ziploc. Son of Samuel Curtis Johnson (d. 2004), great-grandson of former salesman who started wax company 1886. Expanded to industrial cleaning, banking, camping supplies. Runs industrial cleaning outfit JohnsonDiversey.

name: Billionaires
bio: Daughter of Samuel Curtis Johnson (d. 2004), great-grandson of salesman who started wax company 1886. Diversified into industrial cleaning, banking and camping supplies. Kids each attended Sam's alma mater, Cornell, before joining company. Helen runs Johnson Financial and Johnson Outdoors; publicly traded camping and military supplier shares up 120% in past 12 months. Company crusading for environment despite making more than 100 chemical-heavy products; manufacturing plant fueled with power drawn from methane gas from nearby garbage dump.

name: Billionaires
bio: Daughter of Samuel Curtis Johnson (d. 2004), great-grandson of salesman who started wax company 1886. Diversified into industrial cleaning, banking and camping supplies. Winnie oversees family foundation. Company crusading for environment despite making more than 100 chemical-heavy products; manufacturing plant fueled with power drawn from methane gas from nearby garbage dump.

name: Billionaires
bio: Poland's richest man back on the billionaires list; last appeared in 2006. Banking on energy: his Agrogaz growing its biogas capacity to process farm waste and waste from food processing plants. In joint venture with Libya's Tamoil to reportedly bid on Polish refiner Lotos; planning to list his Kulczyk Oil Venture on Warsaw Stock Exchange in first quarter. Also investing in Ukraine's energy sector, including wind power. In early 1990s won a government contract to deliver cars for Poland's police and Office of State Protection.  In 1993 he bought a stake in a previously state-owned brewery for $10 million; leveraged into stakes in energy and financial services firms. After tumultuous parliamentary hearings about his role in the sale of Poland's oil giant Orlen, which included allegations of meeting a Russian spy, Kulczyk's reputation and business suffered. Kulczyk denied the allegations and decided to make holdings more transparent to avoid further accusations of shady dealings. Sold off stakes in telecom, insurance and oil interests. Forced to give up part of his fortune in 2007 divorce from wife.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cochairs Natura Cosmeticos, a Brazilian version of Avon. Helped Natura founder (and fellow Brazilian billionaire) Luiz Seabra build cosmetics business into multinational company, with consultants selling makeup and creams across Brazil and 7 other Latin American countries. With Seabra sold several millions of shares in secondary stock offering last July. Reportedly signed up to join Green Party, or PV, in time for election year. Personally promotes biodiversity and sustainable business practices. Pushed a product line that uses renewable ingredients from the Brazilian rain forest. He is also an active board member of nonprofit groups, and has worked with the World Wildlife Fund of Brazil.

name: Billionaires
bio: Older brother Sudhir joined his father's pharma business in the 1970s and pushed for the diversification into energy. Built it partly through acquisition of 2 state-owned utilities. Today family's most valuable asset is a 53% stake in Torrent Power, which distributes to more than 2 million customers annually; its stock has jumped four-fold this year. Samir joined the Torrent Group in 1980s when he was 22. He is more focused on the pharma side, which makes bulk drugs and formulations sold in 50 countries. Samir plays tennis. Sudhir is a cricket fan.

name: Billionaires
bio: The world's first ethanol billionaire returns to billionaire ranks. With family, Ometto controls Cosan S.A., one of the world's largest growers and processors of sugarcane, also one of the largest producers of ethanol and one of Brazil's key fuel distributors. Cosan listed its shares on Brazilian stock exchange in 2005. The company's origins date from 1936, when the Ometto family established a sugarcane mill. Cosan has grown since 2000 through acquisitions and new partnerships. Bought Esso's assets from ExxonMobil in 2008.

name: Billionaires
bio: Television tycoon made bulk of fortune selling Spanish-language broadcaster Univision for $13.7 billion in 2007 to a group led by Haim Saban. Onetime talent agent represented Marlon Brando, Elizabeth Taylor. Formed Embassy Communications with All in the Family producer Norman Lear, sold to Coca-Cola for $485 million 1985. Plowed proceeds into TV; with partners, bought Univision from Hallmark for $550 million in 1992. Longtime Republican donor helped bankroll last year's victory parade for basketball's L.A. Lakers after team won NBA championship.
title: Founder & Owner

name: Billionaires
bio: Head of the Dogus Holding conglomerate founded by his father; best known for its media interests like CNBC-e, Vogue Turkey etc, which altogether have 10% of country's ad market. Harvard Business School case study documents his challenges in taking over his father's traditionally managed company. Bankrolled "Gallipoli" movie about seminal Turkish military battle against the Allied offensive.

name: Billionaires
bio: Prized property, The Plaza, not immune to New York City's real estate downturn. Struggling to sell condos, struggling to find luxury store shoppers. Hotel occupancy reportedly at 90%. Plans to build a Plaza-themed megacasino in Vegas also turned sour: Tshuva's plot on the Strip is now worth less than half the $1.25 billion he and partner Nochi Dankner paid for it in 2007. Yet shares of his publicly traded Delek Group, which operates 232 gas stations and has interests in insurance, car dealerships and cable television in Israel, are up by more than 100%.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of his family's Yildiz Holding. Completed $850 million purchase of Godiva from Campbell Soup Co. last year; expanding into new products and markets in 2009. Owns candy and biscuit factories in Uzbekistan, Ukraine, Saudi Arabia, Kazakhstan, Algeria and Romania. Cut teeth working at his father's Ulker Food Co. and at Continental Baking Co. in the U.S. before joining Yildiz. Fluent in English and German, enjoys sailing, hunting and travel.

name: Billionaires
bio: Finalized $23 billion sale of family's gum operation to privately held candy giant Mars in 2008; combined company is now the largest confectioner in the world. Wrigley Co. founded 1891 by great-grandfather (d. 1932), who moved from Philadelphia to Chicago to sell soap, then baking powder. Introduced first spearmint chewables 1893; sent 4 sticks of gum to every person in U.S. with listed phone number 1915. Fourth-generation Wrigley took over 1999.
title: Director

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Agaoglu Group, a builder of hotels, resorts, and ski lodges in Turkey; also one of Turkey's biggest housing providers. Even during 2009 downturn, was moving ahead with plans to eventually build 24,000 houses in four projects in Istanbul. Passionate about luxury cars, has a Lamborghini, two Bentleys and a Ferrari California.

name: Billionaires
bio: With brothers, controls one of country's largest private oil outfits. Father, Perry, inherited family fortune created by oil baron uncle Sid Richardson 1959. Passed on to eldest son, Sid, 1968. Bass Enterprises Production planning deepwater exploration off Nova Scotia. Sold one division to Southern Union for $1.6 billion 2005. Lee invests with Sid; billions of dollars in Cayman Islands investment accounts.

name: Billionaires
bio: With brothers, controls one of country's largest private oil outfits. Father, Perry, inherited family fortune created by oil baron uncle Sid Richardson 1959. Passed on to eldest son, Sid, 1968. Bass Enterprises Production planning deepwater exploration off Nova Scotia. Sold one division to Southern Union for $1.6 billion 2005. With help from Stanford classmate Richard Rainwater turned millions of oil inheritance into billions in the stock market. Big bet on Disney 1990s.

name: Billionaires
bio: Along with brother, Edgar Sr., inherited Seagram spirits empire that was built up by their father, Sam, and sold to Vivendi in 2000. Major philanthropist co-wrote book published Nov. 2009 entitled, "The Art of Giving: Where the Soul Meets a Business Plan." His Andrea & Charles Bronfman Philanthropies annually gives $15 million to a host of causes. Helped found Birthright Israel, which sends Jewish youths from North America on educational tours of Israel. Started the Andy Prize in memory of his late wife, Andrea, who was killed by a taxi while walking their dog near their Manhattan apartment in January 2006; prize awarded annually to an Israeli decorative artist for excellence in ceramics, jewelry, textile or glass.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded Environmental Systems Research Institute in 1969 with wife, Laura. Today ESRI is the world's largest mapping software company; tracks stimulus money in some states. Son of a gardener grew up in Redlands, studied environmental science at Cal State Polytechnic, urban planning at U. of Minnesota, landscape architecture at Harvard. Started ESRI with $1,100 of family savings. Goal: use computers to aid environmental planning. Today outfit provides geographic-information software to 350,000 customers, including federal agencies, health departments in all 50 states, Centers for Disease Control & Prevention.

name: Billionaires
bio: Media baron first struck it rich as a founding investor in production company Endemol, associated with such reality TV hits as Deal or No Deal, Fear Factor and Big Brother. Endemol was sold to Spanish telecom giant Telefonica in 2000. Three years ago, bought back into Endemol, picking up a 5% stake. Holds stake in  RDF Media, which produces Wife Swap;  and  RTL Netherlands.  Concentrating his energy these days on developing  TV and multimedia shows via Talpa Media.  Some of its creations:  Battle of the Choirs;  also quiz shows Pretty Smart, Dating in the Dark  and Know your Nation.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandfather John T. Dorrance was a chemical engineer who discovered way to can condensed soup using half as much water, cutting costs by a third. Campbell Soup sales in fiscal year 2009: $7.6 billion. Stock up 8% in last year. Owns other familiar brands: Pace (salsa), V8 (vegetable juice), Pepperidge Farm (cookies, Goldfish), Swanson (broth). Managing director of DMB Associates, Arizona real estate firm.

name: Billionaires
bio: Has a firm lock on his wealth. Major shareholder of Investments AB Latour, which holds stakes in Assa Abloy, world's largest producer of locks; Securitas AB, one of largest publicly traded security companies; and Fagerhult AB, a Swedish maker of light fixtures. A member of the Swedish nobility (a count), his family is of Scottish origin.

name: Billionaires
bio: Harvard hockey star turned pro in Europe. Sidelined by leg injury; took job at Kidder, Peabody & Co. Gigs in junk bond departments at Wachovia, Barclays. Attempted botched buyout 1990. Target: Newark plasticsmaker AAB Manufacturing. Collapse of deal "had a profound impact upon my success as a hedge fund manager." Founded Harbinger Capital 2001 with $25 million. Returned 125% 2007 betting against subprime. Assets peaked at $26 billion in 2008. Today Harbinger manages $8 billion. Main fund lost 25% 2008; gained 46.6% last year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Merged his staffing company French Ecco with Klaus Jacobs' Swiss Adia in 1996 to create Adecco. Now one of world's largest employment agencies, with $28 billion in sales. Per Swiss law, stepped down as co-chairman of Adecco in 2005 at age 73 and is now honorary president. Keeps busy on the boards of Akila Finance and security systems provider Securitas. Lives as a tax exile in London. Partner Klaus Jacobs died in September 2008.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mining mogul flourishing. In October signed $4 billion deal with Mongolia to mine copper and gold at rich Oyu Tolgoi sight. Shares of his Ivanhoe Mining up 300% since last February. Chicago native attended Reed College in Oregon; studied Sanskrit, Buddhism in India after graduating. Made first fortune stumbling on large nickel deposit at Voisey's Bay in Canada; sold nickel-rich property to Inco for $3.1 billion 1996. Sold Ivanhoe Energy's U.S. oil and gas operations to Seneca Resources Corporation for $40 million last July.
title: Founder and Executive Co-Chairman
employment: {'name': 'Ivanhoe Energy Inc.', 'title': 'Founder and Executive Co-Chairman', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of J. Paul Getty Sr. (d. 1976), one of the greatest industrialists in American history. Sold Getty Oil to Texaco for $10 billion in 1986; plowed proceeds into investments, wine. Seeded mutual fund servicing outfit ReFlow Management 2002; stake in investment firm Forward Management. Investor in San Francisco Mayor Gavin Newsom's Napa Valley wine, hospitality business PlumpJack Group. Music lover, opera composer canceled lavish 75th birthday party in February "out of consideration for those affected by the economy."
title: President and Chairman
employment: {'name': 'Ann & Gordon Getty Foundation', 'title': 'President and Chairman', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Became a billionaire shorting subprime credit 2007. Fled to cash; currently taking advantage of low rates by refinancing real estate holdings. Purchased $24 million Palm Beach mansion from billionaire Malcolm Glazer in December. Worked telemarketing gig selling circus tickets while studying at Johns Hopkins U.; saved up $100,000 by eating at Pizza Hut buffet, living out of car. Invested in Boston real estate while earning Harvard M.B.A. Moved to L.A., bought and developed apartment buildings.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of Citadel hedge fund attempting to repair his fortune after severe drubbing. Flagship fund plunged 55% in 2008 but gained 62% last year. Harvard grad founded Citadel with $4.6 million 1990. Stellar returns pushed assets to $20 billion in fall of 2008. Losses mounted as market turned: "Regretfully, I did not foresee the financial disaster that was to unfold." Now manages $12 billion. Bright spots: firm's market-making, administrative operations generated millions in profit as hedge fund performance soured. Firm's oldest fund, Wellington, has returned 16% annually net of fees since 1998.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Duke grad parlayed $200 into $10,000 playing blackjack in Vegas. M.B.A. at UCLA. Managed $10 million portfolio for Pacific Life 1970s; pioneered practice of trading bonds for profit. Fixed-income division spun off, public 1994. Sold 70% stake to Allianz AG for $3.3 billion in 1999. Now runs Pimco Total Return, world's largest mutual fund. Assets under management: $211 billion. Returns in 2009: 13.8%. Publishes monthly investment commentary focused on the economy, bonds, consumer behavior.
title: Cofounder and Co-Chief Investment Officer
employment: {'name': 'Pacific Investment Management Company LLC', 'title': 'Cofounder and Co-Chief Investment Officer', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Started Ann Arbor, Mich. tire store in 1960; today there are 750 Discount Tire stores in 22 states. Aiming to have 1,000 shops. Sales in 2008: $2.5 billion. Company is the largest independent tire retailer in world by revenues. Son Bruce Jr. is president. Collects Latin American art, old tire ad posters. Company's own advertisement is Guinness World Record holder as longest-running TV commercial; same ad has been blasted into homes for 34 years.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Along with brother, inherited drugmaker Cipla, founded by their father in 1935. India's largest pharma company by sales, Cipla is among world's biggest producers of low-cost antiretroviral drugs for AIDS. Claims that one out of every three AIDS patients under treatment in Africa is on a Cipla drug. Also makes Antiflu, a Tamiflu clone; Virenza, clone of GlaxoSmithkline's Relenza. Is in talks with big pharma firms to supply generic drugs. Raised $145 million through a private placement for expansion, including a new special economic zone in central India. Runs a palliative care center in Pune, near Mumbai, for terminally ill cancer patients. Counts renowned music conductor Zubin Mehta, former music director of New York Philharmonic, among his close buddies.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sold stake in North Dakota Bakken Shale to XTO Energy for $1.8 billion in cash and stock in 2008--right before markets crashed. Sale accounted for less than half of Headington Oil's production. Geologist father and uncle ran small oil and gas firm until 1970s. Headington played tennis at U. of Oklahoma. Founded Headington Oil in 1977. Investing in hotels in Dallas and Austin. Going Hollywood: financed Mel Gibson flick Edge of Darkness; will be released next year. Also in pipeline: Johnny Depp in The Rum Diary, and London Boulevard, starring Colin Farrell.

name: Billionaires
bio:
Took over roofing empire ABC Supply after husband and business partner, Kenneth Hendricks, died from a fall at a construction site in 2007. Today controls nation's largest roofing, window and
siding wholesale distributor. Sales: $2.9 billion. Met late husband at age 21, launched ABC together in 1982. Owns large real estate portfolio: 23 million square feet of commercial property across Midwest. Controls Hendricks Holding Company, a portfolio of businesses in wind power, manufacturing, construction, insurance, and recycling industries.
title: Cofounder and Chairman
employment: {'name': 'ABC Supply', 'title': 'Cofounder and Chairman', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Former Exxon geologist buys proven fields, uses advanced technology to boost efficiency; "Acquire & Exploit." Founded Hilcorp Energy 1989; started small, just "3 guys and a telephone." Bought out partner Thomas Hook for $500 million 2003. Loaded up on debt to make acquisitions. Today firm is the fourth-largest private oil and gas company in U.S.; pumped an estimated 21 million barrels of oil and natural gas equivalents in 2008. Donates to Houston Zoo, Contemporary Arts Museum, Houston.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fortunes of Macau and its casino king rebounding thanks to new political leadership in gambling mecca and hopes for economic recovery. Net worth also up due to better information on private holdings, particularly those held through his STDM, which bought Mandarin Oriental Hotel in Macau last year, renaming it Grand Lapa; also has real estate in China. Hospitalized briefly late last year, causing speculation about succession. In Macau, Ho serves as vice chairman of Macau International Airport, the co-chairman of the advisory committee of Seng Heng Bank and the chairman of Macau Horse Racing Co. In Hong Kong, he has been the president of the Real Estate Developers Association since 1984. Ho is honorary lifetime chairman of the University of Hong Kong Foundation for Educational Development and Research.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded Ronesans Construction in 1994 in St Petersburg, Russia. Now builds shopping malls, airports, factories, cement factories, offices, hotels, marine facilities and hydroelectric plants in seven countries all over the world, mostly in Eastern Europe and the Middle East. Has lucrative contract to build a new terminal at Adler International Airport, less than an hour drive to Soichi, Russia, site of 2014 Winter Olympics. Self-described family man spends free time reading books.

name: Billionaires
bio: Widow of Bronson Ingram became chairman of distribution conglomerate Ingram Industries after his death in 1995. Nashville company transports commodities on barges, distributes books. Merged book, print-on-demand and digital divisions last June to form Ingram Content Group; allows publishers to bind books after they are ordered, reducing excess inventory. Son David runs Ingram Entertainment, distributor of DVDs, videogames. Original barge business chaired by son Orrin; president, chief executive of Ingram Industries. Son John chairman of Ingram Industries and Ingram Content Group. Martha remains on board of directors as chairman emerita; Charleston, S.C. native, Vassar grad and performing-arts patron prominent in Nashville society.
title: Former Chairman
employment: {'name': 'Ingram Industries, Inc.', 'title': 'Former Chairman', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: King of concessions expanding reach in resorts and casinos despite declines in food services and hospitality industries. Father, Louis, started selling popcorn and peanuts in 1915; grew into massive sports concession business. Jeremy took over after dad's death; transformed Delaware North into global player in food and hospitality. On a buying binge: Holiday Inn outside Yellowstone National Park, luxury resorts in Australia. Teaming with Harrah's in attempt to develop and manage New York City's first legal racetrack casino. Other bidder: Steve Wynn. Owns pro hockey's Boston Bruins, TD Banknorth Garden, stake in lucrative New England Sports Network.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partner and fellow billionaire Henadiy Boholyubov failed to get board seat on fellow Ukrainian billionaire's Kostyantin Zhevago's iron ore company Ferrexpo last year; their purchase of ammonia plant from government annulled. With Boholyubov controls Privat group, a banking and industrial conglomerate. Began with Privatbank, which was founded with $1 million of capital in early 1990s; bank value has not yet recovered from 2008 credit crisis, which brought Ukraine to brink of collapse. Expected to receive at least $100 million from dividend payout from oil concern Ukrnafafta. Separately, bought Ukrainian assets of U.S. billionaire Ronald Lauder's Central European Media Enterprises Ltd. for $300 million in January; some analysts posit he overpaid.

name: Billionaires
bio: With younger sister Alicia, also a billionaire, inherited Fomento de Construcciones y Contratas from late father. Their husbands ran FCC from the early 1970s until 1989, when both marriages ended. The  sisters took over and ran operations jointly  until 1997 when Esther bought her sister's stake for $800 million. Now owns 45% of $19.5 billion (sales) FCC; sits on its supervisory board.  Also sits on board of Cementos Portland Valderrivas and  Veolia Environnement.  Holds the Gold Cross for Social Solidarity for her social work; her Esther Koplowitz foundation, which supports and houses the mentally and physically impaired, has doled out more than $95 million to date.   A member of Spanish nobility, holds the title of Marquesa  de Casa Penalver. She is married to Fernando Falco, Marques de Cubas, scion of an old Spanish family.  Apparently loves ballet and classical music.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former intelligence officer, banker and, from 2003 to 2007, member of Russia's lower house. This year sold his stake in the Russian national carrier Aeroflot; his airline Blue Wing, based in Germany, filed for bankruptcy. The vociferous critic of the Russian authorities ran for mayor of Sochi, which will host the 2014 Winter Olympics; lost to Putin's United Russia party candidate. Owns Novaya Gazeta, Russia's leading opposition newspaper; bought London's Evening Standard for 1 pound. Appointed his son Evgeny, a London socialite, senior executive director of the paper. He is expected to close a deal shortly to buy the UK's The Independent from Independent News and Media.

name: Billionaires
bio: Net worth of Lee & Man Paper's founder, which dropped from $3.2 billion to $485 million last year, has quadrupled as stock recovered strongly. Group's delayed Vietnam expansion apparently back on track. Horse-racing fan has been generous with the less well off, serving as honorary principal of the Qionghai Jiaji Secondary School and Hainan Guoxing Secondary School in China. He has also been awarded honorary citizenship of Dongguan. Day-to-day operations of Lee & Man are in the hands of eldest son Raymond.  Younger son Lee Man Bun is also on the board,  overseeing manufacturing.

name: Billionaires
bio: Developer of prominent Taipei office and commercial buildings such as Hong Tai Center. Lin's Hong Tai Group also invests in financial services, including Capital Securities. Brother Lin Rong San also a billionaire.

name: Billionaires
bio: Famous for revolutionizing junk bond market, enabling spree of leveraged buyouts in the 1980s. Made $550 million in salary and bonus in 1987. Financed the deals that made many of The Forbes 400 rich: Henry Kravis (RJR Nabisco), Carl Icahn (TWA), Ronald Perelman (Revlon), Ted Turner (CNN, Turner Broadcasting). Spent 22 months in jail after pleading guilty to 6 counts of securities fraud in 1990. Cofounded education and teaching curricula company Knowledge Universe with brother Lowell in 1996; pulled bid for ABC Learning Centres last year. Also owns stake in online education outfit K12. Chairs Milken Institute; issued weight loss challenge to Americans to cut health care expenses in 2007. Generous donations to fight cancer, other diseases.

name: Billionaires
bio: Heads Nidec, maker of micromotors used in DVDs, hard drives, robots, game consoles. Business has rebounded thanks to strong demand for Nidec's automotive motors; also developing motors for electric cars. Pay cuts during downturn have been eliminated and wages restored. Nagamori expects workers to clean their offices and factories. Opened sales office in Shenzhen in October. Company sponsored Japan speed-skating team at 2010 Winter Olympics in Vancouver; apparently paid bonuses to country's medal winners.

name: Billionaires
bio: Eldest son of late Greek shipping magnate, Stavros Niarchos, inherited father's art collection of such masterpieces as Vincent van Gogh's "Self-Portrait with a Bandaged Ear" and Pablo Picasso's self-portrait  "Yo, Picasso."  Philip, who is a board member of the Museum of Modern Art, has added such contemporary works as Jean-Michel Basquiat's "Self-Portrait" and Andy Warhol's "Shot Red Marilyn." Commissioned to do Philip's portrait, Warhol created a series based on CAT-scans of Philip's skull. While Philip is intensely private, multiple art experts pinned his collection as world's most valuable in private hands.

name: Billionaires
bio: Earned fortune building up energy conglomerate Perez Companc, which he sold to Petrobras for $1 billion in 2002. Now has big stake in food giant Molinos Rio de la Plata, diversified maker of pasta, flour and frozen vegetables. Spending $15 million to build a meat-processing plant. At wife Maria Carmen's urging, launched ice cream parlor chain Munchi's.  Established the Bioparque Temaiken, a nature and wildlife preserve outside of Buenos Aires.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of a Greek immigrant met Stephen Schwarzman at Lehman Brothers; duo left to create private equity outfit Blackstone 1985. Total assets then: $400,000. Added real estate, hedge fund, financial advisory divisions. Firm now manages $98.2 billion. Retired rich: received a $1.85 billion wire transfer when Blackstone went public 2 years ago; has committed most of his cash to his new foundation.  Published his memoirs last year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of a stud farm-owner, his Serum Institute of India is among the world's cheapest producers of vaccines. Claims that two-thirds of the world's children in 140 countries have been immunized by Serum, which supplies to global bodies such as UNICEF. The privately-owned firm is one of four Indian vaccine-makers racing to develop a swine-flu vaccine; expects to launch this year. Also has minority stake in rival Panacea Biotec and Orchid Chemicals, maker of generic antibiotics. Family still breeds racehorses at their stud farm in Pune. Recently gave up his long-time chairmanship of the Turf Authorities of India, saying he wants to concentrate on his vaccines business.

name: Billionaires
bio: Built on real estate inheritance to create conglomerate with interests in automotive and industrial batteries, petrochemicals, cement, ceramic tiles, retailing and media. Listed firm Prism Cement, which is expanding capacity, has a joint venture with Australia's QBE in general insurance. He's also a partner of hotelier Prithvi Raj Singh Oberoi, together owning 75% in EIH Associated Hotels. Group recently took cable distribution arm Hathway Cable & Datacom public, raising  $143 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Treatmaker's fortune staying sweet despite sour recession: no layoffs, bonuses continue. Recently bought out part of brother David's stake in Rich Products; now owns more than 70% of company. Father, Robert Sr., parlayed soy-based whipped cream, nondairy coffee creamer into frozen-food empire. Bob Jr. became president of firm 1978. Today company makes more than 2,000 food products: toppings, desserts, pizzas, breads. Sales: $2.8 billion. Hollywood making movie out of his memoir, Fish Fights: A Hall of Fame Quest. Owns Buffalo Bisons minor league baseball team; squad is New York Mets Triple-A team.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sole heir to once deeply troubled estate left by late father. Battled for 14 years to win control of his assets from her stepmother. Legal hurdles cleared in 2003 in time to catch boom in iron ore demand. In late 2007, after decades of promise, Rinehart's family company, Hancock Prospecting, shipped its first ton of iron ore as part of a joint venture with mining giant Rio Tinto. Rival miner Cazaly Resources and fellow billionaire Andrew Forrest are reportedly still teaming up in effort to wrest rights held by Rio Tinto and Hancock to iron ore deposit Rhodes Ridge. Claim Rinehart team failed to develop site under Australia's "use it or lose it" clause. Also has her sights on mining manganese.
title: Executive Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Casino mogul reinvesting in Sin City on the cheap. Sold New Frontier Hotel & Casino for $1.2 billion in 2007 to El-Ad Group (owners of Manhattan's Plaza Hotel). Vegas casinos quickly hammered by recession; paid MGM Mirage $775 million for Treasure Island casino resort late 2008. College dropout flipped burgers for a living. Made initial fortune investing in oil, real estate. Built 64-story Trump International Hotel & Tower with Donald Trump 2005, duo split $500 million. Married to Aleksandra Nikolaenko; former Miss Ukraine appeared in 2004 Miss Universe contest. Two-time winner of the Forbes 400 charity poker tournament lost to billionaires John Catsimatidis and Steven Schonfeld in third annual even t

name: Billionaires
bio: Fashionable sister of fellow billionaire Ferit Sahenk, who runs family's Dogus Holding. Now handles the group's retail partnerships with luxury brands Tod's and Armani. Advocate of women's leadership and one of Turkey's top 100 taxpayers is also president of Ayhan Sahenk Foundation, which sponsors three-day annual international mountain bike festival in Turkey's Cappadoccia region. Also active in the International Myeloma Foundation. Has a large antique collection.

name: Billionaires
bio: His digital television platform Cyfrowy Polsat continues to do well, stock up over 10% since last year. Committed to industry, as opposed to expanding investments in other sectors; investing in internet platform which transmits sports events and popular TV shows. Controls Polsat, now one of the nation's biggest television stations. Also owns shares in Invest Bank, pension fund PTE Polsat, pharmaceutical Bioton and TV producer ATM Grupa. Shares in Elektrim challenged in court; company has declared bankruptcy. Began importing cars from the then East Germany in the 1980s; moved into media in 1992.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairs Geneva-headquartered Steinmetz Diamond Group, which he inherited from his father. The company is De Beers' largest buyer of rough diamonds; diamond sales beginning to rebound with the market. His real estate holdings in Kazakhstan, Russia and eastern Europe remain down as buyers dry up. Worth of mining assets, including privately held Cunico and publicly traded Katanga Mining, not yet recovered from slower diamond demand. With wife, oversees the Beny & Agnes Steinmetz Foundation, which donates to schools, hospitals, army units and the arts.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman and founder of Unicharm, maker of diapers, sanitary napkins and other personal-care goods. Son, Takahisa, group's chief executive is boosting pet food business to offset slowing sales of main products in aging Japan. Moving into other parts of Asia, including Indonesia, Korea, Taiwan, Thailand, Vietnam and China. Is also building a diaper plant in Egypt and operates subsidiaries in Russia and India.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder and chairman of Belle International, China's largest retailer of women's shoes with about 7,000 stores. Its Hong Kong-traded shares tripled in the past year on strong consumer spending. Tang and other executives sold some shares in December. Shares fortune with daughter Tang Ming Wai, group's executive director, to whom he lately transferred more shares.  Tang serves as the chairman of the Federation of Hong Kong Footwear.

name: Billionaires
bio: Yes, the Donald is a billionaire. No, he's not worth what he says he is: "My brand alone is worth $5 billion." Son of Brooklyn developer invaded Manhattan mid-1970s, borrowed heavily, talked tough, built big, got rich. Nearly lost it all in 1990 real estate crash. Learned lesson; claims he tries not to personally guarantee loans. Prized New York City properties: Trump Tower, 40 Wall Street, 1260 Avenue of the Americas. Today several Trump buildings are erected by other developers who pay him a hefty licensing fee to use his name; reaps big money only after buildings are completed, apartments sold. Recent duds: Dubai, Tampa, New Orleans. Has earned more than $100 million in salary, royalties since The Apprentice debuted on NBC 2003. Battling billionaire investor Carl Icahn over control of bankrupt Trump Entertainment Resorts. Last year won zoning rights to develop 2,000 acres of land in Scotland into golf resort; still squabbling with locals over 50 acres.
title: Entrepreneur, Personality

name: Billionaires
bio: Tech visionary, early backer of Google: his initial $100,000 investment is now worth over $1.7 billion.  A cofounder of Sun Microsystems; an inventor of Cisco Systems's switching business. Cofounded and ran Kealia, a computer design system that he sold to Sun in 2004.  Left Sun Microsystems in 1995, returning in 2004 as senior vice president and chief architect. In October 2009 resigned from Sun (now a part of Oracle) to become chairman and chief development officer of Arista networks, a tech outfit that will compete against network equipment maker Cisco Systems. Project reunites him with Canadian billionaire, David Cheriton, co-founder and chief scientist of the venture. The pair's previous project, Granite Systems, was sold to Cisco in 1996.  Also has stake in chip-designing-software maker Magma Design Automation.

name: Billionaires
bio: Daughter of late Taiwan billionaire Y.C., cofounded HTC with her husband in 1997. It makes mobile phones using Microsoft software; now also Google. Transitioning from contract manufacturer to purveyor of own brand. HTC recently hit with patent infringement suit by Apple. With husband, Chen, runs semiconductor firm Via Technologies.

name: Billionaires
bio: Beijing property developer. She and husband, Pan Shiyi, who are Soho China's chief executive and chairman, respectively, are one of China's best-known business couples, renowned for their stylish buildings. Firm paid $360 million for its first Shanghai property in August, an office tower in the city's upscale Jing'an district that had belonged to U.S. investment bank Morgan Stanley. In September, bought land back in Beijing's Chaoyang district for $590 million and two months later picked up a 37-story building, called the Nexus center, also in Beijing. Born in Beijing, Zhang moved to Hong Kong at age 14. She later got a masters degree in development economics from Cambridge University in 1992. Got start at international firms Goldman Sachs, Travelers Group. Started Soho with husband in 1995. Pan who writes a popular blog transferred his shares to her in 2005; company listed in 2007.
title: Cofounder, CEO
employment: {'name': 'Soho China Ltd.', 'uri': 'companies/soho-china', 'title': 'Cofounder, CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Studied law at Harvard, worked in Justice Department's Civil Rights Division. Met James Coulter while working for Robert Bass. Duo left to pursue first deal together: salvaged Continental Airlines with $66 million investment, stake worth $700 million 5 years later. Started Texas Pacific Group 1992. Highlights: Burger King, J.Crew, Petco. With affiliates TPG now manages $45 billion.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fifth generation of family to run $7.8 billion (revenues) Globus & Co., one of Germany's largest food retailers. Also operate 83 hardware stores and nine electrical appliance stores. Great great grandfather, Franz Bruch, opened first store in 1828. Thomas Bruch took over from his father in 1979.  With Bruch's three sons working at firm, continued family stewardship seems assured.

name: Billionaires
bio: Studied accounting at USC; joined multifamily housing firm 1975, bought out partners 15 years later. Renamed Casden Properties; borrowed big, built empire of commercial, residential real estate. Sold majority of firm to Aimco for $2.4 billion 2002; today portfolio includes more than 200,000 square feet of office space, 3,100 luxury apartments. Halted development of White City Tower in Tel Aviv. Collects Jewish antiquities.
title: CEO, Chairman & Founder
employment: {'name': 'Casden Properties LLC', 'title': 'CEO, Chairman & Founder', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Got start as executive at Chinese Olympics hero Li Ning's company. Now far richer than his mentor thanks to success of his own sports-apparel company, China Dongxiang, which he founded in 2004. Sales were up a third in first 6 months of 2009 to $270 million thanks to strong sales at its 500 Kappa stores. Came out of the Vancouver Olympics a winner: Dongxing was a supplier of sportwear to the Norwegian team, which performed well at the games. Shares fortune with wife Liu Peiying.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Fuyao Group, which makes glass used in automobiles. Customers include Audi, Ford, Fiat, Nissan. Gave away 77 million of his shares to minority investors in April 2009 after missing a promised profit target.  Still, stock has more than doubled in past 12 months, and Cho remains one of China's most popular businesspeople.   Announced plan last year to donate 70% of his family's shares in Fuyao to charity, making him one of China's most generous businessmen.

name: Billionaires
bio: Longtime ally of fellow billionaire Silvio Berlusconi cofounded financial services group Mediolanum SpA with Berlusconi's Fininvest Group in 1982. Still runs the group, whose companies provide investment advice, banking services, life insurance and real estate loans. One of Italy's largest such groups by market capitalization. Shares up 30% since last February as financial stocks recovered. Son Massimo, 42, is heir apparent.

name: Billionaires
bio: Oil tycoon pocketed more than $1.5 billion in June 2009 sale of Addax Petroleum to China's Sinopec for $7.2 billion. Biggest deal ever for the tycoon. Started as an oil trader in 1970s; made friends with potentates like Nigeria's Sani Abacha; later moved crude for Saddam Hussein. Acquired oil acreage offshore Nigeria for a song; in Iraq made deals with Kurdish leaders in the north before fall of Saddam. Still runs oil trading operation and owns storage terminals across Africa. His collection of Egyptian antiquities is among best in the world.

name: Billionaires
bio: Senator from Murmansk Oblast is benefiting from the fertilizer boom. His Fosagro owns the full production cycle for phosphorous fertilizer and is the second-largest producer of phosphorous fertilizer concentrate in the world. Former Moscow communist committee leader; in early 1990s became avid capitalist working with Mikhail Khodorkovsky's Menatep Group and then ran a department of Rosprom, a company that managed the industrial assets of Menatep. In 2001 ran the board of directors of Apatit, which was a part of Rosprom. Led a management buyout of Apatit during the prosecution of Khodorkovsky, and acquired control. Apatit became the main holding of Fosagro.

name: Billionaires
bio: Saudi-born son of slain Lebanese prime minister Rafiq Hariri won his father's seat last June in hotly contested elections; heads Future Movement, a moderate, nonsectarian, political bloc founded by his late father. Also runs construction, telecom and real estate conglomerate, Saudi Oger, which he inherited with the rest of the family 4 years ago. In January 2008 bought brother Bahaa's stake; now owns 50%.

name: Billionaires
bio: Honorary chairman of Japan's biggest retail group, Seven & I Holdings, which serves more than 36 million customers daily in 13,500 department stores, supermarkets and 7-Eleven convenience stores. Net income in the first half down a third.  Expanding in Asia, with China revenue expected to balloon 5 times to more than $4 billion in 5 years. Company added a banking unit at home and last year tied up with leading concert and event-ticket seller Pia to help boost profits. Ito has donated $23 million to the Drucker School in the U.S., where son Junro  earned an MBA in 1989.

name: Billionaires
bio: World's wealthiest winemaker runs Kendall-Jackson Vineyard Estate; said to produce estimated 5 million cases annually from 14,000 acres of northern California vineyards. Recession not affecting some wine drinkers; Jackson Family Wines introduced three-day customized wine tastings in November for $30,000. Former attorney bought 80-acre pear-and-walnut orchard 1974, converted to vineyard. Marketed first Kendall-Jackson-brand bottles in 1982. Commands horse-racing empire Stonestreet Stables; star horses include Preakness winner Curlin, new gem Rachel Alexandra.

name: Billionaires
bio: Drug dynamo's fortune unscathed by recession thanks to diversified portfolio focused on pharma. Korean War vet earned law degree from DePaul U.; became sales rep for Miles Laboratories. With partner Phillip Frost, acquired Key Pharmaceuticals. Developed asthma drug Theo-Dur and cardiovascular patch Nitro-Dur; merged with Schering-Plough for $836 million 1986. Launched Kos Pharmaceuticals two years later; created cholesterol-battling drug Niaspan. Sold to Abbott Labs 2006 for $4.2 billion. Plowed proceeds into Treasuries and other bonds afterward; has since moved majority of assets into health stocks, investments in pharma firms. Gives to the Metropolitan Museum of Art and Tufts University.

name: Billionaires
bio: Only son of former Samsung Group chairman Lee Kun-Hee, became executive vice president and chief operating officer of Samsung Electronics in December 2009, just 20 months after his father resigned as chairman amid allegations of tax evasion. Began his career at Samsung Electronics in 1991. Combined net sales of Samsung affiliates is $174 billion; it is the world's top liquid-crystal display panel and memory chipmaker and second largest mobile phone manufacturer after Nokia.

name: Billionaires
bio: His wealth rebounded thanks to improving fortunes of his property developer Shui On Land. Nicknamed "Mr. Shanghai", he is best known for transforming a former crumbling area of the Chinese city into Xintiandi (which means "new heaven and earth"), an iconic mix of upscale boutiques and restaurants that opened in 2001. Has announced plans to find a successor in the next year though says he'll remain chairman. Also heads cement producer Shui On Construction. Took over two hotels in Shanghai in late Dec. after partner stopped work.  An ambitious middle child, Lo struck out on his own in 1971, borrowing HK$100,000 from his father, a wealthy Hong Kong developer, to go into construction materials. Entered China in 1985, one of the first in Hong Kong's building sector to do so. Member of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference. Director at Hang Seng Bank. Remarried former Miss Hong Kong 2008; recently bought a plane.

name: Billionaires
bio: Civil engineer, holds 13% of Spain's largest construction company, $22.3 billion (sales) Actividades de Construccion y Servicios S.A., which he has headed since 1993. Well known in Spain for ties to popular Real Madrid soccer club, once the team of stars like David Beckham and Zinedine Zidane; ran club from 2000 to 2006. Resigned in February 2006 after string of defeats. Club is giving him another chance:  re-elected him president last summer.

name: Billionaires
bio: NYU grad worked in small pharmacy owned by father; built generic-drug distributor after dropping out of law school. Today Kinray is the world's largest independent pharmaceutical and generics distributor in the world. Sales approach $5 billion, razor-thin margins. "Stewie Rah Rah, the #1 King of All Fun" adorns the walls of his Queens office with hundreds of pictures of himself with celebrities including Michael Jordan, Hugh Hefner, Ray Romano. Business card he used last summer: $1,000,000,000 bill with a picture of Rahr with Donald Trump, Arnold Palmer and Bill Clinton. "If I don't tell you how great I am, who will?" Donates millions every year to charity; supports Make-A-Wish Foundation, Robin Hood Foundation.

name: Billionaires
bio: Nebraska native competed for hearts of girls with lifelong friend Warren Buffett in high school; today sits on Berkshire Hathaway board. Father helped land him a job at Kiewit Construction (now Peter Kiewit Sons') as land surveyor. Became chief executive 1979, encouraged expansion into fiber optics, power plants. Key to success: "surround yourself with great people." Supports education through the Suzanne and Walter Scott Foundation. Animal lover plans to help fund new Arctic exhibit at Omaha's Henry Doorly Zoo.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: In September renamed his conglomerate RGE (Royal Golden Eagle), apparently to give it a more contemporary image. Group, which has $10 billion in assets, owns papermaker April and palm oil firm Asian Agri.  Has operations in China, Brazil. Member of the Asia executive advisory board  of Wharton and member of the Insead International Council. Eldest of 7 boys dropped out of school at age 17 to help support his family. Says he taught himself English by translating Readers' Digest, Life and Newsweek.

name: Billionaires
bio: Oil baron recently bought up shares in Leonid Mikhelson's gas producer, Novatek. In the late 1980s ran Kinex, a state-owned oil exporter. Became one of its main shareholders when it was later privatized. Today is one of the co-owners of the Gunvor Group, one of the traders through which state-controlled Rosneft and Gazpromneft oil firms export their products. Controls the engineering and construction company Stroytransgaz, Gazprom's contractor. Has Finnish citizenship, lives in Switzerland.

name: Billionaires
bio: Seventh child of Kentucky farmers yearned to fly after hearing radio broadcast of Charles Lindbergh's 1927 transatlantic flight. Raised money for flying lessons selling hamburgers. Left U. of Kentucky to pursue career as pilot; flew for Pan Am for 26 years. Founded FlightSafety pilot training school in 1951; public 17 years later. Acquired by Berkshire Hathaway in 1996 for $1.5 billion in stock and cash. Berkshire shares up more than 25% in past six months.

name: Billionaires
bio: Barber's son from Minneapolis sold popcorn as kid. Eagle Scout, high school valedictorian worked way through UCLA with night job at aircraft factory; graduated Phi Beta Kappa. Earned Harvard M.B.A., then served in Navy during WWII. After war earned law degree from Loyola, founded own law firm 1953. Started Ace Beverage Co. 3 years later with exclusive rights to distribute Budweiser in Los Angeles. Expanded into real estate, insurance, auto dealerships and agriculture through Topa Equities. Property holdings include commercial buildings in California, Hawaii, U.S. Virgin Islands. Says he'll never retire.

name: Billionaires
bio: Backed billionaire Lakshmi Mittal in his successful 2006 bid to merge steel groups Arcelor and Mittal Steel. Now holds 3% of ArcelorMittal, world's largest steel company.  Very press shy, reportedly never goes out in public without a bodyguard to safeguard him and his family from kidnapping and assassination attempts by Basque separatists. Owns cattle ranch Ganaderias Aguadulce in south of Spain, where he raises bulls for bullfighting.

name: Billionaires
bio: Onetime go-between for major oil companies and state-owned oilfields in the Gulf settled in Britain in 1980 after fleeing Saddam Hussein's Iraq. Today his General Mediterranean Holdings owns 3 dozen hotel and office properties in France, U.K., the Middle East and Chicago; also invests in construction, pharmaceuticals and finance companies. Owns Team Lebanon of A1 Grand Prix Race series.

name: Billionaires
bio: With brothers, controls one of country's largest private oil outfits. Father, Perry, inherited family fortune created by oil baron uncle Sid Richardson 1959. Passed on to eldest son, Sid, 1968. Bass Enterprises Production planning deepwater exploration off Nova Scotia. Sold one division to Southern Union for $1.6 billion 2005. Ed studied architecture at Yale. Built hotel in the Himalayas; spent $200 million building Biosphere 2 project in Arizona 1990s. Invested in venture capital, ranches in Texas, Kansas, Australia.

name: Billionaires
bio: Lent $1,000 to family friend Fred DeLuca to open sandwich shop in 1965. Single store spawned Subway, fast-food franchise known for healthy options. Today outfit boasts 23,040 U.S. locations and more than 32,000 worldwide. Popular "$5 Footlong" sandwiches boosted sales; 2009 revenue was $13.8 billion. First created healthy buzz with ubiquitous Jared commercials; claimed formerly obese student lost 245 pounds eating only Subway sandwiches. Jared recently featured in new campaign along with Olympian Michael Phelps. Planning international expansion in Japan, Russia, India and Singapore. Recently partnered with NBC's "The Biggest Loser" to help contestants with their weight-loss plans.
title: Co-Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Former chief executive of Caudwell Group sold his 85% stake to private equity in 2006, netting himself $2.3 billion; company later changed name to Phones4U. Went from selling used cars to clunky cell phones in 1987, shopping just 26 devices in the first eight months from his store in Hartshill, Stoke-on-Trent. Caudwell Group sales reached $3.6 billion in 2005, the last year he headed the company. Now spends most of his time managing and fundraising for his Caudwell Children charity and investing in start-up companies. In January threw a 40th birthday bash complete with Diana Ross performance for long-time girlfriend Claire Johnson, who was diagnosed with breast cancer in 2009 but beat it off. Avid sportsman scaled Mt. Everest and used to pedal 14 miles to work on his bike. Now lives in large Jacobean mansion in Staffordshire, with homes in London and France.

name: Billionaires
bio: New Balance Arch founded in 1906 to correct orthopedic foot problems. Davis bought company on day of Boston Marathon 1972; company had 6 employees. Shunned expensive endorsement deals with high-profile athletes, focused on selling comfort and performance to die-hard runners. Sales exceeded $1.6 billion in 2007; company claims to make 25% of its shoes in U.S.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Borrowed $1,000 from family friend Peter Buck to open sandwich shop in 1965. Single store spawned Subway, fast-food franchise known for healthy options. Today outfit boasts 23,040 U.S. locations and more than 32,000 worldwide. Popular "$5 Footlong" sandwiches boosted sales; 2009 revenue was $13.8 billion. First created healthy buzz with ubiquitous Jared commercials; claimed formerly obese student lost 245 pounds eating only Subway sandwiches. Jared recently featured in new campaign along with Olympian Michael Phelps. Planning international expansion in Japan, Russia, India and Singapore. Recently partnered with NBC's "The Biggest Loser" to help contestants with their weight-loss plans.
title: President and Co-Founder
employment: {'name': "Doctor's Associates (Subway)", 'title': 'President and Co-Founder', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: His Maruhan, Japan's largest operator of pachinko parlors, also owns Mister Donut, Seattle Coffee and Zoka franchises in Japan. Also operates golf driving ranges, bowling alleys and movie theaters. Overseas business includes a hotel casino in Macau. In 2008 awarded Royal Order of Cambodia, where he owns a commercial bank. Korean immigrant is a member of a council advising South Korea's government on unification with North Korea. Han is also an art collector.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandchild of newspaper baron William Randolph Hearst regained $100 million in past year thanks to stakes in cable networks ESPN, Lifetime, A&E. Newspaper, magazine holdings continue to falter amid weak ad market. News Corp's Dow Jones announced it will buy Hearst's 50% stake in SmartMoney, ending a nearly 20-year partnership. Seattle Post-Intelligencer now publishes exclusively online after print operation shuttered last year. Hearst plans to introduce e-reader this year; "Skiff" will provide advertising next to newspaper and magazine articles. George Hearst owned mining stakes and land; U.S. senator became owner of floundering San Francisco Examiner newspaper in 1880 as payment for gambling debt. Son William (d. 1951) took reins 1887 and created newspaper empire based on sensational "yellow" journalism; built readership with what reportedly were exaggerated accounts and pictures of Spanish-American War. In addition to cable assets, Hearst Corp. owns 15 daily newspapers (Houston Chronicle, San Antonio Express-News), 15 U.S. magazines (Esquire, Harper's Bazaar), TV and radio stations.

name: Billionaires
bio: London-born son of a mechanical engineer studied chemical engineering at Imperial College. Joined European bond desk at Salomon Brothers, rose to managing director. Then headed proprietary trading group at Credit Suisse First Boston. With four other Credit Suisse employees, launched hedge fund Brevan Howard 2002. Returned 14.4% annualized through 2008; up 18% last year. Sold 15% stake to Swiss Re in 2007 for undisclosed sum. Firm now manages $28 billion.

name: Billionaires
bio: National Football League's outspoken owner bought the Dallas Cowboys for $150 million 1989; squad is worth $1.65 billion today. Return on investment: 865% net of debt. America's Team has won 3 Super Bowl rings under his helm. New $1.2 billion Cowboy's Stadium opened this season; added $29 standing-room-only tickets to maximize noise level, beer sales. Capacity: 111,000. Sold personal seat licenses to die-hard fans during the off-season; used proceeds to help pay $425 million in debt. Led University of Arkansas Razorbacks to Cotton Bowl title 1964. Made first fortune in 1970s drilling natural gas wells. Still owns oil and gas, poultry, shopping centers.
title: President and General Manager
employment: {'name': 'Dallas Cowboys', 'title': 'President and General Manager', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Runs one of China's rising automakers, Geely, which means auspicious or lucky in Chinese. Sold 330,000 vehicles in 2009, mostly in China, now world's biggest car market. Made big news when he announced plans to buy Swedish brand Volvo from Ford. Deal expected to close at end of March 2010. Son of a farmer, he reportedly used a small graduation gift to buy a camera and open a photo studio. He later manufactured refrigerator parts. In 1990s, took over an ailing state-run motorcycle manufacturer and turned it into China's best known brand. Has only been in the auto business for a dozen years. Member of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cochairman of Guangzhou R&F Properties, is helping to lead the mid-to high-end Guangzhou real estate developer in cross-country push with developments in 11 cities including Beijing, Tianjin and Xian amid property boom in 2009. Firm's net profit plunged 90% in first half of 2009 in part due to writeoff of an abandoned land contract. Math major set up real estate firm with Chinese partner, Zhang Li, also a billionaire, in 1994. Holds minority stake in Chinese brokerage Haitong Securities. Also invested in China property developer KWG.

name: Billionaires
bio: After graduating from the economics department of St. Petersburg State University, started a residential construction business with a classmate in 1994. During the privatizations, bought one of the largest city-owned construction firms, Lenstroireconstruktsiya, or LSR. Listed its shares in 2007 offering; is still the largest shareholder. Business picked up last year: group won four auctions to build government housing valued at nearly $700 million; also secured $500 million of credit from two state-owned banks, Rosselkhozbank (Russian Agricultural Bank) and Vnesheconombank, to continue the construction of a cement factory in Leningrad Oblast, where he is a member of the Federation Council.

name: Billionaires
bio: Trucking tycoon battling Canadian government to maintain his priceless monopoly over the Detroit River border crossing. Owns Ambassador Bridge, conduit for 25% of commerce between U.S. and Canada; bridge handles 8,000 trucks a day, $100 billion worth of goods each year. Scrambling to build second bridge before Canada builds its own. Filed lawsuit to block construction, claiming Canuck plan will displace minority residents in U.S. Ottawa reportedly considering a bid for Ambassador Bridge. Grew up poor in Detroit; wanted to be a doctor, but medical schools were loaded with returning WWII soldiers. Took job with father's gas station and small trucking operation. Used truck company's credit line to buy Warren Buffett's 25% stake in Ambassador Bridge 1979; acquired the rest later.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairs Kowloon Development, whose business recovered from investment losses in 2008 in part through successful sales of luxury projects in Hong Kong, Macau. Working with Hong Kong's Urban Renewal Authority and Hong Kong Playground Association to create a combination sports stadium, youth center, commercial complex, residential tower. Hong Kong-listed Polytec Asset Holdings is a Kowloon Development subsidiary. Began career as a textiles trader in Hong Kong. Expanded to Macau to obtain export quotas and branched into property investments. Big chunk of fortune comes from 2006 transaction, in which he sold personal property in Macau back to Kowloon. Wife who shares fortune and son are involved in business.

name: Billionaires
bio: Dyslexic fisherman reportedly told by schoolteacher he'd never amount to anything. Main holding, Aker ASA, is maritime conglomerate that operates shipyards, offshore drilling, seafood and shipping. Got start selling fish off a single boat in Seattle, Wash.; returned to Norway and built up fleet and reputation as a ruthless corporate raider. Lived large with giant yacht and Boeing jet but nearly drove his shipping empire into the ground by 2003; sold yacht, paid off debt.

name: Billionaires
bio: Revered vulture investor made fortune buying, restructuring failed companies in steel, coal, textiles and car parts. Now bottom-fishing in banking: bought busted BankUnited of Florida for $900 million last year with partners. Plans to invest up to $1 billion in distressed mortgages. New Jersey native yearned to be a writer; dropped dream as Yale undergrad, turned to Wall Street. Earned MBA from Harvard Business School. Joined Rothschild 1976; cleaned up Drexel Burnham junk bond financings as bankruptcy specialist.

name: Billionaires
bio: Owns half of German publishing house, Verlagsgruppe Holtzbrinck; half-brother Stefan von Holtzbrinck owns the rest. Siblings bought out their other brother, Dieter in 2006.  Last March Dieter acquired Handelsblatt, Germany's biggest financial newspaper, and other assets from his siblings in return for canceling out financial obligations owed to him ; has established a new company: Dieter von Holtzbrinck Medien GmbH.  Monika heads  book publisher S. Fischer Verlag, which dates back to 1886; Group was the original publisher of Thomas Mann, Franz Kafka and Hermann Hesse.

name: Billionaires
bio: FedEx founder was bullish a year ago when plenty of others were worrisome. Optimism has paid off: increased shipment demand, cost cutting measures have helped lift shares 100% during past year. Yale grad laid out vision for integrated network of planes and trucks in senior thesis; launched Federal Express 1971. Pioneered elaborate tracking systems: "The information about the package is just as important as the package itself." Armada of 80,000 vehicles, 658 planes moves more than 7.5 million shipments daily; operates own air traffic control system, weather monitoring service. Owns 10% stake in pro football's Washington Redskins.
title: Chairman and CEO

name: Billionaires
bio: In March 2003 the Stroher family sold their almost 80% stake in Wella AG, the world's biggest professional hair care group, to Proctor & Gamble for $4 billion.  Granddaughter of Wella's founder, she got $1 billion from the sale. She and her husband, a former male nurse, have a well-known collection of contemporary German art that includes works by Baselitz, Immendorff and Kiefer.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Daito Trust Construction, property developer specializing in rental apartments. Construction orders down 10% this business year but stock up lately after news that net income for the first half of fiscal year rose unexpectedly, thanks in part to cost cuts. Tada scrapped sale of stake to private investors, including billionaire Akira Mori after financial crisis locked up credit markets in 2008.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cable news pioneer is the largest individual landowner in North America; owns 2 million acres of land across 12 states and Argentina. Work for father at Turner Advertising until he committed suicide in 1963. Created 24-hour news by starting CNN in 1980. Merged Turner Broadcasting with Time Warner in 1996; became AOL Time Warner's largest individual shareholder after combining the 2 companies in 2000. Shares collapsed; personally lost $7 billion in 2 years. Sold stake, retired from board in 2006. Has donated more than $1.5 billion to charity, including the United Nations Foundation. Invests in renewable energy; formed alliance with Southern Company of Atlanta to start on solar projects. Skilled sailor won America's Cup in 1977.

name: Billionaires
bio: With half-brother Dieter and half-sister Monika Schoeller,  inherited publishing house, Verlagsgruppe Holtzbrinck, from their father George, who founded it as a book club in 1948.  Has run the $3.6 billion (sales) company, which includes Farrar Straus, St. Martins Press and Henry Holt, since 2001.  In 2006 he and Monika bought out Dieter's one-third share. Last March, sold  Handelsblatt, Germany's biggest financial newspaper, 50% of weekly newspaper Die Zeit and other assets back to Dieter, which let them off the hook in terms of paying him cash. No sibling rivalry: he and siblings will sit on Die Zeit's supervisory board together.  A lawyer, Stefan apprenticed at Bloomsbury Publishing in London before joining Holtzbrinck in 1994.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cochairman and president of Guangzhou R&F Properties, is helping to lead the mid-to high-end Guangzhou real estate developer in cross-country push with developments in 11 cities including Beijing, Tianjin and Xian amid property boom in 2009. Firm's net profit plunged 90% in first half of 2009 in part due to writeoff of an abandoned land contract. Set up real estate firm with Hong Kong partner Li Sze Lim, also a billionaire, in 1994 after starting his career as a hotel industry executive. Zhang is vice chairman of China Real Estate Chamber of Commerce and a director and part-time professor of Jinan University. Before setting up R&F, Zhang headed the production department of Guangzhou Baiyun District Township Enterprise Administration.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sits on the board of her family's conglomerate, Koc Group, but has no role in management. Because of parasite in her blood spent years fighting illness in hospitals around the world; the experience moved her to build nursing education and research center in Turkey and to marry a doctor. Fluent in English and German. Brother Rahmi Koc and sister Suna Kirac are also both billionaires.

name: Billionaires
bio: Via his private company, Palmary Enterprises, won control over Australia's manganese ore miner Consolidated Minerals in 2008; value of company plummeted by 40% along with market. Currently in tussle with investment bank JPMorgan over $50 million advisory fee related to the deal. Gearing up for takeover battle for Australia's OM Holdings, regarded as world's last independent supplier of high-grade manganese; now holds 12% stake in the company. With partner and fellow billionaire Henadiy Boholyubov controls Privat group, a banking and industrial conglomerate they founded in early 1990s; bank value has not yet recovered from credit crisis tha brought Ukraine to brink of collapse. Oil concern Ukrnafafta set to pay $600 million in dividends owed from three prior years; his take: at least $100 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fourth-generation banker became head of Banco Santander in 1986.  Built it into Santander Central Hispano. Now one of the world's top three banks in terms of income; posted $12.8  billion in net profits in 2009.   Continues to strengthen position in Latin America,  which generated 36% of profits.  Exposure to Madoff scheme: one of its funds had money with Madoff. Clients lost $3 billion which bank offered to help cover, but apparently not management fees or supposed investment gains.  Daughter and heir apparent, Ana Botin, runs Banesto, bank's retail branch. Botin's great-grandfather discovered the famous Altamira caves in northern Spain in 1879. Emilio enjoys golf, hunting and fishing.

name: Billionaires
bio: Contraction in world economy spoiling food family's fortune. Fiscal 2009 earnings down 15% to $3.3 billion despite revenues remaining steady at $117 billion. William Cargill, son of Scottish sea captain, founded Iowa grain storage business after Civil War. Will's son-in-law John MacMillan took control 1909. Low-profile family owns 88% of Cargill; hasn't run company since Whitney stepped down as chief executive 1995. Firm controls food from stable to table: animal feed, meat, crops. Also runs large commodity trading and risk management operations. Family owns majority of fertilizer maker Mosaic; shares up 30% since February 2009.

name: Billionaires
bio: Contraction in world economy spoiling food family's fortune. Fiscal 2009 earnings down 15% to $3.3 billion despite revenues remaining steady at $117 billion. William Cargill, son of Scottish sea captain, founded Iowa grain storage business after Civil War. Will's son-in-law John MacMillan took control 1909. Low-profile family owns 88% of Cargill; hasn't run company since Whitney stepped down as chief executive 1995. Firm controls food from stable to table: animal feed, meat, crops. Also runs large commodity trading and risk management operations. Family owns majority of fertilizer maker Mosaic; shares up 30% since February 2009.

name: Billionaires
bio: Contraction in world economy spoiling food family's fortune. Fiscal 2009 earnings down 15% to $3.3 billion despite revenues remaining steady at $117 billion. William Cargill, son of Scottish sea captain, founded Iowa grain storage business after Civil War. Will's son-in-law John MacMillan took control 1909. Low-profile family owns 88% of Cargill; hasn't run company since Whitney stepped down as chief executive 1995. Firm controls food from stable to table: animal feed, meat, crops. Also runs large commodity trading and risk management operations. Family owns majority of fertilizer maker Mosaic; shares up 30% since February 2009.

name: Billionaires
bio: China's paper queen makes a big comeback: worth $265 million in October 2008, her fortune is up sixfold with a resurging stock market and also her paper manufacturing firm's ability to get its debt under control; got $500 million loan in January to repay more debt. Daughter of a Guangdong Province army officer and eldest of eight children. A finance job at a foreign paper-products trading company gave her the idea to start her own business. In 1985 she moved to Hong Kong and, with $4,000 in savings, set up a company importing waste paper. Five years later she and her husband, a Taiwan-born Brazilian national, trained as a dentist, traveled to California to open a paper recycler that would ship its output to China. In 1995 she returned to China and, with her husband and brother, started paper manufacturer Nine Dragons (whose name implies "highest fortune"), of which she is chairman. It went public in March 2006; now all three are billionaires.

name: Billionaires
bio: Famed venture capitalist with Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers made millions with early bets on Amazon, Netscape, Sun Microsystems. Became a billionaire with Google. Studied engineering at Rice U., then Harvard M.B.A. Sold microprocessors for Intel, lured to venture capital 6 years later. Bullish on green energy investments: favors carbon credits, alternative energy; recently funded regenerative fuel-cell maker Bloom Energy, biofuel company Amyris.
title: Partner
employment: {'name': 'Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers', 'title': 'Partner', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Brooklyn native studied finance at NYU. Briefly enrolled in NYU's business school; dropped out, became floor broker at American Stock Exchange. Founded first trading outfit Jamie Securities 1984, then Millennium 5  years later. Firm lost 3% in 2008--2.5% of that due to write-down of funds trapped at Lehman Brothers. Returned 17.4% net of fees last year. Assets under management: $7.5 billion. Married to sister of legendary investor Jack Nash (d. 2008).
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Former IBM software engineer cofounded German software firm SAP IN 1972 with four former IBM colleagues.  Successfully built up North American market for SAP, then left the firm in 1997 after a falling-out with his partners. Trained mathematician holds an honorary professorship of mathematics from the University of Karlsruhe for his support of talented students in the math, natural sciences and technology fields. His charitable foundation gives money to cancer and AIDS research, art and historic preservation.  Divides his time between a home in Hamburg and one in the U.S.  Avid golf player.

name: Billionaires
bio: MIT-engineer, his Bharat Forge, among world's leading forgings makers that specializes in auto components, was hit by slowdown in global auto industry. Has been restructuring its European operations, where demand has fallen steeply. Taking steps to expand into non auto forgings in energy, transportation and marine sectors: has a joint venture with Alstom to make turbines for power plants and with France's Areva to make heavy forgings also for the power sector. Also has interests in wind energy; plans to enter solar power. Stock up threefold in 2009.

name: Billionaires
bio: Contraction in world economy, falling fertilizer prices spoiling food family's fortune. Fiscal 2009 earnings down 15% to $3.3 billion despite revenues remaining steady at $117 billion. William Cargill, son of Scottish sea captain, founded Iowa grain storage business after Civil War. Will's son-in-law John MacMillan took control 1909. Low-profile family owns 88% of Cargill; hasn't run company since Whitney stepped down as chief executive 1995. Firm controls food from stable to table: animal feed, meat, crops. Also runs large commodity trading and risk management operations. Family owns majority of fertilizer maker Mosaic; shares down 50% since last August.

name: Billionaires
bio: Delivery boy for family dairy company during the Depression. With two brothers and sister, opened ice cream shop with $1,200 loan in 1940. Today United Dairy Farmers chain has nearly 200 midwestern stores. Left business; started investing in savings and loans in 1959, insurance in 1971. Via American Financial Group, bought Chiquita Brands International in 1984; ran banana company until 2001. Holds 20% stake in pro baseball's Cincinnati Reds.

name: Billionaires
bio: Born in Taiwan; got a degree in dental surgery from the University of Santa Amaro in Brazil in 1983.  Met his wife Yan Cheung in Hong Kong. Moved with her to the U.S. in 1990 where they set up a paper recycling business. Later returned to China and started paper manufacturer Nine Dragons with his wife and brother-in-law. Company went public March 2006. All three are once again billionaires thanks to stock surge in past year. Flags from China, the United States and Brazil hang outside their corporate headquarters.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father got start making watering cans in summer and hot water bottles in winter. Eventually founded Loh KG in 1961. Friedhelm, his second-born son, took over 13 years later. Company, now known as the Friedhelm Loh Group, manufactures safes, post boxes, intercom systems and switch boxes that protect electrical and electronic circuits. Has $3 billion in sales, with around 10,500 employees in over 70 plants worldwide. Known for his religious beliefs, has established the Christian Media Foundation, publishers of Christian literature. Avid collector of antique cars.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former Campbell Soup accountant jumped to pet food in 1970; joined 5-person company Iams as general manager. Became president, later chief executive; bought firm 1982. Pushed premium pet food; stressed nutrition, won over high-end breeders, vets. Sold to Procter & Gamble for $2.3 billion in 1999. Gave employees $100 million in bonuses out of personal cut; structured deal to keep jobs in Dayton. Recently dumped $100 million into entrepreneur center "Aileron." Teaches small business owners professional management skills on 114-acre campus designed to symbolize the entrepreneur's journey; features Focus Reflection Pond, Dream Room, Passion Garden.

name: Billionaires
bio: Warren Buffett's longtime lieutenant gained $300 million in past year; Berkshire Hathaway shares up 28% since last February. Called for ban on credit default swaps: "It isn't as though the economic world didn't function quite well without [them]." Omaha native studied math at U. of Michigan, dropped out to serve as meteorologist in Army Air Corps. Then Harvard Law. Began investing with Buffett after pair met at a dinner party 1959. Known for pragmatic, researched approach to investing. Helped persuade Buffett to back Chinese electric car company BYD in 2008; original $232 million Berkshire investment now worth almost $2 billion.

name: Billionaires
bio: After father's death in 2005 became sole owner of candy company Storck GmbH, makers of Werther's Original, Riesen, Toffifee, and others. Fourth generation of his family to run the $2 billion (sales) group. Company established the Stork Foundation in 1992 to preserve Germany's endangered stork population.

name: Billionaires
bio:
Broadcom cofounder met future partner Henry Nicholas at defense contractor TRW. Designed high-speed telecom chips in Nicholas' spare bedroom. Founded Broadcom in 1991; took public 7 years later. Worth $10 billion in 2000; lost $8 billion in a year. Company forced to write down $2.2 billion in 2007 from options scandal; largest restatement based on backdated options. Resigned as
chairman in May 2008; later pleaded guilty for lying to the SEC, for alleged stock-option backdating. In an impassioned ruling last December a federal judge threw out the guilty plea after Samueli testified at the options backdating trial of former CFO William Ruehle. Charges against Ruehle--and Nicholas--were later dismissed. Samueli name was cleared; he returned to Broadcom as Chief Technical Officer and was reinstated as owner of Anaheim Ducks.
title: Chief Technology Officer and Chairman
employment: {'name': 'Broadcom', 'uri': 'companies/broadcom', 'title': 'Chief Technology Officer and Chairman', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman and 85% owner of investment firm Melker Schorling AB. Founded MSAB in 1999 and took it public in 2006, attracting such investors as fellow billionaire Stefan Persson,  who sits on the board of the company

name: Billionaires
bio: Chicago native earned bachelors, M.B.A. and computer science masters at U. of Illinois, worked as salesman for Oracle. Split in 1990 after Larry Ellison refused to take his sales-tracking software to market. Built rival firm Siebel Systems; sold to Oracle for $5.9 billion in 2005. Now chairs holding company First Virtual; investments include agribusiness and commercial real estate. Siebel Foundation has donated $200 million to meth-abuse prevention, public health, education, fighting homelessness. Recently put his 62,000-acre Montana cattle ranch on the market for $45 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Owns 9 West 57th Street, one of New York City's best commercial addresses; building is home to several high-profile corporate tenants. Longtime tenant Bank of America vacated building last October when lease expired; space not yet completely filled.
