Received approval last March for $4 billion plan to redevelop 9.2 acres of land formerly owned by Con Ed along Manhattan's East River. Also owns several apartment buildings on Upper East Side. Dragged into Marc Dreier scandal after reports that Ponzi-scheming lawyer accused of stealing millions from hedge fund managers once posed as his representative.

name: Billionaires
bio: Studied business at U. of North Carolina, then Harvard Business School. Took over father's failing Bank of North Carolina; merged in 1982 with NCNB. Today owns BofA shares worth $460 million, stock up more than 350% in past 12 months. Also owns National Gypsum, C.D. Spangler Construction. UNC president from 1986 to 1997. Donates to alma mater, Charlotte Teach for America program. Enjoys restoring antique grandfather clocks; says allure is working on something that someone else tinkered with 200 years ago.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father fled Nazi Germany. Jerry studied German literature at Columbia, later joined father-in-law Robert Tishman's realty firm. Divorced the daughter, but Speyer and Tishman continued to work together; created Tishman Speyer 1978. Today owns stakes in New York landmarks Chrysler Building and Rockefeller Center. With BlackRock Inc. lost $5.4 billion bet on Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village apartment and retail complexes in Manhattan this year after defaulting on mortgage. Also reportedly struggling to refinance debt on CarrAmerica portfolio, a collection of 28 buildings in the Washington, D.C. area.

name: Billionaires
bio: Medical device fortune slowly on the mend; Stryker Corp. stock up 20% in past 12 months. Shares lagging market recovery. Surgeon grandfather Homer Stryker (d. 1980) invented mobile hospital bed; founded medical supply Stryker Corp. 1941. Father, Lee, died in plane crash 1976; John Brown became chief executive. Public 1979. Today company produces hospital beds, joint replacements, medical software, surgical cameras. Sales: $6.7 billion. Arcus Foundation supports gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgender causes, as well as great apes and their habitats.

name: Billionaires
bio: Got his start as a chemical engineer and mopped floors to pay for school. Now much of fortune derived from cigarettes and alcohol. Owns the Philippines' largest cigarette maker, Fortune Tobacco; Philippine Airlines; Asia Brewery; mining operations; banks; property developments in Hong Kong. Being prosecuted by the Presidential Commission on Good Governance, which claims that much of Tan's wealth belonged to former president Ferdinand Marcos and should be returned to the country. Hobbies include flying helicopters.

name: Billionaires
bio: He and younger brothers Hong-tu and T.Y. inherited stakes in family's financial service company Cathay Holdings after father Tsai Wan-lin passed away in 2004. For first time, Forbes has been able to split apart family and list each brother separately in ranks. Family also controls Cathay Real Estate, a Taiwan property developer.

name: Billionaires
bio: He and brothers Cheng-da and T.Y. inherited stakes in family's financial service company Cathay Holdings after father Tsai Wan-lin passed away in 2004. Family also controls Cathay Real Estate, a Taiwan property developer. Chairman of Cathay, he brought on his brother T.Y. in 2009 to help revive firm's fortunes during last year's doldrums. For first time, Forbes has been able to split apart family and list each brother separately in ranks.

name: Billionaires
bio: He and brothers Cheng-da and Hong-tu inherited stakes in family's financial service company Cathay Holdings after father Tsai Wan-lin passed away in 2004. Family also controls Cathay Real Estate, a Taiwan property developer. At brother Hong-tu's invitation, took on more visible role at firm last year after disappointing 2008 financial results. Spent much of last year traveling around, talking to employees. Collects cars, has personal investments in property.

name: Billionaires
bio: Owns $2.3 billion (sales) Viessmann Werke GmbH,  one of Europe's largest producers of boilers and heating equipment. Grandfather founded group more than 90 years ago. Ran company since 1993 then in 2008  moved over to supervisory board to concentrate on company strategy. Company supports the  Viessman Academy to provide training for heating architects and engineers; also sponsors cold weather sports like skiing and sledding as well as Formula One racing. President of the Kassel Chamber of Commerce, treasurer of Marburg University. Has a professional pilot's license.

name: Billionaires
bio: Affable Hoosier ran neighborhood snow-shoveling service as a kid. Took over father's billboard business in 1946 after graduating from Merchant Marine Academy, plowed profits into hotel empire. Sold signage operation in 1998 to Chancellor for $960 million. "At that price, what the heck?" Flipped 100 hotels to BET founder Robert Johnson for $1.7 billion 2006. Working on $450 million Marriott Place Indianapolis; complex will feature 5 hotels, public plaza with 60-foot waterwall, murals reflecting Indiana heritage.

name: Billionaires
bio: Brother of fellow billionaire Zhang Jindong, Zhang Guiping is one of the biggest real estate tycoons in Nanjing, the capital of Jiangsu province. Backed out of a deal to buy a pricey parcel of land near Shanghai's Bund in 2008 when market faltered. Then last August paid a more modest $143 million for plot in city's northern Putuo district. Spent $68 million for a commercial site in Nanjing in September. In December, added to two sites in Jiangsu province's Wuxi costing a total of $495 million. Shares wealth with his son, Zhang Kangdi.

name: Billionaires
bio: Leased a faltering iron and steel plant from government a decade ago. Bought 100% of it a year later and renamed it Jianlong Iron & Steel. Still runs group, which also has interests in mining, equipment manufacturing, shipbuilding. Tragic turn of events: company official was killed in 2009 after a brawl at a state-owned plant Jianlong was trying to take over. State media said workers beat official and then blocked ambulances and police from reaching him.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former leader of a collective, he and children own $2.8 billion (sales) Xiyang Group, one of China's largest suppliers of magnetite products, used in making steel. Also makes steel, fertilizer, and has stake in Chinese professional basketball team. Investing in mining firms in Russia and North Korea. Withdrew an earlier bid to acquire Australia's publicly traded Ausmelt, a supplier of furnaces to the metals industry, in February. Xiyang Group has more than 20,000 employees.

name: Billionaires
bio: Diet pioneer among first to capitalize on America's weight-loss obsession; sold Slim-Fast to Unilever in 2000, made $2.3 billion before taxes. WWII vet and fitness enthusiast introduced line of low-calorie shakes and bars in late 1970s; found fans in celebrity dieters. Democratic donor active in Middle East peace causes. Authored Peace Is Possible: Conversations with Arab and Israeli Leaders from 1988 to the Present in 2006; President Clinton penned foreword.
organization: S. Daniel Abraham Center for Middle East Peace
title: Chairman
employment: {'name': 'S. Daniel Abraham Center for Middle East Peace', 'title': 'Chairman', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Consumer goods tycoon controls $5.6 billion (market cap) Hypermarcas SA, a public company that manufactures and sells 170 brands and 4,000 products in realms of food, drugs, cleaning, beauty and personal hygiene products. Founded Arisco, a cleaning product business with father in 1969 and was its director and president for more than 20 years. Under his reign, Arisco became the biggest in Brazil's food sector and was sold off to Bestfoods for $760 million in 2000. In 2002 Joao created Hypermarcas after buying steel wool companies throughout Brazil. Expanded business buying more than 10 new companies through investment vehicle Monte Cristalina SA. Took Hypermarcas public in 2008. Reportedly said he plans to buy one new company every two months. Owns three boats, a private jet called Citation X and extensive art collection by Brazilian artists.

name: Billionaires
bio: With brother and fellow billionaire Dmitry, started out importing computers to Russia. Brothers then set up a bank and have been active in real estate and media. Alexei heads up their IT business and general strategy. Despite their wealth they felt a lack of education and completed executive M.B.A.s at the University of Chicago in 2005. Both brothers are very religious. Alexei uses free time to assist clergymen at Moscow's Church of the Trinity.

name: Billionaires
bio: Brought into the business by older brother Alexei, also a billionaire; they are now equal partners. Started out importing computers to Russia, then set up a bank; active in real estate and media. Despite their wealth, the brothers felt a lack of education and completed executive M.B.A.s at the University of Chicago in 2005. Alexei is in charge of the brothers' IT business and the general strategy; Dmitry is more involved in their bank, Promsvyazbank. In 2009 EBRD announced plans to buy a minority stake in Promsvyazbank. Dmitry recently appointed to a seat on the Federation Council of the gas-rich Arctic region of Yamal.

name: Billionaires
bio: Metals and real estate investor had to suspend a large proportion of his Coalco International's development projects, including high end offices in Moscow, when markets collapsed in 2008. To pay the interest on the debt, he sold his stake in a uranium-mining project in Kazakhstan. In the 1990s was one of the best-known Russian businessmen, co-owner of aluminum plants and the bank Rossiyskiy Kredit. In 2000 sold all his holdings in Russia and was quiet for 4 years. Then in 2004 made a comeback as co-owner of Metalloinvest with fellow billionaires Alisher Usmanov and Andrei Skoch. In 2007 had planned to take Coalco public but wasn't satisfied with the projected valuation of the company--less than $4.5 billion; Anisimov thought it was worth twice that much.

name: Billionaires
bio: After graduating from the Moscow Institute of Civil Engineering started out at one of the divisions of Soviet construction behemoth Glavmosstroi. In 1993 that division became a private company called Construction Department 155, in which Balakin is its largest shareholder. Later worked in highly-placed jobs in the Moscow city government and in 2005, after four years as a bureaucrat, turned his focus to his business. In 2009 won several government-sponsored auctions for the right to build state-financed housing, increasing his total construction backlog.

name: Billionaires
bio: New York real estate tycoon plans to build oceanfront towers in southern Brooklyn "as soon as we sense the market is turning around." Apartment buildings will cater to city dwellers sick of traffic-ridden trips to the Hamptons or Jersey shore. Opened first grocery store at 100th St. and Broadway 1969; owned 10 stores by age 24, made $25 million a year in revenue. Plowed $5 million into Manhattan real estate 1977; property worth $100 million 5 years later. Today his Red Apple Group owns hundreds of millions of dollars' worth of real estate, New York's Gristedes grocery chain. Best asset: United Refining Co. Firm owns 372 gas stations, Pennsylvania refinery.

name: Billionaires
bio: Stanford professor set up students Sergey Brin and Larry Page, now billionaires, with venture capitalists Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers. Rewarded with a chunk of Google stock. Reunited in late 2008 with past business partner Andreas Bechtolsheim, a German billionaire, in new outfit Arista Networks, a low-cost switchmaker aimed at competing with Cisco Systems. Has donated to University of British Columbia to support university teaching led by Nobel Prize winning physicist Carl Wieman: "I think of this as an investment in the most important asset we have, namely the next generation!"

name: Billionaires
bio: Made initial fortune in toy manufacturing at Early Light International, the company he founded and chairs. Now owns dozens of properties in Hong Kong, including parking lots, malls, homes. Other assets include shares in Regal Hotels, Town Health. Collects expensive watches, fishing vessels; has dozens of luxury cars. Expecting delivery of a new yacht this year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fortune of Korea's richest politician jumped $1.8 billion in past year; most of that fortune comes from his stake in Hyundai Heavy Industries, best known for its shipbuilding division. Was the firm's chairman until 1988 when he entered politics. Assemblyman is son of late Hyundai founder Chung Ju-Young and brother of Hyundai Motor Chairman Chung Mong-Koo, also a billionaire. Said to have close ties to current president of Korea, a former Hyundai executive. Owns thousands of dollars worth of folding screens and Korean art. Vice president of FIFA, world governing body for soccer.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cork native sold programs at Dublin soccer stadium Tolka Park while a student. Took job at Citibank, then worked briefly as banking consultant for Pricewaterhouse Coopers in Kabul, Afghanistan. Founded NCB Stockbrokers in 1981; created Ireland's largest independent brokerage. Helped revitalize Ireland's economy in late 1980s with proposal for Dublin's International Financial Services Centre. Sold NCB in 1994 for $39 million, plowed proceeds into private equity firm, International Investment & Underwriting. Sold London City Airport 2006. Still owns international betting exchange Betdaq, online education outfit Intuition, mapping software company eSpatial. Also holds stake in Barbados' Sandy Lane Hotel. Known as The Kaiser for donning distinctive gnarly mustache.

name: Billionaires
bio: His $100 million investment in U.S. edition of OK! magazine has yet to pay off; has had three editors in a year. Made his own headlines in libel trial this year when he sued author Tom Bower over allegations made in his book on Conrad Black; Bower accused Desmond of ordering a negative story on Black in his Sunday Express newspaper. At the time, Desmond said 'I sued Mr. Bower for defamation because he made inaccurate and damaging allegations about me, yet he refused to apologize and publish a correction." Desmond lost; Bower is reportedly trying to get his next book, an expose on Desmond, published. High school dropout started his first magazine, International Musician, in 1974; built stable of titles including at one time more than 40 adult entertainment publications, which he sold in 2004. Launched celebrity magazine OK! in Britain in 1993. Bought British newspaper group Express in 2000. For fun and charity, plays drums with his band RD Crusaders, whose other musicians include folks from The Who and Led Zeppelin. Latest gig raised seven million dollars at a charity event for the state-of-the-art Marie Curie Hospice, a cancer hospice in London, as well as other charities.

name: Billionaires
bio: Born in a small town near Moscow, studied economics at Moscow State University, where he got a doctorate. Headed several investment firms before joining Alfa Group in 1995. Worked in the firm's food-and-commodities-trading subsidiary, Alfa Eco, then led the group's takeover of an aluminum plant in Siberia. Later became a lobbyist and member of the Federation Council, the upper house of parliament -- stepped down last year. Maintains a large stake in Altimo, a company that inherited Alfa Eco's assets and now has major holdings in Russia's telecom industry. Investing in China.

name: Billionaires
bio: Recession finally loosening financial stranglehold on Gage and her sister Marilyn Carlson Nelson; combined fortune up $800 million in a year. Carlson Companies has benefited from industry-wide recovery in main divisions: hotels (Radisson, Country Inns & Suites), restaurants (T.G.I. Friday's), travel agencies. Focusing on global expansion to supplement slower-growth U.S. assets. Father, Curt (d. 1999), began selling Gold Bond trading stamps 1930s; expanded into dining, hospitality. Renamed operation Carlson Cos. 1973.

name: Billionaires
bio: His grandfather founded Gerling Konzern as a small insurance company in 1904; his father turned it into a major player in the world insurance business. Despite his training as an economist, Rolf showed little interest in his legacy and eventually sold his 94% stake in the company in November 2005  to Germany's Talanx Group for estimated $1.6 billion. Established the  Gerling Academy for Risk Research, a think tank set up to study the industrial world's impact on the environment.

name: Billionaires
bio: Emigrated from Israel to Flint, Mich. 1968; first in family to attend college. Got taste of tech business selling computers out of basement. Started buyout firm Gores Group 1987. Today manages $1.7 billion; offices in U.S. and Europe. Targets divisions of technology firms, then pieces into new businesses.

name: Billionaires
bio: Met husband, John Murdoch Harbert III (d. 1995), in grade school. John turned $6,000 in craps winnings into construction titan: water systems power plants, airports, South American pipeline. Purchased coal reserves in eastern Kentucky, Tennessee in 1960s; sold to Amoco in stock deal during energy crisis in 1970s. Son Raymond runs family money.

name: Billionaires
bio: GPS king returns to billionaire status; fortune has nearly doubled as shares of Garmin up 100% from lows. Focused on margin improvements to offset falling revenues. Met partner Gary Burrell at AlliedSignal. Produced Global Positioning System navigation tools for pilots and sailors. Started marketing GPS units to directionally challenged drivers in 1998. Sales: $3.5 billion.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Garmin Corporation', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Senior statesman of Turkish industrialists, ran Koc Group until 2003. Has received numerous awards over the years from the German, Italian and Turkish governments; also recipient of five honorary doctorates. Spent two years traveling the world with his yacht after he retired. Avid sailor spends months calling on ports around the world with his luxury yacht. Worked with Alexander Onassis Foundation to restore wall paintings in historic Antalya, Turkey church. Sisters Semahat Arsel and Suna Kirac are both also billionaires.

name: Billionaires
bio: Leads Cheng Shin Rubber, today one of the biggest suppliers of auto tires in China and one of Taiwan's most successful businesses on the mainland. Started out in 1967 as a supplier of bicycle tires. Key China operation is run from Fujian province, just across the Taiwan Strait from Taiwan.  Supplier to GM, Ford, and India's Tata. Products sold under Maxxis brand in 160 countries.

name: Billionaires
bio: Telecom pioneer and Clearwire chairman forging ahead with plans to roll out national wireless Internet network as rivals Verizon Wireless and AT&T ready their own 4G deployments. Plans to expand WiMax service to cover up to 120 million people, up from 34 million now, by the end of 2010. Son of broadcasting magnate John Elroy McCaw sold cable services door-to-door for dad's company. With brothers founded McCaw Cellular; sold to AT&T in 1993 for $11.5 billion. Invested in Nextel, satellite network; lost $5 billion from net worth during 2000 telecom crash. Rebounded with founding of wireless Internet company Clearwire in 2003; shares up 67% in 12 months. Heads Eagle River companies; invests in communications industry.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cisco stock held steady through recession; up more than 75% in 12 months. U. of Wisconsin grad got start at Honeywell, joined networking firm Cisco as president and chief executive in 1988. Company went public 2 years later. Sales jumped from $5 million to more than $1 billion in 6 years. Firm commanded world's largest market cap in 2000: $555 billion. Plunged 87% to $70 billion in 2002 after tech crash. Chairman emeritus now focuses on philanthropy; with wife, Tashia, donates to alma mater.

name: Billionaires
bio: Nonexecutive chairman of $4.7 billion (revenues) Infosys Technologies, country's second-largest outsourcing firm. He and wife sold shares raising $130 million to start Catamaran, a new venture capital fund aimed at Indian startups. Last August he hosted a wedding reception for his daughter Akshata, a Stanford grad, in Bangalore that had more than 1,000 guests, including fellow tech tycoon Azim Premji. Akshata reportedly plans to launch an Indian fashion label in her own name.

name: Billionaires
bio: Recession finally loosening financial stranglehold on Nelson and her sister Barbara Carlson Gage; combined fortune up $800 million in a year. Carlson Companies has benefited from industry-wide recovery in main divisions: hotels (Radisson, Country Inns & Suites), restaurants (T.G.I. Friday's), travel agencies. Focusing on global expansion to supplement slower-growth U.S. assets. Father, Curt (d. 1999), began selling Gold Bond trading stamps 1930s; expanded into dining, hospitality. Renamed operation Carlson Cos. 1973. Marilyn stepped down as chief exec 2008.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Marvel chief sold the superhero comics outfit to Disney for $4 billion; deal completed in January. will continue to run company. Fought in Israel's 1967 Six-Day War; soon after moved to U.S. with $250. Hebrew came in handy; for a short time presided over Jewish funerals in Brooklyn. With partner became principal shareholder in Odd-Lot Trading Co.; retailer bought by Revco drugstores in 1983. Also owned Toy Biz, which merged with Marvel Entertainment Group in 1993. Marvel characters include The Hulk and Spider-Man. Blockbuster Iron Man was first Marvel-produced flick.
title: Chief Executive Officer
employment: {'name': 'Marvel Entertainment', 'title': 'Chief Executive Officer', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: The split-up of the Pritzker family fortune continues. In November Hyatt Hotels went public; sold $1.1 billion in stock. Family still controls large chunk of shares after offering. Sold 13.6% stake in Hyatt to Walton family's Madrone Capital and Goldman Sachs for $1 billion in 2007. Five months later sold 60% of Marmon industrial conglomerate to Berkshire Hathaway for $4.5 billion; firm will become entirely Berkshire-owned in 2014. Grandchildren of A.N. Pritzker (d. 1986) who, with sons Jay (d. 1999) and Robert, created Marmon (sales: $7 billion) and Hyatt (415 properties worldwide today). Plan to pass control of empire to Tom, cousin Nick and niece Penny collapsed in 2001; family agreed to divide the spoils 11 ways, drawing a lawsuit by Robert's 2 youngest children, Matthew and Liesel. Two heirs settled for $1 billion.
title: Executive Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Sold portion of Barnett Shale assets sale to Devon Energy and Crosstex Energy in 2006 for $2.6 billion cash. Plowing proceeds into prospects in Pennsylvania, Utah, Montana. Last summer Quicksilver Resources snapped up assets on Barnett Shale natural gas field owned by Ross Perot's Hillwood and his own Chief Oil & Gas for $1.3 billion; personally pocketed $400 million. Dartmouth grad studied law at Southern Methodist U. In 1984 left career as Dallas bankruptcy attorney to pursue oil and gas investments. Formed Chief Oil & Gas a decade later. With wife, Jan, Rees-Jones Foundation awarded $2 million grant to Texas Christian University; in 2008 gave $10 million to Dartmouth for scholarships to Texan students.

name: Billionaires
bio: Candy maker is credited with inventing more than 200 sweets including Gummi Bears,  Vademecum sugar-free gum and Maoam fruit chewies. Said he gets his inspiration from reading comic books and watching movies for children. Makes these candies for Haribo, the $24 billion (sales) candy company that he owned with his brother Paul, who died last August. Siblings rebuilt the company after World War II and ran it together; Hans overseeing  daily operations while Paul was in  charge of production.  A bachelor with no children, the succession remains uncertain. His nephew, Paul's son, Hans-Jurgen left in 2005 after a reported falling-out with Hans. Paul's two other sons, Hans-Guido and Hans-Arndt, work at Haribo;  still fit and active, Hans has said he has no intention of stepping down any time soon.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sold Cadillac; used $100 of proceeds to start Conair (formerly Continental Hair Products) with parents after family's Manhattan beauty parlor failed. Company manufactured hair rollers invented by father. Public 1972, then private again in 1985 through leveraged buyout. More than $2 billion in sales; 30% comes from outside U.S. Expanded brand portfolio to include home appliances names Cuisinart, Waring and hair product lines Scunci, Babyliss and Rusk. Has CuisinArt resort in Anguilla, complete with hydroponic farm.

name: Billionaires
bio: Heads Giant Interactive, one of China's most successful online game companies. In October, licensed flagship game ZT Online to Astrum Nival of Russia. Founded the company in 2005. Took it public in the U.S. in November 2007. Got a bachelor's degree in mathematics from the academic cradle of China's software industry, Zhejiang University, and created a huge following for his Zhuhai Giant Hi-Tech Group in 1991, based on the popularity of a single videogame. Zhuhai Giant collapsed under the weight of massive debt incurred for a 70-story skyscraper that was never built. His recent return to games through an online services provider he founded, ZTgame, has given new life to his entrepreneurial reputation. Shi also has stakes in Minsheng Banking, of which he's a director, and Huaxia Bank. Diversifying into Chinese rice wine market.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Kyobo Life Insurance, which his late father founded. Won the 2009 Asia Insurance Industry Award in November 2009. Net profits at insurance firm rose last year despite economic downturn; has had top return on equity among Korea's big three life insurers for the past five years. Kyobo's assets have grown 8.3 percent in 2009, showing a steady rise in sales despite the global economic recession. Educated as an obstetrician; also a former professor of obstetrics and gynecology at Seoul National University College of Medicine.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman and chief executive of $3 billion (sales) Avantha Group is eyeing acquisitions overseas. His Ballarpur Industries, India's largest papermaker, is reportedly  mulling bid for Malaysia's GS Paper & Packaging Group. In September his Crompton Greaves, among country's leading suppliers of power equipment, scrapped a plan to bid for the transmission and distribution assets of France's Areva. Other interests include chemicals, IT, energy, farm forestry and food processing. The Global Green Company, group's food arm, is India's largest exporter of gherkins. Is planning to list Avantha Power, group's power generation unit, this year. Chairs Aspen Institute India and Thapar University, among India's top private engineering colleges. President of the Golf Tour of India, he sits on the board of the Asian Tour.  Recently sponsored the Avantha Masters, a pro-golf championship in New Delhi.

name: Billionaires
bio: With sister-in-law Joan controls family fortune built by their late husbands, investors Preston (Bob) and Laurence Tisch. Duo started in 1946 with small New Jersey hotel. Acquired Loews Theatres 1959. Matrons' sons now run company. Today Loews Corp. holding corporation includes insurance (CNA), natural gas (Boardwalk Pipeline), offshore drilling (Diamond), hotels. Spun off cigarette maker Lorillard to Carolina Group in 2007.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Mediatek, one of the world's largest semiconductor design houses. Its chips are used in mobile phones, DVD players, TVs sold by many of the world's top electronic brands; also frequently end up in knock-offs of popular western electronics brands in China.

name: Billionaires
bio: A great grandson of German auto pioneer, Adam Opel.  Business administration graduate from the University of Rhode Island, inherited over $150 million in 1989;  carefully invested money via investment arm  Hansa AG.  Last year sold his share of the Swiss Jelmoli Holding to real estate company Swiss Prime Site for $230 million in cash and a 9% stake in the company. Also controls  95% of recently delisted investment firm Athris through which he has stakes in a Swiss hotel chain, a restaurant chain, a sports store and shopping centers in Russia and Algeria.  A long-time Swiss resident, his Georg and Emily von Opel foundation funds the care and education of underprivileged children and teens in third world countries.

name: Billionaires
bio: Development company building MediaCity development in Salford Quays; attracting large media tenants including the BBC. Took company private in 2004; a year later led the group's $1.3 billion takeover of Mersey Docks & Harbour Co. in a bid to revitalize the Liverpool waterfront. In 2006 Deutsche Bank's property arm paid $600 million for 49% stake. Group's other holdings include investment properties, airports and ports. Added a stake in Pinewood Shepperton film studio, where James Bond movies, among others, are filmed. Owns Billown Mansion on the Isle of Man.

name: Billionaires
bio: Finalized divorce from wife Elaine in January. She received 11 million Wynn Resorts shares, plus a cut of $114 million in stock sale proceeds last August. Steve still $100 million richer as Wynn shares up 112% in 12 months. Opened $2.3 billion Encore casino in Sin City next to his $2.7 billion Wynn Las Vegas in 2008; says he wishes he hadn't had to open during an economic downturn. Reportedly spending $100 million for entertainment complex at Encore to be unveiled this summer. Dropped bid for Queens Acqueduct redevelopment in November 2009, just days before final offers were due. Reportedly telephone bidder who paid $33.2 million at London Christie's auction in December for Rembrandt's "Portrait of a Man, Half-Length, with His Arms Akimbo," setting an auction record for the artist. Bought 5,500-square-foot Sun Valley home for $7.5 million in November.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Wynn Resorts', 'uri': 'companies/wynn-resorts', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Born in China, Zhong lives in Singapore but much of his wealth comes from his homeland. Shares in his property development arm Yanlord, which develops high end residential properties in China's biggest cities, have more than doubled in the past year amid a big run-up in the country's real estate market. Also has trading, manufacturing and financial services businesses extending across Singapore, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Malaysia and Australia.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of Montreal tobacco and candy seller cofounded Boston Properties 1970 with Edward Linde; public 1997. With partners, company bought Manhattan's GM Building for $2.8 billion last May; highest price ever paid for a building. Mort investing $200 million on 3 new printing presses for his New York Daily News: "I didn't go in media to maximize my profit." Also owns U.S. News & World Report; former weekly recently cut production, now comes out once a month. Claims to have anticipated market turmoil; moved nest egg to short-term bonds early last year. Has donated hundreds of millions of dollars to cancer research; charitable foundation ripped off by Madoff. Despite reports, says he is not running for the U.S. Senate.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Boston Properties', 'uri': 'companies/boston-properties', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: With 3 brothers Sulaiman, Saleh and Abdullah, built small money-changing business in Saudi's Najd desert into the world's largest Islamic bank, the $33 billion (assets) Al Rajhi Bank. Shariah-compliant finance proved as vulnerable to the downturn as its secular counterpart but shares are on the rebound: up 80% since last March's lows. Also heads Jannat Agricultural Investment Co., consortium of 7 Saudi agricultural firms investing in farming projects in Asia and Africa, in effort to diversify Kingdom's food supply beyond imports. With 6 sons, also owns country's third-largest steel producer, Al Rajhi Steel, and 2 gypsum factories.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former rice trader from family of modest means controls Malaysia Mining Corp. (MMC). Recent moves include taking over the national rice supplier, Padiberas Nasional. Through MMC, holds concessions to operate Port Tanjung Pelepas and Senai International Airport in Johor, and has interests in independent power producer, Malakoff. Also holds substantial interests in oil palm plantation and sugar refining businesses through Tradewinds Malaysia. Other business ventures includes Harrods in Malaysia. Sponsors the Islamic Arts Museum in Malaysia (Southeast Asia's largest), and gives scholarships to needy students through the Albukhary Foundation.

name: Billionaires
bio: Detroit-born property baron studied business, economics at Chapman U. in Orange County. Sought first fortune in grocery stores, eventually moved to real estate. Today privately held Arnel & Affiliates owns, manages 5,500 apartments and 2 million square feet of commercial space in southern California. Also owns private equity outfit West Star Capital; invests in health care, aerospace, consumer products. Former owner of pro baseball's Seattle Mariners also major donor to Republican Party; served as ambassador to Spain under President George W. Bush.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Arnel & Affiliates', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Reclusive tycoon became a billionaire after floating his sporting goods retailer Sports Direct International in February 2007. Retained a 70% stake in the company, which has 422 stores and owns brands like Kangol, Lonsdale and No Fear. Company lost $25 million in 2009 but shares more than doubled. Sold stake in JJB Sports to meet regulatory concerns. Locked in court battle with administrators of collapsed Icelandic bank Kaupthing's UK subsidiary over ownership of shares in struggling outdoor clothing chain Blacks Leisure. In February, picked up more shares in Blacks and more recently appears to be mulling a takeover bid.  In July 2007 he bought soccer club Newcastle United but has failed twice to sell it since then. Has become increasingly unpopular with fans as the team has slipped to a second-tier division.

name: Billionaires
bio: Media tycoon took control of Grupo Televisa, Mexico's largest TV contender, when his father died in 1997. Company operates radio, satellite, Internet and publishing businesses; in February bought 30% stake in telecom Nextel Mexico for reported $1.4 billion. Launched 24-hour TV news channel, ForoTV. In December 2009 Mexican Federal Competition Commission slapped Grupo with $3.7 million antitrust fine, reportedly the largest in commission history, for refusing to provide content to a small cable television competitor. In January 2009 it settled a lawsuit with Univision, the top U.S. Spanish-language broadcaster that Azcarraga Jean tried and failed to buy 2 years earlier. Also tangled with the Suprema Corte de Justicia de la Nación, which struck down provisions in a 2006 radio and television law designed to protect Televisa from new competition. In response, group is shoring up its efforts outside Mexico, exporting telenovelas to additional countries, including deal with the Chinese government to make Chinese versions of its soap operas. In recent years has diversified into off-track betting and a discount airline.

name: Billionaires
bio: Secretive founder of hedge fund Moore Capital faring admirably: main fund down 4.5% in 2008, up 21.3% in 2009. Spent summers manning fishing boat for NYSE board member Walter Frank; fellow angler persuaded Bacon to apply to Columbia Business School. Launched hedge fund Moore Capital 1989. First year returned 86% on bet that Gulf war would cause oil prices to spike. Today manages $14.6 billion, down from $20 billion in 2008. Bought Colorado ranch for $175 million from Forbes family 2007.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder and former chairman of Astroc Mediterraneo S.A. Made his debut as a billionaire in 2007 worth $7.7 billion. Lost $6.4 billion within a year amid rumors of inflated earnings and a cooling property market in Spain. Now holds under 3% of the company, renamed Afirma Grupo Inmobiliario.   Is reinventing himself in Latin America, notably Brazil. Has bought into several real estate companies now merged under Agre Empreendimentos Imobiliarios S.A., a real estate group that listed on the Brazilian stock exchange in February and in which he holds 30%. Runs a private foundation that promotes Spain's cultural heritage.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father died of leukemia when he was young; raised by sports-crazed mother. Became obsessed with making enough money by age 35 so his wife and kids wouldn't have to work if his father's fate befell him. Early jobs: pumping gas, mowing lawns, babysitting. Founded staffing firm Aerotek in basement with $3,500 at age 23. Now owns majority stake in Allegis Group, nation's largest staffing firm by sales ($5.5 billion). Owns NFL's Baltimore Ravens.
title: Owner

name: Billionaires
bio: Chicago real estate titan's gamble on casinos paying off despite sour economy. In 2008 won coveted license to build new gambling joint outside O'Hare airport; plans to share revenues with downtrodden neighboring towns. Opened Pittsburgh's Rivers Casino in August 2009, handled $14 million in wagers on opening day. Lead equity investor in SugarHouse Casino, which broke ground in Philadelphia in October. Former lawyer founded JMB Realty with U. of Illinois roommate 1970, grew into one of nation's largest developers. Also partner in Walton Street Capital; firm plans to invest $1.5 billion in real estate.

name: Billionaires
bio: Pittsburgh native majored in economics at Bucknell. Graduate studies at San Diego State. Emulates iconic bargain-hunter Benjamin Graham; identifies companies whose stocks are trading below intrinsic value. Founded Brandes Investment Partners in 1974. Firm's Global Equity Fund fell 44.3% in 2008; rallied 19.3% last year. Total assets: $53.1 billion, down from $120 billion in March 2007.

name: Billionaires
bio: Owns more than 50% of industrial holding company Caltagirone SpA. Investments in construction, cement makers, banks, utilities and media assets. Bought shares in down market: in insurer Generali, building-materials manufacturer Italcementi, and bank Monte dei Paschi di Siena. His personal financial holding company, ICAL, bought 2 buildings in Rome from Goldman Sachs fund for a reported $225 million. Dubbed Franco the Taciturn by media for his quiet ways.

name: Billionaires
bio: Creator of the original chicken sandwich opened Dwarf Grill sandwich shop with brother 1946. Undercut competition buying leftover chicken breasts too big for airplane trays. Launched first Chick-fil-A 1967 in Greenbriar Mall in Atlanta. Developed cultish customer loyalty in mall food courts across the South with tasty chicken sandwiches, nuggets, waffle fries. Today operates more than 1,400 stores in 38 states. Estimated sales: $3 billion. Devout Baptist closes stores on Sundays; keeping the Sabbath holy costs the company $500 million in annual revenues, we estimate.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, William (d. 2002), discovered opportunity in Asia following stint as General MacArthur's trade attaché in WWII, founded sourcing and logistics company in 1949. "Chip" started working for William E. Connor & Associates at age 12. Took reins 1980s. Studied at Stanford, M.B.A. from U. of Southern California, law degree from U.C., Santa Clara. Moved closely held outfit from Tokyo to Hong Kong; expanded to 35 offices in 20 countries. More than half of business comes from women's apparel, home goods; remainder from textiles, lighting, other apparel.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandchild of newspaper baron William Randolph Hearst regained $100 million in past year thanks to stakes in cable networks ESPN, Lifetime, A&E. Newspaper, magazine holdings continue to falter amid weak ad market. News Corp's Dow Jones announced it will buy Hearst's 50% stake in SmartMoney, ending a nearly 20-year partnership. Seattle Post-Intelligencer now publishes exclusively online after print operation shuttered last year. Hearst plans to introduce e-reader this year; "Skiff" will provide advertising next to newspaper and magazine articles. George Hearst owned mining stakes and land; U.S. senator became owner of floundering San Francisco Examiner newspaper in 1880 as payment for gambling debt. Son William (d. 1951) took reins 1887 and created newspaper empire based on sensational "yellow" journalism; built readership with what reportedly were exaggerated accounts and pictures of Spanish-American War. In addition to cable assets, Hearst Corp. owns 15 daily newspapers (Houston Chronicle, San Antonio Express-News), 15 U.S. magazines (Esquire, Harper's Bazaar), TV and radio stations.

name: Billionaires
bio: Plumber's son attended Hunter College, became a Xerox quality-control engineer 1965. Columbia M.B.A.; started Goldman Sachs' asset management arm. Founded Omega Advisors 1991. Investment firm managed $4.6 billion in December. Returned 54% net of fees last year, lost 34% in 2008.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Earned Stanford M.B.A. Met David Bonderman while working for Robert Bass. Duo left to pursue first deal together: salvaged Continental Airlines with $66 million investment, stake worth $700 million 5 years later. Started Texas Pacific Group (later renamed TPG) 1992. Highlights: Burger King, J.Crew, Petco. With affiliates TPG now manages $45 billion.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of a carpenter. Founded Sonae GSPS, maker of decorative laminates, in 1959. Later diversified into supermarkets, eventually becoming Portugal's biggest retailer through his Modelo Continente superstores and supermarket. Holds 53% stake in the now $7.4 billion (sales) company, which today has interests in tourism, car parks, real estate, shopping centers, a radio station, a newspaper and a maker of wood panels. Chairman of company. Son Paulo is CEO;  other son Nuno and daughter Claudia also work at the company.

name: Billionaires
bio: Hedge fund mogul enjoying recent market swell; on average his funds returned 40% net of fees in 2009. Assets: $13 billion. Raised middle class in Worcester, Mass. Studied economics at U. of Pennsylvania. Early career at investment bank Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, then Kellner, DiLeo & Co. Lost life savings in 1987 market crash, developed aversion to leverage. Founded York Capital 1991 with $3.6 million pitched in by former DLJ colleagues. Annual returns since: 16% net of fees.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Dropped out of school at age 16 and bought a second-hand truck. Lied about his age to get a license. Started selling soft drinks out of the back of a single truck in 1957. Today his Linfox has a truck fleet of 5,000, 20 million square feet of warehousing, 2 airports and 1,000 armored vehicles to transport cash. Former pro in Australian Rules Football League, also has large industrial and personal property holdings including Grand Prix racetrack on Victoria's Phillip Island. Still hands out truck-shaped business cards stating: Lindsay E. Fox, Truck Driver. Four of his 5 children work in the business, and the close-knit family lives in mansions within walking distance of one another. Avid car fan owns 130 rare classic cars (among them, a V12 Enzo Ferrari and 1937 Mercedes once owned by the German ambassador to London). Sold down stake in Bank of Queensland late this year, reportedly to expand his Linfox deeper into Asia.

name: Billionaires
bio: Early Berkshire Hathaway investor's net worth recovered after market collapse. His 10,000 Berkshire shares up 30% since February 2009. Harvard Business School grad has been friend of Warren Buffett since 1962; serves on Berkshire board. Founded investment adviser First Manhattan 1964. With wife, Ruth, donated $25 million to Yeshiva University medical school last year.
title: Chief Executive Officer
employment: {'name': 'First Manhattan Co.', 'title': 'Chief Executive Officer', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Inherited a beauty and health care products company from her late husband in 1975. Also has a 7.5% stake in watchmaker Swatch, now worth over $500 million. Biggest part of her fortune comes from her collection of 20th century art, which reportedly includes over 600 pieces by such artists as Pablo Picasso, Paul Cezanne, Salvador Dali, Francis Bacon and Alberto Giacometti. Keeps the works in a converted printing factory where she also lives.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former chemistry professor, borrowed wife's savings to buy a tiny vitamin company in 1968. Today, his Lupin is the world's largest maker of tuberculosis drugs and among India's top five pharmaceutical firms. It derives two thirds of its $833 million revenues from exports. As part of its strategy to tap the American market, it paid $38 million in September to acquire the US rights for Antara, an anti-cholesterol drug. It is locked in a patent battle with Teva Pharmaceuticals over its generic version of Teva's birth control pill, in the US. Daughter Vinita, who studied at the Kellogg School, and son Nilesh, a Wharton grad, work with him. Wife Manju sits on Lupin's board.

name: Billionaires
bio: Partner in Leon Black's private equity outfit, Apollo Global Management. U. of Pennsylvania grad attended Harvard Business School. Stint in M&A at now defunct junk bond purveyor Drexel Burnham Lambert. Created Apollo with Black 1990. Firm's first 2 funds returned 37% a year net of fees. Assets under management last fall: $51.8 billion. Serves on Corporate Affairs Committee at Council of Foreign Relations, Wharton's Undergraduate Executive Board.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandchild of newspaper baron William Randolph Hearst regained $100 million in past year thanks to stakes in cable networks ESPN, Lifetime, A&E. Newspaper, magazine holdings continue to falter amid weak ad market. News Corp's Dow Jones announced it will buy Hearst's 50% stake in SmartMoney, ending a nearly 20-year partnership. Seattle Post-Intelligencer now publishes exclusively online after print operation shuttered last year. Hearst plans to introduce e-reader this year; "Skiff" will provide advertising next to newspaper and magazine articles. George Hearst owned mining stakes and land; U.S. senator became owner of floundering San Francisco Examiner newspaper in 1880 as payment for gambling debt. Son William (d. 1951) took reins 1887 and created newspaper empire based on sensational "yellow" journalism; built readership with what reportedly were exaggerated accounts and pictures of Spanish-American War. In addition to cable assets, Hearst Corp. owns 15 daily newspapers (Houston Chronicle, San Antonio Express-News), 15 U.S. magazines (Esquire, Harper's Bazaar), TV and radio stations.

bio: Grandchild of newspaper baron William Randolph Hearst regained $100 million in past year thanks to stakes in cable networks ESPN, Lifetime, A&E. Newspaper, magazine holdings continue to falter amid weak ad market. News Corp's Dow Jones announced it will buy Hearst's 50% stake in SmartMoney, ending a nearly 20-year partnership. Seattle Post-Intelligencer now publishes exclusively online after print operation shuttered last year. Hearst plans to introduce e-reader this year; "Skiff" will provide advertising next to newspaper and magazine articles. George Hearst owned mining stakes and land; U.S. senator became owner of floundering San Francisco Examiner newspaper in 1880 as payment for gambling debt. Son William (d. 1951) took reins 1887 and created newspaper empire based on sensational "yellow" journalism; built readership with what reportedly were exaggerated accounts and pictures of Spanish-American War. In addition to cable assets, Hearst Corp. owns 15 daily newspapers (Houston Chronicle, San Antonio Express-News), 15 U.S. magazines (Esquire, Harper's Bazaar), TV and radio stations.

Newspaper, magazine holdings continue to falter amid weak ad market. News Corp's Dow Jones announced it will buy Hearst's 50% stake in SmartMoney, ending a nearly 20-year partnership. Seattle Post-Intelligencer now publishes exclusively online after print operation shuttered last year. Hearst plans to introduce e-reader this year; "Skiff" will provide advertising next to newspaper and magazine articles. George Hearst owned mining stakes and land; U.S. senator became owner of floundering San Francisco Examiner newspaper in 1880 as payment for gambling debt. Son William (d. 1951) took reins 1887 and created newspaper empire based on sensational "yellow" journalism; built readership with what reportedly were exaggerated accounts and pictures of Spanish-American War. In addition to cable assets, Hearst Corp. owns 15 daily newspapers (Houston Chronicle, San Antonio Express-News), 15 U.S. magazines (Esquire, Harper's Bazaar), TV and radio stations.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former billionaire Michael Heisley passed away in late April 2014 at age 77. He founded Heico Companies, a Chicago holding company that specialized in buying underperforming or bankrupt companies to turn them around. He started in 1979 by buying Conco, a maker of sewer and drain equipment, with $150,000 in profit from selling his home and $10 million in bank loans. Heico expanded and bought several struggling Rust Belt manufacturers. He bought the Vancouver Grizzlies NBA basketball team and moved them to Memphis. He sold the team to a group led by technology billionaire Robert Pera in 2012. The Grizzlies made the playoffs in 2011.  Heisley was last on the Forbes Billionaires list in 2012. He fell off the list the following year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Satellite TV legend growing subscriber base for his ReelzChannel; movie information and trivia channel now available in more than 46 million homes. "It's unfortunate for cable, but good for us." Father, Stanley Eugene (d. 1992), founded one of the first commercial U.S. airlines; it went bust. Built radio station 1923, TV station 25 years later. Son Stub took charge 1981; started direct-satellite TV with U.S. Satellite Broadcasting. Public 1996; sold 3 years later for $1.3 billion to Hughes/DirecTV. Introduced Reelz in 2006. DirecTV shares up 50% in past year. Newest venture: Hubbard Aviation Technologies; outfit will manufacture technology for Gulfstream 2 and Gulfstream 3 aircraft.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Hubbard Broadcasting, Inc.', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Penny-pinching consumers and falling commodity prices supporting Little Caesar's bottom line throughout economic slowdown. Recession hampering other fortune: wife, Marian, owns Detroit's MotorCity Casino Hotel; gambling industry recently crushed as cost-conscious consumers avoid the tables and slots. Owner of pro hockey's Detroit Red Wings, pro baseball's Detroit Tigers.

name: Billionaires
bio: Joined Harris County, Tex. prosecutor's office 1953 after graduating from University of Texas; replaced district attorney after he was impeached for "running a string of whorehouses." Started personal injury firm. Got rich representing Pennzoil against Texaco 1987; $11 billion lawsuit lined coffers with estimated $345 million fee. Currently sitting in ultra-safe AAA bonds. "When you got this much money, you don't need to try anymore." Recently donated $15 million to alma mater; 30% of students in UT's nursing school are currently on Jamail scholarships.

name: Billionaires
bio: Born in Berlin, Jarislowsky moved to Canada in 1949 after earning his M.B.A. at Harvard. Six years later founded Jarislowsky Fraser, asset manager that today manages $44 billion on behalf of institutional clients and high net worth individuals. Convinced there's a housing bubble "waiting to burst" in Canada. In addition to eclectic art collection that includes jade, Chinese furniture and Eskimo artifacts, owns private island in British Columbia with 16 miles of shoreline. Holds degree in fine art from University of Chicago. Moonlights as professor of investment analysis at various universities, including Queens University, McGill University and University of Victoria, BC.

name: Billionaires
bio: Farmer's son founded Commonwealth Brands 1990, made fortune with discount cigarettes. Left advertising budget sparse; outperformed big brands by keeping prices low. Sold for $1 billion 2001. Reinvested in real estate: owns 1.7 million acres in New Mexico, Florida, Texas. One of the 10 largest landowners in U.S. Opted out of market volatility; claims to have taken defensive position in Treasuries, avoided 2008 market meltdown.

name: Billionaires
bio: Pharma maven sidestepped financial maelstrom by cashing out early. Sold New River Pharmaceutical to Shire in 2007 for $2.6 billion. His take: $1.2 billion. Son of a drill sergeant claims he was reading parents' Funk & Wagnalls encyclopedia by age 4. Attended U. of Virginia law school; before graduating cobbled together group to buy local TV station. Deal scuttled by burgeoning popularity of cable. Next venture a hit: formed pharmaceutical distribution company with pharmacist and physician; sold to Henry Schein in 1998 for $145 million. Started New River; developed abuse-resistant ADHD pill. Now invests in biotech startups via Third Security.

name: Billionaires
bio: "Bob" owns the New England Patriots, NFL's third-most-valuable team. Bought struggling franchise in 1994 for record $172 million; today squad worth $1.4 billion. Team has won 3 Super Bowls this decade. Father was clothingmaker. Bob studied at Columbia, then Harvard M.B.A. Joined packing firm Rand-Whitney. Later bought company, diversified. Today Kraft Group controls real estate, paper companies, private equity, New England Revolution soccer team. Partnered with Massachusetts Lottery for $150 million Patriots game. Winners get cash, lifetime season tickets, autographed memorabilia.
title: Chairman & CEO
employment: {'name': 'The Kraft Group', 'title': 'Chairman & CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: World's largest cutter and polisher of diamonds is trying to hold his empire together. Sold select properties, acquired via his Tel Aviv-traded conglomerate, and put liens on his holdings in company he controls, Africa Israel Investments, to meet debt obligations. High end diamond business hit hard by economic downturn though there are signs worst is over as demand picks up.  Born in Uzbekistan, his Lubavitcher Jewish family fled to Israel in 1971. Made his name undercutting De Beers diamond cartel, striking his own deals with diamond-producing countries like Russia and Angola.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of fishmonger became successful stockbroker for wealthy Indonesian clients; nicknamed King of the Remisiers (Singapore term for stockbroker). Stopped managing other people's money in 1996 to become full-time investor. Bet $10 million on palm oil producer Wilmar; holding is now worth $1.4 billion. Also holds stakes in fashion retailer FJ Benjamin, investment firm Rowsley Ltd. and brewery restaurant Brewerkz.

name: Billionaires
bio: New York native studied economics at Wharton before joining father's cosmetics firm 1958. Pushed product line beyond makeup: developed Permalens, first permanent soft contact lens. Sold operation for $60 million 1971; first sale of lucrative startup streak. Founded Vision Cable 1972; built subscriber base to 230,000, sold to Newhouse brothers for $220 million decade later. Flipped his cell phone firm Metro Mobile to Bell Atlantic for $2.5 billion 1991. Now in energy: chairman of Southern Union, third-largest natural gas pipeline company in U.S. Stock up more than 65% since last February.

name: Billionaires
bio: Deputy chairman of $1.6 billion (sales) Coloplast, a Danish health care company that makes medical devices in the fields of ostomy and urology such as colostomy bags and catheters; Also makes dressings for wounds.  Owns a third of the public company. His late father, Aage Louis-Hansen, founded the business in 1957; took it public in 1983.

name: Billionaires
bio: In 1981, took over L.E. Lundbergforetagen AB, founded by his father Lars in 1944 as a construction company.  Controls 53% of the $2.9 billion (sales) diversified holding company with interests in property management and investments; has about 150 properties in its portfolio. His two daughters have their own stakes in the firm, worth a total of $400 million, not reflected in dad's net worth.  Enjoys hunting and curling; was once a junior world champion of curling.

name: Billionaires
bio: Gained notoriety during the Bank of New York money-laundering scandal at the end of the 1990s, when the Moscow State University graduate was known as "the Yeltsin family banker." (No charges were filed against him in connection with the case.) One of the founders of Imperial Bank, at one point ran MDM-Bank and was a major investor in Troika-Dialog investment bank and Ingosstrakh insurance company. In recent years has preferred the role of portfolio investor, putting money into real estate, retail, construction and oil fields. Co-owner of the Evroset cell-phone retail chain. In 2007 bought the American-based blogging site LiveJournal.com, extremely popular among Russian users. Last year invested in the Netherlands-based Spar retail chain's Russian licensee. Pet projects: Torpedo football club, cultural center, Art-Strelka, and art-house cinema theater, Pioneer.

name: Billionaires
bio: Money man fought back after turbulent 2008. Pair of hedge funds at his Lone Pine Capital up 12% and 18% last year; firm's two "long-only" funds were up 44% and 75%. Assets: $16 billion. Big holdings in December: Apple, Qualcomm, Hewlett Packard. First job after business school: consulting at Mars & Co. Worked at Goldman Sachs before joining Julian Robertson's Tiger Management as consumer analyst; second eldest of the "Tiger Cubs," group of star managers groomed by Robertson. Launched Lone Pine 1997. Firm said to have returned 20% annually net of fees. Dartmouth devotee sits on college's board; named hedge fund after Dartmouth pine that survived 1887 lightning strike, according to college lore. Director of Teach for America.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Started do-it-yourself paradise Home Depot with partner Arthur Blank after getting fired from now defunct Handy Dan; took outfit public 3 years later. Hung up tool belt in 2002 to focus on philanthropy. Donated $250 million to open world's largest Georgia Aquarium 2005. Marcus Autism Center opened in Atlanta 2008.
title: Co-founder, ex chairman of the board
employment: {'name': 'Home Depot', 'uri': 'companies/home-depot', 'title': 'Co-founder, ex chairman of the board', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Worked night shift loading trucks in warehouse of family grocery distribution center 1959; McLane Company grew into international holding company spanning 18 divisions, including food service, software and novelty gifts. Sold out to friend and tennis partner Sam Walton for 10.4 million shares of Walmart stock and $50 million cash 1991. Diversified fortune includes logistics and information technology outfit McLane Group. Added Houston Astros to portfolio in 1992 for $103 million; reportedly interested in selling team for $650 million. Forbes estimated value for team: $525 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Wales-born venture capitalist turned rubber into gold last year despite the dull deal market; his Sequoia Capital flipped hip online shoe retailer Zappos to Amazon for $1.2 billion in stock and cash. Also sold video-camera maker Pure Digital to Cisco for $590 million in March 2009. Studied history at Oxford, then got Wharton M.B.A. Became a journalist. Joined Sequoia 1986. First big hits: Yahoo, PayPal. Then Google. Firm's initial $12.5 million investment in search behemoth now worth billions. Unattractively portrayed in quasi-fictional Facebook exposé The Accidental Billionaires as a "Bond villain."
title: Partner

name: Billionaires
bio: Press-shy aeronautical engineer built world's largest manufacturer of electrical heating appliances (stoves, electrical fireplaces, space heaters, decorative fires, water heaters). Founded Glen Electric in 1973; acquired Dimplex four years later. Became sole owner of Glen Dimplex in 2003. Estimated sales in 2009: $1.7 billion. Trustee emeritus at University of Notre Dame.

name: Billionaires
bio: Broadcom cofounder is a free man after a mountain of drug distribution and options backdating charges were thrown out in January. Judge declared the cases reeked of government misconduct. Met future partner Henry Samueli at defense contractor TRW. Designed high-speed telecom chips in Nicholas' spare bedroom. Founded Broadcom in 1991; took public 7 years later. Worth $10 billion in 2000; lost $8 billion in a year. Nicholas left in 2003. Won't be a billionaire for long; next legal battle will be with ex-wife, Stacey, over the couple's estate.
title: Cofounder

name: Billionaires
bio: California property tycoon suing UBS and others for $500 million, alleging the banks broke promise to invest his cash in only conservative securities. Pleaded guilty to tax felony 2007 for stashing more than $350 million in Europe; paid $52 million in fines, sentenced to 2 years probation and 120 hours community service. Today his Olen Properties owns more than 6.4 million square feet of office space, nearly 12,000 residential units in Las Vegas, Arizona, Florida. Opened restaurant in honor of son Andrei, who died in a 2005 car accident. Daughter Natalia insisted on green food. Olenicoff: "I'll have to find an organic vodka."

name: Billionaires
bio: His late father, a former pharmacy professor, co-founded a pharma empire that got divided in 1995. He inherited the Zydus Cadila group. Derives fortune from 75% stake in listed flagship Cadila Healthcare, maker of branded and generic drugs and rabies vaccines. Partnered with Eli Lilly for discovery and development of cardiovascular drugs. Also developing a swine flu vaccine to be launched in May. Group's Zydus Wellness makes Sugar Free, country's largest selling sugar substitute. In move to expand overseas, acquired generic firms in South Africa, Spain, Japan and Brazil, in past three years. Aiming to boost sales, currently at $647  million to $3 billion by 2015. Son Sharvil is deputy managing director of Cadila Healthcare.

name: Billionaires
bio: Began buying up tracts of California farmland and converting to office parks in the 1960s. Today, with property partner John Arrillaga, oversees more than 14 million square feet of land and office buildings in and around San Jose. Spent past 4 years selling off half their portfolio; sold 5.3 million square feet of office and R&D space 2006 for $1.1 billion. Dearth of venture capital deals pushing up vacancy rates in Silicon Valley buildings.

name: Billionaires
bio: After family split in 1996, built his privately held K. Raheja Corp into leading property developer. Portfolio includes malls, supermarkets, hotels, offices and business parks. Group prides itself on constructing 'green', eco-friendly buildings. Is building Vivarea, a 41-story tower of luxury apartments in South Mumbai, to be completed this year. New hotels include a 428-room Westin in Hyderabad where he's also building a 300-acre special economic zone. Only listed entity is department store chain Shoppers Stop. Sons Ravi and Neel work with him.

name: Billionaires
bio: With brother Jude, lords over Reyes Holdings, massive food and beer distribution conglomerate. Sales: $12 billion. Purchased small South Carolina beer distributor for $740,000 in 1976. Bought Chicago Beverage Systems 3 years later; today delivers over 10 million cases of brew annually. Expanded into food: bought McDonald's largest U.S. supplier Martin-Brower 1998; today outfit delivers burgers and fries to all Canadian, thousands of U.S. Micky D's locations. Named McDonald's Supplier of the Year in November. Added $2 billion in annual revenue with acquisition of Reinhart FoodService in 2004; services sporting venues, schools, hospitals. Reigns as cochairmen; brother David runs beer outfit, James commands real estate.
title: Co-Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: With brother Christopher lords over Reyes Holdings, massive food and beer distribution conglomerate. Sales: $12 billion. Family purchased small South Carolina beer distributor for $740,000 in 1976. Bought Chicago Beverage Systems 3 years later; today delivers over 10 million cases of brew annually. Expanded into food: bought McDonald's largest supplier, Martin-Brower, 1998; today outfit delivers burgers and fries to every Canadian, thousands of U.S. Micky D's locations. Added $2 billion in annual revenue with acquisition of Reinhart FoodService in 2004; services sporting venues, schools, hospitals. Chris and Jude reign as cochairman; brother David runs beer outfit, James commands real estate.
title: Co-Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Vietnam vet's Majestic Realty one of country's largest commercial builders: 60 million square feet in Los Angeles, Denver, Las Vegas, Dallas. Built Staples Center arena in Los Angeles with Philip Anschutz; also owns stakes in pro basketball's L.A. Lakers, hockey's L.A. Kings. Wants to build a 75,000-seat football stadium outside of L.A. in hopes of luring a team back there for the 2011 NFL season; reportedly settled lawsuit brought by residents complaining over stadium's environmental impact. Two daughters joined business in December. USC grad donated $23 million to alma mater's fine arts school 2006.
title: President and Chairman
employment: {'name': 'Majestic Realty, Co.', 'title': 'President and Chairman', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Middle son of Orascom conglomerate founder Onsi Sawiris. Samih owns and runs family's real estate and hotel division with operations in Egypt, Jordan, Oman, UAE, Switzerland, Mauritius, and Morocco. Shares in Orascom Development Holding have gone up 150% over the past year. Fluent in German, has engineering degree from Berlin Institute of Technology. Founded first company, National Marine Boat Factory, in the 1980s. Established El Gouna Beverages Co. in 1997, which he sold in 2001 when it was the largest beverage company in Egypt.

name: Billionaires
bio: Widow of Charles Schusterman (d. 2000), who started in oil and gas business 1961. Founded Samson Resources a decade later; grew into one of world's largest privately held energy companies. Daughter Stacy today runs Samson Investment; spent $4 billion in past 3 years on drilling and development. Operates more than 4,000 oil and gas wells; owns interests in another 11,000. Majority of revenues come from natural gas; net worth down $1 billion in a year as energy prices dropped. Charles & Lynn Schusterman Family Foundation promotes Jewish learning, art and culture; more than $100 million in assets.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former government official started career in commercial real estate and retail in home province of Zhejiang before relocating to Beijing. Chairs Intime Department Store, one of China's largest department store chains. Developed Yintai Center in Beijing, one of the city's tallest towers. Also has a stake in the company that develops property along Beijing subway system.

name: Billionaires
bio: Vice chairman of Lotte Group since 1997 and chief executive of Lotte Shopping since 2006, Shin is the second son of the group's founder Shin Kyuk-ho. He studied business at Aoyama Gakuin University in Japan and received his MBA from Columbia University. Once worked at Nomura Securities. Now playing a major role in expanding Lotte into global markets. Lotte Department Store opened in Moscow in 2007 and Beijing in 2008, with new branches to open in Tianjin and other major cities in China and Hanoi in 2013. Lotte Chilsung Beverage, the company's soft drink firm, acquired Doosan Corporation's liquor unit for $45 million early last year. Its Korea Seven subsidiary bought retailer Buy The Way.

name: Billionaires
bio: Eldest son of Shin Kyuk-Ho is vice president of Lotte in Japan and lives in Tokyo. Sits on boards of Lotte Chilsung Beverage, Lotte Hotel, Lotte Aluminum. Shares of Lotte soared in the past year.

name: Billionaires
bio: India-born entrepreneur joined Netscape 1994. Created online shopping site Junglee; sold to Amazon in 1998. Founded venture firm Sherpalo 2000, became early investor, board member of Google. Still owns nearly 900,000 shares; search giant stock up 70% in past year. Sold voice-application company TellMe to Microsoft 2007, took career site Naukri public same year. Current ventures in mobile and cloud technology: Bump Technologies, ZumoDrive, In-Mobi and Inkling.
title: Managing Partner

name: Billionaires
bio: Medical device fortune slowly on the mend; Stryker Corp. stock up 20% in past 12 months. Shares lagging market recovery. Surgeon grandfather Homer Stryker (d. 1980) invented mobile hospital bed; founded medical supply Stryker Corp. 1941. Father, Lee, died in plane crash 1976; John Brown became chief executive. Public 1979. Today company produces hospital beds, joint replacements, medical software, surgical cameras. Sales: $6.7 billion. Pat, founder of Bohemian Foundation.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mall tycoon making big comeback: shares of his Taubman Centers up more than 100% since last February. Trying to lure Hollywood to Michigan. Backing Raleigh Michigan Studios, movie studio complex housed in former GM truck plant in Pontiac, Mich. U. of Michigan dropout founded Taubman Centers 1950; today firm owns 25 malls in 16 states. Son Robert joined 1976, chief executive since 1990; son William chief operating officer. Bought Sotheby's auction house 1983; took private, then public again 1988. Served 9 months in jail for price-fixing 2004. Shares of Sotheby's down 35% in past 12 months. Owns large contemporary art collection.

name: Billionaires
bio: Trained physicist, he and four former IBM colleagues founded German software company SAP in 1972; with 2009  sales and software profits down during the downturn, SAP is restructuring. Retired from SAP in 1998.  Stepped down from its supervisory board in May 2007. Devotes his time to his Klaus Tschira Foundation, one of Germany's largest philanthropies.  Foundation  supports  scientific research and cultural projects such as a youth software prize given to students who explain math or sciences matters to their peers with the clever use of software.

name: Billionaires
bio: Engineer spent summers working with dad as welder's assistant on a pipeline. Cofounded natural-gas pipeline firm Energy Transfer in 1995 and bought up struggling gas assets. Today company operates more than 17,500 miles of pipelines in ten states. Also runs gas processing and storage facilities; propane delivery. Company structured as a Master Limited Partnership; split into 2 high yielding securities. Limited partnership ETP up 35% since last February; general partner ETE surged 70%. Music fan a cofounder of Music Road Records; throws festival on Rio Grande ranch to raise money for education.

name: Billionaires
bio: Harvard graduate and cofounder of Royal Caribbean, whose stock nearly quintupled in value over last year. Pocketed at least $500 million in 2008 when China Oilfield Services acquired all of Awilco Offshore, including his 40% stake, for $2.5 billion. Chairs the family investment company, with stakes in oil tankers, Russian hotels and Baltic shopping centers. Also owns private Norwegian real estate outfit Linstow.

name: Billionaires
bio: One of China's richest Internet entrepreneur cofounded Tencent in 1999 with fellow billionaire Ma Huateng. Zhang, who has a masters in computer application and system structure, is now its chief technology officer. Its powerful "QQ" brand has attracted almost 500 million regular users that have made it China's most popular provider of online chat services, also a leader in online games. English name is Tony.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded textile company with brother Zeki Zorlu, turning it into Turkey's largest exporter. Now his Zorlu holding company is active in consumer electronics and energy industries. Owns private-label TV maker and distributor Vestel. Building wind farm in Pakistan. Sits on boards of 29 companies. High school dropout shuttles around Europe in custom-designed helicopter.

name: Billionaires
bio: Began buying up tracts of California farmland and converting to office parks in the 1960s. Today, with property partner Richard Peery, oversees more than 14 million square feet of land and office buildings in and around San Jose. Spent past 4 years selling off half their portfolio; sold 5.3 million square feet of office and R&D space 2006 for $1.1 billion. Dearth of venture capital deals pushing up vacancy rates in Silicon Valley buildings.

name: Billionaires
bio: Borrowed $1,600 to invest in nursing home operator Manor Care 1969. Founded Baron Capital 1982; today manages $15.2 billion. Array of funds recovering amid recent market rally. Hosts popular annual investors conference; past conferences have featured performances by Elton John, Billy Joel, Paul Simon. Bookended real estate bubble with purchase of $103 million Hamptons mansion in 2007; recently in trouble with locals over wall he allegedly built along protected sand dunes on property. Other assets: Aspen real estate, art.

name: Billionaires
bio: Third generation to run Bauer Media Group, mass-media company founded by his grandfather 1875. The $2.8 billion (sales)  group publishes everything from TV guides to special interest publications like Auto Zeitung (cars) and Kochen & Geniessen (cooking), to magazines like Neue Post and Das Neue Blatt. U.S. titles include First for Women, Woman's World and InTouch. Sells in 14 countries including Mexico, Russia and China. Is one of Britain's largest radio producers after acquiring various divisions from British media company Emap in 2007. Daughter Yvonne is now CEO of Bauer Media Group and presumably will take over at the company when her father steps down.

name: Billionaires
bio: His Unitech, India's second largest property firm, survived its near-death experience in 2008 when it almost buckled under a mountain of debt and jittery investors battered company's stock price to an all-time low. Since then, company has raised over $1billion through a private placement and sale of assets, including a hotel and an office building, to help pay off expensive debt. It launched Unihomes, a range of low-cost apartments, which boosted sales. Is also expanding outside New Delhi, notably in Mumbai where it is redeveloping a suburban slum. Its Unitech Wireless, in which Norway's Telenor has two-thirds stake, launched mobile phone services under the brand Uninor.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Ashmore Group, a London fund manager specializing in emerging-market debt with $32 billion under management. Fund's assets fell by a third in value in market turmoil of 2008, but have since recovered along with share price. Took company public 2006, raising $2 billion. Started career at Australia & New Zealand Banking Group and rose through the ranks of the emerging-market division. Launched what is now Ashmore in 1992 with other ANZ Group alumni; officially became independent in 1999.

name: Billionaires
bio: Started Poland's largest leasing business, Europejski Fundusz Leasingowy, in 1991. Sold his stake 10 years later to French bank Credit Agricole for $280 million. Since then has concentrated on building a banking, insurance and real estate conglomerate. His publicly listed bank Getin Holding which focuses on retail clients and wealthier individuals, has been affected by a growing number of non-performing loans due to the economic slowdown. Yet signs economy improving: his flagship development - to build one of Poland's tallest high-rises in Wroclaw - has restarted. His Noble Bank folded into Getin; combined group on acquisition hunt.

name: Billionaires
bio: Born in Kenya, spent teens in India. Earned engineering degree from Indian Institute of Technology; moved to U.S. after landing programming job for Tata Consultancy Services in 1976. Founded outsourcing outfit Syntel in 1980 with wife, Neerja Sethi, while earning his M.B.A. from U. of Michigan. Public 1997; shares up 500% since. Revenues in 2009: $419 million, up 2% from 2008. Company now has 12,500 employees. Stepped down as chief executive last year; remains chairman. Played for India in 1994 bridge world championship. Recently established foundation supporting entrepreneurship and education.
title: Chairman and Co-founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Steep rise in natural resources over the past year has boosted Edwards back into the Billionaires Club. Media-shy lawyer-turned-financier also owns big stakes in Ensign Energy, Canada's second-biggest oil services company, and Penn West, one of Canada's biggest energy trusts. Also owns Lake Louise, Canada's famous ski resort, and a chunk of the Calgary Flames hockey team. With wife pledged $1 million over the next five years to create the Edwards Legendary Leaders Series, program designed to bring worldwide acclaimed artists to Banff Centre of culture.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fang's fortune comes from investing in laggard state-owned companies and improving their performance. He leads Shanghai-listed Fangda Carbon New Material, one of China's largest makers of carbon products such as bricks and paste used by the steel industry. In late October, he took control of a second listed company, Fangda Special Steel. He also has unlisted mineral investments.

name: Billionaires
bio: Heads Israeli conglomerate Federmann Enterprises started by late father and uncle. Chairs boards of its 2 biggest publicly traded holdings: defense elctronics maker Elbit Systems and luxury hotel operator Dan Hotels Corp. The hotel group began as a boarding house on the Tel Aviv seafront; now expanding into India. Also deputy chairman of the board of the Hebrew University in Jerusalem and a board member of Weizmann Institute of Science.

name: Billionaires
bio: Volatile few years for chief Yahoo. Turned down $44.6 billion takeover bid from Microsoft in 2008; Carl Icahn led proxy battle to replace board, oust Jerry Yang as chief executive. Yahoo came to agreement with shareholder activist weeks later. Yang stepped down in November 2008; hired Carol Bartz to run Yahoo. Formed partnership with Microsoft in July; Microsoft will provide Bing search engine, Yahoo will run ad sales. Icahn stepped down from board in October. Stock up 26% in past year. Met Yang as Stanford grad student, duo left Ph.D. program 1995 to form Web portal.
title: Chief Yahoo (director)

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of growth investor Philip Fisher (d. 2004) studied forestry, economics at Humboldt State U.
