Left job at father's side, launched money management outfit that would become Fisher Investments 1973. Early proponent of price-to-sales ratio believes companies' earnings are misleading as indicators of future financial strength. Record enviable: between 1997 and 2006 achieved an average annual return of 11.7% compared with S&P 500's 6.8%. Regrets taking bullish stance in 2008: "Usually getting out is the bigger risk." Assets under management $36 billion.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fortune of vehicle distributor falling as Toyota recall shakes confidence in car maker. Secretive ex-Hollywood stunt pilot built fortune as a middleman between Toyota and southern car dealerships. Today Gulf States Toyota drives Friedkin Cos.; has exclusive distribution rights for Toyota vehicles, parts in Texas, Louisiana, Mississippi, Oklahoma, Arkansas. Sales believed to exceed $4 billion. Fortune hampered by crash of the car market. Son Dan chairman of Gulf States. Hunts big game on Tanzania reserve.

name: Billionaires
bio: Runs Benesse, Japan's largest distance-learning school, known for its Berlitz language schools. Other units provide elder and child-care services and student loans. Has a publishing arm that prints child-care books for lifestyle magazines and new moms. Tied up with Toys "R" Us to sell educational toys in Japan. Expanding overseas with correspondence school in South Korea, Taiwan and more recently in China.

name: Billionaires
bio: Patriarch of Jaypee Group whose listed Jaiprakash Associates, chaired by son Manoj, is expanding aggressively on back of increased public spending on infrastructure. India's largest private sector producer of hydropower; also has interests in cement, thermal power, construction, roads and real estate. Merging four subsidiary units into listed flagship last year, it raised $365 million through a partial sale of treasury shares created as a result of the merger. Cash will fund expansion, notably in cement. Plans to list infrastructure arm Jaypee Infratech, which is building a 165 km long expressway connecting Delhi to Agra, site of the Taj Mahal. It is also developing India's first Formula One racing track near Delhi.

name: Billionaires
bio: Longtime New Yorker moved to Florida after Albany passed state's new "millionaire tax" last May. "I'm not bailing out on the state. If anything, New York has bailed out on us." Political junkie mounted 3 failed New York State gubernatorial campaigns with his Independence Party; last attempt reportedly cost $90 million of his own money. Founded political action committee Responsible New York in 2008; sought to free Albany from the grip of special interest groups. Used $3,000 and a credit card to form Paychex in 1971; provided payroll services to small businesses. Expanded through joint ventures and franchising; went public 1983. Stake worth more than $1 billion; stock up 10% in a year. Donated $4 million to Ave Maria University in November for it's first indoor athletic facility. Said to be dating former tennis phenom Monica Seles. Owns NHL's Buffalo Sabres.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of slain Lebanese prime minister Rafiq Hariri, inherited stake in his father's massive construction, telecom and real estate empire Saudi Oger after his death in 2005. Now based in Riyadh, helps oversee family's investments in telecom, media and real estate while older brother Saad carries on political legacy as Lebanon's prime minister. Georgetown-educated engineer got start at global fixed-satellite-provider Intelsat. Now chairs U.S. identity-software management firm Epok, which sells to federal and state customers. Also serves on board of South African mobile phone operator Cell C.

name: Billionaires
bio: Youngest son of slain Lebanese prime minister Rafiq Hariri inherited stake in his father's massive construction, telecom and real estate empire Saudi Oger after his death in 2005. Serves on board of family's Future TV, a satellite and terrestrial television network covering the Middle East. Hariri, who reportedly lives in Dubai, is involved in UAE projects including a five-star hotel due to open in Abu Dhabi in 2011.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chicagoan raised in football family. Father Robert (d. 1997) bought Baltimore Colts in 1972 for $15 million; shocked Charm City residents by smuggling franchise to Indianapolis in 1984 after locking horns with city government for years. Graduated from Southern Methodist U., went from ticket counter to general manager in 2 years. Father's death in 1997 launched legal fight with stepmother for team ownership; emerged as league's youngest owner at 37. Colts won Super Bowl in 2006. Team was outlasted by New Orleans Saints in Super Bowl XLIV in February.
title: CEO

name: Billionaires
bio: The son of a pharmacist cobbled together 1,925 pharmacies to create one of the biggest pharmacy chains in North America. Sold remaining 25 Snyders Drug Stores in Minnesota to Walgreens after unsuccessful attempt to expand in US. Starting in the 1990s Katz bought up distressed pharmacy chains with the help of drug distributor McKesson, then hired capable executives to turn the chains around. Bought Edmonton Oilers for $200 million in 2008. Has spent first few months of 2010 defending plan for downtown arena stadium.

name: Billionaires
bio: Korean immigrant came to U.S. in 1955. Former law student started Amkor Electronics in 1968 as American sales/design partner to father H.S. Kim's Korean chipmaker, Anam Semiconductor. Public 1998. Created Electronics Boutique mall kiosks with wife, Agnes, in 1977; bought out by GameStop in 2005 for $1.4 billion.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ankara-born heiress is youngest sister of magnate Rahmi Koc, head of family conglomerate Koc Group. Fluent in French and English, is former recipient of Woman of the Year award sponsored by university women's group in Turkey. Honorary Fellow of London Business School also named a library for herself at a university founded by her family. Continues to fight serious illness, Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS).

name: Billionaires
bio: Morocco native attended Clark U., then New York Law School. Clerked for bankruptcy judge in Southern District of New York. Later became co-director of bankruptcy department at Cowen & Co. With sister Sonia Gardner founded distressed-debt brokerage Amroc Investments 1989. Launched hedge fund Avenue Capital 1995. Sold 15% stake to Morgan Stanley for $275 million 2006. Flagship fund fell 25% in 2008; soared 66% last year. Assets in December: $20.1 billion.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: President of Shinsegae Group and Korea's richest woman. Youngest daughter of late Samsung Group founder Lee Byung Chull and younger sister of former Samsung Group Chairman Lee Kun Hee. Shinsegae was owned by Samsung until the two separated in 1991. Shinsegae Group is nation's second-largest retailer after Lotte Group. Recently promoted son Chung Yong-jin to Vice Chairman.

name: Billionaires
bio: Construction tycoon, who was one of the first to win a coveted gaming license, is once again a billionaire thanks to rebound in his Galaxy Entertainment. Upped budget of his megaresort on Cotai by 40%; plans to look for funding for resort, now expected to open in first quarter of 2011. Also leads property firm K. Wah International; owns hotels in U.S. With only an elementary school education, got start helping his grandmother run a store that sold food staples. By 1950 was buying construction equipment from Japan and reselling it to Southeast Asia. Received a Lifetime Achievement Award from the American Academy of Hospitality Sciences in 2007. Son Francis Lui is heir apparent.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grew up poor; sold magazines and lemonade as a boy in Portland, Ore. Earned physics degrees from UCLA. Started Spectrolab 1956 and Heliotek soon after; sold both aerospace firms to Textron 1960. Successful biomedical inventor and investor sold MiniMed (insulin pumps) to Medtronic in 2001 for $3.7 billion. Recently reacquired Advanced Bionics (cochlear implants) after selling to Boston Scientific 2004; massive legal squabble finally over. Has invested hundreds of millions of dollars into MannKind; working on diabetes treatment.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of Cogen Technologies sold firm to Enron for $1.5 billion in cash and stock at peak of tech bubble; immediately sold stock, avoided Enron bankruptcy. Used cash to bring football back to Houston in 2002 when the NFL expanded. Today 70% stake in Houston Texans worth $600 million net of debt; squad posted first winning record in history this past season. Sold Kentucky's Stonerside Stables to Dubai's Sheik Mohammed in 2008.

name: Billionaires
bio: He and brother Akira, also a billionaire, inherited initial fortune from father but went their separate ways, unable to agree on a business strategy. Minoru is known for his grandiose projects: he is the builder behind Tokyo's swank Roppongi Hills as well as China's tallest building, the Shanghai World Financial Center. Began construction of 47-story office and residential complex in central Tokyo last year. In September started city's first commercial helicopter service from downtown to its main international airport. In December received honorary knighthood from the U.K.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of an orthodontist studied economics at Brown. Took job in China helping to manage local operations for Boston chemicals maker Wellman. Founded Providence Equity Partners 1989; buyout firm specializes in media and telecom companies. Most famous deal: parlayed $63 million investment in VoiceStream in 1992 into $600 million payday 8 years later. Bid to buy Bell Canada for $51 billion with Madison Dearborn and the Ontario Teachers' Pension Plan came undone in 2008. Late last year took two education companies public. Firm owns 10% stake in Hulu, online television portal created by Fox and NBC. Assets under management: $22 billion.
title: Chief executive officer
employment: {'name': 'Providence Equity Partners', 'title': 'Chief executive officer', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: His 24% stake in gold and silver miner, Polymetal, which has had a stellar year, helps Nesis enter the billionaire ranks. Started out in the 1990s by reinvesting profits from uranium mining in Central Asia into shipbuilding and other metals. Created miner Polymetal; sold the company to fellow billionaire Suleiman Kerimov in 2005; bought back stake at rock-bottom prices three years later during the financial crisis. His IST Group also controls Nomos Bank, a railroad-car repair factory in the Leningrad Oblast, a chemicals factory and land for housing developments.

name: Billionaires
bio: Infosys co-founder stepped down as co-chairman of tech firm in July after he was tapped by the government to head the country's newly formed Unique Identification Authority of India, an ambitious project to provide ID numbers to all Indian residents. Appointment gave him the rank of a cabinet minister. Recent federal budget allocated $410 million for the mammoth project. He will also head the government's newly formed technology advisory group. Authored Imagining India: Ideas for the New Century. Along with wife Rohini, has donated $5 million to Yale University where both their children are students, to jump-start the University's Yale-India initiative. Continues to hold stake in Infosys.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of legendary Texas magnate Henry Ross Perot. Together with father, duo has lost a combined $1.3 billion in past 12 months. Sold data processing firm Perot Systems to Dell last November for $3.9 billion; Dell paid a 68% premium. Last April debt woes reportedly forced family's real estate firm, Hillwood, to cede stake in high-profile Dallas development to German investment partners. Sr.: cotton broker's son served in Navy, salesman for IBM before founding Electronic Data Systems 1962. Sold to General Motors for $2.5 billion 22 years later. Used proceeds to fund two failed presidential bids; Perot Systems.

name: Billionaires
bio: Nuclear engineer turned his family's ailing Naples drug wholesaler into Alliance UniChem Group, which merged with U.K. pharmacy chain Boots Group in 2006 to form Alliance Boots. Took private in $22 billion deal in 2007 with financing from private equity firm KKR. Today Alliance Boots has more than 150,000 employees and 3,200 stores. Active in more than 20 countries. Aiming to grow larger through large acquisitions. This summer named embattled former head of HBOS bank, Andy Hornby, as chief executive.

name: Billionaires
bio: Born in Budapest during Russian air raid. Immigrated to U.S. 1965, found work as draftsman for engineering firm. Taught himself how to program computers by reading manuals. Landed job at consulting firm Aranyi Associates, then trading outfit Mocatta Metals. Bought seat on American Stock Exchange for $200,000 1977. His early marketmaking firm Timber Hill pioneered use of handheld calculators in trading pits; became dominant dealer in S&P 500 options 1980s. Created Interactive Brokers Group 1993. Took 10% of firm public in 2007. Today entire operation is worth perhaps $7 billion. Holds 85% stake in firm "with affiliates"; unclear how much he personally owns. Conservative ownership estimate enough to make him a billionaire.

name: Billionaires
bio: Veteran investor has been eyeing banks with customers in areas lightly affected by real estate meltdown. Learned finance as a $200-per-week research assistant under Max Heine. Sold Heine Securities to Franklin Resources for $670 million 1996; stayed on for 5 years. Now runs investment outfit MFP Investors. His guideline for buying shares of companies involved in deals: "You always want to own the target; you don't want to own the acquirer."
title: President

name: Billionaires
bio: The split-up of the Pritzker family fortune continues. In November Hyatt Hotels went public; sold $1.1 billion in stock. Family still controls large chunk of shares after offering. Sold 13.6% stake in Hyatt to Walton family's Madrone Capital and Goldman Sachs for $1 billion in 2007. Five months later sold 60% of Marmon industrial conglomerate to Berkshire Hathaway for $4.5 billion; firm will become entirely Berkshire-owned in 2014. Grandchildren of A.N. Pritzker (d. 1986) who, with sons Jay (d. 1999) and Robert, created Marmon (sales: $7 billion) and Hyatt (415 properties worldwide today). Plan to pass control of empire to Tom, cousin Nick and niece Penny collapsed in 2001; family agreed to divide the spoils 11 ways, drawing a lawsuit by Robert's 2 youngest children, Matthew and Liesel. Two heirs settled for $1 billion.

name: Billionaires
bio: The split-up of the Pritzker family fortune continues. In November Hyatt Hotels went public; sold $1.1 billion in stock. Family still controls large chunk of shares after offering. Sold 13.6% stake in Hyatt to Walton family's Madrone Capital and Goldman Sachs for $1 billion in 2007. Five months later sold 60% of Marmon industrial conglomerate to Berkshire Hathaway for $4.5 billion; firm will become entirely Berkshire-owned in 2014. Grandchildren of A.N. Pritzker (d. 1986) who, with sons Jay (d. 1999) and Robert, created Marmon (sales: $7 billion) and Hyatt (415 properties worldwide today). Plan to pass control of empire to Tom, cousin Nick and niece Penny collapsed in 2001; family agreed to divide the spoils 11 ways, drawing a lawsuit by Robert's 2 youngest children, Matthew and Liesel. Two heirs settled for $1 billion.

name: Billionaires
bio: The split-up of the Pritzker family fortune continues. In November Hyatt Hotels went public; sold $1.1 billion in stock. Family still controls large chunk of shares after offering. Sold 13.6% stake in Hyatt to Walton family's Madrone Capital and Goldman Sachs for $1 billion in 2007. Five months later sold 60% of Marmon industrial conglomerate to Berkshire Hathaway for $4.5 billion; firm will become entirely Berkshire-owned in 2014. Grandchildren of A.N. Pritzker (d. 1986) who, with sons Jay (d. 1999) and Robert, created Marmon (sales: $7 billion) and Hyatt (415 properties worldwide today). Plan to pass control of empire to Tom, cousin Nick and niece Penny collapsed in 2001; family agreed to divide the spoils 11 ways, drawing a lawsuit by Robert's 2 youngest children, Matthew and Liesel. Two heirs settled for $1 billion.

name: Billionaires
bio: In the mid-1990s gas giant Gazprom created the Panrusgaz joint venture with Hungary's oil & gas giant, MOL. Rahimkulov became its chief executive and 10% owner. To process payments from its local customers, Gazprom bought the Hungarian bank Altalanos ErtekForgalmi Bank (AEB). Rahimkulov headed this as well and later bought it from Gazprom. In 2007 he sold AEB and used the proceeds to buy shares in MOL and OTP, the largest bank in Hungary. Also owns shares of Gazprom and VTB.

name: Billionaires
bio: Took job selling fertilizer for IBE Trade 1985; became president and owner 15 years later. Today company controls 12% of world's ammonia supply, 6% of ammonium nitrate. Clients include Cargill, Con-Agra, Koch Nitrogen. Offices in Budapest, Moscow, Kiev, Odessa; factories in Russia and Ukraine. Owns 14 buildings in New York, looking to expand real estate empire. Gives to education, health; serves on NYC Board of Correction. Enjoys tennis, spas.

name: Billionaires
bio: Insurance tycoon retired from brokerage Aon Corp. in 2008 to focus on Chicago's failed 2016 Olympics bid; appointed chairman of World Sport Chicago, named to panel to improve U.S. Olympic Committee. Attended Northwestern on football scholarship; jumped to insurance, sold policies for 5 years after graduating. Founded own firm, auto credit insurer Pat Ryan & Associates 1964 at age 26. Merged with Combined International 1982, renamed Aon Corp. 5 years later. Grew through acquisitions into world's largest reinsurance broker. Shares down 3% in six months. Chairman, financial backer of new firms ThinkRisk Underwriting Agency, Ryan Specialty Group. Owns stake in pro football's Chicago Bears.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Ryan Specialty Group', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Manhattan real estate mogul pleaded guilty, through a holding company, to illegally importing rare animal parts into the U.S.; a slew of animals and parts--including zebra-skin rugs, bar stools made from python skins and a stuffed lion--were discovered on his 150-foot yacht Mystere at Port Everglades 2007. Paid $150,000 in fines for violating the Endangered Species Act. Claims he believed he was exempt from the act because it has a provision for specimens held in private homes; he lives on the yacht nearly full-time. Russian immigrant borrowed against his NYC taxi medallion to open electronics store selling to Soviet diplomats and officials. Invested in Russian oil, then Manhattan real estate during 1990s recession. Today owns own over 6 million square feet of commercial real estate in NYC. Moscow Oil Refinery (MOR) continues to withhold the $28 million judgment (accrued to over $40 million) from Sapir-owned Joy-Lud Distributors; awaiting a verdict on a new case in the Russian courts. Owns penthouse overlooking Acapulco Bay in Mexico.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former steelworker built Jiangsu Shagang into one of the country's largest steelmakers. Looking to lock in raw materials, Shagang agreed to take a 45% stake in Australian iron ore prospector Grange Resources; merged it with his firm's Australian iron ore unit, Australian Bulk Minerals. In November, Shagang announced a business alliance with Sojitz, a Japanese trading company. Shen is vice chairman of the China Iron Ore and Steel Association, and is a member of the 17th National People's Congress.

name: Billionaires
bio: Like former business partner and fellow billionaire Lev Kvetnoi, was born in a small settlement near Moscow and studied at the same school of athletics, the Institute of Physical Culture. Later worked for Moscow's MontazhSpetsBank. With Kvetnoi joined billionaire Alisher Usmanov's metallurgical business; Kvetnoi was sent to Oskol Metal Works, while Skoch went to Lebedinsky Mining. Later Usmanov joined the two firms with a third to create the Metalloinvest conglomerate. Kvetnoi sold out, but Skoch remains a partner. Became a member of the Russian parliament's lower house in 1999. Sponsors a literary competition for young authors called Debut; erecting a memorial to fallen Russian soldiers in Port Arthur (Lyushun, China), the site of the bloodiest battles of the Russo-Japanese war of 1904-1905.

name: Billionaires
bio: Austrian citizen settled in Hong Kong almost 40 years ago and married daughter of shipping tycoon Yue-Kong Pao. Now chairs BW Group, whose fleet of over 140 oil tankers and gas carriers is one of world's largest maritime groups; includes publicly traded company BW Offshore and privately held BW Maritime, BW Fleet and BW Gas (delisted last year).  Obtained $3 billion loan last year to aid in restructuring debt. Recipient of China's Friendship Ambassador award for his contributions to China-Austria ties. Southern Methodist University law school alumnus, supports a graduate scholarship program for Chinese lawyers studying at SMU's Dedman School of Law. Oxford and Harvard-educated eldest son,  Andreas Sohmen-Pao, is chief executive of BW Maritime and BW Gas.

name: Billionaires
bio: Owns over 80% of $2.9 billion (sales) Hunter Douglas Group, a Netherlands company that makes and markets window coverings and architectural products. Father, Henry Sonnenberg, founded the group in 1919 as a machine-tool company, eventually developing new technology for the production of lightweight aluminum slats for Venetian blinds. Has been chief executive since 1971. Sons Marko and David work alongside their dad.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandson of Reinhard Straumann, who founded alloy research institute in 1954. Reinhard invented metals for use in watch components. Thomas' father Fritz led push into dental implants. Opened offices in United States 1989. Public 1998. Thomas retired as chairman of Straumann Holding 2002; still sits on board. Also owns luxury hotels in Switzerland.

name: Billionaires
bio: World's second-youngest self-made billionaire after Facebook's Mark Zuckerberg, Tanaka also made his fortune from a social networking site, Gree. He started out at Sony, then worked for fellow billionaire Hiroshi Mikitani at online shopping site Rakuten. Left in 2004 to set up Gree at a tech incubator; company name inspired by American social psychologist Stanley Milgram's concept of "six degrees of separation." Eventually transitioned the site into mobile gaming to better compete with rivals. Attracting around a million new subscribers a month, who pay for virtual clothes and accessories for online avatars that participate in social games on their mobile phones. Named his conference rooms Sunnyvale and Mountain View, after the locations of Yahoo's and Google's headquarters.

name: Billionaires
bio: Earned his first rubles in late 1980s helping foreign tourists find rooms in Moscow hotels. In 1990 worked as a consultant for Italian confectionary Ferrero Rocher; then started selling Italian vermouth, winning an exclusive contract with Martini & Rossi. In 1998 created the first upscale brand of Russian vodka, Russian Standard. In 1999, with help of McKinsey & Co., set up Russian Standard Bank, pioneering consumer credit market; became market leader three years later. Came under fire in 2007 from the Russian government, which investigated the bank's fee structure. As a result, Russky Standart, as it's known, has removed monthly account fees and is doing more to attract deposits, focusing less on issuing credit.

name: Billionaires
bio: Rode tech bubble onto The Forbes 400 in 1999 with $9.3 billion sale of Aspect Development software firm to i2 Technologies. All-stock deal left fortune depleted 4 years later. Used remaining millions to start or acquire 9 business software and IT companies; clawed fortune back to ten-figures. Best investment: bought market-research company Information Resources 2003; former moneyloser now generates operating profit margins of 10%. Attended Indian Institute of Technology in Mumbai. Moved to U.S. 1969, earned Ph.D. in electrical engineering at Carnegie Mellon. Founded Aspect 1991. Firm made software that allowed clients to track internal spending, inventory, buying behavior. Sold during dot-com exuberance. Uses little leverage to buy companies: "Financial engineering is not our game."
title: Founder and Chairman
employment: {'name': 'Symphony Technology Group', 'title': 'Founder and Chairman', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Came to Istanbul to serve in the military; he stayed to work in business. Co-founder of Anadolu Group, brewer and distributor of beer and soft drinks including one of country's most popular brands, Efes Pilsen beer. Owns group, which is expanding in Russia and other former Soviet Union nations, with partner and fellow billionaire Tuncay Ozilhan. Also makes Isuzus in Turkish plants; imports, sells Lada and Kia cars throughout Turkey, Ukraine and Central Asian countries. Built a hospital affiliated with Johns Hopkins Medical School in Istanbul. Partners also own Efes Pilsen basketball club, which won the European championship in 1996 and 2000.

name: Billionaires
bio: Climbed into billionaire ranks this year after injecting his polysilicon manufacturing business into his Hong Kong-listed power firm, GCL-Poly. Government-run China Investment Corp. said in November it would acquire a 20% stake in GCL-Poly. Has a degree in electrical automation; also got a doctorate in the Philippines.

name: Billionaires
bio: Boston broadcasting tycoon offended fans of hometown hero Jay Leno: last April announced his local NBC station would air a 10 p.m. newscast rather than the former Tonight Show host's variety show; changed mind when NBC threatened to yank affiliation. Doesn't matter now: Leno back on at 11:35 as host of the Tonight Show. Shoemaker's son parlayed proceeds from Florida real estate investments into television empire; bought Miami station for $3.4 million 1962; later added 3 more in Boston. Owns real estate around Miami and Indianapolis.
title: President

name: Billionaires
bio: Super low profile tycoon has two seaside residences by the Bosphorus, one in Kanlica and the other in Yenikoy. Also has an automobile collection of 80 cars including a McLaren F1, Superamerica, Enzo and a $4.5 million Ferrari FFX. Source of his wealth is Habas Company. Predecessor firms were founded by his father. Today Habas is well-known producer of industrial and medical gases, heavy machinery and LNG.

name: Billionaires
bio: Evangelical tech entrepreneur launched entertainment software maker Liberty Software in 1979 at age 15. Graduated from USC, held posts at Oracle, Apple before launching Salesforce.com. Company's mission: "the end of software." Stock up 30% in past six months. Recently launched "corporate Facebook" Service Cloud 2 with business social networking application Chatter. Yogi favors Eastern philosophy. Favorite book: Sun Tzu's The Art of War.
title: Chairman and CEO

name: Billionaires
bio: Real estate titan investing millions of dollars each month in medical research outfit Cytotech, which is studying treatments for cancer. Former vending machine repairman worked night shifts to pay his way through U. of New Mexico. Bought real estate investment trust Mission West 1997. Portfolio includes 8 million square feet across 100 properties; counts Microsoft, Apple among Silicon Valley office tenants.

name: Billionaires
bio: Do-it-yourself icon riding out volatile economy. Home Depot stock plunged to lowest level in more than a decade last March after the housing market -- and every other sector of the economy -- crumbled. Shares have rebounded since as crafty homeowners look to repair their homes rather than buy new. Cofounded Home Depot with partner Bernard Marcus 1978. Handed out dollar bills in parking lot to lure first customers. Hardware giant went public 3 years later. Retired 2001. Founded The Arthur M. Blank Family Foundation in 1995; has granted over $250 million to various charitable organizations. Owns pro football's Atlanta Falcons, Mountain Sky Guest Ranch.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Art collector's fortune up $100 million in past 12 months as the value of his stellar collection--including pieces by Picasso, Jasper Johns and Andy Warhol--improves. Charitable foundation and grandchildren's trust fell victim to Madoff's Ponzi fraud; personal wealth was not affected. First job: research analyst for a liquor company. Cofounded vitamin retailer Keystone Discount Stores. Merged with Philadelphia Pharmaceuticals 1967, cashed out for $1 million a year later, moved to Florida. Bought Cadillac dealership in Tampa 1972; today owns 16 car dealerships in Florida and Colorado. Stabilizing his personal balance sheet: has investment with money man John Paulson, who famously became a billionaire shorting subprime credit in 2007.

name: Billionaires
bio: Times Square tycoon's stable tenant base and aversion to debt shielding him from worst of commercial real estate meltdown. Father was a notions (sewing supplies) salesman who died young, left family broke. Saved up by singing in synagogues; put earnings toward tuition at Brooklyn Law School. Considered career as vocalist, became entertainment lawyer instead. Became a political adviser for Jimmy Carter; helped broker Camp David Accords between Egypt and Israel 1978. Bought first property--One Times Square--hours after Carter conceded race to Reagan. Today owns 1.5 million square feet of commercial office space including 38-story skyscraper 1441 Broadway. Tenants include Tommy Hilfiger, Liz Claiborne. Hosts The Leon Charney Report, weekly political talk show aired on NYC TV. Claims to be nation's largest individual trader (by volume) of Ginnie Maes--mortgage-backed securities guaranteed by U.S. government.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of an advertising executive grew up in New Jersey. Studied finance, economics at Alfred U. First job at Merrill Lynch doing mergers and acquisitions. Started investing money in 1985 for Alliance Capital Management. Held post at investment bank Allen & Co. before founding hedge fund Chilton Investment Co. 1992. Firm buys long, sells short in hopes of generating high returns independent of market's ups and downs. Firm lost 23% in 2008; rose 24% net of fees last year. Assets under management: $6 billion. On board of Metropolitan Museum of Art.
title: Founder
employment: {'name': 'Chilton Investment Company, LLC', 'title': 'Founder', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Former government bureaucrat got into real estate development in 1992. Listed his Hopson Development on Hong Kong stock exchange in 1998. Hopson is now a property conglomerate with interests in residential, commercial, hotel properties as well as tourist and vacation businesses. Stock has benefited from pick up in real estate demand in China. BBMG, a property firm in which Hopson has an investment, successfully listed in Hong Kong last year. Still, Hopson has seen a series of departures of senior executives of late. In January, the company said Chen Chang Ying resigned as CEO.

name: Billionaires
bio: Oldest son of Hyundai chairman Chung Mong-Koo was promoted to Hyundai Motor's new Vice Chairman last year; had been president at smaller affiliate Kia Motors Corp. He will manage the automaker's expansion plans including the construction of a new plant in Brazil and a third plant in China. He is credited with successful launch of Kia Cee'd (small family car) in Europe and other models such as Soul and Forte. President of Asian Archery Federation.

name: Billionaires
bio: Shopping-mall mogul father bought NFL's San Francisco 49ers 1977; garnered 4 Super Bowl Championship rings between 1982 and 1990 while Edward Jr. was at helm. No longer owns team; forced to swap his share with sister Denise for hefty stake in industry giant Simon Property Group following federal bribery conviction in 2000. Today owns 14.8 million SPG shares worth $1 billion; stock down 30% in past 12 months, but up 60% since March. Also owns stake in Famous Famiglia pizza joints, DeBartolo Sports & Entertainment.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded 1&1 AG in 1988 with a borrowed desk and some $300.000 in seed capital to service software and telecommunication companies too small to reach clients on their own. in March 1998 took company public  on the now defunct Neuer Markt, Germany's exchange for high-tech companies. Presently owns 36% of the company, renamed United Internet AG, which posted $2.3 billion in revenues in 2008. Company stock rose 80% in a year.  With over 9 million customer contracts they are a leading international Internet Service Provider. Avid sailor owns yacht;  his company sponsored the German sailing team in the 2007 America's Cup.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded hedge fund and private equity outfit Highbridge in 1992 with grade-school chum Henry Swieca. Sold 55% stake to JPMorgan Chase 2004 for more than $1.3 billion. Sold remainder of firm to investment bank in installments; finished cashing out last year. Assets under management: $21 billion. Firm's flagship "multi-strategy" fund returned 39.2% net of fees in 2009 after falling 25% in 2008. Attended SUNY Stony Brook; married doctor who is former Miss Sweden. Parted ways with longtime partner; Swieca left Highbridge last year.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Unofficial czar of Turkey's medical and pharmaceutical sector, got his last name from the honorary title given to his grandfather, Turkey's head pharmacist, 95 years ago. Now runs $2.8 billion (sales) Eczacibasi Holding, with interests in pharma, ceramics and building materials. Overseeing the expansion sdof the ceramic tile manufacturing unit into Russia and Ireland. Group has a sports club that has won national championships in basketball, volleyball and table tennis.  Along with wife, Oya, Bulent was a major benefactor of Istanbul Museum of Modern Art, a renovated 86,000-square-foot former customs warehouse on the waters of the Sea of Marmara, which opened to visitors in 2004. Oya serves as the museum's director.

name: Billionaires
bio: Bought first bank in 1975 for $1.2 million; with partners, sold for $100 million. With Ronald Perelman, sold Golden State Bancorp to Citigroup for $6 billion in stock 2002. Hedged his block of 22 million Citi shares with $80 million in put options; lost only 10% of value despite stock's 95% plummet since. Actively looking to invest in regional banks through new private equity firm Flexpoint Ford. Continues to sit on wallet until enticing deal comes around: "patience has rewarded us in the past." Runs cattle operation in spare time.
title: Managing Member
employment: {'name': 'Ford Financial Fund', 'title': 'Managing Member', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Former member of parliament is chairman emeritus of RPG Enterprises, a $2.8 billion (revenues) conglomerate, now run by sons Harsh and Sanjiv. Descendants of one of Kolkata's oldest business families, which used to trade with the East India Company incommodities like textiles, jute and tea. Made several notable acquisitions in the 1980s including Ceat Tyres, retail chain Spencer's and utility CESC. Today group has more than 20 companies in such sectors as power, biotech and IT. Harsh, a well known art collector recently appointed his son Anant, 28 as deputy managing director of Ceat.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sold Pace Salsa empire to Campbell Soup for $1.1 billion in 1996. Trinity University graduate married Linda, daughter of Pace founder, David Pace. Cut vegetables on assembly line, moved to sales; president 1977. Later bought company with wife; purchased her half for $95 million after 1991 divorce. Developed 22-acre Pearl Brewery complex in San Antonio; restaurants, shopping, condos.
title: Chief Executive Officer
employment: {'name': 'Silver Ventures', 'title': 'Chief Executive Officer', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: One of seven co-founders of Infosys Technologies, India's second largest software exporter. Took over as chief executive from Nandan Nilekani in 2007, after being chief operating officer and then president and joint managing director for five years. Company is tapping opportunities in the domestic market and other emerging markets to combat the slowdown in the US from where it derives over half its sales. Its outsourcing unit bought US outsourcer McCamish Systems in Atlanta for $58 million. Hired 24,000 people last fiscal year. Along with family, donates $1 million annually towards education, including providing scholarships to poor students.

name: Billionaires
bio: Returns to billionaire status thanks to rebound in shares of his electronics retailer Harvey Norman. Quite a reversal of fortune since talking on national TV in early 2009 about how stock market had lopped $1 billion off his wealth: "In a way I'm sort of proud...I never thought I'd have it to lose," he said at the time. The closest thing to Australia's king of retail, Harvey is a consummate salesman. With partner Ian Norman, he started electrical goods retailer Norman Ross. When that business was taken over, both men quit, later opening Harvey Norman in 1982. Remains chairman of the now publicly traded group, which has 245 stores, mainly in Australia. Has a passion for horses: owns part of Magic Millions Thoroughbred auction house and personally owns some 900 horses.

name: Billionaires
bio: Started apparel chain with one shop near University of Pennsylvania in 1970. Today Urban Outfitters sells hipster apparel, kitsch in 151 stores. Sales: $1.8 billion. Operates 3 brands in addition to flagship Urban Outfitters; Free People, Anthropologie, Terrain.
title: Chairman, President & Chief Executive Officer
employment: {'name': 'Urban Outfitters Inc.', 'title': 'Chairman, President & Chief Executive Officer', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'salary': 1.0, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Finland's first dollar billionaire heads $6.4 billion (sales) elevator, escalator maker Kone; company is also involved with the products' installation and maintenance. The firm was founded 100 years ago and purchased by Herlin's great grandfather in 1924. Chief executive of firm from 1996 to 2006; chairman since 2003, the year his father Pekka died. Chairman of Security Trading Oy; also sits on the board of Finnish construction firm YIT.

name: Billionaires
bio: Got start selling eyeglasses. Has investments in gem trader Xinhu Zhongbao; real estate firm, Zhejiang Sinhoo. Merged a third company, Zhejiang Xinhu Capital, into Zhejiang Sinhoo. Most of the shares in Sinhoo have been collateralized. Runs a club for Chinese wei players.

name: Billionaires
bio: Consumer finance lender Promise, which he founded, has been struggling despite long tie-up with Japan's third-biggest bank, Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group. Promise is closing half its branches as profits are hit by government limits on loan rates and the amount each customer can borrow. Son Hiroki replaced as president in September in favor of Sumitomo Mitsui executive, ending family's 47-year reign running firm. Retired 9 years ago, Jinnai now grows mangoes and bananas in greenhouses on Japan's northern island of Hokkaido, known for its frigid winters.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chemicals king went to government for help refinancing $500 million in debt last year; company faring better. Son of a Moscow department store director; graduated from the Moscow Aviation Institute and set up a computer-trading firm in late 1980s. Later became friendly with the governor of Novgorod, Mikhail Prusak, and through privatization bought local fertilizer producer Azot. Renamed it Akron and made it the basis for his chemicals empire, now publicly traded. A passionate collector of paintings by Russian artists of Jewish origin, chairs Russian Jewish Congress. Spends most of his time at his mansion in Geneva.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fertilizer tycoon forced to refinance debt on the $1.4 billion license he won at auction against rival Dmitry Rybolovev to develop one of the world's largest potassium deposits. The graduate of the Magnitogorsk Iron and Metals Institute, worked for 35 years at the Silvinit fertilizer factory and in 1990 became head of the company. He organized the privatization of the company and became one of its largest shareholders. Today the factory, located in the city of Solikamsk in Russia's Perm region (in the Urals), is the second-largest producer of potassium fertilizer in the country.

name: Billionaires
bio: Born in a small town near Moscow. In 1995 joined Alisher Usmanov's (also a billionaire) metals group, for a time serving as chief executive of an Usmanov company. In April 2006 sold out to Usmanov when his patron created a metals conglomerate that included a Kvetnoi company. In 2007 used some of the capital to buy National Standard Bank, which had been affiliated with yet another Usmanov company, and NovorossCement, Russia's third-largest cement producer. Largest shareholder in Moscow's Vnukovo Airport joined its board of directors last year; main shareholder in a number of airport service companies including an airplane-repair factory.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of Hong Kong billionaire Li Ka-shing is chairman of telecom PCCW, Hong Kong's leading phone company. Police searched his home in February as part of a larger investigation. The inquiry was apparently the result of  last year's failed attempt to take PCCW private. A lawyer for Li said at the time that he did not believe the mogul was the target of the investigation. Formed joint venture with China's Caijing magazine to start a news and information service. Also negotiating to buy AIG's asset management business for $500 million; deal has not closed. Has cash to do deals after he sold his 55% stake in Landmark Marunouchi Building. Tower sold for $1.7 billion in 2007; highest price for single piece of Tokyo real estate. New dad: girlfriend Isabella Leong gave birth to a boy in April; actress stared in The Mummy: Tomb of the Dragon Emperor.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Shanghai Stock Exchange-listed Sanan Optoelectronics made his early money in steel and, reportedly, tea. In 2008, Lin injected his LED electronics business into a listed, money-losing edible oils company that he had bought control of a year earlier. Stock has tripled in the past year; traded at a recent lofty 80 times trailing earnings. Still also invests in steel.

name: Billionaires
bio: During the Soviet period, worked in an organization that exported Russian raw goods and materials. In 1992 started the International Potassium Company (MMK), persuading three of the largest post-Soviet producers of fertilizer--Silvinit--Uralkali and Byelaruskali--to unite. But several years later the alliance broke up over an inability to agree on sharing their reserves. In 2005 MMK began exporting only fellow billionaire Pyotr Kondrashev's Silvinit's production; exports three-fourths of Silvinit's fertilizer abroad. Last year, elected chairman of the international fertilizer industry association.

name: Billionaires
bio: U. of Chicago grad used $80,000 in savings to start Morningstar in 1984 out of his Chicago apartment. Investment research outfit gained fame rating mutual funds. Took public 2005; shares up 29% in last year. Bought Standard & Poor's fund data business 2007, U.K. data, media and investor-relations Web site Hemscott 2008. Less stellar assets: Fast Company and Inc.
title: Chairman and CEO

name: Billionaires
bio: Hotelier's father, J.W. Marriott Sr., opened Washington, D.C. root beer stand Hot Shoppe 1927. Expanded into catering, restaurants, hotels; opened first hotel, Twin Bridges, 1957. Group of hotels became Marriott International. Split company 1993 with brother, Richard, amid bondholder protest; Richard controls real estate investment trust Host Hotels & Resorts, Bill runs worldwide hotel operator and franchisor Marriott International.

name: Billionaires
bio: Lodging tycoon fortune lifted by investor optimism. Marriott International stock has almost doubled during past year; company revenue has remained stagnant during same time period. Father, J.W. Marriott Sr., opened Washington, D.C. root beer stand the Hot Shoppe in 1927. Expanded into catering, restaurants, hotels; opened first hotel, Twin Bridges, 1957. Became Marriott lodging empire. Split company with brother J.W. amid bondholder protest 1993: Richard oversees hotel ownership operation (Host Hotels & Resorts).

name: Billionaires
bio: Dropped out of law school to sell cars. Founded Clear Channel Communications with partner Lowry Mays 1972. Cashed out when Clear Channel Communications went private in a $26 billion deal with private equity outfits Thomas H. Lee Partners, Bain Capital. Other holdings: oil, real estate, more car dealerships. Texas alum spends spare time rooting on the Longhorns.

name: Billionaires
bio: Temple U. grad studied medicine at Hahnemann Medical College (now part of Drexel U.). Made first fortune as a surgeon inventing spinal implants. Banked $1.4 billion after winning nasty intellectual- property lawsuit with medical device maker Medtronic 2005. Set up 2 foundations funded by investment gains: one supports scientific research, the other saves unloved pets; the latter set to give out grants for reproductive biology this fall. Also invests in California real estate.

name: Billionaires
bio: Stepped down as chairman of U.K. food retailer Morrisons in March 2008 after 55 years at the company; had been chairman since 1956, when took over from his father, who founded the retailer in 1899. During his tenure transformed it from small market stall into a $8 billion (market cap) company. Suffered criticism from some shareholders for his management style. Fortune is almost entirely tied up in Morrisons stock. New chief executive Dalton Philips takes over this March.

name: Billionaires
bio: Turkey's brewmaster created one of the country's most popular brands, Efes Pilsen beer. He and fellow billionaire Kamil Yazici control Anadolu Group conglomerate, founded by his father and Yazici. Also makes Isuzus in Turkey; imports, sells Lada and Kia cars throughout Turkey, Ukraine and Central Asian countries. Apparently built a hospital affiliated with Johns Hopkins Medical Schoo in Istanbul. Ex- basketball player co-owns Efes Pilsen basketball team; tries to never miss a game. Onetime judge of TV program, Cirak, Turkish version of Donald Trump's The Apprentice. Has a collection of 3,000 pens.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former race-car driver moving from car dealer to carmaker. Agreed to buy beleaguered economy brand Saturn from bankrupt GM in June; nonbinding deal set to close later this year. Worked for aluminum company Alcoa, purchased Philadelphia Chevy dealership. Founded Penske Corp. 1969; distributed Detroit Diesel for GM. Today Penske Auto Group operates more than 300 car dealerships. Shares of publicly traded Penske Automotive Group Inc. up 36% in past year on strong used car sales and cost-cutting. Owns Penske Racing; team has posted a combined 313 wins, including 15 Indy 500 victories.

name: Billionaires
bio: The split-up of the Pritzker family fortune continues. In November Hyatt Hotels went public; sold $1.1 billion in stock. Family still controls large chunk of shares after offering. Sold 13.6% stake in Hyatt to Walton family's Madrone Capital and Goldman Sachs for $1 billion in 2007. Five months later sold 60% of Marmon industrial conglomerate to Berkshire Hathaway for $4.5 billion; firm will become entirely Berkshire-owned in 2014. Grandchildren of A.N. Pritzker (d. 1986) who, with sons Jay (d. 1999) and Robert, created Marmon (sales: $7 billion) and Hyatt (415 properties worldwide today). Plan to pass control of empire to Tom, cousin Nick and niece Penny collapsed in 2001; family agreed to divide the spoils 11 ways, drawing a lawsuit by Robert's 2 youngest children, Matthew and Liesel. Two heirs settled for $1 billion.

name: Billionaires
bio: The split-up of the Pritzker family fortune continues. In November Hyatt Hotels went public; sold $1.1 billion in stock. Family still controls large chunk of shares after offering. Sold 13.6% stake in Hyatt to Walton family's Madrone Capital and Goldman Sachs for $1 billion in 2007. Five months later sold 60% of Marmon industrial conglomerate to Berkshire Hathaway for $4.5 billion; firm will become entirely Berkshire-owned in 2014. Grandchildren of A.N. Pritzker (d. 1986) who, with sons Jay (d. 1999) and Robert, created Marmon (sales: $7 billion) and Hyatt (415 properties worldwide today). Plan to pass control of empire to Tom, cousin Nick and niece Penny collapsed in 2001; family agreed to divide the spoils 11 ways, drawing a lawsuit by Robert's 2 youngest children, Matthew and Liesel. Two heirs settled for $1 billion.
title: CEO

Sold 13.6% stake in Hyatt to Walton family's Madrone Capital and Goldman Sachs for $1 billion in 2007. Five months later sold 60% of Marmon industrial conglomerate to Berkshire Hathaway for $4.5 billion; firm will become entirely Berkshire-owned in 2014. Grandchildren of A.N. Pritzker (d. 1986) who, with sons Jay (d. 1999) and Robert, created Marmon (sales: $7 billion) and Hyatt (415 properties worldwide today). Plan to pass control of empire to Tom, cousin Nick and niece Penny collapsed in 2001; family agreed to divide the spoils 11 ways, drawing a lawsuit by Robert's 2 youngest children, Matthew and Liesel. Two heirs settled for $1 billion.

name: Billionaires
bio: Qi's father died when he was young. Got his first job in a government district office before moving on to a management job at a construction firm. In 1996 turned down a bigger government position to set up Hangzhou Binjing Real Estate Group, which mostly sells properties in his hometown of Hangzhou. Hangzhou Binjing listed its shares at the Shenzhen Stock Exchange in May 2008.

name: Billionaires
bio: Surge in energy prices boosted the stock price of Riddell's key asset, Paramount Resources, by more than 200%. This Winnipeg, Man.-born geologist made it big by finding natural gas in remote and often Arctic-like areas. In the 1970s founded Paramount Resources, which developed huge natural gas inventories. Was inducted into the Order of Canada in 2008.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partner and fellow billionaire, Alexander Shnaider, purchased several ships in late 2009; had exited business 3 years prior after building fleet of 34 ships. Also with Shnaider, owns Ukraine's fourth-largest steel mill and commercial real estate, including office and retail projects in Moscow, and a share of the Trump Tower Toronto. Reportedly selling a stake in Ukraine's struggling supermarket chain, Amstor, to Ukrainian billionaire Rinat Akhmetov's Smart Group. Plans to build strip malls in Moscow suburbs put on hold. Met Shnaider while working as rival steel traders in Ukraine; partnered to acquire majority stake in steel mill giant Zaporizhstal during Ukrainian privatization auctions in mid-1990s. Friend of the Ukrainian film producer Alexandr Rodyansky, provided almost a third of the budget for the film The Inhabited Island, the Ukrainian-Russian film, which cost $36 million to make.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partner and fellow billionaire, Eduard Shifrin, purchased several ships in late 2009; had exited business three years prior after building fleet of 34 ships. Also with Shifrin, owns Ukraine's fourth-largest steel mill and commercial real estate, including office and retail projects in Moscow, and a share of the Trump Tower Toronto. Reportedly selling a stake in Ukraine's struggling supermarket chain, Amstor, to Ukrainian billionaire Rinat Akhmetov's Smart Group. Plans to build strip malls in Moscow suburbs put on hold. St. Petersburg-born magnate immigrated to Canada from Israel via Ukraine at age 13. Began trading textiles and electronics with aging Soviet factories while still living with parents as a college student. Founded steel trading firm in Belgium at 25; went on to acquire steelmaker Zaporizhstal in 1990s Ukraine privatizations. Chairman of Royal Laser Corp. Sold soccer club Maccabi Tel Aviv last August.

name: Billionaires
bio: Left humanities professorship at San Jose State in 1976 to start University of Phoenix. Son Peter joined 1983. Apollo Group went public 1994. Today more than 400,000 students take classes for associate, bachelor's, master's and doctoral degrees. Stock popped 75% last winter as investors anticipated a spike in enrollment as workers became unemployed; shares have dropped nearly 30% since.

name: Billionaires
bio: Native of China's eastern Shandong province. Served in the People's Liberation Army for several years and fought in the Sino-Viet War. After leaving the military, Sun is said to have entered the delivery business in western China.  He founded Guanghi Group in 1994. Today, from headquarters in Urumqi in Xinjiang Province, Sun's companies employ thousands and have operations in real estate, natural gas and logistics. He is one of China's largest private investors in energy.

name: Billionaires
bio: Owns prominent buildings in Shanghai's Changning district, a popular office location, including the 51-story Summit Mall and the Regent Hotel. Started signing up tenants for Shenyang Cloud Nine Shopping Mall's office area in northeast Liaoning province last year. Also has a new project in Shanghai's Hongkou district.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded auto parts and repair outfit Auto-Teile-Unger in 1985. Sold 80% of company to a British investor group for $800 million in 2002. Sold rest to Kohlberg Kravis Roberts in July 2004 for estimated $360 million. Now retired.

name: Billionaires
bio: His former Dutch TV production company, Endemol, launched reality-show craze with the creation of programs like Big Brother and Fear Factor. Made fortune when  Endemol was sold to Spanish telecom giant Telefonica in 2000 for $5.3 billion. Then focused on theater, a passion he's had since childhood. (At age 6 Van den Ende put on  puppet shows for neighborhood children in his hometown.) Owner and founder of Stage Entertainment,  a musical theater company and Endemol spin off that produces blockbuster musicals like The Lion King and Mamma Mia. Its U.S. division has won 46 Tony Awards.  Stepped down in September 2008 as chairman, now president of the supervisory board.  Humble beginnings; started career as party-supply salesman. Was awarded the cross of Honor of the House of Orange in 2009.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Rongan Property, based in Zhejiang province's thriving port city of Ningbo. The real estate developer ascended into our billionaire ranks after completing a reverse takeover and obtaining a listing on Shenzhen exchange.

name: Billionaires
bio: Governor Meg? Former Ebay head running to be California's next chief executive. Republican frontrunner raised $10 million in individual contributions along with $39 million from personal coffers. Likely opponent: Jerry Brown, the state's Attorney General and former governor. Election to succeed Arnold Schwarzenegger slated for November 2010. Got taste for politics as cochair of John McCain's presidential run in 2008. Joined Ebay in 1998; led through Internet boom and bust. Expanded services to Europe, Asia, Latin America. Acquired PayPal, Skype, StubHub. Stock up 60% in 12 months. Resigned from boards of Ebay, Procter & Gamble and DreamWorks last year to concentrate on gubernatorial race.
title: CEO

name: Billionaires
bio: Volatile few years for chief Yahoo. Turned down $44.6 billion takeover bid from Microsoft in 2008; Carl Icahn led proxy battle to replace board, oust him as chief executive. Yahoo came to agreement with shareholder activist weeks later. Stepped down from post in November 2008; hired Carol Bartz to run Yahoo. Formed partnership with Microsoft in July; Microsoft will provide Bing search engine, Yahoo will run ad sales. Icahn stepped down from board in October. Stock up 26% in past year. Met future partner David Filo as Stanford grad student, duo left Ph.D. program 1995 to form Web portal.

name: Billionaires
bio: Onetime pharmacist sold family pharmaceutical business 1985; invested proceeds in several industries, from banking to textiles. Accumulated 10% stake of construction giant Sacyr Vallehermoso, of which he is a vice president. Often appears in tabloids alongside well-known politicians and members of Spanish artistic and cultural circles. Known for his valuable art collection which includes works by Edgar Degas, Toulouse-Lautrec, Salvador Dali and Van Gogh, among others. Enthusiastic hunter; enjoys bullfights, soccer.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ex-husband of billionaire heiress Esther Koplowitz. He and his first cousin, Alberto Cortina, who married Esther's sister Alicia, ran Construcciones y Contratas (now called FCC), the large industrial company their wives inherited, together from the early 1970s until both marriages fell apart in 1989. Los Albertos, as they were dubbed by the press, then moved into banking, running Banco Zaragozano. Sold their combined 40% stake to Barclays in 2004. Cousins now hold their wealth in investment arm Alcor Holding. Alcocer reportedly enjoys hunting.

name: Billionaires
bio: Owns 30% stake in miner New World Resources, which recently announced modernization plan to improve output. Also owns 11% of Ukrainian iron ore producer Ferrexpo after bailing out Ukrainian billionaire Kostyantin Zhevago, who faced a margin call in the fall of 2008; got stock at 28% discount to what stock had been trading at. Started out in finance in the 1990s: launched the Prague office of Credit Suisse First Boston in 1991 and three years later founded Patria Finance, one of the largest investment banking boutiques in the Czech Republic. Took control of coal company OKD in leveraged buyout in 2004; now part of NWR. "The forgotten old economy assets have given us a better return than sexy assets. We like tangibles." Dartmouth MBA grad started a foundation to give Czech students scholarships to study abroad.

name: Billionaires
bio: Born into poverty in wartime Taiwan 1944, grew up doing farm chores and helping his father fish. One of the junior-high-school graduate's first jobs: mixing cement at a construction company. Arrived in Taipei with a suitcase of rice and little money in his pocket. Eventually started supplying cement to builders, taking on subcontracting jobs, and developing his own real estate projects. Today, his Farglory Land Development is one of Taiwan's largest developers. Also invests in projects in the mainland; operates an insurance company and hotel chain in Taiwan. Hikes for an hour each day before coming to work.

name: Billionaires
bio: Inherited fortune from late husband, Hunan entrepreneur Wei Dong, who died in 2008. Low-key Chen holds stakes in four listed companies -- Sinolink Securities (brokerage), Zhuzhou Qianjin Pharmaceutical (drug maker), Jiuzhitang (Chinese medicine maker), and Zhejiang Dahua Technology (security equipment manufacturer).

name: Billionaires
bio: Co-founder of Shanda Interactive, a pioneer in China's online game industry. Busy in 2009, although with mixed success: subsidiary Shanda Games listed on the Nasdaq in Sept. but dropped more than 25% after. Parent announced in January that president Tan Qunzhao would resign as president to focus on work at Shanda Games. Stock dropped 20% after stock watch day, amid worries about its revenue outlook. Moving deeper into content, Shanda Interactive in November forged joint venture with influential Hunan Broadcasting and Television Group to produce and distribute movies. Prior to establishing Shanda, Chen served as the vice director of the office of the president of Kinghing Trust & Investment from 1998 to 1999. From 1994 to 1998, Mr. Chen served in various management positions with Shanghai Lujiazui Group, a state-run property developer. He holds a bachelor's degree in economics from Fudan University in Shanghai.

name: Billionaires
bio: Construction and real estate tycoon owns millions of square feet of office space, 15,000 residential units in Washington, D.C. area. Heavy construction keeps fortune afloat; museums, prisons, university buildings, stadiums. Built Camden Yards and M&T Bank Stadium (Baltimore); FedEx Field, Verizon Center and Nationals Park (Washington, D.C.); Miller Park (Milwaukee); Petco Park (San Diego). Clark Construction sales in 2008: $4.7 billion.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ex-husband of billionaire heiress Alicia Koplowitz. He and his first cousin, Alberto Alcocer, who married Alicia's sister Esther, ran Construcciones y Contratas (now called FCC), the large industrial company their wives inherited, together from the early 1970s until both marriages fell apart in 1989. Los Albertos, as they were dubbed by the press, then moved into banking, running Banco Zaragozano. Sold their combined 40% stake to Barclays in 2004.  Cousins now hold their wealth in investment arm Alcor Holding. Said to like boating, collecting art and hunting.

name: Billionaires
bio: Opened his first drugstore in 1969. Now the Jean Coutu Group is one of North America's largest pharmacy chains. Saw boost in sales for flu-related products thanks to Swine Flu scare. Bought into the Eckerd brand in 2004 when it purchased the chain's stores in the Northeast and mid-Atlantic states for $2.4 billion. Just two years later announced it was selling its U.S. operations, including the Eckerd and Brooks brands, to Rite Aid, in a deal worth $3.4 billion in stock and cash. Jean Coutu Group is Rite Aid's top shareholder. Coutu's son Michel is nonexecutive cochairman of the board at Rite Aid, while other son Francois is president and chief executive at the Coutu Group.

name: Billionaires
bio: Retired chief executive of publicly traded pipeline company Energy Transfer Partners. Teamed with Kelcy Warren to form gas pipeline company Cornerstone 1993. Bought small pipelines, consolidated holding into efficient network. Flipped to El Paso 1999, duo formed Energy Transfer Partners 1995. Stepped down as co-chief executive in 2007, sold $600 million worth of stock. Still owns nearly 19 million shares.

name: Billionaires
bio: UCLA dropout landed first job in mailroom at talent agency William Morris. Networked way into entertainment-executive gigs at ABC, Paramount, Fox. Launched e-commerce empire 1997 with purchase of Home Shopping Network and HSN Online. Last year split up IAC/Interactive into 5 separate entities after nasty feud with John Malone; longtime backer accused Diller of trying to dilute his stake. Justice Department approved merger of Ticketmaster Entertainment and Live Nation in January, paving the way for the merger of two of the largest entities in music and entertainment. Consummate dealmaker says he is committed to reducing IAC's $1.7 billion cash pile to a more 'rational' level, though not with acquisitions. "The only thing worse than spending cash stupidly is essentially not to put it down at all, not to do any thing with it."

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded a small currency-exchange shop in central London more than 30 years ago; built Travelex into the world's largest foreign-exchange specialist, with operations in 31 countries. Sold a majority stake to private equity firm Apax Partners in 2005; still holds 30%. Ceded his chief executive role that same year but remains chairman. In January made 34-year-old, Peter Jackson, chief executive. Sponsors London's National Theatre to help lower ticket prices.

name: Billionaires
bio: Heads Rizhao Steel Holding, one of China's largest private steel manufacturers in Shandong province. May soon merge with a provincial government company; parties have reportedly an agreement. Deal would make Du a minority shareholder in a state-controlled company.

name: Billionaires
bio: Electrical engineer founded back-office software maker PeopleSoft in 1987. Forced to sell out to Oracle for $10 billion in 2005 after 18-month takeover battle with nemesis Larry Ellison. Fighting Oracle chief with new enterprise software startup, Workday. Funded nanotech research building at alma mater Cornell; with wife, created Maddie's Fund, pet rescue foundation with $300 million endowment devoted to saving shelter dogs and cats.
title: Chairman and co-CEO

name: Billionaires
bio: Shares pharmaceuticals fortune with older brother and fellow billionaire, Bulent. Worked in family business since 1980 except for a stint in U.S. at American Hospital Supply Co. Now vice chairman of Eczacibasi Holding, Bulent is chairman. Founder and, since 1995, president of the Turkish Informatics Foundation (T BV). Also on board of Turkish Technology Development Foundation (TTGV).

name: Billionaires
bio: Tough economic times have been a boon for his Funai Electric, maker of low-cost DVD players and televisions, sold under brand names such as Emerson, Symphonic and Sylvania in the U.S. Stock has more than doubled in the past year. In April named consumer electronics supplier of the year by Wal-Mart. Funai stepped down as chief executive to become chairman in 2008 soon after firm bought rights to Philips and Magnavox brands in North America.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former factory director got started on a sewing machine in a small village three decades ago. Launched his flagship brand, Bosideng, in 1994. Bosideng is now China's largest maker of down apparel including jackets and vests sold under such brands as "Snow Flying," "Kango" and "Bingjie." Started making non-down apparel in 2008. Bought women's wear brand, Charming Point, in October 2009. Operates more than 5,600 retail outlets in 65 cities in China. Wife Mei Dong, 41, joined firm in 1994 and is now executive director and board member; also beneficiary of family trust that owns stake in Bosideng. Cousin Gao Miaoqin is also a board member, in charge of public relations. Gao took minority stake in Dashang Group, one of the country's largest department stores, last year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fell out of the billionaire ranks last year when shares of Porto Seguro, Brazil's largest auto insurance firm, dropped. Back in after firm merged with Itau Unibanco in 2009. Company was founded in 1945 and purchased by the Garfinkel family in 1972. When his father died in 1978, Jayme was groomed to take over. Took the company public in 2004. Through Porto Seguro, Garfinkel has supported the creation and maintenance of schools for young children in favelas, or shantytowns, around Sao Paulo.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded Renrenle Commercial Group in 1996 in the southern city of Shenzhen. Took the company public on the Shenzhen Stock Exchange in January. Renrenle operates 82 supermarkets and shopping malls around China; plans to open another 100 stores later this year. Wife Song Qi is vice chairman. Wealth estimate doesn't include her shares.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former chief executive of Banamex bank made almost $2 billion in 2001, when he sold the bank to Citigroup. Stepped down from Citigroup's board in April 2009, after a letter was sent to the SEC saying he and another board member could be "conflicted outside-related directors" and that Hernandez's $2.6 million in security and other services in 2007 "raised concerns about our board's ability to remain an independent and effective counter balance to management." Ramirez, at the time, had an ownership stake in Aeropersonal, which he and other Citi executives flew on. Owns luxury resorts on the Yucatán Peninsula.

name: Billionaires
bio: With her five children, Gunter, Joachim, Michael, Wolfgang, and Daniela, inherited a fortune from her late husband, coffee magnate Max Herz. Personally held 15% of Maxingvest AG last year; now  holds 10% after an internal reorganization of the family holding. Originally called Tchibo Holding, the consumer good group was run by her late husband, then by her son Gunter but nasty family feud led Gunter and Daniela to cash out in 2003. Sons Michael  and Wolfgang now control the holding.  Son Joachim  died in May 2008 after being hit by a boat while swimming in a Georgia lake. Joachim, who was childless, left his share of the fortune to a charitable foundation in his name.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Hong Kong-listed Maoye International, which operates one of China's largest department store chains with 17 stores and 350,000 square meters of space. Huang entered the real estate business in Shenzhen in 1992, according to Chinese media. Formally set up Maoye Group in the city in 1996. Share price has been volatile of late on reports that Huang was under investigation for financial wrongdoing; company later denied the reports and attributed Huang's absence to "personal matters." Shares fortune with wife Huang Jingzhang, a company director. Both are citizens of Belize.

name: Billionaires
bio: Widow of logistics tycoon Johnnie Hunt (d. 2006). Couple met in high school, cofounded J.B. Hunt Transport Services 1969. Today company is one of the largest transportation logistics outfits in the nation, serving U.S., Canada and Mexico with more than 10,000 trucks and tractors. Sales now exceed $3.7 billion. Revenue continues to grow despite high oil prices; 65% of profit comes from intermodal business (using two or more modes of transportation). Retired 2009. Philanthropist also owns commercial real estate in Rogers, Ark.

name: Billionaires
bio: Now a German citizen, the former commercial director of Kuznetsk Coal became president of the Swiss firm Conares Holding in 1995, overseeing export sales and financing. The public learned about him for the first time in October 2004, when Mechel, the largest producer of special steel and alloys, listed on the NYSE and Iorikh was named general director; he turned out to have the same size stake as better-known partner Igor Zyuzin, also a billionaire. But between 2005 and 2006 the two became divided over the direction of the company, and by January 2007 Iorikh had sold his shares to Zyuzin. Established an offshore fund to buy stakes in mining and machine firms in Turkey, Canada and Australia.

name: Billionaires
bio: Studied hotel management at Cornell after high school guidance counselor advised "there's no future in science or engineering." Eventually lured back to geekdom. Fled engineering professorship at MIT in 1966 seeking warmer climate; landed UC, San Diego teaching gig. Founded Linkabit; company developed technology that is now basis for most of the telecommunications industry. Sold out 1980. Founded Qualcomm 5 years later; commercialized ultraefficient CDMA digital wireless technology. Son Paul took over as Qualcomm chairman in March. Rights advocate and cancer survivor recently donated $10 million to ACLU and $6.5 million to UCSF School of Medicine for head and neck cancer research.
title: Cofounder & Chairman Emeritus

name: Billionaires
bio: School buddy and close confidante of India's richest person, Mukesh Ambani. Chairs Jai Corp, named after his father Jai Kumar, which is listed on the Bombay Stock Exchange. Has interests in plastics, steel, infrastructure and real estate. Farmers' protests have delayed its project to build special economic zones near Mumbai in partnership with Mukesh's Reliance Group. Investigators from the income-tax department searched Jai Corp's offices and Jain's residence last year, causing company's stock price to fall 5% in one day. A fan of Bollywood films, he does yoga everyday.

name: Billionaires
bio: A graduate of the prestigious Moscow State Institute of Foreign Affairs, ran a division of Absolut-Moscow, a private insurance company, until 1991, when he started his own firm. His Mercury group of companies started out as trader of imported food and cigarettes and became the largest tobacco products distributor in the country. In 2005 began widening its activities, when Mercury acquired a controlling stake in the oil company Sibir Energy; had to sell his stake to state-controlled Gazpromneft after his partner and now ex-billionaire, Shalva Chigirinsky, was apparently accused of tax evasion. At the end of 2007 bought a controlling stake in Dixy Group, the sixth-largest retail chain in Russia.

name: Billionaires
bio: After studying construction and finance in Moscow secondary schools, got a job at privately held BIN Bank; then Slavneft, an oil company then led by fellow billionaire Mikhail Gutseriev. Between 2001 and 2003, Khachaturov and his partners spent $60 million buying the insolvent insurance giant Rosgosstrakh from the government. Managed to transform the Soviet-era company into one of the highest-volume Russian insurers.

name: Billionaires
bio: The Urals and its metals industry are in his blood. Grew up in the town of Verkhnaya Pyshma in the Urals region and studied at a metallurgy institute. In 1979 went to work as a mechanic at Uralelectromed, now the main factory at the Ural Mining and Metallurgy Co. Served as general director from 1995 to 2002. Now fellow billionaire Iskander Makhmudov's closest partner, helping him build up holdings in Urals mining and metallurgy companies. Currently investing in the construction of Ekaterinburg City, an office complex in the biggest city of the Urals.

name: Billionaires
bio: Attended Harvard, worked at First National Bank of Boston. Founded private equity shop Thomas H. Lee 1974. Signature deal: acquired Snapple for $140 million 1992; 2 years later flipped to Quaker Oats for $2 billion. Walked away from firm that bears his name 2006, started anew with Lee Equity Partners. Holds stakes in Dunkin' Donuts, Warner Music. His Blue Star hedge fund of funds suffered sizable losses in 2008, generated large gains last year. Collector of Andy Warhol, Francis Bacon, Mark Rothko; sits on boards of Whitney Museum, Museum of Modern Art.

name: Billionaires
bio: First job was at the Bank of China in freewheeling Shenzhen. Later worked for another lender, the Agricultural Bank of China, and added to his income by investing in stocks. He quit banking in 1995 to set up his Liye Group; invested in finance, electronics and mineral water. Best bet: bought $68 million shares of Chinese insurer Ping An Insurance at auction in 2003; they are now worth $1 billion.

name: Billionaires
bio: Worked for father's construction company in Singapore in his twenties. Moved to Indonesia in 1972 for better opportunities. Thrived as a building contractor but hit the jackpot after moving into coal mining. Bought first mine in 1997, five years after becoming an Indonesian citizen. After a failed effort to sell out, took his coal company Bayan Resources public in 2008. Also has a large stake in Singapore-listed Manhattan Resources. Animal lover has zoo in Borneo with gibbons, sun bears, dozens of peacocks; rehabilitates orangutans for reintroduction into the wild.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former English teacher once offered tours to English-speaking tourists of Hangzhou's famed West Lake. Started the China Pages, one of nation's first internet companies in 1995. Three years later,  founded Internet company Alibaba in 1998 with $60,000 in capital, mostly to offer a way for companies outside China to find manufacturers and suppliers inside China. Took his business portal Alibaba.com, in which Yahoo! is an investor, public in 2007. Alibaba Group, which now has 17,000 employees, also operates Taobao.com, a consumer e-commerce portal similar to Ebay, and AliPay, an online payment system. Serves on the board of Tokyo-listed Softbank, run by Japanese billionaire Masayoshi Son.

name: Billionaires
bio: Proud Oklahoma State U. grad studied agriculture; fellow alum T. Boone Pickens drew him to oil business. Bought Riata Energy with $500 loan 1984; grew into one of nation's largest private drillers. Sold 46% stake to former Chesapeake Energy president Tom Ward for $500 million in 2006. Large shareholder of Transatlantic Petroleum; runs Longfellow Energy. Also invests in venture capital and agriculture. With wife, Amy, last year donated $57.2 million to alma mater to fund entrepreneur program; school's second-biggest giver behind Pickens.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fast-rising real estate tycoon got noticed when Morgan Stanley bought 10% in his Oberoi Constructions for $152 million in 2007. Company's land bank is concentrated in suburban Mumbai where his showpiece project is Oberoi Garden City, an 80-acre complex of offices, apartments, a mall, a school and a five-star hotel managed by Westin. Hoping to cash in on the stock market rebound: revived plans to list his firm, likely this year. Married to a former Bollywood actress, enjoys skiing.

name: Billionaires
bio: Oil magnate cashed out last year. Sold remaining shares in several oil refineries to billionaire Vladimir Yevtushenkov, who had already purchased a stake in 2005. Only son of Murtaza Rakhimov, the "permanent president" of Bashkortostan, an industrial autonomous republic within the Russian Federation. Graduated from Ufa Oil Institute, then continued his education in France. In 1990s worked in the republic's oil and energy industry. In the next 10 years set up a company called Bashkiria Capital and became owner of nearly all of the republic's oil-production and processing companies.

name: Billionaires
bio: Partner in Leon Black's private equity company Apollo Management. Studied at U. of Pennsylvania; stayed at Wharton for M.B.A. With Joshua Harris (see) took job in M&A department of Drexel Burnham Lambert, joined Black to create Apollo 1990. Firm's first 2 funds returned 37% a year net of fees. Assets under management last fall: $51.8 billion. Active with National Jewish Outreach Program, Youth Renewal Fund.

name: Billionaires
bio: Socialite and philanthropist splits her time between London and New York and has homes in Geneva and Monaco. Won court fight with Russian oligarch Mikhail Prokhorov over $53 million downpayment he had given her to purchase her Villa Leopolda estate; sale fell through when his lawyer didn't show up for the closing. Claims to be donating proceeds to 10 different charities. Counts among her friends the U.K.'s Prince Charles and his wife Camilla. Inherited her fortune from late husband Edmond Safra, a billionaire banker who died in a fire in his Monaco apartment in 1999. Reportedly bought Alberto Giacometti sculpture, "Walking Man I," for $103 million in Sotheby's auction after 8 minute bidding battle this February.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son and grandson of Washington, D.C.-area mortgage lenders set up Chevy Chase Bank in trailer 1969. Grew to be Washington, D.C. area's largest commercial bank. Hit hard by mortgage crisis; sold to Capital One last year for $476 million. Founded first real estate investment trust 1964, second REIT 1969. Today Saul Centers manages 7.9 million square feet of property in 6 states; shares up more than 60% in past year. Trustee of Johns Hopkins Medical Board, National Gallery of Art.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Saul Centers Inc.', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Heir to T. Mellon & Sons banking fortune still in divorce court with second wife, Ritchie; Pittsburgh drama now in its third year.
