In May 2009 judge sealed all documents related to the case; salacious documents became public in 2007 after a clerk at the county court accidentally published information--such as the value of various personal trusts--online. The seal is so tight lawyers representing Scaife and his soon-to-be ex reportedly had to get a special pass to review the court docket. Owns Pittsburgh Tribune-Review newspaper, Pennsylvania radio stations. Supports right-wing policy via Heritage Foundation.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cofounder of financial information and media juggernaut Bloomberg LP. Launched financial data and analysis firm Innovative Market Systems with Michael Bloomberg, others in 1982. Renamed Bloomberg LP; sold Merrill Lynch on prototype of terminal that allowed for financial data analysis and made information on government bonds readily available. Merrill became investor and first customer, buying a $30 million cut in the company; sold 20% stake back to Michael Bloomberg for $4.5 billion in 2008. Head of financial products owns more than 4% stake. Earned master's degree in math from SUNY Binghamton, worked in systems research at Salomon Brothers, traded bonds at Morgan Stanley.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fordham M.B.A. a minority stakeholder in oil magnate Roman Abramovich's Millhouse LLC; firm founded 2001 to manage assets owned by Abramovich and his partners. Duo founded oil-trading outfit Runicom early 1990s. Took control of oil firm Sibneft 1995; sold stake to Russian state-owned gas monopoly, Gazprom, for $13.1 billion a decade later. Agreed to buy 41% of Evraz, Russia's largest steelmaker, in 2006. Took drugmaker Pharmstandard public 2007. Other investments: Russian meat processor, Moscow real estate.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father John left humanities professorship at San Jose State in 1976 to start University of Phoenix. Peter joined 1983. Apollo Group went public 1994. Today more than 400,000 students take classes for associate, bachelor's, master's and doctoral degrees. Stock popped 75% last winter as investors anticipated a spike in enrollment as workers became unemployed; shares have dropped nearly 30% since.

name: Billionaires
bio: Has run Berjaya, which means "success" in Malay, since 1984; interests in hotels, lotteries, real estate, finance. Bought 100% of Friendster.com, a social networking website, through his internet company MOL.com; also selling 33% stake in UMobile to Singapore Technologies Telemedia. Plans to list the Singer retail business and the 7-Eleven convenience store chain under Berjaya Retail Bhd (BRetail). Operates Wendy's, Starbucks, Papa Johns Pizza, Kenny Rogers Roasters, Krispy Kreme and Borders bookstores in Malaysia; water and sewage treatment and sanitary landfills in Malaysia, Indonesia and China. Co-owns a yacht called ASEAN Lady with Singapore businessman Brian Chang. Exercise buff loves scuba diving.

name: Billionaires
bio: Runs Turkey's largest construction company, Enka; at age 26, took reins from his father Sarik, company's co-founder. Under contract to build a nuclear power plant in Turkish capital of Ankara. Using family foundation funds to start Enka Schools, one in Istanbul and the other in Adapazarı; 2,000 students enrolled. Known for his modest character, his office has bare white walls.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chess prodigy was ranked 7th in the U.S. under-13 bracket by age 12. Stanford law grad spent time at Credit Suisse before founding Thiel Capital 1996. Renamed Clarium Capital 2002; fund reportedly fell 25% last year. Cofounded PayPal in 1998, sold to Ebay in 2002 for $1.5 billion. Personally netted $60 million. Plowed proceeds into venture capital outfit Founders Fund in 2005. Facebook's first outside investor initially gave founder Mark Zuckerberg $500,000 in 2004; took minority stake. Net worth up as shares of Facebook change hands privately at lofty prices in anticipation of a public offering. Enjoys running, hiking, surfing.
title: Partner

name: Billionaires
bio: With sister Monika Schoeller and half-brother Stefan, inherited publishing house, Verlagsgruppe Holtzbrinck, from their father George, who founded it as a book club in 1948. For 21 years ran the company, which owns book publisher Henry Holt and German newspaper Die Zeit. Retired in May 2001, turning over management of company to brother Stefan.  Sold his share in business to siblings in 2006 and resigned from the supervisory board.  His share was to be disbursed over 15-year period to prevent too large a cash drain on the company.  Last March, acquired Handelsblatt, Germany's biggest financial newspaper, 50% of weekly newspaper Die Zeit and other assets from his siblings canceling previous deal and letting his siblings out of any financial obligation to pay him cash. Has formed a new company,  Dieter von Holtzbrinck Medien GmbH. No sibling rivalry: he and siblings will sit on Die Zeit's supervisory board together.

name: Billionaires
bio: One of the last dot-com billionaires to still command a 10-figure fortune. With partner Mark Cuban, sold live sports and concert Web site Broadcast.com to Yahoo for $5.7 billion in stock 1999. Instantly made 300 employees millionaires, Wagner and Cuban billionaires. Avoided impending crash by shrewdly protecting shares with put options. Yahoo toyed with site for nearly a decade before finally fizzling out domain address. Co-owns 2929 Entertainment, Magnolia Pictures, Landmark Theatres, HDNet.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandfather John T. Dorrance was a chemical engineer who discovered way to can condensed soup using half as much water, cutting costs by a third. Campbell Soup sales in fiscal year 2009: $7.6 billion. Stock up 8% in last year. Owns other familiar brands: Pace (salsa), V8 (vegetable juice), Pepperidge Farm (cookies, Goldfish), Swanson (broth). Owns Live Oak Stud horse-breeding operation.
title: Director

name: Billionaires
bio: Former deputy mayor of Shenzhen in the city's high-flying days back in the early 1980s, took plunge into business in 1986 setting up a trading company. Today his pharmaceuticals firm Salubris, which went public on Shenzhen Stock Exchange in September, makes tablets and injections. Serves as a board member of China Renmin University in Beijing. Son Kevin, with whom he shares his fortune, is the company's general manager.

name: Billionaires
bio: Co-founded paper manufacturer Nine Dragons (whose name implies highest fortune) with sister Yan Cheung and brother-in-law Lin Ming Chen. Cheung is chairman; Zhang is deputy chief executive, responsible for the daily management of the company's marketing and distribution, finance, procurement, sales and IT departments. All three return as billionaires this year as stock has strongly rebounded.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ukraine's youngest billionaire returns to the billionaires list as his iron ore producer Ferrexpo recovers from 2008 market collapse. At the time, company's share price tumbled 94% in 5 months, and Zhevago was forced to sell  21% stake to meet margin calls; he also took over as chief executive. His Finance & Credit Bank still struggling; it recently reported losses for 2009. Deputy in Ukraine's parliament, his party leader was defeated in recent election. Started out as finance director of bank Finance & Credit in 1992 when he was just 19. Eventually gained a majority stake in its holding company.

name: Billionaires
bio: Oilman used petroleum proceeds to build pigskin fortune. Bought pro football's Houston Oilers in 1959 for $25,000; moved to Tennessee 1997. Today the Tennessee Titans are worth $870 million net of debt. Fined $250,000 in November for making "obscene gestures" at opposing fans. Demanded quarterback Vince Young regain starting position after 0-6 start; team won 80% of remaining games. Earned engineering degree from University of Kansas, Navy post in the Pacific during WWII. Founded ADA Oil Co. in 1946, later became Adams Resources & Energy. Public 1974; shares down 35% in past year. "Bud" is part Cherokee; collects Native American artifacts, Western art. Owns ranches in Texas, farmland in California.

name: Billionaires
bio: Trade fair operator and retailer funded the construction of Moscow's Myakinino metro station, which opened at the end of 2009; the station is on the same property as Agalarov's Crocus shopping center. Got his start trading computers, but soon saw that trade fairs had more business potential. In 1988 established Crocus, which became one of the country's largest trade-fair operators. Opened the Crocus Inter store, which grew into a retail company with malls offering house wares and the luxurious Crocus City Mall, the "city of boutiques." Seen as the unofficial representative of the Azerbaijani diaspora in Russia. In 2006 his son, Emin, married the daughter of Azerbaijan's president, Ilkham Aliyev. Publishes Baku magazine, which is edited by daughter-in-law Leyla Aliyeva.

name: Billionaires
bio: Estranged brother of mall mogul Majid Al Futtaim oversees family's auto assets, which he received when Ruler of Dubai Sheikh Mohammed bin Rashid Al Maktoum brokered split between feuding siblings in 2000. Holding company Al Futtaim Group is UAE's exclusive distributor for such brands as Toyota, Dodge, Jeep and Lexus. Also has big footprint in hard-hit retail and real estate sectors: local franchisee for Ikea, Marks & Spencer, Toys "R" Us and Ace Hardware, and main developer behind Dubai Festival City, the Middle East's largest privately funded mixed-use real estate project. Crushed property values due to Dubai's burst speculative bubble has group looking outside Gulf: currently planning to replicate Festival City in Cairo and Syria. In June purchased 360-foot yacht from Russian tycoon Boris Berezovsky for a reported $340 million. Boat boasts 7 decks, a helipad and 2 swimming pools.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder and largest shareholder of RMK, Russia's third-largest copper producer, returns to billionaires list with rising copper prices. In the fall of 2009, with Iskander Makhmudov's UGMK, bought a controlling stake in Chelyabinsk Zinc Factory, the largest zinc producer in Russia. Started out in the early 1990s trading scrap metals. In 1997 established Uralelectromed-Vtortsvetmet, which became the main supplier of scrap and copper to Makhmudov's UGMK.

name: Billionaires
bio: Third generation head of 84-year-old Bajaj Group after ending long simmering dispute with younger brother Shishir, who now runs sugar and consumer products businesses that were once part of joint group. Rahul and three cousins oversee core businesses, which include motorcycles, financial services and specialty steel. Flagship Bajaj Auto, under son Rajiv, has decided to stop making its iconic scooters and focus on motorcycles. Also partnering with Renault-Nissan to make a small, low cost car. Younger son Sanjiv oversees financial unit including insurance joint venture with Allianz.

name: Billionaires
bio: Real estate kingpin paid $23.5 million for debt on Michael Jackson's Neverland Ranch in 2007, became part-owner; helped broker late King of Pop's ill-fated comeback concert tour. An editor of the law review at U. of San Diego negotiated deals in Saudi Arabia after stint there working for construction giant Fluor. Later joined real estate side of Robert Bass' investment firm. Founded Colony Capital 1991. Made first fortune buying up bad real estate loans from Resolution Trust Corp. amid S&L fiasco. Today firm manages $30 billion. Holdings include Parisian soccer team Saint-Germain, hospitals in Switzerland, offices in Germany. Sifting hotel industry for deals: "Generally, occupancy levels below 60% signal excellent buying opportunities."

name: Billionaires
bio: Corporate raider known for snapping up large stakes in distressed companies. Got start as a bank trainee at Edmond de Rothschild. Has targeted advertising companies: built up a stake in French agency Havas, demanded board seats, gutted management and made himself chairman. Also has shares in Aegis Group, the British media and market research concern. Eclectic portfolio includes African shipping, Asian palm-oil plantations, plastics. Group is developing an electric car, called the BlueCar. Hosted close friend French President Sarkozy on his yacht for a post election holiday off Malta in 2007. Has a collection of 1,000 comic books.

name: Billionaires
bio: Low-profile former banker derives chunk of his fortune from 2000 sale of Banco Bozano, Simonsen to Spain's Banco Santander Central Hispano. In 2006 reportedly sold stakes in coffee plantation and Rio de Janeiro shopping center to new Brazilian investment fund. Owns a 10% stake in Brazilian jetmaker Embraer, the world's third-largest maker of airplanes. Bozano has invested in Azul, the new discount Brazilian airline launched by JetBlue founder and former chief executive David Neeleman. Devout thoroughbred horse owner reportedly has 300 mares between several farms around the world. Has a home in Greenwich, Conn.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Stryker Corp. Left corn, pigs and cows of Tennessee farm to study chemical engineering at Auburn U. Took job as a product manager at Bristol-Myers Squibb; eventually led surgical instruments division. Joined Stryker Corp. after Lee Stryker died in 1976. Expanded company from hospital beds to heavyweight in replacement knees, hips.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former Pizza Hut store manager served the masses online with AOL. Now pushes vacation homes for upper class via Exclusive Resorts. Invested $500 million in health and wellness concerns via investment company Revolution in 2006; sold payments platform Revolution Money to American Express for $300 million in January. AOL founder made biggest bet in tech boom, merging with Time Warner. Ensuing debacle prompted resignation as chairman 2003. Other investments include real estate, pineapple farming in Hawaii. Heads the Case Foundation and Accelerate Brain Cancer Cure.

name: Billionaires
bio: Long-time real estate investor is developing properties on Jinbao Street, Beijing's luxury shopping district. Customers and partners include the Regent Hotel, the Hong Kong Jockey Club, Ferrari and Lamborghini. Politically connected Chan is also curator and founder of China Red Sandalwood Museum; "cultural diplomat" facilitates exchanges between the museum and others such as the Smithsonian.
title: Philanthropist

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of the Evergreen Group, a large transportation group based in Taiwan with major shipping and aviation interests. Evergreen's history dates back to 1968 when it operated small ships to transport cargo. Today it has a fleet of 100 container vessels and ranks as one of the world's largest shipping companies. Major group companies are Evergreen Marine, Evergreen International, EVA Air and Evergreen International Storage. Two sons sit on the board of Evergreen Marine.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of SK Group, South Korea's third largest conglomerate by assets; group has 77 affiliates with interests in energy, telecom, chemicals. Most of these assets are held within SK C&C, the holding group that he listed in November. His stake in the newly listed firm is worth nearly $1 billion. SK recently donated funeral service center to town outside Seoul. Chey was pardoned in 2008 for accounting fraud. President of Korea Handball Federation. Wife is daughter of South Korea's former president, Roh Tae Woo.

name: Billionaires
bio: Studied geology at an oil-and-gas university in Moscow. Sensing deep demand in post-Soviet Russia's deteriorating oil sector, set up an oil-services firm, PetroAlliance, in 1995. In 2003 sold PetroAlliance to oil-services giant Schlumberger. A year later, with Russian oil companies consolidating and shedding assets, teamed up with partners including former Halliburton managers to buy Lukoil's well-drilling business. The firm, Eurasia Drilling Co. listed in London in 2007; stock price has rebounded from financial crisis lows, rising along with oil prices.

name: Billionaires
bio: Parents Donald (d. 2009) and Doris founded Gap as a San Francisco jeans and music store in 1969. Now more than 3,000 locations; expanded empire includes Banana Republic (1983), Gap Kids (1986) and Old Navy (1994). Shares up 120% in past year. Father Donald died in September of cancer at age 81. Doris owns large contemporary art collection, featuring pieces by Andy Warhol, Chuck Close, Richard Serra and Alexander Calder. Loaned collection to San Francisco Museum of Modern Art in September after attempt to open museum in San Francisco's historic Presidio district was nixed following resident complaints. Has controlled company with brothers Robert and William since 2004. Owns minority stake in Oakland A's baseball team.
title: President

name: Billionaires
bio: Parents Donald (d. 2009) and Doris founded Gap as a San Francisco jeans and music store in 1969. Now more than 3,000 locations; expanded empire includes Banana Republic (1983), Gap Kids (1986) and Old Navy (1994). Shares up 120% in past year. Father Donald died in September of cancer at age 81. Doris owns large contemporary art collection, featuring pieces by Andy Warhol, Chuck Close, Richard Serra and Alexander Calder. Loaned collection to San Francisco Museum of Modern Art in September after attempt to open museum in San Francisco's historic Presidio district was nixed following resident complaints. Has controlled company with brothers John and William since 2004.
title: Director

name: Billionaires
bio: Grew up wealthy in Greenwich, Conn. Played goalie on Yale's hockey team, then law degree at Columbia. With brother, founded buyout shop Forstmann Little 1978. Critic of junk bonds minted large fortune buying, growing, selling Gulfstream Aerospace and General Instruments. Paid $750 million for talent giant IMG 2004. Among the company's clients: golfer Tiger Woods, model Gisele Bundchen. In December, Citadel Broadcasting filed for bankruptcy, decimating shareholders; Forstmann once controlled 28% stake in the troubled Nevada radio outfit. Also owns 24 Hour Fitness.

name: Billionaires
bio: Dropped out of high school, served in Marines in WWII. GI Bill provided training in television repair. Started cable company in Liberty, N.Y. with $1,500 in 1956. Developed into 5-channel system; sold to Time Warner in 1996, netting $900 million. Investment portfolio includes hedge funds, private equity, real estate. Gives to environmental, education, medical causes. His Woodstock museum garnered recent attention for festival's 40th anniversary.

name: Billionaires
bio: Dropped out of college to join father's small construction firm in Mumbai and helped expand it into the Dynamix group whose interests include a dairy business. Partnered with the Balwa family in 1999 to build a Meridien Hotel near Mumbai's international airport. Partnership later became DB Realty, now a leading real estate firm that the two families recently listed, raising $323 million. Partners also own 45% stake in a telecom joint venture with UAE's Etisalat, which has still to start services. Grant of telecom licenses, including that to the former Swan Telecom, being probed by the Central Bureau of Investigation.

name: Billionaires
bio: Retailer turned real estate guru. Made his first fortune in 1973 when he sold his U.K. discount retail chain Kwik Save for $28 million. Repeated his Kwik Save model in New Zealand, Ireland and the U.S., investing the profits in real estate in places such as Liverpool, Manchester, Sheffield, Hull and tax haven Isle of Man. While recuperating from a bad back, decided to open fitness centers; sold his health club chain Total Fitness (but not the real estate it sits on) for $154 million in 2004. Devout Catholic has pledged his wealth to both religious and secular causes, like the building of new churches and university scholarships for Isle of Man residents.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandson of a soldier, sent to military school at age 13. Former member of Soviet internal intelligence unit, sent to East Germany in 1985. Resigned four years later, with just 20,000 rubles in savings. Worked as a cook on ships for a year and a half. During privatization era, picked up an old Soviet ship no one wanted and repaired it. Now his Palmali Group has a fleet of around 200 vessels that transport oil. Azerbaijan native took Turkish citizenship in 2006 and two years later changed his last name from Mansimov to Gurbanoglu. Sleeps four hours a night; flies at least 120 hours a month. Animal lover has 12 dogs; also keeps dogs and monkeys in his botanic-garden-like Istanbul office. Built shelters for homeless animals in Russia and Azerbaijan.

name: Billionaires
bio: Reportedly left a Communist Party job to set up a minerals company in the 1980s in Liaoning province. Today, his Houying Group is one of China's largest producers of refractory materials; also has interests in steel and soybean processing. Son He Xianshu helps him run the business.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ex-Australian army captain and papal knight created Convertible & Quantitative Strategies (CQS) hedge fund in London in 1999 after stints at Goldman Sachs and Credit Suisse First Boston. With $7 billion in assets under management across 10 listed and unlisted funds, CQS saw funds rise an average 30% last year. Collects rural properties in Australia. Funds restoration of Michelangelo's frescoes at Vatican's Pauline Chapel.

name: Billionaires
bio: Blackstone tycoon made back some of his fortune amid market rally. Shares of the investment firm surged 120% in 2009; still off 60% since public offering 2007. Graduated from Harvard 1973. Spent 25 years at investment bank Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. Served as chairman of investment banking and private equity at Credit Suisse First Boston before joining Blackstone 2002. Firm went public three years ago; now manages $98.2 billion.

name: Billionaires
bio: Owns stake in Hong Kong-listed mining firm Zijin, along with fellow Chinese billionaire Chen Fashu. Sold shares in recent years, invested proceeds in real estate and other public companies such as Chinese electronics manufacturer BOE and Shanghai airline China Eastern.

name: Billionaires
bio: Venture capitalist continues to flog the green theme: dismisses wind power, electric cars as too expensive, unreliable to become mainstream. Says efforts should go to solving greenhouse-gas emissions from cement, oil, coal, steel industries; still bullish on ethanol. India-born engineer came to U.S. to attend grad school at Carnegie Mellon. With partners, founded Sun Microsystems in 1985. Four years later joined Sun investor John Doerr at venture outfit Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers. Split in 2004 to start Khosla Ventures. Recently raised $1 billion across 2 funds to invest in clean tech, IT.
title: Partner

name: Billionaires
bio: Moscow-born banker emigrated to America with parents in 1976; became U.S. citizen. Studied at Carnegie Mellon, M.B.A. from Harvard. Returned to Russia in mid-1990s, headed Credit Suisse First Boston's Moscow operation. Became chief of Alfa Bank, Russia's largest private commercial bank. Now director of Pamplona Capital Management; British private equity firm helps Russian businesses invest overseas. Part of team of Russian investors who brokered a September 2008 truce between TNK-BP's squabbling foes AAR and BP.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of LG Group, Korea's 4th largest conglomerate by assets; has more than 50 affiliates in electronics, home appliances, chemicals, telecom. Son died in an accident in 1990s. Adopted brother's son Gwang-mo (who got married last September) in 2004; he is now Koo's heir apparent to run LG group. Loves wine; has collection of over 50,000 bottles stored in special wine cellar in a cave.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son-in-law of Kazakhstan's President Nursultan Nazarbaev owns large stake in Halyk, Kazakhstan's third-largest lender. Deputy chief executive of government's Samruk-Kazyna fund, which gave Halyk a $600 million bailout. Bank stock up fivefold since March 2009 low returning Kulibaev to billionaire ranks along with wife, Dinara Kulibaeva, another big shareholder of the bank. Chairs 3 national companies: national oil and gas company, KazMunaiGas; national railway company, Kazakhstan TemirZholy; and power sector operator, Samruk-Energo.

name: Billionaires
bio: Second daughter of Kazakhstan President Nursultan Nazarbaev returns to the billionaire ranks along with husband Timur Kulibaev, as their jointly owned stake in Halyk is up fivefold since last March. Executive director of education foundation named after her father reportedly purchased a $70 million villa on the shores of Lake Geneva.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chief executive of Fimalac, parent of Fitch Ratings, which operates in 50 countries. Vilified  for his rating agency's role in sub prime debacle, he nevertheless makes his return to the billionaire ranks thanks to 28% rise in stock price in past year. Founded the company in 1991 after a varied career. Started a teen magazine in 1961 at age 21. Sold it off a few years later. Attended elite Ecole Nationale d' Administration, then moved into banking and finance. Eventually landed at L'Oreal, where he spent 15 years, rising up to group executive vice president of finance. Now a board member at L'Oreal and Renault. A theater buff, he has helped fund renovations for the Theatre du Rond Point in Paris. Is also on the board of the American Friends of the Louvre. Last August was named good will ambassador by UNESCO.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairs Tibet Cheezheng Tibetan Medicine, a Tibetan-style medicine company initially formed as a joint venture in December 1995. Firm makes ointments, plasters and powders to relieve pain and respiratory problems; went public on the Shenzhen Stock Exchange in August. Shares trading at a lofty 46 times earnings. Owns 81% of firm. Has a degree in vacuum physics.

name: Billionaires
bio: Wharton M.B.A. started at Oppenheimer & Co.; learned investing from firm's cofounder Leon Levy. Took over company that became First Reserve 1983; launched buyout fund 9 years later. Big score: earned $240 million profit over 6 years selling stake in drilling equipment producer National Oilwell. Last year finished raising $9 billion fund, creating the world's largest energy investment firm. Total assets: $19 billion. Fishing for deep-sea oil in Gulf of Mexico, Gulf of Guinea via publicly traded portfolio company Cobalt International. Enjoys bird-watching.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of Bob Magness (d. 1996), founder of cable television titan TCI, which merged with AT&T in 1999 in a $54 billion deal. Inherited hundreds of millions of dollars in stock. Owns water rights in Colorado through ranch holdings; also invests in oil, gas, cattle. Getting into entertainment business: produced critically acclaimed movie "Precious" with wife, Sarah. Movie won several awards at Sundance Film Festival, nominated for six Oscars. Grossed $45 million domestically and being released internationally.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fan of U. of Texas and Texas Christian football got first taste of energy business at age 10 with wildcatter father W.A. (Monty) Moncrief Sr.; Tex witnessed dad's discovery of 6-billion-barrel East Texas oilfield. Wanted to quit school to become a pro golfer 1939, dad talked him out of it. Studied petroleum engineering at U. of Texas; Navy in WWII; later worked for father's Moncrief Oil. Acquired one-third of Wyoming's Madden Deep natural gas field; still company's biggest asset. Has 20,000-acre parcel on Barnett Shale, leaving undeveloped for now. Falling natural gas prices at 7-year lows, shaving $900 million from fortune. Last summer bought stake in McMoRan Exploration's deepwater drilling operation in the Gulf of Mexico.

name: Billionaires
bio: Worked in chemical industry his entire life, first for a state-owned company, later on his own. Currently a major stakeholder in five biggest chemical plants in Romania; also owns InterAgro, the largest domestic agricultural producer. Bought up agricultural land on cheap in past year. Invested more than $100 million in a bio-ethanol plant in Zimnicea in September 2009. Diverse portfolio includes interests in refineries, four-star hotels, consulting firms, restaurants, slaughter-houses, soccer teams and real estate. Says he enjoys Romania far more than faraway destinations; prefers the Danube to the seaside.

name: Billionaires
bio: Family firm Yıldız Holding, which he owns with brother Murat Ulker, also a billionaire, is one of Turkey's oldest food firms. Group has 68 companies with over eight divisions, bought Godiva last year. Also has stakes in half-dozen other businesses in banking, logistics and information technology sectors.

name: Billionaires
bio: Dropped out of Wharton 1963. Scored big with Triangle Industries' acquisition of National Can 1985; sold company for $4.2 billion 1988. Another winner: bought Snapple for $300 million 1997; sold 3 years later to Cadbury Schweppes for $1.5 billion. Merged holding company Triarc with Wendy's in 2008; renamed Wendy's/Arby's. Today controls 22% of company via investment vehicle Trian Management. Other large holdings as of December: Tiffany & Co. (jewelry), Legg Mason (mutual funds), H.J. Heinz (food products). Elected to board of Legg Mason in the fall.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Graduated from Oklahoma State 1951 with degree in geology. Three-year stint at Phillips Petroleum. Left to start Mesa Petroleum 1956 with $2,500. Sold to Richard Rainwater; made name with attempted takeovers of Phillips, Unocal. Invests via energy fund  BP Capital; owns extensive water rights in Texas Panhandle. Born-again environmentalist still stumping for "Pickens Plan," proposal to replace addiction to foreign oil with mixture of wind, nuclear, natural gas. Delayed construction of massive wind farm in Texas after credit markets seized and natural gas prices fell in 2008. Published memoir The First Billion Is the Hardest last year.

name: Billionaires
bio: A graduate of Simferopol State University, in mid-1990s founded Russian General Bank with fellow billionaire Alexander Skorobogatko, which served the Novorossiysk Sea Trading Port. After the 1998 crisis the partners began buying up shares in stevedoring companies that were working at the port and combined them to form one holding company. The firm, Novorossiysk Commercial Sea Port, went public in November 2007, resulting in a windfall of $1 billion for the partners. Bulk of fortune is his stake in the company. In 2008 the partners sold 20% of the port to Arkady Rotenberg, a powerful businessman who does judo with Russian Prime Minister Vladimir Putin.

name: Billionaires
bio: Inherited stake in family's Sainsbury's, one of the U.K.'s largest grocers; in recent years group has expanded into insurance, banking and travel businesses. Stepped down from management in 1998 to enter politics; Minister for Science & Innovation for 8 years, resigned in 2006. Has given away hundreds of millions through his Gatsby Charitable Foundation, which supports education, medical research and the arts. Recently donated more than $1.5 million to U.K. Labour Party.

name: Billionaires
bio: Swedish badminton prodigy attended college outside Stockholm. Stint in Paris covering European stocks for Atlantic Finance then MBA at Columbia. Joined legendary investment banker Ace Greenberg at Bear Stearns 1988. Memorable assignment: worked on billionaire Kirk Kerkorian's bid for Chrysler. Launched hedge fund Sandell Asset Management 1998. Lost 30% in 2008; returned 10% last year net of fees. Firm now manages $1.5 billion, down from $7.5 billion 2 years ago. Believed to be raising $1 billion for credit, merger arbitrage funds.

name: Billionaires
bio: Pipemaker recovering with two massive deals; his OMK (United Metals Company) is supplying an oil pipeline to China and a gas pipeline to Germany. Graduate of Moscow State Institute of Steel & Alloys, which several of Russia's tycoons attended. Worked as an economist in the Central Research Institute for Ferrous Metallurgy. In 1989 started a joint venture in scrap-metal recycling with a $1.5 million loan from Sberbank, one of Russia's largest banks. Then started buying up shares in pipe producer Vyksunsky Metallurgical Plant (VMP), a factory in the Urals region that was founded in 1757; by 1999 Sedykh and his partners were controlling shareholders. Later established the United Metallurgical Company, Russia's second-largest pipe producer and its largest maker of railway wheels.

name: Billionaires
bio: Left U. of Pennsylvania for military in WWII. Moved to San Francisco with pregnant wife and $1,000. Started as salesman for commercial real estate firm. Became partner 1951, president and owner 1960. Built up portfolio of office properties, including the Bank of America Center in San Francisco. Benefited from real estate price hikes during Silicon Valley dot-com era. Onetime owner of 20% of city's office space started selling after tech bubble burst. Recently built office space in Portland, Ore. Son, Douglas, is chairman. Daughter, Carole, has won 5 Tonys as a Broadway producer.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mall owner returns to billionaire status as Simon Property Group stock surges 57% in a year. With brother and business partner Melvin (d. 2009), covered country with shopping malls. Today Simon Property Group is the largest publicly traded real estate investment trust in the U.S.; firm owns or has interests in 261 million square feet of leasable space at 382 properties in North America, Europe, Asia. Recently made $10 billion bid for rival General Growth Properties in February. Sole owner of Indiana Pacers; recently welcomed seventh child with third wife, a former Miss Universe.
title: Chairman Emeritus of the Board of Simon Property Group, Inc.
employment: {'name': 'Simon Property Group', 'uri': 'companies/simon-property-group', 'title': 'Chairman Emeritus of the Board of Simon Property Group, Inc.', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: If your name is your destiny, Skorobogatko got the right one: his means "rich soon." In 1989 formed a small perfume-production company in the Crimea with Alexander Ponomarenko, now also a billionaire. Three years later moved to Moscow, where the pair traded consumer goods; with their earnings established a bank. Now the partners have a controlling stake in the Novorossiysk Sea Trading Port, the largest port in Russia and the fifth-largest in Europe in terms of cargo volume. Since 2002 he hasn't been involved in the business: five years ago became a representative of the Kaliningrad region in the upper house of parliament and a year later became a lower-house deputy. In 2008 Skorobogatko and Pononarenko sold 20% of the port to Arkady Rotenberg, a powerful businessman who does judo with Vladimir Putin.

name: Billionaires
bio: University of Maryland dropout became a millionaire with marketing outfit Snyder Communications; outsourced marketing for companies lacking own sales force. Bought pro football's Washington Redskins for record $750 million in 1999, became a billionaire as the team surged in value. Team's net-of-debt value: $1.3 billion. Recession racking restaurant and entertainment portfolio; Snyder has 6% stake in amusement park outfit Six Flags, which filed for bankruptcy last June. His Red Zone Capital owns chunks of Johnny Rockets restaurant chain, Red Zebra Broadcasting and Dick Clark Productions.

name: Billionaires
bio: Swimmer at University of the Pacific worked in his parents' bakery. Started catering company 1951 with $800 loan; plowed profits into real estate. A.G. Spanos Cos. has built 120,000 apartments in 19 states in 6 decades. Bought controlling stake in pro football's San Diego Chargers 1984; net worth up $100 million in past year as real estate losses offset by increasing value of football squad.

name: Billionaires
bio: "The Boss" christened new $1.1 billion Yankee Stadium with World Series Championship in October; team had a relatively frugal off-season compared to last year's $450 million spending spree. Bought Yankees from CBS for $10 million in 1973; franchise now worth $1.5 billion but is 95% leveraged thanks to Yankee Stadium debt. Vast majority of net worth made up by YES Network: regional cable channel broadcasts the Bronx Bombers to New York City and beyond.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder and chairman of Kazakhstan's largest bank Kazkommertsbank benefited from a near billion dollar government bailout last year. The move buoyed investors, stock price up over 50% returning him to the billionaires list. In the past two years, the bank repaid $2 billion of debt burden, $7 billion still on the books; plans to focus on deposit growth this year. Via his stake in Central Asian Investment Co., has interests in oil and gas, energy, telecommunications, transportation and media companies in Kazakhstan. Attended Moscow State University with fellow billionaire returnee Timur Kulibaev.

name: Billionaires
bio: With grade-school chum Glenn Dubin founded hedge fund and private equity outfit Highbridge 1992. Sold 55% stake to JPMorgan Chase 2004 for more than $1.3 billion. Sold remainder of firm to investment bank in installments; finished cashing out last year. Assets under management: $21 billion. Firm's flagship "multistrategy" fund returned 39.2% net of fees in 2009 after falling 25% in 2008. Attended SUNY Stony Brook, then Columbia Business School; serves on executive committee of pro-Israel lobby American Israel Public Affairs Committee. Left Highbridge last year, plans to invest via new firm.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Bartender's son studied at Southern Illinois University; paid tuition with money earned selling life insurance. Pounced on booming telecom market; founded long-distance provider Excel Communications 1988. Public 1996. Merged 2 years later with Teleglobe in what ended up as a $3.5 billion deal. Reinvested in stocks, bonds, horses; recently buying up mortgage-backed fixed income. Spends time sponsoring 2 sons' nationally competitive youth basketball teams.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandfather John T. Dorrance was a chemical engineer who discovered way to can condensed soup using half as much water, cutting costs by a third. Campbell Soup sales in fiscal year 2009: $7.6 billion. Stock up 8% in last year. Owns other familiar brands: Pace (salsa), V8 (vegetable juice), Pepperidge Farm (cookies, Goldfish), Swanson (broth). Son Archbold commands Campbell's sales force.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Ufida, one of China's largest suppliers of software for businesses. Company operates complex in Beijing's equivalent of Silicon Valley, Zhongguancun. Born in an isolated farm village in Jiangxi province, a poor region in southeast China. Entered a local business college at age 14 and received a degree before turning 18. Worked for the government before getting into the software business with a friend.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cofounded Video Technology in 1976 to make home TV game consoles. Today VTech, which he heads, is one of world's largest makers of cordless phones; number one in U.S. Also makes electronic educational toys. Serves as independent director of the Bank of East Asia, China-Hong Kong Photo Products Holdings and Li & Fung.

name: Billionaires
bio: His Meijin Energy is the largest coking company in Shanxi Province; has thrived on China's rapid demand for steel. Meijin also has investments in coal; recently bid for an Australian coal company.  Founded firm but has since turned over daily operations to his son, Yao Junliang.

name: Billionaires
bio: Started Orient Group as a construction firm in 1978 in northeastern Heilongjiang province, just as China's economic reforms were getting started. Orient has diversified into financial services, logistics, furniture retailing and energy.  Zhang has stakes in Orient Group, Jinzhou Port, and China Minsheng Bank, where his is a director. Daughter Zhang Meiying is on the board of United Energy, which trades in Hong Kong and is majority owned by Zhang.

name: Billionaires
bio: Largest shareholder of Hualan Biological Engineering, which went public in 2004 and trades on the Shenzhen Stock Exchange; biotech firm is one of China's largest producers of gamma globulin and serum albumin. Firm was founded as a joint venture with Taiwan and Hong Kong investors. Former government employee was general manager of a predecessor firm; majored in biology.

name: Billionaires
bio: Entered billionaires' ranks this year after successful merger of his chemical and agricultural food company, Agrofert Holding, with rival Agropol Group. His group encompasses over 100 companies including meat processors, bakeries and fertilizers (it is the second largest exporter of fertilizers in Europe). Currently in arbitration over soured deal with Poland's PKN Orlen; claims PKN Orlen did not hand over fair assets of Czech oil company Unipetrol; PKN Orlen denies the charges. Son of diplomat was born in what is now Slovak Republic; began as trader for Petrimex, precursor to Agrofert, which he now owns outright.

name: Billionaires
bio: Michigan State grad left Wall Street in 1969 for a fresher perspective on markets; moved to Denver, founded mutual fund giant Janus. Enjoyed exceptional returns during bull markets of 1980s, 1990s; became fourth-largest mutual fund company in the country. Losses mounted in 2000; resigned chief exec post 2002. Stepped down as chairman 2 years later. Now breeds horses at his Iron Rose Ranch in Carbondale, Colo.

name: Billionaires
bio: College dropout migrated to Mumbai with his family from Gujarat to start a restaurant business. Moved into hotels, ending up partnering with Vinod Goenka in DB Realty and also in telecom outfit DB Etisalat. Their real estate firm currently has 60 million square feet under development. Projects include Turf Estate, a luxury high-rise, and the 108-storey Park Hyatt Hotel in South Mumbai that will be completed in 2013. Fitness fanatic works out every day. Both he and Vinod are rumored to be politically well-connected.

name: Billionaires
bio: Born into prominent Kolkata business family with interests in jute, paper, cement and power. Inherited cement outfit after split in family conglomerate in 1992. Built Shree Cement into leading cement maker in northern India, his stronghold. Company also operates thermal power plants. Set up and runs a Sanskrit school to promote Indian heritage. Involved in the preservation of sand dunes in Rajasthan where his factories are located. Handed over day-to-day operations to son Hari Mohan who has been managing director since 2002.

name: Billionaires
bio: Wisconsin oilman bought majority stake in pro football's Denver Broncos in 1984 for $78 million; nabbed rest of team with family a year later. Dominated football in the late 1990s, winning back-to-back Super Bowls. Team has lost luster recently; Bowlen fired legendary coach Mike Shanahan last year. Fitness guru has completed Ironman Triathlon, several marathons.

name: Billionaires
bio: Met partner Min Kao at AlliedSignal, founded Garmin in 1989 to make navigation devices for aviation and boating using newfangled Global Positioning System. Original office: 2 folding chairs and a card table. U.S. Army servicemen loved GPS units during Gulf and Iraq wars; Garmin never had a military contract. In 1998 duo realized GPS could sell to directions-starved drivers on U.S. highway. Fortunes soared, spouses stop bickering. Burrell retired as co-chairman 2004, now chairman emeritus.
title: Chairman Emeritus

name: Billionaires
bio: Textile entrepreneur owns Gap Textile, one of world's top 10 denim producers, which sells products to Diesel, Levi Strauss, Armani, Gap and other Western brands; also owns Turkey's second-largest media company, Sabah and ATV. Company publishes Forbes Turkey, under license from Forbes Media LLC. More recently, conglomerate has been bidding on electricity-distribution companies being privatized. Last October signed a memorandum of understanding with Italy's Eni and Russia's Transneft and Rosneft to construct Trans-Anatolia pipeline.

name: Billionaires
bio: Beekeeper's son from small North Island town now heads Legatum, an investment firm, venture fund and think tank. Made first fortune when he and brother Richard, also a billionaire, invested proceeds from selling parents' department store in Hong Kong real estate. Together founded investment firm Sovereign Global in Monaco, focusing on transitioning industries in Russia, Latin America and eastern Europe. Brothers amicably split to go solo in 2006. Based in Dubai, Legatum continues investment approach of predecessor with special emphasis on socially sustainable enterprises, such as microfinance. At one point his investments in India were estimated to be worth $4 billion; In 2009 was reported to be dumping investments there. Founded Legatum Center for Development & Entrepreneurship at MIT, which sponsors students from developing countries who aspire to launch businesses back home.

name: Billionaires
bio: Majority owner of electric power plants and copper, aluminum and soda ash mines in Turkey, he also has smaller interests in gas and aviation. Savings Deposit Insurance Fund (TMSF) confiscated his media group's assets (ATV and Sabah Newspaper) in April 2007. The TMSF reported that the seizure was due to newly acquired knowledge on some secret contracts allegedly signed between him and Dinc Bilgin, the ex-owner and founder of Sabah newspaper and ATV. Still moving ahead: has since built a new media center in Istanbul. Also started publishing newspaper last year; signed a 2009 agreement with Bloomberg Television to launch BloombergHT. Owns apple farms on the outskirts of Istanbul. Personally pays for multiple school construction throughout Turkey.

name: Billionaires
bio: Got rich helping masses balance their checkbooks. Cofounded Intuit in 1983; popular personal financial-planning tool Quicken inspired by wife's complaints about paying the bills. Products now include Quicken Health Expense Tracker, Quick Books and TurboTax. Stock up 20% in past year. Claimed victory against Microsoft last June when software Goliath stopped producing Quicken-competitor Microsoft Money. With wife funded brand-management research center at U. of Wisconsin-Madison's business school.

name: Billionaires
bio: Turkey's media king pin returns to the ranks despite scandal. His Dogan Yayin Holdings (Dogan Publishing Holding), the country's largest media group, was fined 3.8 billion liras (approximately $2.5 billion) in September 2009 for tax evasion, on top of another 862,4 million liras (approximately $583 million) fine in February 2009. Company is challenging those penalties in court; a tax court overturned $520 million in February 2010. Officially retired in January, handing post to daughter Arzuhan; Dogan will remain as honorary president. His four daughters own shares worth about $450 million apiece in the holding company; not reflected in his net worth. Also owns a large gasoline company. Charitable foundation supports literacy programs. Avid walker and swimmer in his spare time.

name: Billionaires
bio: U.K.'s new "tech tsar" urging cultural change to increase value society places on scientists and engineers; tax breaks for tech investments to improve U.K. innovation. Inventor of famous bag-less vacuums attended art school to study design and engineering. Ran through 5,127 prototypes until he perfected G-Force, an upright vacuum using spinning technology to maintain constant suction. Introduced product in U.K. in 1993; it was an immediate hit. Guards technology zealously. In January 2008 won a patent-infringement case against Samsung Electronics. Stated: "We may not be a commercial giant like Samsung, but we will vigorously defend all the technology we have worked hard to develop and protect."

name: Billionaires
bio: Built boats in his Seattle garage before founding Bayliner Marine 1955. Goal: to enable average Joes to own a boat. Doubled revenue every 3 years; sold to Brunswick for $425 million 1986. Invested in smaller yacht company Westport shortly after, revived struggling builder. Majority of fortune believed to be held in stocks, bonds, real estate. Spends days flying helicopters, skiing, cruising in 164-foot yacht, Evviva.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cofounded Research In Motion with childhood friend and fellow billionaire Mike Lazaridis in 1984. Back in ranks thanks to loonie and 10% rise in value of RIM shares.  The former vice president of operations retired from company 2007. Fregin was instrumental in designing the first circuit boards that were used in early versions of the company's wireless technology. He was also key in selecting the materials that are now standard in the BlackBerry.

name: Billionaires
bio: Pioneer in commercial breeding of chickens in China at the start of the country's economic reforms in the early 1980s; got start with a RMB20,000 loan in Fujian province. Big break: became a supplier to KFC in 1994. Today, his Fujian Sunner Development, which went public in October, is one of the largest producers of chicken meat in China. Shares fortune with daughter.

name: Billionaires
bio: Read market reports for fun, bought first stock at 13. Founded Gabelli Asset Management 1977; launched first mutual fund 1986. Public offering 1999. Today GAMCO Investors manages $26.3 billion, up 30% since beginning of 2009. Columbia business school grad skips salary, bonuses, stock options; prefers management fee-based compensation instead. Lucrative tradeoff: earned $46 million in 2008. Shares of GAMCO rose 75% last year.

name: Billionaires
bio: A criminal who makes his fortune illegally and violently has become a symbol of Mexico's deadly drug wars. Mexico's most wanted man, El Chapo (or Shorty) heads the Sinaloa cartel, one of the biggest suppliers of cocaine to the U.S. Thousands have perished in turf wars and attempted government crackdowns, including key competitor and former ally, Arturo Beltran Leyva, in December 2009. Arrested in Mexico on homicide and drug charges in 1993, he escaped from federal prison 8 years later, reportedly through the laundry. However, he was believed to have had a heavy hand in his organization even from behind bars. In 2008 Mexican and Colombian traffickers laundered between $18 billion and $39 billion in proceeds from wholesale shipments to the U.S. Shorty, an alleged tunnels and air logistics expert, is believed to have directed anywhere from a third to half the wholesale shipments since his 2001 prison escape. Drug scholars believe Shorty has made trafficking inroads to Europe. Apparently started out working with Miguel Angel Felix Gallardo, (El Padrino, or the Godfather), head of the most powerful drug-trafficking group in Mexico at that time. U.S. government is offering up to a $5 million reward for information leading to his capture.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fortune could use a get-well card: down $900 million in past 2 years as recession and electronic greetings have cut demand for Hallmark cards. Dad, Joyce C. Hall (d. 1982), founded postcardmaker Hallmark 1910. Donald took over in 1966, expanded into crayons (Crayola), and real estate (Crown Center shopping complex). Son Donald Jr. runs Hallmark, son David heads wholesale operations. Hall Family Foundation gives to Kansas City area: education, arts.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandfather John T. Dorrance was a chemical engineer who discovered way to can condensed soup using half as much water, cutting costs by a third. Campbell Soup sales in fiscal year 2009: $7.6 billion. Stock up 8% in last year. Owns other familiar brands: Pace (salsa), V8 (vegetable juice), Pepperidge Farm (cookies, Goldfish), Swanson (broth).

name: Billionaires
bio: Onetime head of Banamex who made almost $2 billion in 2001 when the company was sold to Citigroup suffered great personal tragedy last year. His son Alfredo Harp Calderoni, 39, died in July 2009 of an apparent heart attack. The father and son had together bought a majority stake in sporting goods retailer and gym Grupo Marti in 2008; his late son's portion of the investment is not reflected in Harp's current net worth. Active philanthropist is president of two Banamex-affiliated foundations. A baseball fanatic, Harp also owns the Red Devils, a minor league team in Mexico City. Kidnapped in 1994 for 3 months. Cousin of World's richest man, Carlos Slim Helu.

name: Billionaires
bio: Got start making wood floors and other wood products in Guangdong province. Expanded into real estate in 1996. Today his privately-held Star River Property Holding, which specializes in luxury residences, has properties in Guangdong, Shanghai, Beijing and Taiyuan.

name: Billionaires
bio: Wharton grad made plastic egg cartons during 1960s before buying a styrene plant 1970. Turned Huntsman Corp. from fast-food container supplier into nation's largest private chemical company via acquisitions. Rising oil prices squeezed profits; forced to give up 49% of firm to settle debts with creditors. Took public 2004; personally netted $275 million. Sued Apollo Management after firm backed away from buyout agreement; settled for $1 billion 2008. Recently won $1.7 million settlement from Credit Suisse and Deutsche Bank over roles in spoiled deal. Huntsman shares up 350% since last February. Son Peter expanding Huntsman into Asia; son Jon Jr. governor of Utah.

name: Billionaires
bio: Bullish investor, often referred to as India's Warren Buffet. Son of an income-tax officer, he started dabbling in the stock market with $100 after qualifying as a chartered accountant. Now trades his own money through his Mumbai investment firm, Rare Enterprises, which draws its name from his first two initials and that of his wife Rekha. His portfolio recovered in the stock-market rally and he remains resolutely bullish on the Indian economy. Plans to sell his mutual fund joint venture with Shinsei Bank to Japan's Daiwa. The walls of his office are lined with portraits of legendary investors including Buffet and George Soros. Enjoys cigars and whiskey, which he imbibes daily.

name: Billionaires
bio: Numbers junkie earned Harvard math and physics degrees in 3 years. Piloted B-17 bomber in WWII. First job: statistician at Occidental Life. Earned $225 a month, quit after realizing salesmen made more. Created property and casualty insurance company. Then Mercury General 1962. Targeted customers having trouble getting auto insurance, used snoop unit to flush out suspicious claims. Took public 1985. Believes ZIP codes key statistic to setting insurance rates; now fighting California officials, who say motorists' driving records are more important. Said to relax in the evenings with a lapful of trade magazines and agent reports.

name: Billionaires
bio: Made fortune as an original investor in Amdocs, a customer-relationship management-and-billing software firm for large telecom outfits. He has cashed out nearly $1 billion worth of shares since Amdocs went public in 1998; now focuses on venture capital and philanthropy in Israel. As principal of Aurum Ventures, has invested in a dozen emerging life-science and tech companies like Atlantium, which specializes in water disinfection; and N-Trig, which makes a multitouch screen for computers. Lives on Israel's Mediterranean coast and spends most of his time on a 100-foot yacht. Cofounder of Coral World International, a string of aquariums in locations such as the Bahamas and Australia; still owns a 50% stake. Son, Benjamin, is a marine biologist.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former store manager teamed up with partners John Herman and Jay Baker for management buyout of Kohl's department store. Then: 39 department stores in Wisconsin. Now: more than 1,050 stores in 49 states. Took public 1992; shares up 60% in past 12 months. Sales rose 5% last year to $17.2 billion. Stepped down as chief exec 2001; owns 10 million shares worth $550 million. Also owns shares in auto dealer CarMax.
title: Director and Member of Executive Committee
employment: {'name': "Kohl's", 'uri': 'companies/kohls', 'title': 'Director and Member of Executive Committee', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Iranian-born academic and former art dealer has one of the world's largest private collections of Islamic art with over 20,000 items spanning 1,400 years.  Collection is his passion and the basis of his wealth.  Artifacts include ceramics, metalwork, glass, rare Koranic manuscripts, paintings and textiles. Bought his first piece, a 19th century Qajar lacquer pen box, as a teenager.  Also collects Japanese Art from the Meiji period, Indian and Swedish textiles, Spanish metal works.  Nicknamed the secret sultan, left Iran before the 1979 revolution, now lives in London as a dual U.S.-British citizen. Also owns commercial and retail properties in and around London, including tony Mayfair.  Building an innovative energy efficient office block named "The Wave".

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded Jones Apparel Division in 1970 while working at W.R. Grace. Bought company with a partner 5 years later. Notable lines: Jones New York, Evan-Picone, Nine West; licensing deals with Ralph Lauren. Left Jones in 2002; has sold most of his shares in the publicly-traded company. Today owns art, real estate, movie production outfit Sidney Kimmel Entertainment, small stake in pro basketball's Miami Heat. Active philanthropist.

name: Billionaires
bio: Born in then Soviet Republic of Estonia and graduated from the Moscow Power Engineering Institute; served as commercial director at a small firm founded with the institute's help. In 1992 was hired by Alfa Group to oversee establishment of a privatization-investment fund; months later became chief executive of Alfa Capital, the group's fund-management company. After expanding Alfa Capital became responsible for all of the bank's investment units. Also board chairman of Alfa's Altimo telecom-holding company.

name: Billionaires
bio: Auto dealer's son started used computer sales operation after a $3, 3-line ad in the Chicago Tribune for his old IBM was met with high demand. Turned $300 profit on second sale, saw explosive growth potential in a market to sell computers directly to customers. Founded Computer Discount Warehouse (CDW) 1984; company became one of world's most profitable resellers of tech products. Public 1993. Retired 2001. Company bought by private equity firm Madison Dearborn Partners for $7.3 billion in 2007; donated more than $350 million in shares to charity.

name: Billionaires
bio: Queens-born investment banker made small fortune taking Ross Perot's Electronic Data Systems public in 1968. Made hundreds of millions providing seed money for Home Depot. Home Depot shares up nearly 60% in past year; his stake worth more than $450 million. Former New York Stock Exchange director holds economics degree from Bucknell, MBA from NYU. Married high school sweetheart 54 years ago. Philanthropist donates to cancer research, alma maters, local charities.

name: Billionaires
bio: Native Jamaican sold Canadian wealth management and mutual fund business AIC to Manulife last year. Originally acquired AIC mutual funds in 1987. Owns Columbus Communications, Barbados media company that sells broadband to Central and South American countries. Also owns stakes in National Commercial Bank Jamaica and Total Finance in Trinidad & Tobago. Personal real estate portfolio includes 250 acres of beachfront property in Ocho Rios, Jamaica and homes in Canada and Florida.

name: Billionaires
bio: Daughter of Al Lerner (d. 2002), who made fortune creating credit card giant MBNA. Family's fortune up on Bank of America stock; shares gained more than 350% in past 12 months. Al Lerner, born in Brooklyn to Russian immigrants, sold furniture, invested earnings in Cleveland-area real estate. Bought control of Equitable Bancorp 1981, merged with Maryland National 1989; spun off MBNA 1991, eventually sold to BofA. Returned pro football to Cleveland in 1999.

name: Billionaires
bio: Widow of Al Lerner (d. 2002), who made fortune creating credit card giant MBNA. Family's fortune up on Bank of America stock; shares gained more than 350% in past 12 months. Al Lerner, born in Brooklyn to Russian immigrants, sold furniture, invested earnings in Cleveland-area real estate. Bought control of Equitable Bancorp 1981, merged with Maryland National 1989; spun off MBNA 1991, eventually sold to BofA. Returned pro football to Cleveland in 1999.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of Al Lerner (d. 2002), who made fortune creating credit card giant MBNA. Family's fortune up on Bank of America stock; shares up more than 350% in past 12 months. Al Lerner, born in Brooklyn to Russian immigrants, sold furniture, invested earnings in Cleveland-area real estate. Bought control of Equitable Bancorp 1981, merged with Maryland National 1989; spun off MBNA 1991, eventually sold to BofA. Returned pro football to Cleveland in 1999. "Randy" took control of Cleveland Browns, bought British soccer team Aston Villa.

name: Billionaires
bio: Australia's best-known rag trader. Joins billionaires club as his Premier Investments vehicle almost tripled in value in last year. Took reigns of father's retail business in 1964 at age of 18 and built it into an empire. Sold stake in country's second-biggest retailer Coles for $950 million in 2007. Last year Premier launched a $800 million takeover bid for 900-store retailer Just Group.

name: Billionaires
bio: Princeton grad was an underwriter at father's Cleveland auto insurer, Progressive Corp., 1955. Took helm 1965. Today $14 billion in annual premiums, 28,000 employees. Stepped down as chief exec 2000. Activist-philanthropist donates to ACLU, Marijuana Policy Project, which lobbies for legalization of medical marijuana. Art enthusiast decorated Progressive headquarters with 6,000 pieces of contemporary art to inspire creativity.

name: Billionaires
bio: Took over as chairman of Shanxi Haixin Iron & Steel Group after father was shot in 2003.  Haixin, based in Shanxi province, is one of China's biggest private steel manufacturers. Products include pig iron, crude steel, billet and cement. Total assets are $1.2 billion; company employs 7,200. Since taking over, Li has also diversified into finance; group now has stakes in Beijing's Yinhua Fund Management, Minsheng Insurance, and brokerage firm Shanxi Securities. Li, who spends a lot time in Beijing, reportedly married Chinese actress Che Xiao in January.

name: Billionaires
bio: Caused stir signing disgraced quarterback Michael Vick to his Philadelphia Eagles last year; other football teams looking to roll dice with the past star anxiously waiting until Eagles announce his future. Grandfather Philip Smith (d. 1961) built family fortune with investments and movie theater operator General Cinema. Earned Ph.D. from Brandeis University; taught social policy at Boston University. Left for silver screen, founding Chestnut Hill Productions 1985; films included Foxfire, one of Angelina Jolie's first movies. Paid then-record $195 million to buy Eagles from Norman Braman in 1994. Team worth more than $1.1 billion today.

name: Billionaires
bio: Imploding housing market crushing hopes of rapidly expanding 84 Lumber. Sales in 2009 down 36% to $1.35 billion. Recently borrowed $590 million to stay afloat; closing stores, selling assets to pay off debt. Learned lumber business from father, Joe Hardy, who founded 84 Lumber in 1956 and passed the operation to "Maggie" 36 years later. Firm ceded do-it-yourself market to Home Depot, Lowe's; focused on selling directly to contractors, developers. Also owns Pennsylvania resort.

name: Billionaires
bio: Flashy liquor-and-airline baron facing tough times. His money-losing Kingfisher Airlines, which he started five years ago and built into India's largest, has retained an American consulting firm to help it restructure operations. His deal to sell a minority stake in his debt-laden United Spirits, the world's third largest spirits company by volume, to Diageo, fell through. In October, he raised $350 million through a private placement of United Spirits' shares. He resolved long-simmering dispute with Heineken, his partner in United Breweries, and will manufacture and market its beer in India. He plans to combine his sports interests - a Formula One team, a cricket team and a football league - under one company called UB Sports. The making of his Kingfisher swimsuit calendar was the subject of a reality show on television.

name: Billionaires
bio: Pakistan's first billionaire. Born during the tumultuous Partition winter of 1947, when his parents were among those Muslim families making the trek from India to Pakistan. His father and uncles jumped into textiles with Nishat Mills in 1951. Mian went to college in the U.K.; joined family business after graduation. Father died one year after his return. Eventually split with uncles and took over his family's business in West Pakistan decades ago. (The East Pakistan division later went bankrupt). His Nishat Group is now Pakistan's largest exporter of cotton clothes (for brands like Gap) and nation's largest private employer; also invests in power projects, cement and insurance. Smart bet in banking: Won a controversial bid for Muslim Commercial Bank during the country's privatization push in 1991. Sold more than half of his MCB shares for $900 million May 2008.

name: Billionaires
bio:
October 2008 margin squeeze forced Chesapeake's once largest shareholder to sell more than 31 million shares. Today owns 2 million shares; rebuilding stake. Keeps billionaire status via diversified investments: hedge funds, energy, real estate. Co-founded company with $50,000 1989; current market cap exceeds $16 billion. This January sold 25% of Texas shale assets to Total for $2.25 billion. Wine collector owns 20% stake in NBA's Oklahoma City Thunder. Duke grad.



minority stake in NBA's Oklahoma City Thunder. Duke grad collects wine, maps.

name: Billionaires
bio: Civil engineer joined family's road building business in 1990 at the age of 19. He took over in 1998, expanded the business and created IRB Infrastructure, which builds and maintains roads and highways. Company went public in 2008; a leading toll road operator in western India where it operates an expressway connecting Mumbai to Pune. Recently diversified into real estate and has been selected to build an airport in his home state, Maharashtra. Loves to travel.

name: Billionaires
bio: Baseball's best boss started in billboards; partnered with advertising guru William Levine, who founded Outdoor Systems 1980 with billboards, bus station ads. Sold to Infinity Broadcast Corp. 1999 for $8.7 billion in stock. Became Viacom following 2000 merger, still owns pile of stock. Vietnam vet owns Arizona commercial real estate; stake in pro baseball's Los Angeles Angels of Anaheim. Sells some tickets for $6: "Should it have been $8? Maybe. But now their butts are in there. They'll go buy a beer or a dog. We got them in the stadium."

name: Billionaires
bio: Recently changed name of his pachinko and slot-gambling company from Aruze to Universal Entertainment Corp to mark its 40th anniversary. With a 20% stake his group is biggest shareholder in Wynn Resorts, run by American billionaire Steve Wynn. Universal is spending more than $2 billion to build casino in Manila Bay, Philippines. Expects to return to profit this fiscal year thanks to strong sales of new pachinko machine featuring Don Chan character. Lobbying for Japan to legalize casinos.

name: Billionaires
bio: Upon the death of his older brother in 1984, inherited family's fading textile business. Expanded into pharma through series of well-timed acquisitions. Today Piramal Healthcare, his listed flagship, is among India's top five drug makers. Has denied reports that he plans to sell out to a big pharma firm. His wife Swati, a qualified doctor, and daughter Nandini, a Stanford MBA who looks after the contract research division, are directors of the company. Also has interests in real estate. A onetime horse-riding champion, he draws inspiration from the Bhagvad Gita.

name: Billionaires
bio: The split-up of the Pritzker family fortune continues. In November Hyatt Hotels went public; sold $1.1 billion in stock. Family still controls large chunk of shares after offering. Sold 13.6% stake in Hyatt to Walton family's Madrone Capital and Goldman Sachs for $1 billion in 2007. Five months later sold 60% of Marmon industrial conglomerate to Berkshire Hathaway for $4.5 billion; firm will become entirely Berkshire-owned in 2014. Grandchildren of A.N. Pritzker (d. 1986) who, with sons Jay (d. 1999) and Robert, created Marmon (sales: $7 billion) and Hyatt (415 properties worldwide today). Plan to pass control of empire to Tom, cousin Nick and niece Penny collapsed in 2001; family agreed to divide the spoils 11 ways, drawing a lawsuit by Robert's 2 youngest children, Matthew and Liesel. Two heirs settled for $1 billion.

name: Billionaires
bio: Farmer's son and one of six siblings, he got start at uncle's tiny construction firm in Hyderabad. Went on to found his own venture making particle boards in the US. Returned home in 1991 and snatched license in 1992 to build a power plant, among the first in the private sector. Big break came in 2006 when he won the bid to modernize Mumbai airport, India's busiest. Son Sanjay, who is vice-chairman of GVK, looks after this project. Also second largest shareholder in Bangalore airport after buying stakes late last year from Zurich Airport and Larsen & Toubro for a cumulative $250 million. Is also building a 600MW thermal power plant in North India for $700 million. Wife Indira and daughter Shalini oversee Taj GVK Hotels, a joint venture with the Taj hotel chain. Tennis fanatic, he plays everyday and sponsors tennis champ Sania Mirza.

name: Billionaires
bio: Farmer's son founded NYSE-listed generics drug maker Dr. Reddy's Laboratories 26 years ago. Today his company has $1.5 billion in sales and ten plants certified by the U.S. Food & Drug Administration in India, Mexico, the U.S. and the U.K. Last year, forged an alliance with GlaxoSmithKline to market generics in emerging markets. Denied reports that he's considering selling a stake to GSK. Company posted loss in latest quarter owing to slowdown in generic drug sales in the U.S. and loss of orders by its German unit. Son Satish and son-in-law G.V. Prasad run operations. Reddy, along with daughter Anuradha, is involved in The Livelihood Advancement Business School, a program of company's charitable arm Dr. Reddy's Foundation, which aims to create jobs for young adults.

name: Billionaires
bio: NYU dropout started career in mail room of Philipp Brothers in 1954. With long-term partner Pincus Green, built Phibro into world's largest trader of oil, grain, metals. Left mid-1970s, founded Marc Rich & Co. Fled to Europe 1983 after being indicted for trading with Iran during hostage crisis, evading $50 million in taxes. Duo pardoned by Clinton 2001. Born in Antwerp, Belgium 1934, spent childhood in Philadelphia, Kansas City, New York. Now resides in Switzerland; has given more than $100 million to Jewish causes and leukemia research. Lost millions to Madoff. Net worth estimate likely low. Recent book by Swiss journalist Daniel Ammann says Rich revealed in interviews his extensive dealings with Iran, Cuba, South Africa; said he provided intelligence to U.S. diplomats about regimes while on the run.

name: Billionaires
bio: World's richest author expecting a big 2010. Theme park "The Wizarding World of Harry Potter" expected to open this year in Universal Studios, Orlando. Film "Harry Potter and the Deathly Hollows: Part 1" debuting later this year; Part II in 2011. Six previous Potter films have grossed more than $5 billion. Her wizard tales have been translated in 65 languages. Personal story is nearly as magical as the fiction she writes: single mother living on welfare in a coldwater flat in Edinburgh, Scotland completed her first story of the teenage wizard in 1997. A year later Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone was published in the U.S. and became a children's literary sensation.
title: Author

name: Billionaires
bio: Got MBA at Boston University in the U.S. Returned to family's Sabanci Group as head of treasury department of BNP-Ak DresdnerBank. Later became assistant treasure of its Akbank. Eventually tapped to became Akbank's executive chairman in 2008, taking reins from her father Erol Sabanci. Husband is chairman of Sabanci Holding's retail group. Suzan has taken rumba, mambo, salsa and tango; states that she uses the dance techniques to relax.

name: Billionaires
bio: Stepped away from family's Sabanci Holding in 2000 and founded Esas Holding, now run by daughter Emine. Spends as much time in London as he does in Istanbul. Has libraries named for him at Harran University and Yildiz Technical University in Turkey. Past charitable projects include an archeological site in Turkey, first excavated in the 1960s, and a refurbished park in Bodrum, Turkey.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mother of billionaires Ferit and Filiz Sahenk and widow of Dogus Holding founder, Ayhan Sahenk, who died of a heart attack in 2001. As a passive investor, she shares in the family's companies that cross industry verticals, including one of Turkey's largest banks, Garanti Bank, as well as high-end Porsche, Audi and Volkswagen dealerships, retail and food stores, construction companies and tourism businesses.

name: Billionaires
bio: Telecom titan facing legal trouble: Italian authorities allege he, along with more than 50 other people, were part of $2.7 billion money laundering and tax-evasion scheme: Scaglia claiming innocence. Founder and former head of Fastweb, a broadband telecom company that delivers voice, Internet and television over a single broadband connection. Long considered a takeover target, Scaglia had insisted there were no plans to sell; $4.2 billion purchase offer from Swisscom in 2007 was apparently too tempting to resist. Before founding Fastweb in 1999 he was chief executive of wireless outfit Omnitel, now Vodafone Italy.

name: Billionaires
bio: Raised in Ohio, worked nights at a pipe-fitting factory to pay for classes at Ashland College. Became a junior high school teacher, moved to real estate. Bought land for Ryan Homes; quit to branch off on own. Founded NVHomes 1979; took public 1986. Borrowed big to buy former employer Ryan Homes same year. Filed for bankruptcy 1992, recovered. Has netted hundreds of millions from stock sales since mid-1990s. Owns minority stake in pro football's Washington Redskins. Bought Ronald Perelman's Palm Beach property for $70 million in 2004.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of a fabric manufacturer graduated from Emory; worked as stockbroker at Prudential Bache. Developed trading strategies while executing orders; founded trading outfit Schonfeld Group in 1988. Business model: front cash to traders, who use it to quickly buy and sell stocks, futures; split profits. Employed 1,100 traders in 2001 before dot-com bubble burst; today oversees 400 traders. Market volatility in 2008 spelled riches for "prop trading" maverick: Schonfeld Group's total revenue reached $570 million that year, up 86% from 2007 as traders profited from securities dumped by skittish investors. Hiring programmers, mathematicians to build computerized trading systems; "quants" account for a third of the firm's revenue. Last year completed $90 million home on Long Island featuring 9-hole golf course designed by Rees Jones. With grocery tycoon John Catsimatidis, won 3rd annual Forbes Billionaire Poker Tournament in October; event raised $1.2 million for charity.

name: Billionaires
bio: Turned small kimono shop into 1,500-store discount-clothes retailer Shimamura. Retired from management but owns a large stake in the firm, considered one of nation's lowest-cost operators. Employees expected to follow a cost-cutting manual. Company has athletic department with 5 coaches and 10 women competing in marathons and other long distance running events around Japan. Son Hiroyuki is an auditor at the company.

name: Billionaires
bio: Newspaper entrepreneur bought shares in chemical company Dwory; funded expansion with debt, taking advantage of low interest rates. Diversified into ceramic tiles, wood floors and real estate. Left management roles two years ago but is still an active investor on Warsaw Stock Exchange. Has stakes in ceramic maker Cersanit, developer Echo Investment, flooring company Barlinek and chemical company Synthos. Avid race car driver.

name: Billionaires
bio: Runs Para Group, with interests in banks, TV stations; has franchise rights to Baskin-Robbins; high-end brands Prada, Jimmy Choo. Opened theme park in September with partner, former vice president Jusuf Kalla. Is now focused on expanding lifestyle and entertainment business. Got start selling study guides while in dental school.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, Tom, opened first Raley's grocery in Placerville, Calif. 1935. Revolutionized grocery industry with drive-in market, prepackaged meat, in-store pharmacies, natural-foods section. Joyce worked in store as teenager; left to raise children. Returned 1985. Expanded: bought Bel Air Markets, Nob Hill Foods. Became sole owner after dad died 1991. Son, Michael, rejoined company as CEO in January after abruptly resigning from same role in 2002. Plans to keep company in private hands.

name: Billionaires
bio: His Rimbunan Hijau group has substantial interests in palm oil, timber assets and property development in Malaysia, New Zealand and Papua New Guinea. Has global Chinese media aspirations - some call him Asia's Rupert Murdoch. His Media Chinese International's portfolio comprises six dailies with a daily circulation of over 1 million, including the influential Sin Chew Jit Poh and Nanyang Siang Pau in Malaysia, as well as over 30 magazine titles in North America, Southeast Asia and Mainland China. May sell  EON Capital, one of Malaysia's smallest banks, to Hong Leong group.

name: Billionaires
bio: Amassed companies in banking, insurance, auto leasing and retail; sold off stakes to Western companies and plowed proceeds into Romanian real estate. In November 2009, sold 49% stake in the Romanian importer of Mercedes Benz. Current projects include residential offerings in Bucharest, Timisoara, Brasov and Sibiu, as well as four office complexes in Bucharest. Outstanding athlete, he competed in the 1960 Olympics as an ice hockey player. Later switched to tennis, eventually coaching several tennis greats including Boris Becker, Steffi Graf and Goran Ivanisevic. Patron of the Madrid Masters tournament today; goal to turn Madrid into a Gland Slam event like those in London, Paris, New York and Melbourne.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chief executive of BIM, which operates discount stores. Keeps assortment to 600 items, preferably private label. Has partnership with Ulker group.

name: Billionaires
bio: His idea for a mobile phone company was eventually funded by billionaire Mehmet Karamehmet and became Turkcell. Sat on the telecom's board from 1993 until 2005; still owns a big stake in the NYSE-listed outfit. Bought 50% stake in one of Turkey's largest hotels in Izmir, the Grand Efes, for $120 million in October 2005. Started Turkish search engine Hakia in 2006. Rents out his 120-foot yacht, Jasmin, docked at Antibes, France, for $70,000 per week in low season.

name: Billionaires
